Pros and Cons. The Bosphorus is one of the great waterways of the world and definitely worth a visit. Should you view it from a cruise ship? It depends - it is a waterway, not a scenic bay or river. You will be in the company of many ships. Also, depending on the cruise company, you may get some grumpy or aggressive staff, as we encountered. Ask your travel agent for a cruise with manners!

Boat trip is simply fantastic. There's this popular boat trip and it's public and cheap (we paíd 12 Turkish lira). You'll find many tourists on board. You see the banks of the straight and the famous historic buildings and beautiful harbours. We took the two hour round journey. You buy the tickets in an office by the straight when you get off EminonuStation. Don't miss it. Ideal on a sunny day.
Get the lay of the land. Nice to take boat trip to get an idea of Istanbul's locations etc. relaxing and well organized. Have fish under the bridge after your bost trip.
Must do a cruise. This strait separates Europe from Asia. Get a cruise from the port. The problem is the audio guide isn't very clear on the tour.

Tour this waterway for an exceptional view of the old city from the water!. A unique way to see the old city skyline. Catch a tour boat right from the end of the Galata bridge - easy to access on foot - a nightmare if you're driving. Leave the car at your hotel. I don't recommend taking a Bosphorous night dinner cruise, this is just a mediocre party boat that will take you away from the sights you want to see.Bring your camera - impossible to take a bad pic! Later have some fresh grilled fish from one of the resto's under the bridge and watch the setting sun illuminate the mosques against the backdrop of the evening sky.

Perfect for sunset. I took a commuter ferry with my friends to experience Bosphorus and I loved it. We saw Istanbul from the water and even did it again the next day cause it was cheap compared to those Bosphorus cruises I guess. Really recommend this when in Istanbul.

Europe and Asia. not sure whether you'll like reading my thoughts on this strait. me and the group went to cruising the strait. we can see Turkey on the Europe side and the Asia part. yet I feel like nothing too special about the view. I instantly comparing the strait with others. oddly enough, no standout buildings (houses I mean). certainly you would admire some of them but in general, I find this Bosphorus strait just an ordinary one. even the bridge looks too common.

Amazing views. Wonderful perspective from the Ortakoy Mosque having the Bosporus bridge on the background.
Very recommended specially at sunset for pictures.

Take a tour up the Bosphorus. Beautiful and restful tour up and down both sides of the Bosphorus. This canal is one of the most important in the world. Learn the history of the various landmarks along the shores in advance.

Ocean in a City. In many ways, Istanbul is the most exotic interesting city I've visited (been to 61 countries) perhaps because it has an ocean in the middle. Captivating views of the Bosphorus and the never ending traffic of ships and boat, anytime day or night.
Beautiful. The Bosphorous strait is beautiful. Make sure you take the trip around the strait which provides views of both the Asian and European sides of Istanbul.

Well worth it. We booked a trip from a local travel agent near the Blue Mosque, it was very reasonably priced, we had a bus take us to the boat and the use of a guide who was very good, I'm afraid I don't recall the companies name but I'm sure they all provide a similar service.the trip took us under the 2 main bridges linking Europe and Asia and we could sense the history of the place.only a 2 hour trip and well worth it.
Amazing Views. This is again something that you should definitely do as part of tour as there are quite a few places and interesting did bits you get to learn from tour guides.

Ferry trip. When in Istanbul you really must take a trip on one of the big yellow and white ferries the ply busily and efficiently across and up and down the Bosporus.Buy and Istanbul Card (an electronic ticket that you add money to). This means each ride is far cheaper and each successive ride (when changing ferry, bus, metro, tram etc) is even cheaper still. Plus it saves buying umpteen different Jeton tokens for each journey.There are numerous ferry rides, if you have time ride out to the Princess Islands, or like I did take the hour long ferry ride from Üsküdar right along the Golden Horn to historic Eyüp where you can change into a cable car to the top of the hill.The ferries are part of Istanbul and are delightful, complete with buffet and chai waiters who will serve you a glass of chai for a few pennies. In summer you can sit outside and in winter be snug and warm inside sipping tea! No wonder the Istanbul people are so good natured if this isn't what their commute is like! Be aware that the ferries run spot on time so don't dawdle or you'll miss it - though if you do the waiting areas are heated (if you're there in winter of course)....Pick up a pocket timetable which is readily available and free - and show all of the routes and the cheap cheap fares. The ferries are a key part of the public transport so run early to late every day even holidays! Wonderful and not to be missed.

Istanbul Ferry. There are several Ferry services crisscrossing the Bosphorus and connecting Europe and Asia in Istanbul city.I have had the good fortune of several crossings and I liked each trip even though the vessels were of different models and sizes. The crossing it self takes about 15 minutes, and is like a nice boat ride. The views of both the Asian and European sides of Istanbul are marvelous, day and night.There are shops selling lights refreshments: I will recommend the traditional tea, which you will observe is popular among the passengers.You can imagine that I intend to go crossing again as soon as I have an opportunity to do so.

Gorgeous trip!. The view on both sides is very beautiful. You have a very nice view of the city, there are nice houses at shore and photographers have many opportunities for taking breathless pictures. On board you can have black tea on the house in the traditional tea glasses.

Beautiful view. On a bright sunny day, regardless of which month you are in Istanbul, you ought to try the cruise. Heading north east from the jetty from the Europe side, enjoy the view of Istanbul from the strait, Asia on your right. Who says you can't have the best of both continents?

Visit the market there at night. And eat grom the fresh fish sandwichs sold on the water side.
I do recommend it for couples at night.
Very romantic area

Beautiful, scenic, relaxing. Had a yacht tour late morning/noon-ish - we were out there for the mid-day call to prayer and it was magical to hear the calls across the water! Recommend a guide to hear the stories of all of the beautiful buildings.
For a strait it's quite windy. We took a boat tour up the Bosphorus. It's full of loads of historical references and is older than the hills - or nearly anyway.

Go on a sunny day and get the audio tour. Make sure you go on a sunny day. If not you won't be able to see the sights from the boat. Also when you stop in the small village you have 3 hours to hike to the fort and have lunch. A sunny day makes this a much better experience. Also get the audio tour which was great at explaining all the houses and landmarks that you pass. Well worth $5

Strait bringing Asia & Europe together. Turkey a destination known as eurasia. We were very excited to know and see what makes it eurasia. It is Bosphorus Strait which brings Asia and Europe together. Earlier people use to use ferry to move across, but after 1973 this famous Bosphorus bridge helped people commute faster and safely.

Enjoyable cruise. We were on a group tour and had a cruise boat all to ourselves. Highly enjoyable with great views of the European and Asian side of Istanbul. Sit on the upper deck for best views and enjoy the cool breeze . The tour only lasted about 2 hours and the sunset upon approaching Istanbul was really nice . You get to see different angles of all the famous landmarks eg. Blue Mosque . Highly recommended when in Istanbul.

Do not miss the chance to ride up the Bosporus!. If you've read Orhan Pamuk's book on Istanbul (which you should!), you'll notice how much emphasis he puts on the Bosporus in the life of the city. We noticed it in the recommendations made by our Turkish friends, who were always steering us toward the water, whether it be a Bosporus cruise, a ferry ride, or simply a waterside meal. If you spend a day, or even just an afternoon, on the Bosporus, you will see why. We did the all-day Bosporus cruise on the city ferries, which takes you up the Bosporus for an hour and a half, provides a 3-hour lunch stop at a village on the Asian side, and brings you back on another hour and a half ride. We got the audio guide, thinking we wanted to learn about everything on the way, but soon abandoned them, realizing we were better off watching the gulls, listening to the water, and taking everything in. The experience was magical. We were lucky to have a sunny, warm day in December. The water was deep blue, the gulls were everywhere, and the shores were dotted with houses, mosques, and medieval fortifications. Fishermen plied the waters while freighters made their way through the strait. We brought bread for the birds. As we approached Istanbul, the sun hung quite low, putting the city skyline in silhouette and illuminating everything from the Dolmabaçhe Palace to Eminonu in orange light, making for one of the most spectacular urban views I had ever seen. Go. Don't miss this. (You can also drive along the shore, or simply take one of the municipal ferries to any port on the Bosporus. You don't need to take the tour!)
Worth The Sunrise. Fantastic, bustling waterway. My husband and I walked across the bridge at dawn for an absolutely priceless experience.

Dont get stuck with the 6 hours tour. 2 hours tour is enough for the bosphorus strait. And yes I recommend that. But the 6 hours tour is a touristic scam to make you eat in a touristic zone at the end of the strait.

fantastic. must do on your list of activities in Istanbul. travelling to the two parts of the city through the strait, either on the ferry, or on the two bosphorous bridges, can be exciting, we had a great time, Go on the bosphorous bridge, especially during the evening, sunset time.

Tourist Boat Cruise- definitely!. Ok, yes it's touristy, but a cruise on the Bosphorus is just a must- do in Istanbul. We started on the upper deck with beverages (bring sunglasses!) and later had dinner below. Check the weather (if you need a sweater) because the view on the outside deck is better!
Nice Boat Ride. It's pretty cheap and leaves often. you can jump off in Asia and jump right back on to. Nice sights and very relaxing.

Interesting background and views. It was a beautiful day in December-but the trip was a little chilly. Get the headphones for this one-some interesting information--but some gets redundant. We took the 4 hour tour with the lunch stop. When you stop, go on the hike to Yaros castle first. There is a restaurant with amazing views at the top. It's a hike-but worth the views on both sides.
Nice half day trip. Lovely trip which gives you opportunity to see Istanbul from water : bridges, palaces, seaside villas etc.

Bosphorus Strait-Linking Asian & European Istanbul. Bosphorus strait links Asian & European parts of Istanbul. 2 famous bridges (Bosphorus bridge & Fatih Sultan Mehmet bridge) are built over it to support the massive vehicular movement between the 2 sides.

Morning tour in mid winter. Crikey it was cold! Well by our soft UAE standard it was effin-freezin!We started on the open deck but even coffee served to us couldn't save the day and we had to admit total weakness and retreat inside.The architecture on display was amazing and the whole tour just left me wondering about buying here and moving countries to live. I loved it.

The most beautiful place in the world. You would have heard it all: how special it is to have Europe on one side, and Asia on the other...But to be in the middle of it all, sailing the Bosphorus is a magical experience that makes you feel good in the soul. No matter the season, it's an experience to remember, for a very cheap fare to get on a ferry. Ferries vary in time for the trip-there's one that is a leisurely sail slowly up the Bosphorus towards the Black Sea. You must consult the schedule well to make sure you get the right one. Morning and afternoon rush hours will mean the ferries will be packed with work commuters which will change the tone of your experience, so plan accordingly. The ferry ride in sunlight hours are a different treat to the ferry ride in the night time hours-and both are a must-do. Get your cameras ready, look good and enjoy. You're in the most special place on Earth!

Bosphorus Cruize. If you've come on a short trip like a 2 or 3 day trip, then do not take the 6 hour cruise which allows you to halt at various islands, instead take the 1.5 hr short cruise, which takes you on a boat ride/round trip, you cannot get down anywhere, however its still worth it.Make sure to bargain, we met someone who offered at 30, kept moving forward and finally got a nice one for 12 TL per person.Make sure to carry 2 packets of biscuits with you on board the ship.Why?Thousands of sea gulls flock the ships/ boat, keep breaking the biscuits in small pieces and throw them in the air close to you, and see the birds scoop / fly down in a second and catch it mid air.Also if your not afraid then hold your hand out high and see them come get it off your fingers if your lucky.Joyful ride.

Cruise up the strait. Went on a boat cruise along the Bosphorus. For me it was probably the highlight of the trip. The scenery was amazing, the sound of the waves was therapeutic and the cool refreshing breeze was soul-quenching. Our trip lasted about 2 hrs, you can see many of the landmarks on the cruise and its generally quite quiet as its difficult to hear anyone else due to the engine/sea/breeze combination, so you can just relax in your own thoughts and soak up the views. Definitely would do it again!

Must Visit at night time. Had visited this place only in the night time , due to time constraints .1. Surrounded by Restaurants , and happen to go to the same restaurant twice , CHEESE CAKE 2. Night time road market is also right there , lot of things to buy especially souvenirs.4. KUMPHIR - is a Turkish Dish ( MUST TRY) , So is the WAFFLE ICE- CREAM , 5. Sheesha is available in almost all restaurants .6. Bosphorus bridge is barely visible from this place .7. Mosque was closed in the night time .

Beautiful Bosphorous. A cruise on the Bosphorous is a must to be on the waterways steeped in history. A beautiful day enhanced the experience and was a great way to see everything Istanbul has to offer

Not at night . I think it is a very nice tour through the Bosphorus, but Not the night one.
We made that mistake and toke the night water tour..we sow things... its nice but its much nicer i think if we have taken the day tour. The night tour can add nice finish to the day tour.

dreamy at night. me and my wife took bosphorus night tour at first we tought it was a waste of time but then it made us to change our mind , its been so dreamy visiting bogaz bridge "the bridge of dreams that locals believe if someone passes under bogaz bridge for first time his dream will come true " so we did so and seeing colorful lights of istanbul mosques from far away was so nice its a great experience

Take the local ferry. If you take the local ferry up to Anatolu Kavagi, be aware that this place is full of fish restaurants and nothing much more in a tourist sense (less you walk up to the castle to enjoy the views, recommended). You feel stuck. A remedy would be taking the local ferry to Rumeli Kavagi on the other side for a token or use your Istanbul card (ask at the hotel where to get it, strongly advisable to get one). Pick up the boat for your return there.
Yumm . One of the best part of my visit.... Enjoyed the trip.... Both at day n ni.... Must hv a ride... Something u ll remember
Magic!. There are many spectacular things in life, and then there is Bosphorus - even more so spectacular! The blue of strait takes the blue away!

Buy the cheap tour . Don't bother with the expensive tours. We took one for 12 TL... you can get the exact same trip on a fancy tour package for 35 euros.... don't be a fool. Great trip down the strait. Look out for dolphins

The Bosphor. I really love it, whenever I go to Istansul I always ask for a bosphorus view room, and I always stay at the European side. I love waking up very early just to watch the bosphour from my balacony and also watch sultan Ahmed district. Breathing the cool nice air and walking on the side of the bosphourus straight is amazing.

Must must must . It would be not only Shame but also waste if you come to Istanbul and go back without being in this oldest bazaar of IstanbulFinest herbs and spices of the planet , best quality gold jewelry in cheapest price , traditional gifts etc The place !
Marvellous Experience. It's a very good experience to watch the Dolmabache Palace, city view, villas. No one should miss this while visiting Turkey.

You can't beat this geographic sight!. How can you beat crossing a body of water connecting Europe and Asia while spanning waters of Golden Horn, Marmara Sea and Black Sea...? You can't, so plan on hopping on one of the many working ferries in the harbor by Galata Bridge or pay little extra and get a boat tour with a guide giving you the lowdown on history and description of everything you see around you while boating in this unique Straight. Do you know what Bosphorus mean? Neck; neck connecting important regions.

Boat trip. We had a 4 hour boat trip for10€ each, very good value for money. You start in Golden Horn part of sea, then up the Bosphoros you have a one hr stop for lunch near the fort.nice choice of restaurants very reasonable prices.

Great Waterway. In my time in Istanbul I too two trips down the Bosphorus Strait and both times I was impressed by the architecture on both sides of the straits.There are a wide variety of boats offering a trip at a very low cost. It gives a great idea of eth two sides of the amazing city of Istanbul.

Magical start to our trip . We flew into the Asian side of Istanbul and wanted to catch the ferry across this legendary stretch of water. We alighted at kadikoy ferry port after departing out bus the airport. The journey cost 4turkish lira and we sipped Apple tea while we sailed serenely from Asia to Europe like many a foreign traveller/invader have done for thousands of years. It's a definite to do in your list

A very nice cruising the Bosphorous strait. We took a tour of the Bosphorous using a private tour guide . There are many regular ferries that we saw along the way and they said its much cheaper but nevertheless the cruise was very well done with the guide announcing the special points along the way . We took a whole day tour together with Dolmabhache palace .

A Cruise Never To Miss When in Istanbul!. You must take this Bosphorous ferry or cruise ride whenever you visit Istanbul. Don't miss a chance! Its divided Asian & Europe side of Turkey. A ride one should experience , relax & enjoy pretty sceneries. Try their streets foods of grilled fresh fishes.

Absorb the Asia/Europe meeting place. We took a fascinating tour boat ride up the Bosphorus from Istanbul to the mouth at the Black sea and back. You got a sense of the extensive commercial development on the European side, the more agrarian lifestyle on the Asian side, with the melding of many cultures in the architecture on both sides. For me, it was a humbling experience, imagining the rise and fall of empires centered in this area, the clash of cultures that continues to this day. If you have a sense of history, this is a must see.
try fish in bread. hit to the sea side and look around the bhosphorus. You will see all city lanscape. View is impressive. drink a tea at sea side and eat fish in bread

Take a Bosphorus Ferry tour.... We took a Bosphorus boat tour for 29euros each and really enjoyed it. There are plenty of tour agents who arrange this service. Our guide spoke very good english and explained the significant attractions on either side of the Bosphorus and the history behind them. Really enjoyed. Be prepared to spend at least 4-5 hours from pick-up to drop-off.

Simply gorgeous!. The Boshporus Strait may be the source for Istanbul's beauty and even its economical importance through out the ages. We can still see how restaurants, hotels and residences among others. try to attract customers by offering a view to Istanbul's main "asset".And even though is one of the busiest straits in the world, it inspires pace and serenity when you are around it.Just go to a cafe or a restaurant by its shore in the neighborhoods of Beşiktaş, Ortaköy, Arnavutköy or Bebek and you will understand. Or simply take a boat crossing from the European side to the Asian side and viceversa and the waves, the smell, the wind and the seagulls will stay in your mind for years.However, the best two ways to enjoy it by far are the Long Bosphorus Tour which departs from the port of Eminönü in the European side of Istanbul, right from the place where the strait begins in the Sea of Marmara to 2 towns located at the other end, close to the Black Sea, one in the European side and one in the Asian one. On the way you can enjoy looking at the fortresses built hundreds of years ago by the empires ruling these lands; the villas built by famous people, including sultans of the Ottoman Empire or the 2 bridges (plus one currently under construction) connecting both continents.The second best way to enjoy it is at night, thanks to tours as the one provided by Istanbul Tourist Pass. The tour normally departs from the port of Kabataş up to the 2nd bridge, allowing you to enjoy the magnificence of the city lit up by the lights of palaces, touristic landmarks, mosques, shopping malls, buildings, etc. The tours also include dinner and traditional shows to make sure tourists expecience the best the city has to offer.
We took a ferry ride up the Bosphorus for lunch. This historic waterway has to be seen to appreciate how it has been both a highway and barrier over the ages. The sea traffic remains constant.

Sip a g and t, take a boat ride and spot the dolphins.... We began sitting in one of the many restaurants looking out onto the water watching dolphins jumping in and out sipping a g and t. We then took a 90 min boat ride up the river to see Istanbul from the water. What a fabulous afternoon it was - not to mention an opportunity to give our feet a rest. Take some small change to buy a drink on the boat from the roaming waiter and sit snapping happily with your camera. Take a coat as the wind picks up on the journey! Left side of the boat is best.

Beautiful and Historic and free. I biked up the European side from Kabatas to Sanyer and then to the ferry back down to Kadikoy on the Asian side. There were beautiful views all the way, and the only cost was food on the way, the bike rental and about a dollar for the ferry (and bikes are free on the major ferry line). I'd recommend a round trip on the Kadikoy-Sanyer ferry for a cheap view of the entire straight. You can also do side trips on other ferries, and that particular ride has a couple of stops on the European side. Only one ferry a day does that route, but down in the ancient area of Byzantium, ferries are every 20 minutes or so from many locations on the Asian and European side, and all the rides are cheap. There are also tourist boats that include some commentary on the sites to be seen, and those are also relatively inexpensive.
Beautiful Bosphorus . We went on an afternoon cruise and the views were fab, lovely to see the city from the river. Lots of photos opportunities.

Take a boat to see the City from a different perspective. It's one of the reasons we love Istanbul. You see old mosques juxtaposed with modern glass and steel buildings. It really makes the passage of centuries come into focus! It's a 'have to'!

Cruising the Bosphorus is a must when visiting... Where can you go and see 2 continents in one afternoon!. Cruising the Bosphorus is a must when visiting... Where can you go and see 2 continents in one afternoon!You can take a local ferry, but for $30 USD the 2 hours guided tours are well worth the money. The views of the city are tremendous!

Incredible City views when passing through. Our cruise took us through the strait as we headed to the Black Sea. Everyone was on deck to have a great vantage point to see Istanbul flanking the banks. So many mosques line the water and afternoon prayers were being called as we went through. What a sight ~ visual and auditory. Only mounted the excitement for our return trip when we docked in the city.

Along one of oldest waterways in history. The Bosporus Strait is about 30 km long and connects the Black Sea and the Marmara Sea. It is a unique waterway because the waters flow from North to South on the surface and about 15 meters deeper, while an even stronger current goes to North. They never mix because the surface waters are of very low salinity (less than 8 %o) while the water from the Mediterranean has a higher salinity than the oceans. Newest research suggests that this place was the stage for the Flood about 9.000 years ago. And the city about 8.000 year old. The Strait was before the Flood the valley of a river, and it still looks like a flooded valley with hills on both sides. The width changes between 500 m and about 2.000 m, the depth is about 60 m. On both sides were villages long before Jesus Christ was born. Now, the city on the South end, earlier Byzantium, later Constantinople, and now Istanbul, spreads over the whole length. The wooden old houses built at the edge of the water, yalı, are now restored and dwelled by the wealthy from Istanbul and the Middle East. It is said, that the Russian population counts about 250.000 while other nationalities are not counted because this city has been one of the most cosmopolitan places of the world. You can travel the entire Strait either with public transportation (taxi, dolmus (collective taxi, very cheap), bus on both sides or take a boat. The cheapest boats are those for public transportation with incredibly low prices, party boats, tour boats etc. are much more expensive, but still affordable, and the highlight is renting a boat for yourself. You can get some from $ 100/day till about $ 15.000 (in Ortaköy). You can also combine bus/boat/taxi as you wish.
amazing trip. Really this boat trip on the Bosphorus is interesting & amazing it also allows u to see the beautiful views along this wonderful river

If it is a nice sunny day, go out on a ferry .... Spent a warm hour or two out on the Bosphorus, and it is one of the memorable sights that we went on while we visited this city. While I went with a group, I broke off and sat by myself in a window seat and reflected on life, the city and history. I'm not big on going out onto water, but this was a beautiful experience!

Take the two hour tour. I will confess that I like Boat rides anywhere, but the historic scenery, the palaces and castles, and the posh modern homes, made this a great afternoon event. It can get chilly
Cruise. We cruised the Bosphorus all the way to the bridge that links to Asia. Nice to do on a beautiful day.
I love this Syltrsit. I really love Le this strait. It is more than landmark for Istanbul. Crowded with ferries and passing boats and cruises.

Adds in to the glamour and beauty of Istanbul. One of the many things which makes Istanbul very beautiful, It is a border between Asia and Europe. A boat trip on a sunny day is worth but is equally terrible when one gets rain or cloudy weather especially in winters. Better choose the right day or avoid.

Worth to have a cruise. This is the river that divides Istanbul inti two parts, connects Black sea and Marmara sea, draw lines between Asia and Europe. It is good to take a paid cruise from European part Istanbul (from Emononu pier of from Sirkeci) or anyone having an Istanbulkart() metro card) can board on by spending 5-6 liras. Tourist can watch blue watersof the Bosphorus, birds, high rise buildings, old monuments. Can have street food on board, restauranrs are also there. Public ships take bicycles or motorbikes also. Tourists can get off at kodikoy (Asian part of Istanbul) also.

Much to see and learn about. WE had a two hour boat trip up the Bosphorus and along the eastern shore and back down the western shore. The buildings along it were interesting and many of special historical significance. We did not have an audio tour but had information about the various places along the way, when they were built and who built them - some are amazing in terms of size and some in terms of beauty. I would probably recommend a trip with an audio as there is much to see and we did not have information on all the buildings. There were some great old boats tied up at various places as well.

Sightseeing with the seagulls . The Bosphorus cruise is a must do in Istanbul. It's a peaceful ride with a lots of places to see. Plus initially the seagulls will entertain you before the cruise embarks on its journey. They're the one who never seem to get tired day or night (seagulls). Tip-- coming in the boat choose to sit on the right side. Just choose the side where the streets are..

A vital boat trip. Perhaps the best way to view this ancient city in all its moods.This waterway is 'steeped' in history even perhaps back to the Biblical flood.The only route from the Black Sea countries to the open ocean; potentially maritime perilous and frantically busy.

Cruise on the Bosphorus Strait. We took the 'half' cruise 3 years ago and on our return visit we took the full version. The short cruise is in fact quite adequate, had I known that we would not have taken the longer one. We thought we could actually see the Black Sea as some claimed on the net, but that is not true. The longer cruise is chaotic from lining up to purchase tickets to disembarking at 4pm. It can get very crowded and noisy on the ship. There is nothing to do at the last stop where you get off for 3 hours. The castle ruins are in fact too far to walk one way, let alone return. Then the only option you have is to hang around the harbor which is lined with similar looking seafood restaurants all emitting terrible burnt grilled fish smells which stink up the whole harbor and there is no escaping it. For lack of anything to do we ate at one of them. Not cheap and not good. I got very sick that night, can't tell if it was from the seafood.The stop before last looked more promising, it had some seafood restaurants, but also some other buildings and dwellings. Perhaps that would have made a better stop for the 3 hours.Along the way you do see the various buildings so don't forget your camera. But I'd still say the 1.5 hrs cruise would allow you to see quite a bit without getting bored and forced to spend 3 hrs on shore.

Dolphins!. Took a 2-hour Bosphorus cruise and spotted dolphins! It was an amazing experience even on the rainy day we had, especially with a competent tour guide shedding light on many of the buildings on the banks.
sunset is like a fairy tail. One of the most amazing things to do in Istanbul is to walk the Bosphorus side and watch sunset it is a great combination of sky, sea, seagulls and boats...

Mesmerising.. The best way to sail on the Bosphorous is on the ferry. It costs 12tl return and takes you from Asia to Europe. There isn't any commentary but it's a nice cheap way to see the beautiful city of Istanbul and the many hotels and mosques which line her shore. There is a more expensive cruise you can take and there are many boats competing for your money. However you see it though it's a breathtaking view.

Amazing view. Totally worth it!. We took the 1.5 hrs ride, encompassing the 2 bridges. The view was breathtaking, plus there were refreshments served on the cruise. A good idea to bring video camera if you like to record the journey. The price for my ride was just 12 lira. To get there, just take the metro to eminonu. Get down at the station and go to the leftmost side of the pier. We rode the cruise named Turyol. Bought the ticket from the counter. We took the 10 am ride.

get the cruise. We went in a great cruise along the bosporous. The views are beautiful and serene. The sights of mosques and the bridge are to be seen to believed. We as a couple went into a romantic mood and enjoyed the whole experience.
must do if in Istanbul. Be sure to do the tour as can see palaces, the fort/castle, strait to the black Sea and more You will definitely miss a key piece of Istanbul if you do not do this trip !
GOOD VIEWS. We can get a good view of isthanbul where europe and asia joins,when we travel through bosphorus cruise

The Bosphorus is beautiful, the ferry ride isnt. The Bosphorus is beautiful and you can get great views of both sides of IStanbul on the cruise. IT costs 15 Lira. The problem is that the audio is inaudible and we couldnt figure out what we were seeing while we passed by different buildings. We had to let it go and decided to relax and watch the water.

Thru the straits by boat. The boatride is pleasant and takes about 2 hours in all. Make sure you are seated on the correct side though ! Theres no real need to go in the fancy boats, the government run boats are sturdy well maintained and safe.
Take a boat ride for the best views. Take a boat ride down the strait for the most amazing views of the city as you go between the Asian and European sides of Istanbul. Not to be missed.

Bosphorous Cruise is an absolute must!. If you go to Istambul, do not miss the cruise through the Bosphorous. You get to see the city from a different angle and I would suggest you do it in the afternoon in order to see the sunset. Absolutely lovely!

Boat Excursion a Must. The coastline along the Bosphrous is unique for its geographic character, history. The boat provides exceptional views of the European as well as the Asian side of this unique city.

Between two continents !. What can be better than this in trip in Istanbul ? To let yourself flowing (on the boat , of course ) on Bosphorus waters...We were big family group with small kids and in the beginning we thought will not be a good idea, but the temptation was huge...Just 15 TL per person to find yourself between two continents ...Amazing trip , well informed guide on the boat's speakers (public transportation ) and the rest it is just history ...

Do the short ones!. For anywhere between 12 to 15 TL you can hop on a boat that leaves every hour on the hour that takes you down the Bosphorus. Some of them are 90 minutes while some are 60.We took the 90 minute one and while the sights are really good, it does tend to get a bit boring after about an hour.There is an option to go on the night one as well but my guess is the one during the day gives you a chance to see the city better

Did not get what we were promised. We booked a Bosphorus cruise through the Gokkusagi Travel Agency. Our timing was tight to make our airport transfer, but my boyfriend was promised that we would be dropped off first at the end of the cruise at our hotel so that we could hopefully make our airport transfer. When we arrived for our cruise the next morning it turned out there was no transport at all. We had to walk to the boat and we would have to make our own way back at the end of the day. It was poorly organised and the travel agent used the timings merely as a suggestion. The travel agent then tried to convince us to get a taxi after the cruise even though that would have meant we were stuck in traffic. Thankfully, I knew we could get the tram to our hotel much more quickly and we did that instead. The boat cruise itself was poor, the commentary was minimal, we had an hour at Rumeli Fortress which was closed for Winter, so 30 minutes would have been fine and then 30 minutes on the Asian side where there was even less to do,10 minutes for a photo stop was all that was required. I work as a tour guide and if I ran my tours like this I would never work again! I suppose you can't expect much for 10 Euros, but we would have been better off using the ferries than going on this cruise. I wouldn't recommend this to anyone.
Nice. Nice trip but not much to do , a little bit boring. All what you do is staying in a boat and watch Asian part of turkey and European part. Good in afternoon as you can watch sunset.

Afternoon on the Bosphorus is a relaxing way of learning the history of Istambul but do hire a guide.. November might seem an odd time to cruise the Bosphorus but with the help of a good guide it is both relaxing and informative. I was fascinated to see the luxurious houses on the asiatic shore-a sign of considerable wealth. Without a guide it would not have been any more than a slightly ramshackle chug round the bay (or do I mean Bey?) Don't expect a luxury tour but buy a cheap glass of black tea and go with the flow. And by the way if you have not taken a tram ride now is your chance its a cross between the underground in London and the NY subway but on the surface.

Choose a good boat charter. We chose to select someone of the street , there are touts all over trying to win you over. Look online and select a boat operator with good rating, ours was bad in the sense that they didnt say anything about the tour , there were so many historic sites along the cruise
Take the public ferry.. There is a public ferry that runs up the Bosphorus with a stop for lunch at the end before returning to the Sultanahmet District.

Best to enjoy the boat tour in good weather.... A boat tour of the Bosphorus really helps to situate many of the features of the city. Commentary from tour guide helps one to appreciate how many impressive buildings there are for a long stretch of waterfront heading towards the Black Sea.

History Imagined. This is one of the most important and most historic waterways in the world. History that changed the world was made on this waterway, so enjoy the view of the coming and goings from any of a hundred spots, one I recommend is the restaurant (no alcohol) inside Topkapi Saray. Gaze over to Asia and imagine.

Great cruise at a low price and easy access. We walked to the cruise line location from our hotel. Just follow the tram until it reaches the water and cross over to the water side and walk along the waterfront until you go under a bridge. The public cruise lines are 12 Lira per person for a wonderful 90 minute cruise. Great picture taking on a clear day.

a lazy afternoon trip between two continents. This area of istanbul is a great place to visit when one is not in a hurry...a ferry ride will take you to both the european and asian side of istanbul: two continents, one waterway.

Do it at sunrise or sunset, and it will be awesome!. This was a really great thing to do. One that we wouldn't have thought about ourselves. It was our host that suggested we should end our day on a boattrip across the Bosphorus strait. It was just another highlight to our day in Istanbul.
Tour . I really recommend you to take a boat for s tour on the river. It is very fascinating to see all of the different types of buildings.
Don't miss a ride on the Bosphorus. We had a ride as part of our crusie. It lasted about 2 hours and was simply wonderful. Saw many beautiful sights that you can't see on land.

2 Hour Tour. Our last day on our cruise included a Bosphorous boat trip, which took about 2 hours. It was really a great way to gather a good understanding of where everything is located in Istanbul while also learning about some of the history of the city. The scenery was truly breathtaking. On our boat, you could either sit outside, or inside. Inside there were snacks and beverages available for purchase. I highly recommend this.

Bosphorus Strait, copious boats and ships of all kinds. It was fascinating to see the Bosphorus Strait; the world's narrowest strait used for international navigation, connecting the Black Sea with the Sea of Marmara and divides the European Continent from the Asian Continent. The Bosphorus Strait, being straddled on both sides by the city of Istanbul (a city with a population in excess of 17 million people), is a very busy waterway with copious maritime traffic of all types from small boats to large ships. Our view of the Bosphorus was from our 10 story high Island Princess Cruise ship balcony state room, which gave us wonderful and memorable views of Istanbul and the Bosphorus Strait, during our 8 hour Istanbul port of call.
Fantastic!. Take a Ferry, This straits links the Black Sea with the Sea of Marmara which separates Europe from Asia. Fantastic panorama.
No comment.......excellent trip. I made I don't know how many videos. I couldn't leave any second. My children liked it as well, it's discovering and relaxing time as well

Great views during the day or evenings. We did this sunset trip as past off the Big Bus tours and there were good informative commentary. Then on another day took one of the affordable TL12, one hour boat trips from opposite the spice market, and although no commentary we had a lovely trip with lots of photo opportunities. Wonderful sightseeing to do when your feet cannot walk anymore

Don't miss the boat ride. The ride is about 1/12 hrs. We started at light, watched to sunset over a mosque and saw all the buildings lite up on our way home. It got cold once the sun went down so even though you can sit inside still breezy so dress warm. It really helped to understand the path from the Mediterranean Sea to the black sea and the Asian side from the Europe side. They gave a running talk during the ride pointing out all the important sites and history of them. Excellent boat tour.

THE BOSPHORUS IS A TAXIWAY. Make sure you take a fast ferry to Bostanci for shopping, a slow ferry to Anadolu Kavagi to eat fish and a speed boat or slow boat to the Asian side and visit one of the many excellent restaurants.This way you will get a flavour of Istanbul as well as a flavour of the cuisine.

Ferry from GoldenHorn to the Asian side. This was a great way to see both sides of the European side plus the Asian side. Istanbul is huge! If you drive back over the bridge, there is the sign "Welcome to Europe" which is cool.

Great way to spend the day.. Take the public ferry. It will take you almost up to the Black Sea. It stops at the town of Anadolu Kavagi for about 2-3 hours. You can have lunch and climb up to the fort for some great views of the Bosphous. The whole trip takes about 5-6 hours.It is a public ferry. So it is cheap. 25TL for a round trip ticket. ( about $10).You get to see the city of Istanbul and the European and Asian sides from the water. A great way to spend a day.

Take a boat from the harbour and dont get suckered by the hustlers !!!. Take a walk down to the harbor and there are a number of cruises that go up and down the river. It's fairly cheap, they sell some snacks on board and you can see some very cool buildings and see Istanbul from the water. Watch out for the hustlers on the docks that claim they will give you some great deal - just walk over to the boats and get the prices - most of the hustlers will try and charge you double what the real costs are. Bring a blanket or wear a warm jacket, and go up to the top deck if its a nice day and get a good seat by the rails - it can get fairly crowded. Enjoy !!
Wonderfull View. Exactly best wonderfull place ..you must join the boat tours. very cheap like 5 Euro . maybe this is the best side seeing ..

Beautiful river cruise. A must do if you have the time. Use the Sehar Hatlari cruise boats if you can - they are much cheaper than the private tours for the same view. Interesting landmarks along the strait, including some lovely quaint ones.

Wonderful Boat Trip. My friend and I spend a wonderful, if but chilly, two hours sailing up, then down, the Bospherus one late afternoon in November. Our boat was small and open-air which allowed us a splendid view of both banks, with a cabin below. Tea and coffee were served and most of our fellow travellers were Turkish. Although most couldn't speak English we exchanged 'comments' and joked about the cold once the sun began going down. It was a great experience and can thoroughly recommend it at any time of the day (just take a jacket for the evening!).

Puzzling mega-city that works. Very friendly and welcoming people in Istanbul. Clean and orderly city. Heavily guarded by police everywhere.We toured the European and Asian sides in our own small coach with driver and an excellent English-speaking professional guide: Ms Emi Ulygun (emiuygun_74@hotmail.com), we really got value for money with regard to information and sites.
Bosphorus Cruise. A great way to cruise between Asia and Europe onboard the commuter ferry up the Bosphorus and over the sea of Marmara.

East meets West. The remarkable part of this Strait is how just crossing a bridge takes you from Europe into Asia of which Turkey is 83% in Asia but the trip on the Bosphorous lets you see the vast difference in Architecture either side of the Strait quite remarkable
Ortakoy. When we went there we tasted Kumpir. It was so delicious. Like a potato mountain. Also you may try Waffle too.

A memorable experience. We caught the Bosphorous ferry from the riverside near Kadikoy metro station. This allowed us to visit the Asian side, travel on the Moda heritage tram and catch lunch.The boat ride is magnificent. We were served tea from a silver salver by an excellent waiter. The sights are eye-catching-the main Mosques, forts and bridges.An enthralling experience.

No to be missed. A cruise along the Bosphorus Strait is one of the highlights of a trip to Istambul. You get to see impressive palaces as well a outstanding private residences and many interesting public buildings.

Must go to Bosphorus by ferry (Day & night). The ferry trip around the bosphorus is breath taking because you see the amazing combination of sea, sky, nature, and monuments.
If you are going on a romantic trip, u must go there at night. Breathtaking.

Amazing ride and skyline. The boat ride will let you see the beauty of istanbul...we went in the evening and the skyline of istanbul was absolutely majestic with the silhouette of the minerets against the sunset really highlighting the depth and culture of this amazing city. Would definitely recommend as part of trip to istanbul. Relaxing, scenic and breathtaking.

Our Visit. On our last day in Istanbul, we took a bot ride up the Bosphorus to the Black Sea. Our trip lasted about 3 hours and included lunch. The views from the boat were quite revealing. Once out of the Istanbul city area, the scenery was beautiful and the mansions along the river showed that there was 'money' in this region. The Bosphorus is a very busy shipping lane into the Black Sea, but the beauty of the area is not spoilt by the big tankers. It seemed to us that only a few were allowed to travel up the river at a time, so that the views were not spoilt for the site seeing public. I would certainly recommend a boat ride along this stretch of river.

A boat trip not to forget. Visiting Istanbul means undoubtedly also seeing Istanbul from the Bosporus by boat. It gives you another view on the city and is a must do, if not you will miss a special aspect of this city at the Bosporus and the Golden Horn. Make sure you book for a journey seeing most of the Golden Horn and pass under the famous Bosporus bridge. Take enough time for this activity, you will be on board for at least 2 hours

A boat trip up the Bospoot to be missedrus is n. Boats leave from the Galata Bridge area and go every hour on the hour, the trip we took lasted an hour and a half and went up to the FSM Bridge and back. There is a bit of a commentary, but hard to hear, so take your guide book and do it yourself! Drinks and food continuously available on the boat, and there is an upper deck, covered but with open side, and a lower enclosed deck....
Cruising the Bosphorus. Enjoyed a fab afternoon cruise on the Bosphorus. The houses and other properties along the Bosphorus are truly stunning.

Beautiful divide between modern and historic. Suggest a boat ride to explore the area as the contrasting sights unfold. The skyline with the mosques and palace are beautiful to observe from the water.
A Great Boat Ride. A boat ride along the strait will let you see the true majesty of Istanbul. Views of monuments, mosques, palaces, etc on both sides give you a whole other feel for the city.

A good half day trip. We spent an afternoon on a boat trip including lunch. Very enjoyable and equally excellent value. You get some good views of riverside buildings as well as some amazing skyline views on returning st dusk. Highly recommended.

Bosphorus boat ride. It was recommended by many tourists and many people. I did not take a tour boat, instead, I went on the regular boat to Princess Island and to Asia area, So I got to see the Bosphorus strait. I can not help but taking lots of pictures. On the way back, I just sat there playing my cell phone. What a difference!!!! Maybe I just was tired of extremely excitement.

Boat cruise is a highlight. Don't miss the opportunity to go on a boat cruise of the Bosphorus. We opted for a 3 hour cruise for 30 TL each. In fact it lasted more like 4, including a one hour stop giving chance to explore an ancient castle. It was fascinating to see every aspect of the city - industrial docklands, ancient cityscape and high tech/high rise offices.

Great Way To Learn Istanbul's History. We took a full day tour of Bosphorus Strait, which lasts 6 hours and allows you to go through a lot of historic buildings learning about the city's past. If you are planning an economic tour, I would recommend using the government run service - Seher Haltari. Full day tour leaves around 10:30 from Kabatat and returns at 4:30, costing 25 TL per person and another 10 TL for the audio guide.It breaks for 3 hours at the Island where you can see the European Castle & have a nice fish dinner either on the shore or up near the castle - both with awesome views. Must admit that the break is a bit long and tiring.An alternative way is to do a 2 hr tour with the same company that starts at 2:30 PM in the afternoon.

Take a bite next to the river!. Take a cheap bite (fish sandwich next to the strait) and do take Sehir Hatları's Short or Long Bosphorus Tour (we took the short one, quite worth it for the price, be early, queue is long and you wanna get a good seat (the left side of the ferry btw)

See Istanbul from the water..... If you have the time a boat ride on the Bosphorus to the Black Sea is a must. You get to see many buildings along the journey with a guide to point out all the sites. You pass across Europe and Asia - the only place in the world you can do this. The little island at the end of the boat ride has heaps of fabulous looking seafood restaurants - if you want to eat there - make sure you are not on a boat tour that includes lunch (as some do) and that you can go back on another boat - as you need a lot of time to eat there and walk to the fortress. We thoroughly enjoyed our boat trip.
Cross or take a boat trip.. I crossed the bridges, on foot, in a taxi, and in the tram and went on a day cruise and a night dinner cruise. It's a wonderful part of Istanbul.

Our next vacation home? (I wish). Lunch at a fish restaurant on up toward the Black Sea, followed by a boat ride on the Bosphorus. Our group of 30 was easily accomodated. The historical houses were explained in context of the times. Next time I have a couple of million to spare, that's where I would live!

.. It was fantastic
Me and my husband we took two cruises down the bosphorus strait and it was great both times.
Istanbul is a very beautiful place to visit

An incredible beautifull rivier that splits Istanbul in two great parts. Between many monuments & buildings you certainly must visit the Bosphorus Strait with the beautifull bridges, many boats and great views. Must see !!!!!

wekk worth a ferry trip. only takes 7 minutes for the ferry to go from Europe to Asia and cost 4 Turkish Lira (1 sterling)
AS with all public purchase tokens first before getting on ferry
Significant difference when landing in Asia - it just feels different
Well worth the visit
Mrs.. We took a half day cruise and I highly recommend this tour to all. The took guide spoke good English, it was a comfortable, interactive tour that took us down memory lane on Turkey's history.

Overview of history of Istanbul. Really worthwhile to take the cruise of the Bosphorus Strait with a tour guide - so much to see artistically, historically, information about invaders and defenses - should do in first couple says of arriving I think1

Ride the State Ferry the full length of the Strait, for a full and delightful day.. Avoid the private tours, and take the state ferry from Kabatas, at the southern end of the ferry landings, not the private ferry. Take it all the way to the Black Sea, and stop at the town on the northwestern end of the Bosphorus, eat a nice lunch at a waterfront restaurant, and return with the current.

Excellent views, excellent scenary, definitely a must in istanbul. We took the sehir hatlari, full bosphorus tour.It costs 8euros and the audio guide costs 5euros. The view was amazing, very nice buildings throughout the stretch. Th boat had canteen and was fairly priced. It would have been good if we had got the audio guide with us to hear more about the history surrounding that area.

You should have to see before you die. Amazing place to see once in a life, there are lot of historical places arround aswell. And should have to do bosphorus trip with small boats.... Amazing place to see once in a life...

Beautiful scenery. We took a cruise ship on the Bosphorous the night we came into Turkey. It was a boat that had dinner and a show. The dinner was fair, and the show was ok. The boat ride was very nice. You were able to see the buildings lit up at night with different colors and see the bridges at night. It is amazing to be both in Asia and Europe at the same time. We did see the Bosphorous in the day time which was even nicer. I would suggest doing a boat ride of some kind on the Bosphorous preferably in the daytime though.

Search More for a Good Tour, tons are weak. Just a tip, all boating trips can be fun however do spend a bit of time to find a tour with good history and find out what your getting, we booked a place via our hotel and it was ok but no real talk of the history which was important to us, all quite pretty though.. 20 more minutes making sure you have a good tour will pay off, Enjoy!

Wonderful cruise. Don't go to Istanbul without seeing it from the water. The views along the Bosphorus will enhance your appreciation of just what a beautiful and historic city this is. If you can, it's worth allotting the time to go all the way to the Black Sea.

Lovely cruise. This was the highlight of our trip to Istanbul
It was a great cruise taking in the sights along the way including ciragan palace,ortakoy,Rumeli fortress,bospherous bridge,kucuksu palace,Maiden's Tower,and the golden horn.

Not So Dire Straits. Talked into a Boat Tour on landing at the Airport and the end result was great but on reflection at 40 euro each a tad expensive for a ferry ride !! While their was a virtual D-Day Armada out on the Strait , they all played well together and kept a reasonable distance, no ramming speed here ! A pleasant way to spend a couple of hours and see the sights from the water especially on a glorious sunny day, Magic ! Tip, just turn up and pick a boat/price to suit.
Very interesting watching all the fishermen on the dock.. We took the metro under the Bosphorus Strait and walked backover on the bridge. Very interesting watching all the fishermen on the dock.

Behold the Beauty. I was saddened that I never got to cross the bridge let alone cross over to Asia. But every time I drove by or visited many of the clubs near by I could never help but to admire its beauty. Club Reina offers the best view of the bridge as it is an outdoor night club. Club Black offers a nice view as well from its second story floor.

Cruising the shores. Took a couple hour guided cruise of the Bosphorus Strait. Perhaps it was our tour guide, but I quickly got bored listening to how much the houses cost and who lived in them. Wasn't worth the time.

River. If only our room had been over looking the Bosphorus, we stayed at the CVK Park Bosphorus Hotel and unfortunately they put us in one of their most unattractive rooms right on the street at street level so all night we heard the cats fighting the street dogs barking and the guy who came home late get a thorough tongue lashing and locked out!!! Not good CVK your review will come soon. The Bosphorus is an amazingly busy water way with ferries, fishing boats, huge passenger liners and much more. it looked clean snd beautiful early in the morning from the dining room.

One of the Highlights of any trip to Istanbul. Whether you're taking a cruise, or just using on of the plentiful, and very inexpensive, water taxis, sailing on the Bosphorus is not to be missed. The boat traffic between the Sea of Marmara and the Black Sea is multitudinous and varied. You'll see giant container ships as well as many Liquid Natural Gas carriers coming from Russia. The buildings along the Bosphorus are amazing too. You'll see many palaces as well as the beautiful mosque which has been chosen as a picture above. Be sure you spend some time on the water!

Cannot Escape the Bosphorus!. The Bosphorus is the life blood of Istanbul. No matter which side or which hill you view it from it beckons you. It is beautiful to say the very least. No matter where you are in Istanbul, there are magnificent views of the city along the water. Spend some time there, take walks along the water and absorb the current of the world passing in front of you.
Lies between Europe and Asia. Excellent shipping lane loads of ship traffic liners, boats, tankers cruisers and ferries is a real hustle bustle atmophere.

Wonderful view. Stunning and incredible view even in winter (and with the snow :P )
The boat trip is a must to be able to actually see most of this area.

I love any attraction with water but this is especially cool!. With Europe on one side of the water and Asia on the other side it is easy to reminisce of how traders used this area. The tour boats give great history without having to do the research. It's a win/ win.
touristy. best way to see is from a cruise ship after all it is these straits that link the Mediterranean with the sea of marmara

Splendid views on both sides when cruisng the Boshorus Strait. We went on a half day cruise, and the views on both sides were splendid. We especially enjoyed the view of the bridge and the Dolmabache palace.

Be sure to get out on the water when you visit Istanbul. We took a tour boat that travelled the coastline - lots of wonderful spots to see along the way - and it's simply wonderful to see Istanbul from the water.

A thing to do..... You can see some nice sites, use the public transport with a Istanbul kart. Dont use a tour not worth it. Rent an audio device to get an idea of what's what. You can get the two hour ride or the longer one, I suggest the shorter one or they take you and leave you in a small town where restaurant over charge you and nothing much to do there. Go for a quick cruise in a loop otherwise gets boring.

One of the busiest waterways in the World. Around 50,000 ships pass through the strait annually and there are plenty of cruises and ferries to bring you between Asia and Europe. This was my preferred way of crossing the Bosphorous as you get a feel for the scale of the strait as well as Istanbul itself. The ferries operate under the Istanbul public transport system so it is not expensive at all.

Worth taking a cruise on the Bosphorus while in Istanbul. Taking a cruise on the Bosphorus while in Istanbul is definitely worth your time. It allows you to see so much of the city from a different perspective.

Cruise it! . Cheap and a huge selection of boats. The views are amazing! Don't forget to eat Balik ekmek there. Although I found the staff a the one we ate at were quite rude, but the food was awesome!
My favourite!. The strait must have been my faovorite thin to do in Istanbul. So refreshing and beautiful. I woud recommend anyone to do it.

Public Transport!. You can get all the way up and down the Bosphorus straight on a boat for 40p. We took the 25E bus from the end of the Kabatas tube all the way up the coast and caught the bus back down! A wonderfully sunny, beautiful adventure!

A must when you are in Istanbul. When in Istanbul you must take a trip on the Bosporus. Beware of the tourist boats, they are usually overpriced and the boats can be overcrowded. Do what the Istanbul's do: take the ferry. There are a number to choose from - you could go to Ortakoy where there are nice restaurants, or to lively Kadikoy. If you have more time to spare, take a ferry to where the Black Sea starts. You will have to plan this as the ferry leaves (and returns) only twice a day but it is certainly worth it, particularly in summer.

Sunset. I would recommend a trip down the bosphorus just before sunset. Sit on right side of boat (as you get on) as this side always closet to the bank so best views. Drinks on board reasonable price. We also brought round seseame seed bread bun from a seller who came on board that was nice

Historically amazing sight. We rode ferries across the Bosphorous. They were very inexpensive, and offered great views of the European and Asian sides of the city of Istanbul. Unfortunately, it was cold and rainy and windy, but fortunately, the boats have enclosed compartments from which you can see the world. Do it on a nice day, if you can!
Great experience. Did this boat trip during the day and it gives you the opportunity to take great pictures. Had lunch under the bridge at one of the restaurants.
Beautiful Relaxing view. Such an awesome and beautiful sight. Really enjoyed it - a must see especially on the cruise. Great view from the palace as well

Bosphorus Istanbul-Ortakoy. It is another wonderful place to visit and enjoy the seen few meters down under the bridge, while eating a Roasted jacked potato, with your favorite toppings, finishing with a sweet lovely waffle mixed with your favorite fruits and chocolate toppings, ending it up with a slow market visit that is beside the famous mosque, getting a souvenir back home.

This is a most important waterway and it is easily possible to sail on it too. The Bosphorus divides Istanbul into European and Asian parts. Ferries go back and forth to several docks and other ships are there too. It is possible to see the Asian side or take a halfway cruise or go all the way to the start of the Black Sea. We took a ferry to the Asian side and also another ferry for the halfway cruise that turned around near the second bridge. It was a great way for a good look at the lovely buildings that are along the shore on both sides.

Very nice boat ride. You can take any tourist boat that leaves from near the Istanbul railway station. You do not need book in advance. There is lot of space.If it is hot you can sit in the air-conditioned and cabin and see the sights. However the outside is lovely too.The sights are pointed out by the tour operators. We took the day cruise because we heard the night cruise with dinner is a rip-off.

You know you want too!. Weather you like boats or not, a trip on the Bosphorous straight has to be done, a whole variety of trip lengths and destinations are available.We just opted for a 90 min, minimal guided version, onlyy 12 Lira each, suited our needs. Lots of points of interest to see, and of course you get to span 2 continents.

Awesome views and buildings. We took the ferry and our guide provided lots of information about the buildings, history, etc of the Bosphorus Straight. We enjoyed drinks on board as we relaxed and experienced the amazing views.

Beautiful Views. We took the river cruise, and it was really exciting! We got to see a lot of attractions, and many activities around the area. Beautiful views also. They served some drinks and snacks on board, so we got ourselves NesCafe to go with the cold weather around the time we were there.
worth the view. You get stunning view of the bospherus and the bridge . a real nice photo shoot spot. the view from here is realy good.

Ideal afternoon boat trip. The Bosphorus straight runs between the sea of Marmara and the Black Sea dividing Europe from Asia. It is about 25 miles long and varies in width between 1 and 3 miles. It is a very busy sea way handling about 6000 plus ships a year. The tour stars just inside the Golden Horn and travels north along the European side passing under the 2 main bridges joining Europe and Asia, a third is currently under construction near to the Black sea. Either side of the straight has a great range of buildings to admire from palaces, castle fortifications, and the homes of the rich and famous. One property was sold for 100 million euros. This is definitely not a cheap place to set up home.our boat stopped at a village Anadolu Kavagion the Asian side just before the Black Sea where the third bridge is being constructed. Here you have about 1/2 hour to get a coffee or buy some souvenirs. The boat then travels back down the Asian side. A hot buffet is served on-board during the trip. This is an absolute must do trip!

Amazing Tour. l visited this tour and could not get enough of what l was seeing, the ferry begins from one port and then makes its way up the sea, and returns down the other side, l took over 200 photos and was very overwhelmed by the historic sights. If visiting Turkey this is a must highly recommend.

Take the Cruise. Many cruises are offered from the Galata Bridge area. Often these are short 1 to 1.5 hours and may suit. However consider the 10:30 cruise up the Bosphorus to Anadolu Kavagi. Youstop here for lunch, tour round or visit the castle before returning.We started from Kabatas a little further out avoiding the crowds at Eminonu.Fabulous views of the Bosphorus and get to visit the Asian side.Plenty of fish restaurants to choose from and very competitive for your custom.
Always something moving!. Fishermen on the bridges- the twinkling lights of Asia across the other side and constant ships and ferries - one of the great harbour cities for sure

Boats and boats . This would have to be one of the busiest straits. It certainly ,the busiest that I have seen. We crossed it a few times and crossed boat after boat. Ships would be more accurate. The views are great. Mike

The boundary between Europe and Asia. The Bosphorus Strait that runs along the Turkey boundary forms part of the boundary between Asia and Europe. The Bosphoros connects to the Black Sea. This is where a millenia of history can be felt

A scenic sunset or nighttime cruise option with sight-seeing on the Europe and Asia shorelines. While in Istanbul, you literally can't miss the Bosphorus Strait - it's that large, moving body of water separating the European and Asian halves of Turkey. If you hike over the busy Galata bridge, you're crossing the Bosphorus and you can check the box that you've seen it. For those who might want to spend more quality time on this body of water, I'd recommend a cruise - but be selective about which cruise you book and do some homework to understand what you can expect. I've been on two Bosphorus cruises - one was an economical sunset cruise that included a brown bag to put over my tepid can of Efes, and the other was a higher-end nighttime cruise complete with dinner, drinks and (fairly ridiculous) belly dancing acts and folkloric dance (food = meh; drinks = watered down). Whatever your financial situation, there are options to take a cruise or ferry. Both cruises I took were spectacular in their own right and provided different ways to see waterfront houses, landmarks and the illuminated suspension bridges. Bring layers of clothing to keep warm, and be prepared to spend at least 2-3 hours on a cruise (it's a commitment!). I dressed casually on both cruises, but some folks on the higher-end ride were dress to the nines - though somehow stilettos don't seem like the very best choice for this adventure (although almost as entertaining as the belly dancers).

A Watery Continental Divide. After seeing how dangerously overloaded the ferryboats can be we took a pass on the boat ride. We did visit both sides of the strait by bridge to enjoy the views form each continent, which are especially nice at night.

Careful which tour you take, but lots to see. Choppy waters, cold and windy but we had a knowledgeable tour guide that pointed out all the key buildings and bridges on the Europe and Asia side. Our tour didn't drop us off anywhere so a waste of a lot of money but an enjoyable few hours nonetheless

The waterway that sperates Eurpoe from Asia. Our boat trip was arranged through the tour agents we initially booked our holiday with, therefore don't know cost of 1 hour boat trip. It was wonderful, the sights, the history, the views, not too be missed if in Istanbul.
Another for the bucket list. How often can you leisurely walk from one continent to another? You can also take a boat ride on the strait or just sit and enjoy the view.

Must see - Just take a ferry boat.. This is must see in Istanbul. The Bosphorus is such a busy waterway - a narrow connection point from the Black Sea to the Agean. It's easy and inexpensive to get a ferry and travel from the Europe to the Asian side and back in an afternoon. Or you can take one of the many organised tours. But I think it's just as easy to go the way of the locals and take the ferry. You can buy a token from the machines right at the ferry terminal.

A Cruise is a Must Do. We took a 75 minute cruise with commentary up & down the Bospherus. It's an excellent way to see both sides of the Straits. Lots to see. The boat had a café serving hot & cold drinks & cold snacks.
A magical sunset. to have the opportunity to see a sunset on the Bosphorus is an experience I will never forget. A magical moment

Take a cruise to see it best.. We took a half day cruise up the Bosphorus Strait which included lunch and a stop at Anadolufeneri.You see history, politics, culture and amazing residences on the cruise.Highly recommended.

Modern and historic diversity of Istanbul. On our fourth trip to Istanbul finally got around to an hour's trip up the Bosphorus. Caught a ferry from beside the Galatea Bridge; combined this with a visit to the Spice Market nearby first. Really enjoyed the ferry trip - seeing the old and newer areas of Istanbul side be side, and with the help of a guide, understanding some of the history of the various buildings along the way and the cultural mix and style of the various suburbs now developing in the wider city. This helped us find the Istanbul Modern Art Museum which we hadn't seen advertised or promoted previously. We went back there later - great restaurant with stunning views across the Bosphorus to Topkapi from its outdoor deck. Turns out we were staying nearby. Wendy and John, Adelaide Australia.

Beautiful Bosphorus!. Beautiful Beautiful bosphorus strait! I got the opportunity to sail through it when we traveled to one of the prince's islands, and spend some time by the strait when we went to various clubs and hotels off the shore. Taking the bosphorus strait tour is totally worth it. Beautiful view of the two continents!

Fatimah . We took the cruise on the bosphorus and loved every second of it
The sights are breath taking
U really see a different side to istanbul
I took the cruise with a tour group but it can be done alone
U need to take the fairy and take metro or bus
Not hard u just need a map really

Take the boat trip!. A beautiful waterway from any angle, take the boat trip and enjoy an hour or two viewing it all. Great way to spend a sunny morning or afternoon. Try the fish rolls on the wharf on your return

A great cruise. Dont miss out a night cruise with dinner, live music and dance! Good food, great atmosphere, great view of the Bosphorus shore , palaces, mosques! Great on every weather, if the cruise is organised and it is not too windy

A wonderful Sunday tour. We were in Istanbul for a Sunday and wanted to take one of the daytime ferries to the end of the Bosphorus. You don't need an expensive private cruise. We boarded a ferry which can be done near the Galata Bridge or near the Dolmapache Palace, which ever is more close. We boarded around 10:30 AM and returned around 4pm. We went to the last village on the route which offers lots of restaurants. Don't eat the GOLD restuarant as it is not the best. Actually we realized the ones right on the water front were the most populated and probably had the best food as well. You see great houses and bridges and many things that makes this tour a must door in Istanbul.

One of a kind!. Crossing the Strait from Europe into Asia and vice versa is quite an experience if you manage to think of it that way - two conitnents in one short ride. The bridges offer quite a view while crossing.

A visit to Istanbul isn't complete until you cruise the Bosphorus. There are many cruise companies to choose from starting at dock side from a cost pp of Euro 5 average 15 but some charge as much as 45 a head. You get to cruise the same route so choice is yours. Average duration 2.5 hours. Great photo opportunities, not a lot of places to hide onboard when it rains. Dennis
Loads of people!. A very nice spot for photo op. Interesting cafes and restaurants and the view of the bosphorus and the bridge. However it is very, but very touristic.

Great way to take in the sights. Took the TurYol ferry with the audio guide which had good info on most attractions. There's lots to see on both sides and the ferry goes close on both sides of the strait. Definitely a must do when in Istanbul and a great way to get oriented.

A must for any visitor to Istanbul!. This was the highlite of our visit to Istanbul. We took a ferry that left at around 10am and returned late afternoon - a full day trip. The ferry stops at many picturesque towns up the Bospherous. Specialities from the villages are sold on board as you leave each harbour e.g. delicious, creamy yogurts. The ferry stops at the last port close to the Black Sea and leaves in the mid afternoon. Most passengers climb the low mountain to the the old fort. There are plenty of restaurants up there where we had lunch overlooking the Bospherous and Black Sea before wandering down to the harbour. Before boarding the ferry we had delicious Baklava and espressos at one of the many waterside restaurants.
Amazing views from the ship. Awe inspiring views as we sailed sailed up the strait at sunrise. The sunset views were wonderful too.

skip the tour boats and take the public ferry. the ferry, 15 tl leaves once per day and crises crosses the straits out to the black sea the returns in the afternoon. get off at the last european stop for lunch and catch the boat on its return or bus back to the city
loved it. take the boat tour with TulOyl for 12TL. Worth the sights from the water. If you´re lucky, you might even see some black dolphins that we saw near the famous lighthouse.

Not worth the time or trouble. Took a 1 1/2 hour hop-on,hop-off boat ride. We could not hear the commentary, which was in Turkish and English, and really were not very many items worth seeing anyway. If you really want to see the old fort, go there for a separate tour.

Europe and Asia at the Same Time. A unique way to experience two continents at the same time. Istanbul is the place to be. the boat tours are really nice since it allows you to see the forts and castles. You can even stop off and have lunch.
Dinner Cruise on the Bosphorus. A magical experience for those who love middle eastern music,food and dancing. I would recommend this this delightful experience for all ages and all nationalities.

So many boats. Advise you to go to the top of the boat for the best views. We did not use headphones and wish we had as we were just able to enjoy the ride and see the sites but did not know the various buildings. But very enjoyable. There is a spice market nearby - much like the Grand Bazaar but so much smaller and nicer! Didn't feel hustled here and there were many of the same stores

One side Asia the other Europe. The Bosphorus Strait basically forms a boundary between Europe and Asia. Turkey is the only country that is located on two Continents! Many cruise packages are offered but beware of false tickets and prices! Cruising it you will see many landmarks and Palaces etc. It is beautiful at night when the city and the 2 bridges' lights are on; a third bridge to the north is still under construction. There are numerous public ferries criss-crossing all day and night so if a "tour" is not up your ally, just get a public day pass by the Galeta Bridge and explore....very cheap compared to the organized tours.

Beautiful Way to Spend the day - Cruising! . We spent two wonderful relaxing days cruising the bosphorus. One day was with the hop on hop off boat and the next was a full day cruise with a stop at a small fishing village. Best 17 TL we spent during our vacation!

Pleasant tour. We paid a small amount of money to get on a big boat with about 100-200 people on it. The boat went to Bosphorus strait and back in about 90 minutes and it was such a pleasant and lovely experience that me and my friend went for the second time the next day. One of our tours was during sunset, and I really recommend you to do the same because we really saw some of our most beautiful scenes ever during that tour. :)

One of the Highlights of Our Trip. During our tour of Turkey, we took a 90 minute cruise from the Golden Horn up to the 2nd suspension bridge across the Bosphorus, then back part way. It was a lovely morning and the sightseeing was beautiful, especially near the Fortress of Europe, which was constructed in 1452. Definitely a must see.

Fantastic views. One of the busiest waterways in the world, fascinating to travel and incredible feeling looking at Europe on one side and Asia on the other along with the wonderful views along the route.

Landmark View of Istanbul. Watching a movie, this mesmerising view of a blue watery passage between two land masses, dotted with structures of a mosque with equally blue domes and minerette gave me a 'bucket list' item very early in life. This impression was truly matched the experience, crushing in a yacht, along this river like passage between two diverse Continants which is referred to as Bosphurous. You will never be disappointed, sailing along, whether it be dawn, day or dusk, either in rain or sunshine. A must experience location.

Definitely worth undertaking. We took a 1 hour long Bosphorus cruise on the boat, which is a must for all touristsCruise includes a to and fro travel starting from the European side of Istanbul and returning from the Asian side.
