Huge metropolis. Cruising along this mighty river gives you an idea of just how huge this exciting city is. There are some fantastic luxury homes on the waterfront. A very pleasant way to spend a few hours in Istanbul.

Bosphorus cruise.. All visitors should do a cruise along the Bosphorus. The cruise needs to be at least 2 hours duration and like for most things in Istanbul, do bargain for the cost of a ticket. My ticket cost started at 50tl and in the end I got it for 15tl....! Enjoy.

Lovely to sail through on nice day. Make sure you pick a nice day to do this as it can be absolutely fantastic. Beautful views and a fantastic opportunity to take some great photos while sailing along the Seas.

**Lovely Bosphorus tour**. We bought our tickets for the Bosphorus Tour near to the bus station where you can buy bread and fish. The ticket costs 12 TL and the tour takes about 1,5-2 hours. There is service on the boat (sandwich, snack, salep, tea, coffee). I recommend to use this service if you want to take this tour.
wow. overall beauty and seeing a lot of people lined up next to each other with a fishing string. Amazing view.

Unforgettable cruise and views. Unforgettable cruises and views
From Europe and Asia side riding the ferry
Or watching the views from my hotel
Plus the nice cruise still giving me
Avery pleasant Unforgettable memories
The best thing the cheap tariffs

good view. very beautiful place with good view in every weather(when i was there its rainy) . some people fishing and some people sale something.side streets is beautiful.its good experiment.everybody should see Bosphorus.i love it
Great Little trip. Would have been nice to stop on the Asian side. The guide was grat fun with a really nice since of humor

Most beautiful view of Istanbul. We were lucky to book a cruise in a sunny day and the view of the town was exquisite.You can admire the shores on both sides: palaces, impressive mosques, hotels, gardens, restaurants, old ottoman wooden houses...We were picked by a bus at Rumeli fortress and taken back to our hotel.It is a tour you shouldn't miss in Istanbul.

Best way to see Istanbul. You have not really seen or felt the spirit of Istanbul if you have not taken even a short tour of the Bosphorus Strait ! There are even short 1-2 hour long tours that are affordable. At least try to take one of these
Worth it. Worth going up and down at least once. Beautiful landscape on both sides. Istanbul is a beautiful city and both the European and Asian side are worth a visit.

Half Day tour with Senkron Sightseeing Tours. We took the 1/2 day afternoon boat tour with Senkron Sightseeing Tours (Tour ST-09 in their tour book) - with buffet - 1 - 5.30pm. It was great, the guide spoke into a mike and the details were pipped around the boat so where-ever you sat - either inside or on the top deck, you could hear his discriptions and explainations - he was very knoweagble. The buffet catered to almost every taste with hot and cold choices, and a bar served alcohol which was not as expensive as expected, as we know some of these tours where you have to purchase their drinks on-board can be a rip-off. The tour lasts just over 4 1/2 hours, 2 hours cruise down to Anadolu with about a 45 minute stop-over, and then 2 hours back for 45 euro each - we thought this a tad expensive, however the buffet was so large, we had seconds and then didn't want an evening meal that night. I recommend this to anyone as access to the boat is easy to buggies can get on safely and they pick you up and drop back to your hotel.

A must. This is must for tourists that come to Turkey. Ali Yulniz our guide hire a private yacht for us. Tour the Bosphorus Straight from one end to Maiden's Tower. On the straight you'll see the Europe and Asia sides. You'll see the old city Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, palaces, nice private houses and many more. This is a 2 hour tour, so relax, slip some tea or wine and watch the sunset. A must.

Beautiful Setting. Took a Bosphorus tour on a Sunday afternoon, just before sunset that resulted in a beautiful setting after a day of good weather. The tour started off well, with interesting sights (especially when you've just arrived to the city and haven't really seen much), before heading up north, where the sights thin down (more residential setting?), but the lit up bridges and buildings made up for it on the return, meaning I got to see both in daylight and nighttime. Tour is of a decent amount of time (from Sultanahmet to past the two bridges). Overall, much to see, beautiful!

We just had to do the ferry ride. You can watch Bosphorus from plenty of places without getting on a ferry - Topkapi Palace, rooftop terraces of the hotels and restaurant. However, to grasp the history and sights thoroughly, do take a ferry ride. We decided on a 90 minute ride, which was just enough for us. We used the basic Turyol that charged 12 TR per person. Private cruises will advertise narrated tours, but you can get the info you need from any good guidebook that will clearly point out the sites on the map. In our case, the headphones of the person next to us who bought an audio guide would beep up as soon as we pointed out the site using our Lonely Planet Guide. Tip - sit on the right side of the boat - it will back up and turn direction, which will effectively get you on the left side. All Turyol boats hug the left side of the coast both ways providing you close up view of the palaces and grand houses.
Mighty. The fact that this is in some measure the gateway between Europe and Asia says it all really.Views from Biyoglu, or Fatih are equally impressive.

A traffic jam, when you are already late. Loved crossing the bridge on this strait more than once. Did so on my way to a from the airport and also as part of the hop on and off bus tour. Great views of Asia and Europe but there is always traffic trying to cross this bridge. I traveled it a total of 3 times at 3 different time of the day and there was always traffic. If you plan to visit or drive through in any capacity make sure you add time for possible traffic jams.

at least one cruise is a must :). you gotta do a dinner cruise on the the day-time fishing boats....they are cleaned up and can be made to accommodate 6-8 people o if you want a private party:)you can also do the day-time tourist thing to see and hear about all of the structures along the Bosphorus......get the book....."Views from the Bosphorus" at a local book store :)

Ferry boat tour. I took a public ferry boat going to Kadikoy and made a short Bosphorus cruising tour because the Bosphorus Cruise arranged for tourists was long for me and the weather was not good. For only 20-minute tour, I saw Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Galata Tower and so on from the sea. I also drank a glass of tea. I really enjoyed the local atmosphere of Istanbul.

Great Views. We took a boat ride up the Bosphorus Strait. There were many great views of the Mosques and the city. It would have been a bit better for us if it was warmer and sunnier but we still had a great time. It was about 1.5 hours long. And I think the tickets were about $10 for a family of 4

Sunset view is the best!. Come just before sunset and you'll love the view of the mosques behind you.The trip is about 1+ hours and yes you can get cheaper tickets!I bought my ticket for €8, from a stand or if you walk around the harbour and you'll see ticket salers walking and offering tickets.Depending on where you purchased your ticket, you'll get a map of what you'll see during your trip ( you'll be too busy taking pictures to read the leaflet).The trip shows you the European and Asian side of Istanbul, which in my opinion is beautiful.Wear warm cloths as it might get cold and windy.

This can be "Very Good" or it can be "Terrible". When it is warm with gentle breezes blowing, the Bosphorus Straits cruise is great. Sometimes live musicians are on board, sometimes recorded music is blasting. I love riding up and down large rivers, straits etc. This time it was great fun, no rain, cold wind or annoying incidents. Sometimes not.

DON'T do the boat trip in bad weather!. Everyone does the boat trip up and down the Bosphorus. We had bad weather, too cold to sit outside and a vicious wind driving snow, so sat inside, warm enough but all the windows were steamed up so nobody could see anything! Two men were very energetically squeezing fresh oranges and pomegranates to make juice, then brought it around, loudly encouraging everyone to take one. No price list anywhere, and you'd be forgiven for thinking the juice was paid for as part of the trip? Nooooo... and the oranges in February are SOUR. This was our first lesson in Tourist Hospitality - always, always ask 'How Much?' before taking anything offered. Also, there are some quite aggressive map-sellers hanging around the docks, and one poor old dear had money stolen from her bag by one as she was trying to refuse to buy from him! Keep your bag zipped, your face blank, and be ready with a big, angry shout of NO!! when approached by street sellers. They are not official, they are known to be a real nuisance, and the less they sell the sooner they'll stop pestering tourists. In clear and warmer weather, the boat trip is great - the banks of the Bosphorus are lined with elegant palaces and great buildings, and the historical commentary on the boat can be very good indeed.
Simply Istanbul!. Don't forget to take a ferry, and stay outside, watch the surroundings. (Warm clothinh needed for winter)

Great Man Achievement. No matter how long you stay beside it , you cant feel any boredom
everything around makes you feel fresh .

Crossing the Bosphorus. For me it's still a treat to pass the Bosphorus by ferry even after 13 years of living here. There are different departure places such as Karaköy or Eminönü or Beşiktaş on the European side. Pass the river in about 20 minutes to the Asian side, that is if you take the regular ferry. On the ferry there's a possibility to get snacks, coffee or tea, soft drinks, crisps etc. for cheap prices. The view is wonderful and if you're lucky you might see dolphins although it doesn't happen much.

Take a walk. When you are finished with your offisial sightseeing of the town, you schould take a walk over the Bosphorus Strait.On both sides of the bridge it is a lot of people, tourists, shops and attractions.Even in wither it is lovely.When you come to the other side of the bridge go to the big tower and take the lift up. It is an fantastic sight over the town.

A must do. Take the public boat up the Bosphorus....it's a magnificent ride and get off at the last stop to walk around , shop, have a little lunch. There are great stops along the way and a lot of history to many of the stops. It's one of the best attractions in Istanbul, I think.

Ferry tale. We stayed in Kadikoy when we visited Istanbul and loved it. One wonderful part was taking the ferry over to the Old City, or to the Princess Isles. The trip to the Old City on the European side is 20 minutes to relax, watch the water and the approaching turrets and domes. You can also sip tea brought to you on a tray. We often struck up conversations with other passengers, anyone from a farmer from the countryside sight seeing like us, to a lovely young couple on hajj who were brimming with joy from their travels. Take the ferry. Treasure the bosphorus.

Interesting but longwinded!. We took a Bosphorus tour as I wanted to add Asia to my list. The first and last 30 minutes of the trip is very interesting, unfortunately the other 4 hours was quite monotonous. Still recommended, but bring reading material or work on your tan.

LOVED the views. I was warned about going, and I thoroughly enjoyed it all. We cruised the Black Sea and went through the Bosphorus Strait out, back, and then again on a small boat tour. Loved the views from the water. Highly recommend!
Highlight of the holiday. Cruise on the straits. Mixture of locals and tourists of different nationalities. Old Turkish lady sharing her picnic helped to make it extra special

The most Glorious city in the world!. Istanbul. Constantinople. Byzantium. This is a city that straddles two continents, both Asia and Europe - meeting place of the east and the west. It is a city that has fascinated and attracted people from around the world for centuries. In short, it is the most glorious city in the world. Walking down one of the longest pedestrian streets in the world (İstiklal Caddesi) one can see beautiful women in mini-skirts next to those who are "covered" in traditional garb. Istanbul is unforgettable and Turks are amongst the most hospitable people in the world. It is the rare person who visits Istanbul only once; one is compelled to return to this most fascinating and ancient of cities, where the nightlife is 24-7, and yet reminders of antiquity hold a constant and magical presence. However, perhaps the most emblematic image of this unique modern-yet-ancient city is the waterway that runs through it: the Bosphorus. To see it by day is inspiring; to view it by night is enchanting, when the lights on both sides of the water (European and Asian) shine like luminous beacons and touch the souls, hearts and minds of inhabitants and visitors alike. There is no other city quite like Istanbul.

Jewel of the World!. I used to live in Istanbul for 16 years. I guess it is much more beautiful than many European cities because it is a city of 24 hours.You can find anything and do anything 7/24.And the most amazing part of the city is the Bosphorus Strait.It is a must to take a boat trip there. One side of it is Europe and the other is Asia. You can enjoy the views of a city of lights!

Night time cruise. We went on a night time cruise beautiful panaramic views of the bridges and buildings all lit up at night. Live music belly dancer, lots of food and drink. You can stop inside of the boat or wander around the deck outside

One of the most beautiful places on earth. This is a must-see for everyone. The Bosphorus Strait connects the Sea of Marmara and the Black Sea and in the same time is the border between Europe and Asia. The whole strip is wonderful on both sides with many different sites and sounds.

Good. We enjoyed a boat ride on the Bosphorus. It was a pretty day and interesting scenery. If we'd had more time, it would be nice to take the longer cruise and go clear to the Black Sea and possibly get off at some points.

How can you not?. I cannot see how anyone can visit Istanbul and not take a cruise on the Bosphorus. Such great historic events took place here, Google a little before you go to appreciate the significance of the small stretch of water.

I would have done it everyday.. It looks great from the dock in land, but once you hop on, the breeze and the trukish tea makes the difference. You can get audio guide also that will be explaining every place you are passing through. It lasts 1.30hs and is a great experience with a sumny day, fog is not recommended.
Amazing. Wonderful trip, you get to see both sides of Istanbul the Asian and Europe.......😃😃😃😃, and only few minutes walk from the port as well.

A rainy day boat ride on the Bosphorus. We took one of the big tour boats at 14.30 on a rainy afternoon . Very good calue for money 12TL for 2 hours up the Bosphorus taking in sights of palaces and Istanbul from the water. You can rent an audio guide, but they want a large deposit or your passport. I would agine that in the summer this becomes pretty chaotic if the boat is packed.There's a cafeteria on board, but you can equally take your own food and enjoy a picnic. You can be inside or out, good for taking pictures. One big gripe - the toilets were disgusting ! Blocked, over flowing and smelly.

Enjoy the Ride!. Pretty and some cool sites to see while riding the river. Just make sure you negotiate your payment for a ride down the river. They start up crazy high and you can talk them down way lower. The boat is leaving no matter what-- they just want more people on it. It's definitely a chilly ride, so bring a jacket!
relaxing ferry. with very nice views and calm atmosphere, specially in a sunny day and specially in a local ferry from Galata to Uskudar, very cheap, really a nice moment of peace

Awesome Cruise !!. Nice way to see both the Asian and European parts of Istanbul on the Bosphorous. The cruise lasts for about an hour,with halts on the way,where one can get off and spend time and hop on the next boat. The Dolmabache Palace and gardens on the way is worth visiting.

Boat tour OK. But beware of people offering these cruises in the street. May be you don´t have enough time to be in Instambul. So you want to go everywhere and enjoy the most. But if you are an early bird, don´t let yourself be caught by the song "you wait here in the van, we will thakw you to the boat and the cruise of two hours will began shortly". We go to the boat, and have to wait almost 2 hours for several groups that were joining, one after another. Inclusivly we sail, go to the golden horn, and get back to pick up another group of tourists.

Great!. We made the cruise in the morning, from the local regular line boats, no fancy cruise. Went all the way to the entrance of the black sea, walked up to the fort and came back down to eat at the fishing villa. What a great experience! 100% recommended.
Wonderful cruise. So much to see and photograph. So much history to take in.We went past the Galata bridge which links Europe and Asia, and up to the 2nd bridge.About an hour and 15 minutes.
Cruise the Bosphorus. Great way to see both the European and Asia sides of Istanbul without the traffic. 90 minute boat ride is worth the time. Take a jacket the wind from the Black sea can be cold.

A must do. While in Istanbul, you have to take a trip to Bosphorus strait. The view of both continents divided by it and the ferry taking you through the beautiful sights along its shores is a fantastic experience that you could experience. The ferry ride is the best way and they also give you a worthy tour around Bosphorus and then round off the cruise or ferry ride with a nice little meal in any of the restaurants around.

Nice scenery. have a great time going through the strait. You can see Asia on one side and Europe on the other side. there is alot of interesting places also along the strait. Pls keep your camera ready.

Maybe the best part of the city!. Sailing in the Bosphorous strait is an extraordinary experience! It is an easy-going trip that combines sightseeing and relaxing. Start the sail during daytime in order to have a wide view to all the landmarks. The best part of the sailing is during sunset when the city is like a painting allowing you to feel its essence. The trip finishes when it's dark and it's also a nice part even if you can't really see a lot. Don't miss it!

breathtaking view. Having taken a cruise on the Bosphorus was breathtaking. This gave one a view of both the European and Asian side of the same country. It surrounds were presented by many visible tourist sights , but the view also gives one some insight into the local life style of the Turks. E.g, They seem to take to fishing a lot in their older years. Many mosques are visible from any vantage point and vary in size and architecture. There are therefore central to each community as some are built on the shore line while others remain iconic structures on top of hills in the distance.

Turkey Asia and Turkey Europe. If you are coming to Turkey a cruise down the Bhospherous is really recommended to get you into the feel of things. We went when it was winter so it was pretty cold and windy but nevertheless we enjoyed it immensely. The gulls come and sweep crumbs right off the water. You can see the Turkey Asia and Turkey Europe, both of which we were able to explore. You can even arrange private boat tour and dinner cruises. We took a regular ferry boat ride but it was super relaxing to be able to see the sea and click pics!

A sunny day cruise. We wee fortunate to get a sunny, warm day in February for our trip.I love the ferries that ply the Bosphorous. It was a beautiful 90 minutes with three stops to the mouth of the Black Sea, then a 20 minute hike up the hill to the ruins of the 2,000 year old Yoros Castle and a wonderful meal at the top overlooking the Bosphorous. The small village of Anadolu Kavagi was so peaceful after the bustle of Istanbul. We took the ferry and not the official Bosphorous Cruise, very relaxed, the stops at small villages are great and it's cheaper.

An epic world history site!. I cannot imagine too many locations more strategic to the ebbs and flows of world history than the Bosporus Straight! Be sure to time your return by ferry to the Europe side in early evening as the sun sets and the lights of the city light up the historical landmarks like the Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque. Stunning!
Short river cruise. We went on a short informative Bosphorus river cruise to the 2nd bridge and back, saw lots that not possible from the road

One word, exceptional. Made a cruise around the Bosphorus Strait
Was a mix of weather, the sailing, the views, the brease, hard to forget. Sat at a bar in the coast, see the ships passing, the cruises going from Asia to Europe, is hard to realize, how fortunate the Turkish people are.

Good cruise. Took a cruise suggested by hotel and was pleasantly surprised. I wish I had taken this the first day and got a little bit more familiar with city before I went around on my own. Great tour guide who was very informed. Good way to spend an afternoon.

Ferry to Kadikoy. Frequency every 20 min. Last 20 min and the view of Aya Sophia, Blue Mosque and the Palace is amazing.
Very cheap same fare as the tram or bus.

Interesting Facts. It is quite interesting when going travelling along the Bosphorus Strait. There are a lot of historical and geographical facts about the strait. How it forms a border between Europe and Asia. How it forms a connection between the Black Sea and the Aegean Sea and then the Mediterranean Sea. The very populated banks of the Bosphorus. But what fascinated me was the abundance of fishermen that fished off the Bosphorus Bridge. You cannot see space for another individual. My 11 year wanted to know if it was legal to fish off a bridge like that!!Definitely worth the tour.

Spectacular view!. The Ottoman Empire's first palace was Topkapi Palace. It is located in the old city and can be visited as a museum. Ottomans used Topkapi from 1460 to 1850 almost for 400 years. Sultan Abdulmecid (reign 1839-1861) decided to move the palace along the Bosphorus. Because he was in love with the view of the Bosphorus Strait. He built Dolmabahce Palace at 1850s and the royal family moved to there. Then all the important people in the city including authors, poets, high ranking officers, mayors, wealthy people moved to Bosphorus as well. The old city became old fashioned and Bosphorus shores became trendy. We can still observe those houses made by these people during the second half of the 19th century. Some of them are also the most expensive houses in the world.There are two ways to make a Bosphorus trip. There is a government ferry everyday leaving 10:35 from Eminonu Area. (Old city pier right next to Galata Bridge) or you can go to Eminonu sea side and catch one of the private boats leaving almost every hour during the high season. (from april to november)

Wonders on the Bosphorus Strait. We took a boat ride on the Bosphorus Strait.. It was well worth it to be able to see two continents at the same time....the boat commentator was very good ... Explaining all the interesting sights along the way. When in Istanbul make sure to take this excursion.

Bosphorus Strait. Your opportunity for great photos on a good-weather day is one of the boat cruises. Istanbul is very crowded around the waterways. Watch your pockets and protect yourself especially in the high traffic areas.

Lovely view. Take the cruise from the Eminonu pier. Buy tickets only from the shops, not touts. 12 TL for a 2 hours cruise. Recommend bring your own book for info e route. Try a cuppa Cay for 1 TL while aboard

Beautiful. Bosphorus strait is what divides Asia and Europe so it is only natural to have a curiosity to see this place and that is why we picked up a ferry ride on it as our very first experience in Istanbul. The ferry ride is perhaps the best way to enjoy Bosphorus. Tickets should be purchased with a bit of caution so as not ending up being cheated on some private cruises taking you only half way for an enormous amount. The sites are pretty amazing and the restaurants will keep you well fed too.

Gorgeous body of water. We found a boat tour for approximately $10 US for an 1 1/2 hour trip up the Bosphurus and back to Eminonu. Find the boats near the Galata Bridge. Its a beautiful ride to see the sites along the water and see where people live, work, eat....Very peaceful way to see another part of Istanbul.

An awesome introduction to Istanbul. On this two hour boat ride, one could witness the old city, some places of historical significance, Asia on one side and Europe on the other....and the suburban neighborhoods. It is a great start to getting to know Istanbul.

Take a ride. I like to get on a ferry and go down this waterway as far as I can go and turn around again . You can go to an area where there are housed numerous seafood restaurants about 20 minutes ferry ride downstream. Even if you just take a ride to the other side and turn around again , its a good thing to experience the river . You can appreciate the massive size of the city by doing so.
Lovely.... Cant decide where to eat.. Got a place where pick up facility is available. Cant remember the name of the restaurant but a superb place.

Gorgeous Views of the City. The Bosphorus Straight is a beautiful part of Istanbul worth seeing. My husband and I chose the official 2 hour-long cruise (round trip). Lots of people around Istanbul will try to sell you cruises on their own personal boats. We read that it wasn't advisable, so we stuck to the ferry whose tickets are sold at Eminonu, near the Galata bridge. The time at which the ticket booth opens is usually written on the booth itself; try to get there early because there will be a line. I personally don't recommend renting the tablet guide; it was only for 10 TL but the sound was so low, and the boat was obviously loud (especially if you are sitting on the top deck (which fills up fast; another reason to get there early). Another alternative is spending your time reading the information off the tablet and missing out on the scenery around you. If you are interested in the history behind what you are seeing, then your only choice is the tablet. Try to get a listen before leaving the renting booth, so that you can exchange the tablet/earphones if the sound quality is poor. Also note that there is a cafe on the ferry and the prices are great there. All in all, an enjoyable way to see Istanbul.

Natural beauty. You can view the strait from the woods around it (both from the Asian side and from the European side), especially the Emirgan woods, Mihrabat woods, Fatih woods and Çubuklu woods. You can have a walk by the strait especially from ortaköy to aşiyan or from beylerbeyi to kuleli.

Bosphorus Cruise. Take the ferry from Eminonu (European side) for the Bosphorus Cruise. A return 25 lira. One way 15 all the way to Anadolu Kavagi (Asian side). Busy waterway, lovely views. No regret.

Took the sunset cruise discount tickets by Blue Mosque. I believe we paid $35 for a non meal sunset cruise a piece . We rode along both sides of the Bospurus Europe and Asia had a running commentery of what we were seeing. So we saw one side at dusk the other as the lights came on . Most buildings are lite at night making this a fun trip . Get a deal on tickets lots of boats do this .
Happening. This place is so lively with a lot of ships and boats crossing the straits. The banks are lined by vibrant shops and many restaurants with fish dishes as specialty
Visit to Istanbul. gives a panoramic coverage of the both sides of the city - European and Asian. Enjoyed the cruise on the Bosphorus and recommend a trip on the same.

Get on the water.. Nothing more beautiful than seeing the Asian and European side of this mysterious, exciting city. Take a city cruiser...you don't have to do a private yacht to get all of the good stuff/sights.

"Boastful Bosphorus". Rightly called the lifeline of Istanbul, of which the city can boast. A must do tour to soak in the real energy of the city.There's no dearth of operators who can take you on varied cruises and tours of the kind and for the duration you desire.Just make sure you have the map of the route the boat is taking and seat yourself on the right side of the boat to get a closer glimpse of the sites that pass by.

Relaxing. Very interesting long cruise. And the fare is fairly cheap too. On board the boat itself, you they have a small 'cafe'. Best view is always on top of the boat, in the open air. To add more interesting experience, you can even but some bread from the shop below and throw bits to the ever hungry seagulls outside.

Interesting. Took a boat trip, hawkers are everywhere selling tickets. It is inexpensive but we waited until we were at the wharf before we bought the ticket to be sure it was real. It is a great way to see what is along the waterfront, something you would not see otherwise. It is certainly a big place and very busy, shipping wise.

Wonderful day on ferries in the Bosphorus Strait. We took 3 different ferries to get around the city of Istanbul and this was a nice experience on a very sunny day in January. A perfect way to see the city from Bosphorus and to get a feeling of how the locals get around. It reminded me of some of the ferries around Manhattan.

Great tour and very ceap. I took a one and half hour non stop tour. The fare was only 10TL. One leg of the journey was along the Asian side and the other leg was along the European side. There were regular announcements highlighting the places that the ferry passed. I strongly recommend this sightseeing.
Worth the trip!!!. A cruise not to be missed. Took a while to complete to tour. But Magnificent and picturesque views are worth the time. The last island stop over is excellent for a tranquil time.
incredible. one of the best time in istambul, people, clothes, sound... magical moment! See you on our next visit
Great view at night!. Something about this strait is so nice .. still haven't figured that out!! couldn't keep my camera away!

Go local. Our tour offered the 2hr Bosphorus cruise with commentary for US$42 but at the dock the locals were advertising the same trip, without commentary, for 10 Turkish lira, the equivalent of US$6, a no-brainer. The scenery was stunning. I especially enjoyed the water view of the Dolmabahce Palace.

A must in Istanbul. There are many Touristic tours but we took thepublic boat to Anadolu Kavagi. We climbed up to the Hill to see The BlackSea. And had this best fish in one of the restaurants near the harbour.

Very nice. If you watched the movie "Taken 2" once than you are crossing the Bosphorus you will remember the movie, BEAUTIFUL you will able to see the Istambul Skyline any time you cross the Bosphorus its stunning BUT with the sunset it will take your breath away!

Beautiful Beautiful. I love everything about it, the view, the water, the boat, the history, the location.. its so pretty.. between two continent. its so different, i like how they keep this historical place clean and still feel the ancient ambience.

Where two continents meet... It's the Bosphorus; it connects and separates two continents. Small neighborhoods scattered all around the Bosphorus all have their own identity and culture. Definitely take a boat cruise on a nice sunny day. The municipality have cruises that leave from Eminonu at affordable prices or you can pick up a private cruise from neighborhoods such as Ortakoy. Make sure to have a guide though because even for a local; there is so much history to learn..

Boat lagged. What an extremely busy waterway with boats of all sizes cruising up and down between the Marmaris and Black Seas, back and forth between Europe Istanbul and Asia Istanbul.90 minute boat cruise to 2nd bridge and back going up European side before coming back down Asian side takes in some stunning skylines, mainly on the European side

Breathtaking!!. Been to Turkey without visiting Bosphorus Strait? Probably you left without knowing which part of continent you were. This is a must visit, Bosphorus Strait divides Istanbul to Europe side and Asian side...

Wonderful Trip - Be Careful of what you buy. I took a boat trip on the Bosphorus Strait and it was amazing. Be sure to pick a nice day and the day I went was just perfect. If you get the chance do some reading on the sites before you go as the boat I took gave no information on anything. It is well worth the effort and I think an absolute must for any visitor to the city.Okay, these are tips you won't read about in any tourist brochure but I wish someone gave me them before I bought my ticket.You can buy a ticket for the trip from street vendors who peddle tickets near the public ferry terminals. They will tell you that you can take a 2 hour or 4 hour trip. The brochure they give you clearly has 10 Euro for 2 hours and 20 Euro for 4 hours, that's until you buy the ticket and suddenly the 10 Euro is 15 and the 20 Euro is 25.Once you buy your ticket you will be huddled onto a shuttle bus and taken to the boat, you are told the boat leaves every 30 minutes, maybe it does, but it is more like the boat leaves when enough tickets are sold as more and more people are piled on until the owner/captain decide they have enough - we waited nearly 1.5 hours.There is no commentary on the boat, so take a map or do your reading ahead of time or you'll sail past historic sites and have no idea what they are.When the boat returns, don't expect a ride back in the shuttle bus, you have to make your own way back thankfully it is not to far, about a 15 minute walk.If you take the above into consideration, you will have a fabulous time, it's a pity that such a wonderful event can be masked by unscrupulous vendors who are only interested in making a dollar from tourists. The tourist brochure I got listed Gokkusagi Tourism and Mert & M not sure if these are the owners but just be careful of this operator.Definitely go on this cruise - it was wonderful.

Bosphorus cruise. It is well worth doing a cruise along the Bosphorus. Down by the Galata bridge there are plenty of people selling cruises. My only regret is that there is so much history in the area that having a cruise with a guide would be so much better than taking a cruise where you get a great view but have to work everything out for yourself. My recommendation is ask if there is a guide before signing up for a cruise. You will enjoy it far more.

Sweet and lovely. This is an amazing tour where you can be both in Europe and Asia, the ferry takes you to the most interesting places in Istanbul, you can have a look at famous Turkish palaces where ild meets the new and it all leaves you a great impression. You can also drink turkish tea which is brought to you. You dont even have to get up and order.

Relaxing boat ride for a different view of the city. Great way to get your bearings in Istanbul. We took a charter cruise, and really enjoyed the day out of the city. It's just a nice way to see the sites from a different angle.

2 hour cruise. be careful! As you approach the quay guys will approach you with plastic cards advertising the 2 hour cruise. The further from the quay the more expensive. Our invitations started at TL 40 per person. If you wait and pay as you board the boat its TL 10!We went in January, and although weather was excellent its breezy coming back into the wind so take a coat!

great experience. Took the 1/2 day cruise with lunch and a stop at the black sea - very interesting experience. We got to see a lot of the historical buildings from the boat. Buffet lunch was good too.
admired from many points. From many viewpoints in the city we admired views of the Strait, including a view of ships coming and going from our hotel breakfast area.

Take a River Tour!!!!. Our tour group had the opportunity for a river tour on a bright sunny day after having a delightful lunch on the Eastern side. From there we boarded a boat and sailed up stream for a few miles and then down to the main dock area in Istanbul. Beautiful ride!!!

Another view. Cosy take a boat ride and see Istanbul from another view. You get to see the Bosphorous Bridge, Dolmabahce Palace etc. There was also a photographer on the boat that could take nice pictures. Recommend to go in the afternoon when it is bright outside and come back when it's dark.
has to be done. If you come to istanbul, you have to take a cruise around the bosphorus. This is simply the best place to view the entire city.

This is where History meets geography. Can't think of many places which are historically more significant than the Bosphorus strait. This body of water saw the Romans, the Greeks, Ottomans, Arabs, Muslims, Christians, Germans, The Axis forces, the Allied forces, Bismark, The sultans and monarchs and princes of Europe and the east. All came here or passed through these waters. Other than its significance, the charm and ambiance of the straits are everywhere. The Golden Horn, the Galata Tower, the Sulaymani Mosque, the Blue Mosque, Topcapi palace, and much more over looking the bosphorus strait. Could not help while taking lunch in Bebeck that many Russian ships passed through these waters, during the cold war, under the eyes of many intelligence services watching every wave going through.. Amazing and beautiful place. A must see and enjoy a good day under the sun. I recommend taking a ship up and down the straights...

The strait separating Europe from Asia. If you have the opportunity and with good weather, take the cruise along the strait where you can see many magnificent structures and houses along the strait. The cruise will likely go pass the 2 bridges crossing the strait and you can enjoy the fresh air and the water is clear and clean

Must do. This should not be missed. So much to see. I would recommend doing this with a guide as the audio on the boat itself was not decipherable. In fact I'm not even sure what languages it was in as it was that difficult to hear. Luckily we were part of a tour so got all the information as we went from him. - I did it with True Blue Tours, during the Best of Istanbul full day tour.

Boat trip on the Bosphorus!. They have boats that do a historical tour that last about an hour or so which is a great way to spend a morning. You pass by some of the major historical palaces, mosques and government buildings as you sail across the Bosphorus and back. Tea and snacks served on the boat, it's cheap and mostly filled with locals which is brilliant.

Fantastic!. Is one of the most beautiful place I saw! It's a must for at least once in the life time. Not even the best picture or word in the world could explain the sensation this place will let you!
Bosphorus river. Lots of seafood restaurants under the Galato bridge. Buy a fresh fish roll for 5 TL from a local fisherboat. Go on a 2hr trip down the river for 10 TL
Great. We took Bosphorus cruise and we also stopped on the Asian side. It gives you really nice view of the city and it's interesting to see what each side has to offer.

A sight beyond belief!. Have fun on all the ferries and enjoy all the rides up and down the bosphorous. Make sure you stop in Kadikoy and walk across the street to the outdoor market place. Great place for souvenirs!

Take a ride down the Bosphorus. Having read about the strait dividing istanbul into Asian and European sides, I knew I had to try the boat trip. Luckily, I had a local guide who made my trip easier. The river is clean as well as the ship. Buy their local delicacy Kumpir, a huge baked potato that you can buy near the dock. You can customize the toppings to your taste and you can eat this while on the cruise. Another must-do when you're in Istanbul.

Not exciting, stop on Asian side to shop. We took a short tour with Turyol up the Bosphorus to the second bridge. It was one and a half hours. The first tour was at 11.00am, and the cost was 12 Euros. The Turyol tour is on the western side of the Galata bridge. There is another company on the eastern side, with earlier departures and 2 hour tours for the same price, but the boats seemed bigger and older. The bigger boats apparently do not go as close to shore as the smaller ones.A few things to note. There are lots of touts about. We almost went with one, who offered us a tour for 30 Euros (we thought for 2 of us at first, but it was per person). When challenged, he immediately lowered his price to 15 Euros. Just ignore the touts, and walk on and you will see the tour booths.The info booths are not very helpful. The English spoken is a bit poor, and they will just direct you to the boat companies. We could not find public toilets on the pier, and there were decent toilets on the boat we took.When you get on the boat, a man comes around with trays of tea and food. This is not complimentary, although he does not ask for money. He will come around later to ask for money when collecting the tea cups! It's not much - just 1 Euro for a small cup of tea, but not worth the money unless you really want a hot drink. Bring your own flask!The boat ride gives you great views of Istanbul. We went on a rather dreary day, so the photos were not great. But you might need short tele lens if you want to photographs the unless number of mosques and palaces you will see! We grew weary after a while, and the boat ride got a bit monotonous the further up the Bosphorus we went. It was a cold day as well, so sitting on the open upper deck gave good views, but was very cold.Our boat stopped at Uskadar on the way out and on the way back. Seems like it also serves as a ferry to this stop on the Asian side. We got off the boat on the way back at Uskadar, and later took a public ferry - the ferry costs 4 Euros. It's very worthwhile to stop at Uskadar if you want to buy local foodstuffs like teas, dried fruits, helva, olives, honey. Much cheaper in Uskadar than in the main tourist areas in Sultanahmet, Sirkeci, etc. Even the restaurants are cheaper, although still quite touristy. The local "wet" market - selling fish, meats etc - is just a short 5 minute walk from the ferry, and you can get decent foreign exchange at a change office there.It's worthwhile to do the boat tour ... but stop on the Asian side to explore.
One of the Best Places. Yes it is really my Favorite place when i visit Istanbul. I never get enough from Bosphorus and all other attraction spread it on its both sides

Great just to be there. Istanbul has an airport I hate, and a waterway I love. From the Dardanelles to the Black Sea it is exotic, and culturally vital. I remember the multitude of ferries from when I was a child, and most of them still seem to be in use! The best area is Bebe (baby?), with bars, cafés and restaurants by the water. Arriving by ship as I did this time was one of the best introductions to the orient anyone could have and the cruise down past the Princess Islands just lovely.

Best way to check out the city layout . To say I was turned around during my visit is an understatement. Istanbul is such a huge city and trying to get your bearings can be a little hard. A cruise down the Bosphorus allows you to really see the city from a different perspective and see the sites while relaxing on a boat. I went with a charter that cost 8 euros for a two hour Bosphorus cruise with no stops. Not a bad deal in my book. Definitely one of the best ways to see the city

Th best in Istanbul!. The main attraction in Istanbul. A cruise on Bosphorous is a must. Its thrilling to cruise between the two continents, Asia and Europe. There is a wide range of choice for boats / cruises depending on facilities and costs. All are really enjoyable.

Very Nice. Try to sit by the river! on Sunny morning! Watch the Strait Its beautiful! Watch the Golden Horn! and if time permits take tour of bosphorus but honestly I enjoyed the morning sitting by river on the bench

A busy, wonder of a waterway. The bosphorus is one of the busiest waterways of its type in the world. As Russia's only outlet from the Black Sea it is used constantly by bigger vessels and as a means of livelihood for local fisherman it is also the waterway for small craft. We did not have the time for a long cruise on the Bosphorus but did not want to miss the experience. The weather was cold and very wet so we waited until the very best day we could possibly find in our schedule for the outing. We opted for a two hour cruise and that turned out to be just right for us. We went on a private craft and it was very easy to find a cruise, just go to the dock and you will be approached. We found that the rates were very reasonable. I think we paid about 20TL a piece and we were taken by van and delivered right to the craft. Because of the weather we did not go on top so our pictures aren't the greatest but still fun. Make sure your craft has a snack bar and restroom. Both can come in handy. Our boat had tea being served as part of the price and was brought around several different times. If you have your heart on setting foot in Asia this is not the way for you. The vessel will not stop. Sit on the left of the craft as you face the front and you will have a great view of Europe on the hour down and then Asia on the hour back. We found this to be a great option for those people like us that want to experience the Bosphorus and because of weather or time need to limit there visit. You can also get a fresh fish lunch afterward if you desire. There are stalls and vendors everywhere. Again, the weather drove us away to an inside luncheon.

Amazing. It was on my bucket List before and I must say that the view on the strait is amazing. Its so busy and you get the feeling to see the world at once. Enjoy and take that ferry tour to the other side of the Bosphorus.

Great way to see the city. Ferries are well run and frequent, costing 4TL each way across the Bosphorus. There is an excellent service of hot and cold food and drink on board. You can choose to keep warm inside or go outside and enjoy the close presence of seabirds and photo opportunities of the historical sites of Istanbul. The local ferries are there to serve local people, but there are also tourist excursions.

Nothing extraordinary. We took a 2 hour Bosphorus cruise during our recent trip. I had intended taking the public ferry which only costs about 12 TL. However it was a very cold and windy day and taking the public ferry would have been a whole day affair - it takes 2+ hours to get to the Asian side, you will spend about 1.5-2 hours waiting for thee return ferry and then another 2 hour ride back. We were initially quoted 15 Euros per person for the private 2 hour tour. My husband tried bargaining and to our surprise we got it for 10 Euros. Later we saw another person bargain it down to 7 Euro. There was an English speaking guide in the boat who gave our information about the monuments along the shore. The first 30 minutes were a lot of fun, but after that it got a bit repetitive for me. And in fact we gave up our vantage point on the deck and came down into the shelter. If you take the public ferry, you can go up to the castle on the Asian side and grab a meal - but the downside is it takes a whole day. Anyway, don't feel like you are missing out on a whole lot if you take the 2 hour ride. If you are pressed for time on a short trip, this is a perfectly decent option.

Avoid any offers on street. Just go to the bay near Galata bridge, and find an official kiosk to buy a ferry ticket and cruise even more of the Bosphorus for around 4 euro. Usually they will offer you the prices between 20 and 60 euro, dependable on your negotiation efficiency.
normal. It's just normal. My expectations was much more then that what I saw. I was imaging the seems of turkish moovies, spirit of old times, but - no.

Soak in the view. What an experience, We took the Ferry to Buyukada/ Princess islands and had a great time there. The Strait is amazing and gives you a feeling that istanbul is a never ending city. Had so much fun here. Love it
Feeling Like to be in Fairy Tales. One ord describes there: WONDERFUL... Turkish culture and hospitality let you fly with it's amazing historical dynamics. Please take a visit through that line...

A Tale of Two Continents. Whether one is on the European side or the Asian side the Bosphorus, the waterfront restaurants, cafes, or benches are very inviting. One can simply spend hours just watching the tankers, passenger boats, water taxis, tour boats, yatchs sailing by. The Asian side is more romantic with fish restaurants and centuries old houses. One can take side trips to see a small summer pallace or formal gardens. The European side is more modern with upscale restaurants. There are two bridges connecting the two continents, the third one is still in construction. In the evening, the lights on the bridges change colors every ten minutes. Music can be heard from the clubs or concert venues.The water traffic for the comercial ships is one way in the morning and it reverses in the afternoon to control the traffic going to Black Sea or to the Mediterrenean Sea.

Get a guide. I would highly recommend this cruise but make sure your cruise has a guide who can tell you something about what you are seeing. During our first trip to Istanbul a few years ago we did this cruise via a tour and the guide was excellent. This time we went with one of the touts on the seafront, it was cheap (only 20 Turkish Lira) but there was no guide and we had to wait on the boat at the dock until they had collected enough people to start the trip. This meant we waited for almost an hour in freezing weather before even getting started. So, do the cruise, but pick your host carefully.

Different. It's an amazing experience to go there and take a cruise between both continents.The ride costs about 15 TL (Turkish Lira) and lasts about an hour.If you are planning on going there, be sure to stop at one of the small boats to get a fish sandwich.I am not a fish eater, but i ate my brains out over there:))You can take really nice pictures at the bosphorus strait!

Best!. When in instabul one of the best things to do is to take a cruise on the Bosporus!!Chose a nice day and enjoy it!!Both sides of the shore are great, interesting and different!!It's best to chose an official company, one of the best is on the left side of galata bridge when walking towards the old city!The prices are about 10-15 Turkish Lt, depending on the duration!

Stunning, but careful. Stunning cruises available to see the Bospohrous, but do NOT use the local people who attack/ poach you with their boards and pestering ways. Use the boat service that only runs in weekends (plan accordingly) because it is the same liner that runs for 9TL instead of 90euro!!!! Save your money for gifts rather :

A wonderful experience not to be missed. The sights along the Bosphorous are something that should not be missed on a visit to Istanbul. You could take a ferry as explained by a lot of people. Or, for a really special experience, take a private boat cruise. You can see a wide range of sights showing various periods from the history of this city.
Stunning. Lovely to do one of the many tour cruises on offer. We didn't realise there was so much property and areas/suburbs so far down the strait. Interspersed with historic buildings too.
Nice trip along the Bosphorus. It was a beautiful but cold day, the trip was 2 hrs long so if you might think you can get sea sick take something, I am used to boats so I had no problem whatsoever.

Wonderful view but choose carefully the boat. The trip is wonderful, with a exclusive view of the strait, its islands and the palaces from the sea.If possible take a full day trip, or at least stop for lunch and get back later on the boat, so as to see the sunset on the sea.ATTENTION: many companies sell the same trip, but some boats are really awful, so ask to see the boat in person and the trip on the map before starting the trip
A must see ....... Where East meets West and watching all the massive supertankers gliding by is an unforgettable sight by both day and night.
Great sea trip. Took a boat trip up the Bospherus and brilliant value for 90mins@ just 12 lira each ! Great way to see some of the iconic buildings

Must take a ferry ride over. Definitely a must to take the ferry over. Have a hot cup of coffee or apple tea while on the ferry and take lots of photos of Sultanhamet and the old palace, and enjoy the sea breeze. A must do.

good cruise. We have done a day trip to include Bosphorus cruise with Dolmabache palace and spice bazar. we also cruised Bosphorus cruise at night on a dinner cruise with nice entertainment. Both the tours were booked through TURISTA travel agency in Sultanahmet. Mr. Dawood Dogan did a great job. I recommend both this trips if you are staying for 2-3 days.

Wonderful views of the historic city of Isanbul !. On our first full day in Istanbul we walked down to the Golden Horn waterfront and took a very inexpensive ($6/person !) trip along the Bosphorus Straits to the Bosphorus Bridge and back. This allowed us to get an overview of the historic city that straddles two continents. Its beautiful skyline dominated by the many massive mosques and palaces along the Bosphorus is most impressive. This stretch of waterway is also a very busy international marine shipping lane and also traveled by many ferries travelling between both sides of the Staits.

nighttime cruise. the cruise was a lovely way to see istanbul by night , staff were very helpful.Food was good but not wonderful, entertainment was also good .Oddly the itinerary stated no single men on the dancefloor during the disco !

Great for a laid-back day!. If you are planning a more laid-back day, buy a ticket to cruise the Bosphorous. It was a relaxing boat ride after our previous day in the markets. You do not need to buy a ticket from men on the street. Go to the ticket office and buy a proper ride! Arrive early in the morning to buy your tickets if you want to avoid the line and ensure you get a seat. The line gets very long closer to the start of the ride. We loved viewing the beautiful houses and fisherman. Our boat ride stopped in little town. It was very touristy but we had a simple fish sandwich and then walked around for a bit. If going anytime but the summer, remember it might feel much colder on the boat than on land because you are on the water.

full day cruise (Şehir Hatları). took the cruise on a sunny Christmas Day. Full day cruise, with three hours stop just before the Black Sea.Nice; interesting scenery (I love bridges, to that was great). As you leave Istanbul, the view becomes a little less glamorous, but there are spectacular old castles and buildings to be seen.
Nice. It would have been a much better experience if we went there during the summer, but overall it is a must do in Istanbul.
Expensive real estate. Beautiful scenery as one travels between Europe on one side and Asia on the other toward or from the Black sea.
Gorgeous Bosphorus. The view of the Strait is amazing, ever-busy, ever-lively. Surely there is no other strait like the Bosphorus, dividing Europe and Asia the way it does
Boat trip. We traveled up and down the Bosphorus straits. There are so many sights to see, The most wonderful was being between Asia and Europe.

Wonderful cruise on a ferry. The general ferries are very crowded. If you book a half day tour that includes a Bosphorus water tour, that is usually just for the people on the tour, so much more spacious. Highly recommend booking a tour just so for the non-crowded public ferries.

A must in Istanbul. The great Bosphorus goes between the two continents and provides many amazing landmarks. Head to the local ferry docks (Sehir Hatlari) in eminonu and get a tour for 12TL at 2:30 PM, by taking a tour through the Bosphorus you will see the magnificent Dolmabahce Palace, Ciragan Palace, the Bosphorus bridge, Beylerbiye Palace, Rumelli fortress and the 2nd bosphorus bridge. Overall, taking a tour through the Bosphorus is a must if you are in Istanbul
Sailing between 2 continents. A boat trip on the Bosphorus is a great opportunity to see both sides of the 2 continents. There are various options for longer or shorter trips.

Boat or Bridge. A visit to the Asia side either by boat or across one of the two bridges over the Bosphorus is a must do in Istanbul. Ferry rides are cheap, take a tour boat for more information and fasinating history. This is a VERY busy harbour, a great place to see all the different modes of transport, from cruise ships, freighters, fishing boats, ferries, water taxis - similar to busy Hong Kong harbour with a more exotic back drop. Going over the bridge is interesting as well, but you miss the up close and personal feel of the boat ride.

Great view!. You can just sit and watch all the ships pass by - it's so peaceful. We took the strait tour after we visiting all the historic places, and it was nice to see/recognize them from the ship.

River trip between two continents. Boats go regularly from Kabatas Pier - at the end of the tram line T2. The commentary is very helpful - enough information to make the trip interesting but not too much that you can't just sit and watch the scenery. Drinks are available as are snacks and you can sit inside or out. Whether you are interested in history, boats or local fishermen you will be certain to get a good overview of Istanbul.

Visit the border between two continents. So many stories involve travelling to Istanbul to visit the city that spans two continents. We took a boat cruise along the Bosporus to enjoy seeing Europe and Asia at the same time. Granted, Istanbul culture is on both sides of the straits; however, it is just very unique to see two continents like this.So much history has taken place here in the Bosporus from the early territorial expansion of people from Europe into the Middle East and vice versa to the Moorish Expansion, the Crusades, the expansion of the Byzantine Empire, the expansion of the Ottoman Empire, the Crimean War, both World Wars, and the Cold War. The Bosphorus Straits remain a key waterway today connecting the Black Sea to the Mediterranean Sea. This is a must do while in Istanbul. Just find your way to the docks at the end of Galata Bridge on the Sultanahmet side and catch any of the ferry trips along the Bosphorus. Prices for public ferries are as low as 5-8 Euros while dedicated Bosphorus cruise lines can run upwards of 25 Euros per person.
Sophisticated. It's the most sophisticated place in town. Rent a car and drive from the bosphoros till Kilyos. But be careful: Turkish drivers are simply mad!

Very nice experience when visiting the Asian side. We spent some time on the Asian side bank and it provides some nice views. The river is huge! Really wide. We did not take the cruise but it was enjoyable to spend the afternoon on a nice sunny day.

Nice boat ride. We toured the Bosphorus Strait on a boat booked by our tour. It was cold and rained a bit. It did not detract from the history of our surroundings. The food and drinks were not included in the tour.
Avvery beautiful streach of water. Were Asia meets Europe. Cross over to a new Continent by Ferry or Bridge. There is plenty to do on the water front.
pretty area. Really loved our time in Instanbul. Great scenery all around. There's even wildlife that is great to view.
beautiful scenery. Beautiful scenery, nice to see the boats coming in and out it's different from other cities in the world totally unique..
A million stories lie across both banks. Nature at its best, wild life all around, ducks, sea gulls, Ravens, views of Istanbul iconic buildings, quiet, safe, and cheap in gov. Boats. Love it...

So cold but so nice!. The time when we had Bosphorus cruise from Eminonu was very cold season, but all the view through the strait was so wonderful.
The cruise time is about one and half hour. We enjoyed tea, SIMIT and yoghurt from Kanlıca during the time. So nice.

A lot of fisherman.... Bosphorus strait is a must to see place when you visit Istanbul. You can use the T1 tram to Eminonu or by foot. We walked all the way to Bosphorus strait (from Beyazit) an it took us half an hour. In the lower floor of the bridge you can find many fish (balik) restaurants. We preferred the local "fast food boats" that serve this fish sandwich called "ekmek Balik". Many people afre fishing on the top level. Lovely at night!

Take the ferry. It was a little tough to find the public ferry (it is the pier closet to the bridge on the Bosphorus side of the Golden Horn.)Nice boat ride up and back (Anadolu Kavağı). Good view from the Castle at the top of the hill (steep climb). Had a nice lunch to the "left" (facing the dock) Kavak Kebap was on the sign.

Sailing on the Bosphorus. Rather than taking one of the scheduled tours down the Bosphorus we jumped on to one of the ferries down at the Galata Bridge and got off at Uskador- the next ferry stop. It cost us 5 lira and at Uskador we walked along the promenade then settled down along with all the locals to watch the sun set and drink chai on the carpeted steps. The Maidens Tower is close and you get fabulous photos from this vantage point as well as a sunset view of all the minarets.

The Continental Divide!. A cruise on the Bosphorous is a must-do for visitors to Istanbul. Amazing views of the city along a beautiful stretch of water makes the Bosphorous a unique experience. Strongly recommended.

Seafood Heaven, Snacks and Boat Rides. By the large bridge, there are a ton of snack vendors selling chestnuts and sesame pretzels. The actual pier has lots of fishermen (even at night) and many seafood restaurants to choose from. I took a evening cruise that had Turkish music, traditional dancing and even a belly dancer for entertainment. I'd make sure this gets on your list of things to do when you visit!

Worth doing. We had a private guide and took a public pedestrian ferry up the Bosphorus Straight. The guide provided a lot of information and history to make the trip far more interesting than it would had we gone on our own.

Amazing sights. Studied a bit of post NT history back in my younger days regarding Constantine's rule and the onset of early Christianity. So I was very eager to visit the city from a historical perspective.I went on a cruise on the Bosphorus straight and the sights were amazing. I had a slow mid-day lunch at one of the restaurants dotted along the bridge with my wife, which was ok. It was a very relaxing evening ride on beautiful waters whilst the sun was setting. Along both shorelines are shops, residential buildings and holiday homes peppered here and there with palaces of old. What is evident are the number of towering mosque silhouettes along the skyline. They come alive as the sun sets, first with their beacon lights and then the evening prayer call.In all a great experience.

Tour guide missing!. We didn't do all the homework necessary for this attraction. We walked down to the waterfront and got overwhelmed with men selling boat tickets for an afternoon boat trip on the Bosphorus. We had our mackerel sandwich and then decided to do the boat trip after. Prices are all about the same, (pay attention though) and got boat they bussed us to, it was further down from the main area. The ride was a couple hours. We quickly discovered, no tour guide telling you history! we had our book but would recommend definitely check for a tour boat with a guide speaking English and it would be much more interesting. I would recommend the boat tour WITH A GUIDE.

Make sure to see it from the water... It is quite an experience from short, the shops, the people, etc.We had a fish and onion sandwich by the water. Great experience.From the water, the sights are something to see, the water so blue.Very enjoyable.

Cruise on the Bosphorus. Get tickets for a cruise on the Bosphorus toward the end if your visit. It is a quiet way to spend a could of hours seeing the edges if the city amidst the harbor traffic.....and relax as the city passes by .

Take the Sehir Hatlari ferryboats. Don't waste your money on the boat tours and cruises offered by companies like Turyol. Take what the locals use to commute between continents and use the Sehir Hatlari ferryboats, especially since these are the most frequent, quickest, and cheapest way to cross the Bosphorus. These ferryboats leave every 15-20 mins from 6:30 am - 10:30 pm and takes 20 mins if you're going from Eminonu on the European side to Uskudar on the Asian side; from Eminonu to Kadikoy (further south on the Asian side), runs every 15-20 mins from 7 am - 8:30 pm and takes 30 mins. Ports north of Eminonu on the European side are Karakoy, Kabatas, and Besiktas, while the Asian ports to the east are Uskudar, Harem, Haydarpasa, and Kadikoy. Simply buy an IstanbulKart from any yellow machine at every tram or metro station for 10 Liras (6 liras for the card and 4 liras in ride credit). Each ride is 2.15 liras, as opposed to 4 liras w/o the card. This is basically a debit card that you can add money to at the same machines so that you merely swipe to enter and ride any bus, tram, metro, or ferry within the city. While crossing the strait, enjoy all the major sites as you see the Hagia Sophia and Blue Mosque tower over the skyline. A trip on the Bosphorus while in Istanbul is a must because this is the only city in the world that straddles two continents, and riding across the strait allows you to experience both the eastern and western facets of this unique town.

Teriffic View of Istanbul Europe and Istanbul Asia. We were on a Celebrity Cruise that traveled along the Straits. The views were great.The Bridge we went under was greatThe Mosques in Old Town Istanbul are dominate in the skyline

A nice walk. Didn't take any of the boat tours because we only had 1 day in Istanbul before catching a tour, but it was definitely worth it to walk across the bridge and back. Nice views of the Bosphorus Strait and Istanbul. You walk by people fishing off the bridge, as well as restaurants and shops.

Definitely a must on your itinerary!. We travelled in December but were lucky enough to have a sunny warm(ish) day for this cruise so we could sit outside. The homes on the European and Asian side are stunning. The fort is a site to behold.

Nice boat tour. You can find a whole day tour (about 5 hours) or a short tour (about 1:30 hours), I got the short tour, and found it was enough, but it will depend of how much time do you have for this attraction.The boat leaves on time and goes through the main highlights in the Bosphorus, you will have a different view of the city, highly recommended.

Very pretty at night.... I recommend taking a ferry at night from the north of the Strait down to view the lights and the Mosques. If you have metro card, it will work for the ferry. Still very cheap( around 2 TL )

Good way to see Istanbul. The tour is pleasant, I think about 30 hours at the most and doesn't include meals. I opted for a tour company that included some sights by bus, and the telefrik experience on the Asian side...

East Meets West. The funnel off our cruise ship precariously scrapes a path just metres beneath the spans of multi highway bridges. Not ancient archways but gleaming modern architecture that soars above the Bosphorus Straights. We have Mustapha Kernal Atatürk the man who ended the Ottoman empire and reformed the country into modern day Turkey, to thank for the eclectic mix of old and new along this ancient waterway. Mosques and minarets rub shoulders with steel and glass. Palaces on both shores are spanned by designer bridges both history and modernity beneath your gaze. Its unusual and exiting but then it always has been because Istanbul is situated on the ancient spice route and was the gateway between Europe and Asia. The Bosphorous straight is not a long journey but whether you choose a cruise ship or local boat tour it is a pleasant relaxing trip.
Worth doing. On a nice day great view of the shore line of a Istanbul Did this with a local tour company Try to do on a weekday less crowded

Planning Full Bosphorus Tour? Think again. After reading numerous reviews suggesting full Bosphorus Tour, I took Sehir Hatlari Full Tour. It takes 6 hrs altogether. 90 mins to the last stop + 3 hrs stopover + 90 mins return, that is a WHOLE day. If you are staying in Istanbul for many days, then this could be the activity for one of the days. But if you are staying for few days take the 2 hr tour. Any how most of the city attractions are closer to start point (Eminonu).

Magnificent istanbul. I took a cruise for 3 hours and I must say I was not bored for a single minute as u see amazing views of istanbul from the outside, no doubt Istanbul is a city to be explored on foot but views from bosphorus strait gives u an idea of magnanimity of the city.A must do .

Wonderful!. One of the most interesting and wonderful urban experiences around. The strait is always busy with traffic and islands and bridges crisscross the water. It is a wonderful place to walk and rest and watch life go by. This body of water also is the boundary between Europe and Asia and as such has cultural implications that speak to the heart of the split within Turkey.

Excellent boat trip. This is not the best time of the year to visit Istanbul, however, it is so beautiful that you can appreciate it even on a smoggy day. It is an amazing trip to see the city from the water. Magnificent houses and monuments await you in this straight of water that divides two continents. Awesome!!!
Bosphorus. Unique and magical.A strong sense of history and a very intense feeling of the importance of the Bosphorous strait.
Nice cruise. Cruising along the strait with explanation on historical monuments was very satisfying. Could have been better if good food was also available on the boat.

Best during late afternoon, but beware of the cold during winter. Paid 75TL for 5 people and the boat was relatively small that tugged hard on the way back due to high tide. The cruise goes all the way through the Bosphorus so we had a view of the whole city (from start to end) on water! It's amazing to see how the Asian & European parts of the city meet. Of course, AMAZING pictures if you have a good camera, like some of our fellow travelers.Con: beware of PDA & the cold during winter & the lengthy trip (may get bored of it halfway back to the Galata bridge).

Bosphorus at night. We took a Dinner Cruise on the Bosphorus and it was an excellent choice. The river bank comes alive as darkness falls with most of the significant buildings and mosques along the trip being floodlit. The overall effect is quite breathtaking. We spent most of the meal time running outside the dining room to photograph the stunningly lit sites. Would thoroughly recommend it to any visitor to Istanbul.

A quick trip to Asia and back. the 25 minute boat ride across the Bosporus was well worth it. The Ferry ride is cheap and frequent. The Boats are large and comfortable with tea and snack service on board. Once on the Asia side there a large labyrinth of streets to wonder around and you will have a chance to sample foods, and a large variety of shops before heading back to Europe.

The Bosphorus is what makes Istanbul Special. The Bosphorus is a deep and wide waterway that runs through Istanbul and connects the Black Sea to the Marmara. Along its shores are the most beautiful neighborhoods in the city, with many places and wonderful old "yali" (waterfront homes). On a nice day a few hours spent on a Bosphorus ferry ride can be the highlight of any visit to the city.

Took a ferry across. Took a ferry over the Bosporous! It was definitely worth it. Enjoyed taking pictures over to the modern part of Istanbul, and then back again on another ferry boat. Cost up 4tl max there and back. Definitely worth doing. Who needs a guide! Cos you don't need one!

Bosphorus is amazing. The boat trip through the Bosphorus is a must. The landscape is marvelous, the boat large and safe. One can hardly believe that is in a spot so full of history, in the very point were Europe and Asia meet. And remember that the Bosphorus was a river flowing into the Sea of Marmara up to 8,000 years ago, when the glaciers melt, the sea level rose and the Mediterranean was linked with the Black Sea.

important to do. Thanks to our host we were able to take a trip during the sunset. It looks amazing, especially if you are fond of taking pictures. The image of the city from the water's perspective is memorable.

A Must See in Istanbul. This is a must see in Istanbul. By getting a ferry or a cruise allows you see the Europe and Asia continents and also many other buildings along the sea. For example, you can see the Ciragan Palace, Dolmabahce Palace, the beautiful and grand Bosphorus Bridge, etc. The cruise or ferry ride allows you to be close with the sea gulls, enjoy the beautiful scenery on both Europe and Asia continent, see hundreds and thousands of little jelly fishes floating everywhere in the water, etc. In a nutshell, this is a ride that should not be missed when one is in Istanbul.

The local ferry was great. We took a local ferry, at the suggestion of a local tour guide. We were staying in The Old City, and we walked to Eminonu. You can also take the tram right there. We walked past the fish food boats (towards the left) and found the ferry line we needed. It took us up the Bosphorus and back. The entire trip was a bit more than an hour, and was perfect for us. While other people said that they do not tell you about any sites, they do. They will point out the highlights and tell you a bit about them. We were happy that we did not do the 4 hour cruise. After the boat ride, we walked over the bridge and continued our touring.

Gives the city a new perspective. This is a must do trip.It shows the sheer size of the city. You can get some very nice shots looking back on Istanbul as the boat pulls away. We loved seeing the bridges and the buildings from the river . To know you are between two continents is very special. One of the best parts of our trip to Istanbul.
wow. I like everything what is connected with see I like bosphorus tor on boat, this is thihg you must do while you are in Istanbul

Superb. Getting the public ferry from Europe to/from Asia for €2.50/$3.00 return is great fun. Asian Istanbul is much less touristy than its European sibling. However, it is fun to wander around as a local. It makes for a fun, interesting afternoon. Eoin

Cruise between two continents. We took the afternoon cruise, so we were able to enjoy the sunset and that lights come on during our time on the Sea of Marmara. It was beautiful to experience this once in a lifetime trip. Our last night in Turkey was sealed with this lovely cruise. We saw the lights of the city twinkle as we went northward toward the Black Sea and then southward toward the Aegean. I would highly recommend this! Bring your camera.On a side note, there is a hospital that was used during the Crimean War, at which Florence Nightingale worked. As a nurse, I appreciated this tidbit of trivia.

Must do in Istanbul. This tour takes about 2 hours and there are different ways to see the attractions. I think the best way is to take a cruise from the harbor near the traditional fish and bread boat restaurants for 12 Turkish Lira for each person. You don't need a guide because you can rent an audio guide for an additional fee from the harbor. The first time we were at the Istanbul we booked this tour from the city center for an expensive fee but we found this way next time very better. But don't forget to do this activity to feel the real atmosphere of the Istanbul.

Stunning on a good day. Travel up the Bosphorus by ferry or river cruise, get some nice historical sites each side to view. See the luxury mansions towards the Asian side and the castle/palace on the European.

Cruise up the Bosphorus. Shy away from the many touristy cruises and get a cruise from the city operated boat company Şehir Hatları. Of course there will be mostly tourists with you anyway, but you'll pay a third of the price the other companies or hagglers will sell you. Then get an audio guide. I don't usually get one, but if you take a full 6 hours cruise, you'll need it.The cruise is about 1.5 hours up the Bosphorus, with a few stops along the way, and stops for 3 hours next to some (very uninteresting) Roman ruins. You will get lunch there, walk around, take some pictures, take some more tea, and go back on the boat (you are free to do anything you want there). Then another 1.5 hours down back to Istanbul. Seat on the same side of the ship on the way in and back, this way you can look and learn (with the audio guide) about all places of interest on either side.This is a bit long cruise, but it's the only way to see the other end of the Bosphorus and the Black sea.Cash only.

Take a ferry across the Bosporus for the views. For just over 4 Turkish liras, round trip, you can take a trancontinental cruise across the Bosporus, and admire the scenery on both sides of the water - the palaces and mosques of Sultanahmet, the 19th century palaces north of the Golden Horn, and the views of the Bosporus Bridge and Anatolia. There are more expensive guided tours of the Bosporus, but the trips in the ferries are just as scenic, and quite a bit cheaper (if less well-explained).

Great Day Out. A nice day trip to spend a day. Join a local tour that will take you through both landmark at the European and Asian Continent. Beautiful weather would add on to the leisure as you would have clear shore line from the cruise.

Bosphorus Strait. You must find some time to venture on the Bosphorus if you visit Istanbul. If you do not you are doing yourself a disservice. It was incredible as we traveled towards the opening of the Black Sea viewing the beautiful villages and towns and cities that lined the historic waterway. Beautiful Mosques and the beautiful sound of the call to pray echoing across the valley as the boat glided through the blue waters was unforgetable. The old fortresses, homes and mansions we passed along the way were incredible. Spring for the slightly more expensive boat tour with the larger and nicer boat. That tour is longer but worth it. Do not forget to take a quick 30 min ride to the Asian side and do lunch it's a great trip that many miss out on, your Tram pass works on the ferry to the Asian side of Istanbul, how convenient... THE TRAM PASS DOES NOT COVER THE COST OF THE BOSPHORUS CRUISE...

Bosphorus Strait. You can take any boat up the Bosphorous from every harbor, to see the sights on both the Asian and European side of Istanbul. There are 3 or 4 options do to the cruise, depending of what you like and how much time do you want to stay on the cruise. I think it's a must do if you are in Istanbul.
Fantastic. Amazing really nice trip the sea and food everything was fantastic views ferry and values of money just one thing time was short can't complete everything you want
