While away a pleasant afternoon. Take any boat up the Bosphorous to see the sights on both the Asian and European side of Istanbul from a different perspective. Costs around 30TL for a 2 hour trip. great views of the Dolmabache Palace

The most important sight in Istanbul. So they say that Istanbul connects Europe, Asia and the Middle-East. Yes. And no. Istanbul is in fact where they meet and you can see all of them at the Bosphorus Strait, but they are not connected by the bride(s). They mix and interact, but are still not connected.
A beautiful cruise!. One of the best ways to see the vast expanse of Istanbul.Beautiful sights all along the way with an opportunity to see the gulls up close!

Fascinating!. Our group opted for the 2 hour cruise. Fortunately, it was a lovely, sunny and warm day, and being on the water was a brilliant choice. Seeing some of the sights (and sites!) from the water gives a different perspective. We were treated to some delicious apple tea as an option, or coffee. Our tour guide gave us a wonderful talk about what we were viewing, some of the history of the the city and it was a bit thrilling to think that here we are, right between Europe and Asia. But I am a bit of a nerd that way!!

If you have the time, go on the Bosphorus.. Istanbul is a fantastic city to see by foot. But after three days of extensive walking it was nice to have another option, and that was to get on a ferry and just watch the world sail by.The chance to see the city from a different perspective, and to have Europe and Asia either side of you is quite special. And for those of you that are into your history, it is quite an important waterway.

A must cruise. If you don't cruise the Bosphorus, you cannot see and know Istanbul. There are many cruise choices, short and long. My advice would be to take the long one, see the two bridges, see the old and new buildings by the water and reach the point where the Bosphorus opens to the mighty Black Sea. Get out of the boat at Anadolu Kavagi, eat lunch. And to digest what you ate, climb up the (there are buses going up there as well) Yusha Hill and have a breathtaking view of the Bosphorus.
Take a ferry ride on the Bosphorus. We joined locals on a 1 1/2 hour round trip ferry ride on the Bosphorus. We sat outside next to families enjoying the views from the water and the local culture.

Nish part of the city. If you are staying sultanahmet area or karakoy/ galata, take a bosphorus tour. There are two local boat companies, one leaving from Eminonu ( turyol) or the other from Kabatas ( dentur).Dentur is a hop on hop of tour which makea it more convinient.There are other small tourist boats but ı would not recommend them since they play too loud musics and ruin all the peaceful sigthseeing.The masons located on the shore are beautiful. It seems the only green zone left in the city.Small fishing boats on the sea makes a great view.Good breeze during the hot summer nights.Worth to make it.

The Crown Jewel of East/West. The straight is must see and Istanbul is one of my all time favorite trips for foodie's, shoppers, culture lovers with a family. The straight is a one of the most memorable tourist type excursions I taken while traveling and when I go back to Istanbul I would take the boat tour again to see the beauty of east & west Istanbul from the sea. It's a welcome break form the hustle and bustle of shopping and negotiating with local shops
Take a cruise. Interesting 2hr cruise though it rained that day. Vantage point from the river is worth the trip, though a bit hairy when the big ships pass you by

Cruise the Bosphorus. There are many ways to cruise the Bosphorus and many companies to choose from. There are 2 hour cruises and up to 6 hour cruises. We chose a Full Brosphorus Cruise run by the public ferry company Sehir Hatiari. It is the cheapest full tour. With a few quick stops it took 90 minutes to reach the village of Anadolu Kavagi where it has a 3 hour layover, then returns to Galata Bridge. During the layover you can have lunch at one of the many waterside restaurants and see the ruins of Yoros Castle above the village. Be warned! The climb up to the ruins is steep and, depending how fit you are, can take up to 1/2 hour of steady climbing. Once up there, you are rewarded with a beautiful view of the Black Sea. There are many private homes and historic buildings to see on both sides of the Bosphorus. Ear sets are provided to give you a running commentary. But you are at a bit of distance, so if you prefer to see things close up close, this may not be for you

Bosphorus Strait Cruise. Get on one of these cruises. Easy going, no time stress. Incorporates the Spice Bazaar, and lasts for around 2 hours on the water. You will go under both of the existing bridge crossings from Eurpoe to Asia - quite magnificent engineering works if you are into that sort of thing.

Must see Boğaziçi. Boğaziçi/Bosphorus is the best part of İstanbul to see.The most convenient way to see it through is to take a long Bosphorus Tour by boat from different parts of İstanbul as it travels up to the northern part up to opening to Black Sea.Very good scenery to see on both sides.Strongly Recommended.

Don't miss it!. The cruise on the Bosphorus was a highlight of our vacation to Istanbul. Stopping along the way to see some of the sights on both the European and Asian sides made it a very significant trip. The Bosphorus was correctly on my bucket list. Wonderful!

OK to skip. Did the required boat ride up and down the Bosphorus but honestly feel like the time could have been spent wandering the city more. There's too much to do to spend time in a boat seeing things from a distance. I prefer to be up close.
Great day trip!. Took the public ferry trip and thoroughly enjoyed it! We used a Rick Steves book and read about what we saw on the way up. Paying for a private trip is completely unnecessary!

Beautiful Bosphorus. Our group travelled by boat up this historic waterway that I have read about for years and never thought I would see. The palace and Mosques as we glided along, under the high road bridges to dock and lunch to see the opening into the Black sea - MagicWas fortunate to see the beginnings of the new bridge hopefully will see the completed bridge on my next visit

Unique. How exciting it is to look at one side, see Europe, and look at the other side and see Asia! If anything it is a great Geography lesson. It is also so beautiful to see the buildings from the boat, and learn a bit more about one of the most fascination cities in the world. A stop at the Asian side is essential. My stop was near the entrance to the Black sea. There are some nice little shops and it's a chance to maybe buy some souvenirs. I went in the Autumn, so it was a bit windy and cold but still worth it. I'd recommend it in the summer, although I imagine everything to be busier. A must do in Istanbul. Try a service that includes lunch on the boat.

Beautiful. We were on a cruise ship and sailed in and out of the Bosphorous Strait. It was amazing, both in daylight and darkness. The skyline is like no other in the world, with the mosques and old buildings conjuring mages of a centuries-old, exotic culture. It is truly magnificent to see and is rivaled only by sailing into Venice. Being on a cruise ship provides an amazing view, for miles around, above many of the buildings.
Amazing Experience. You can view the elegance of the city fthrough a ferry ride in the Strait of Basphorus. You would not like to end the ride.
A MUST see!. Definitely recommend that everyone do this. Watch out for Gypsey kids around the wharf. Unless you like really intense heat, I suggest you go in their early Spring or early Fall.

stunning. The cruise or the boat ride along the blue waters is a must...amazing coastline with magnificent view of many palaces n bridges...you are in the middle of 2 continents...really nice chance to capture the view of historical places...the commentary of the guides is also really helpful...a not to be missed experience..

A unique perspective. The views of the shoreline are quite good and contains some relatively newer architecture and some fairly old as well. It is a unique experience to look on one side of the boat at the European coast and the other at the Asian coast. People are constantly walking around the boat selling tea and snacks so you should not get thirsty or hungry. It is better to take this excursion with a tour guide who can explain the old walls and structures that are seen along the shores. Worth the price of admission
Cruise. Took a local ferry to take a trip up and down the Bosporus just chilling out and watching the world go by

Impressive, significant body of water. To know how many countries depend on the straits for commerce and the history of the efforts of the Allied forces during WW 1 to control it from the German highlight the importance of the strait

Busy Cruiseship Passage. Ocean Princess arrived at north end at dawn and proceeded thru under overcast skies. The on shore expert was able to provide a running informative commentary over the ship's intercom to the upper observation deck. As a photographer, there were many opportunities for taking pictures of the historical sites, the modern bridges and shore facilities, the other boat traffic, and some water and shore bird activity around the ship. Bring a long lens.
Best Deal. The one hour boat ride was well worth the price. Beautiful coast line with views of magnificent palaces Takium, Gatlin Tower, Eyup and of both bridges.

Amazing. Take a cruise along the Blue waters of the Bosphorus Strait. You are at the middle of two continents - Europe and Asia. You can choose to take an evening ride after a tiring day of sightseeing - it will rejuvenate you truly.
Great to see. Enjoy the view from the boat and relax, but if the weather is rough or cold, wrap up warm - it is chilly!

A Cruise Adds A Lot. You can see the Bosphorus from lots of places in Instanbul and it is indeed an extremely busy place. A Bosphorus cruise added a lot to our enjoyment. It enabled us to see not just the historic sites that we'd seen from land, but so much more - neighborhoods, boat traffic and Maiden's Tower, a distinctive structure in the middle of the water. We found the views of land to be well worth the cruise.

The water view. Fork over a few dollars and take one of the tour boats that convey you up and down a section of the Strait. You'll be glad you did. The canned narration is a bit annoying, but the views are spectacular and you'll get a perspective of Istanbul impossible to obtain any other way. You can also take a ferry, but be prepared for a much longer journey. I found the 90-minute tour just about right.

The 1/2 day with lunch was great for us. We had relatively dreary weather during our 6 days in Istanbul but the sun shown a bit on the day with did this trip and it was delightful. Being November it was not crowded; the buffet lunch was ok - one doesn't expect more - and sitting in the open upstairs was a great way to view this historic area; the bridges are interesting, each quite different, and the historical edifices along the banks of the river are impressive. We found it a relaxing way to see the area after spending days pounding the streets of Istanbul. The "guide" who announces sites as you pass them did a very adequate job and the the stop at the fishing village gave us the opportunity to walk a bit and view yet more cats and shops!

Such a busy waterway. We did a late afternoon cruise which ended at night, so we got to see strait during sunset and then lit up at night. This would have to be one of the busiest waterways I have ever seen and it seems as though there are no seafaring rules. Really nice to see Istanbul (both sides) from the water.

A nice break from the August heat. Head down to Eminonu Pier for a cruise along the Bosphurous. There are plenty of cruises to choose from . We literally hopped on one that was just leaving and it was only 10lira each for a 90 minute journey down the river towards Topkapi and back again. A lovely breeze to staunch the stifling August Istanbul heat and a great way to see some of the beautiful riverside ottoman homes and palaces. When we returned we stopped off at one of the famous floating fish sandwich stalls for a quick streetfood style snack which finished off the afternoon nicely.

Romantic.. Romantic, particularly on a sunny day. One of the best seaside trip I have ever taken. Take the government Ferry and go to last stop. Have a seafood lunch by the seaside and back. It would be the best value romantic trip you have ever taken. Do not forget your camera / smart phone and of course your sweetheart.

Nothing special. We had high expectations and were desapointed. Boats for about 400 persons, uncomfortable wooden seats, almost impossible to sincronize recordings on the audioguide with the sights (difficult to identify); if you want to take a photo you have to fight for a place. Definitely, not the best way to explore the famous strait.

Make sure you buy the right tickets!. This is the best single tip I can share with future travellers who consider to take a cruise on the Bosphorus. Yes, it is worth two hours of your day to enjoy the fresh breeze and the beautiful landscape of both continents with a cup of tea. You'll definitely get a much broader perspective of the city and it's surroundings, however there are no live or recorded commentaries on board of the ship.That said, this was the second time I went on a Bosphorus cruise on different boats. Even though I mentioned to the cashier we would like to purchase a 2-hour Bosphorus Cruise return ticket (till the Fatih Sultan Mehmet Bridge), we got tickets for a full day trip (25TL/ person - from 10.35AM till 4.30PM) to Anadolu Kavagi unknowngly. This was a trip leaving at 10.35AM, arriving to Anadolu around 12PM and departing 3h later back to Istanbul. I'm sure it would be a lovely day trip because this charming fishing village, besides many fish restaurants, also had a castle overlooking the Black Sea. Later we found out this is Yoros Castle and it dates back to Phoenicians and Greeks times.As mentioned, it would have been a day trip if we didn't have to drop off one of our friends at the airport 4h later... If you really need to rush back to the city and you can't spend 3h in Anadolu, find the bus stop (2min walk from the ferry) that will take you to Beykoz (1h drive) and from there take the bus #15 to Uskudar (also 1h drive). From there, simply take the ferry to Eminonu and you're back in Istanbul within 2h30.

The Only Way to Get the Wide-Angle Perspective of Istanbul. Riding the ferry from Eminou or taking one of the Bosphorus Strait boat tours is the only way to get a wide angle view of both the "old" and the "new" cities of Istanbul. This trip gives you a perspective on the massive size of the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, and especially the Suleymaniye Mosque. It also gives you the bragging rights to have transitioned between the European continent and the Asian continent...actually sailing down the centerline. That alone is probably worth the fare!

Maybe a highway but still scenic. This maybe the M25 of Turkish Waterway's but still business & pleasure can live arm in arm. A trip from the harbour up to the second bridge & back at night was a treat & good photo opportunity. It was good to see so many young people enjoying the trip.
Cruise bye. Passed through on a few cruises - the scenery is great and some of the houses and public buildings are amazing.

Very nice on the cruise. We took the cruise around to see the Bosphorus Strait. The cruise took 90 minutes. The view was awesome. You will get to see the european and asia part of Turkey. The cruise goes around. There is the upper and lower deck. They sell Turkish tea, juice and bread snack. It is worth while if you have a audio set that they can explain what you see.

A Don't Miss Outing in Istanbul. For a view and feel of Istanbul from the water, the Bosphorus tour (self-led) should not be missed. Maybe take a guidebook along so that you know what you are looking at. And even if you don't, it's a wonderful escape from the harried pace of the city.

Absolutely cruise the Bosphorus. When you need a break from the intensity of Istanbul, take a couple hours and cruise the beautiful Bosphorus. Some trips are as short as 90 minutes or so and offer amazing views of Dolmabahce Palace and the Rumeli fortress.

Refreshing and the ultimate sightseeing experience. Our tour guide booked a boat tour on the Bosphorus Strait and we were fortunate to have the entire boat to ourselves. This is the way to sightsee - the entire trip took just over two hours. The weather was not great and it was chilly and cloudy, but once we were sailing the weather was the last thing on our minds. The crew was friendly and served us beverages the entire time. We saw mosques, fortresses, palaces, naval yards and everything in between. I love to brag that we were in Europe and Asia in only two hours! Took magnificent photos and learned a great deal of history. It was interesting to see all of the huge cruise ships lined up at the port - no wonder the lines to see attractions in Istanbul were so long! Istanbul is indeed the crossroads of the world.

Give your legs a rest. The ferry leaves from Eminonu pier at 2:30pm on Saturday & Sunday through the winter season. The tickets are 12 liras per person but you can get 25% price reduction on production of an Istanbul Museum card. You can board from 2:00pm & take a seat on the left hand side for the best views. For the next two hours you will sail past palaces, sky scrapers & pretty sea side villages whilst resting your weary legs.

Bosphorus Boat Trip. 2 hour trip which was just long enough. Great service on board. Use boat tours that go from Eminonu. Take tram to Eminonu and walk under the Galata bridge (through small tunnel) and the boats leave every hour from here. The tours are 12 TL per person and very good value for money.

Amazing amazing. Its an amazing place to see the beauty in Istanbul, especially if you take a boat and go from Europe to Asia side its gonna take about 15 minutes i thinks its a nice short trip and transportation, nice view nice water and nice bridge , but at night its gonna be so cold in winter to take the boat.
By boat. travelling by boat over Bosphorous was splendid. This we did several times and everytime it was possible. And was fast.

Choose your boat tour wisely. You have to visit the Bosphorus Strait if you go to Istanbul. It gives you a different view of the city. There are many tours on offer from expensive tourist ones to cheaper ferries. Decide where you want to go and what you want to see before you decide who to choose or youcould get ripped off.

Very enjoyable afternoon. We hopped on the Ferry for a 2 hour tour. It was plenty, we didn't need to be on the longer one. We didn't have a day for that. It was a beautiful day and it went up and down the bosphorus. They serve food on board which was perfect since we got there just in time and were starving! The ferry was very inexpensive compared to all of the millions of people advertising bosphorus tours. Perhaps the only difference would be a bit of narrative which there isn't on the ferry... didn't matter. We enjoyed it a lot.
Not as good as i thought. Went round in circles three times, the whole place looked the same, maybe the cold wind got to us too.

Bosphorus. I didn't really enjoy this boat trip as the day was very windy and cold. I thought that the boat could have travelled closer in to the buildings as they seemed too far away to see them very well.

Beautiful site. We viewed this from the bridge and along, water edge and from our cruise ship . Dinner views were beautiful and you can see so much of the city and the mosques. The boating traffic is very interesting to watch. It is amazing to be able to see Europe and Asia at the same time.

A cruise is worth it. The Bosphorus Strait is both beautiful and steeped in history. Especially on a mild, sunny day, it's well worth booking a narrated cruise and spending a relaxing afternoon on the Bosphorus. A tip: try your hotel's concierge service..
Great place to visit.... Many great restaurants around - what a nice place to visit. Try to arrange a local guide to show you around and tell you about the history.

Bosphouros Cruise . It was a lovely boat ride for just 10 Turkish lira for about 2 hrs. But no ongoing speaker to inform u of the places we passed. But u could rent an audio tour tape in various languages. It was a nice way to venture the straits.

Fantastic . This is a beautiful and mysterious area, east meets west.I took a river cruise at night and it was a most enjoyable way to see it.Teeming with activity, boats, ships, etc. reminded me of a harbor or waterway in China.Look back across the city and the many minarets.

The Straits that Separates Asia and Europe. Going for a cruise along the Bosphorus is indeed one of the thing that you really must do when you are holidaying in Istanbul. The view along the Bosphorus of the multitudes of grand private house, palaces, apartments, old forts and such is truly a sight to behold that you will remember for a long time. The cruise will be for about 2 hours and if you do go from October to February i suggest to wear warm and thick clothing so you can sit on the upper open air deck to truly enjoy the sights. Remember also to bring some bread with you to feed the seagull which in itself is quite an experience (there's gonna be LOTS of seagulls following your boat)

A Boat Tour. You can visit the Bosporus strait & see Istanbul from the water.
Sections of it have very opulent homes built over time, now worth millions. Reminded me of visiting the Thames River in London.
A very important trade route as it connects the Black Sea to the Aegean & the rest of the Mediterranean.

Worth seeing, but half day is enough.. Lovely Morning. We were picked up at the hotell and had a very nice tour around the city picking up everybody else. The guide was very good in english bus She had the mic to close... Didnt understand very much. Loved the litle stop in Asia, and bought a beautiful lamp. Food on board and bus back to the hotel. Perfekt half day in Istanbul
Persia at your doorstep. A great way to experience Istanbul and its rich history in a few hours. Wonderful guide and delicious lunch included

Lost? Follow the river. Most of the tourist sites are located alongside or near the Bosphorus and a walk along the riverside is pleasant, especially as you move away from the busier areas and head towards the two bridges. What surprised me was the large amount of people fishing from the riverside. Although most fishermen congregate in certain areas, you're never too far from someone casting a line into the river. This means the riverside is lively and vibrant, even at night.Most important, however, is that it's easy to follow the river. Istanbul can be very confusing to navigate unaided, especially if you leave the main streets, intentionally or not. Find your bearings relative to the river and you'll find it easier to find your way back to your hotel.

Magic Tour with Gossukagi Travel Agency!!!. We did 2 tours with this travel agency. The Bosporus Day Tour and The Princes Islands Tour (Which we see that we can not leave our review here, why???). Both Tours were excellent and we thank this travel agency for all. We booked those tours to have also food inside which was an excellent choice as the food was perfect and we got full. It was an open buffet which had the traditional kebab and spicy chicken and many other choices like rice, potatoes, many salads and deeps. The price was the best we found and very reasonable for the things it included. Pick up from your hotel and drop off also. Tour all the way to Bosporus which is something unique and magic as you see all the historic buildings and sightseeing and also unique houses, harbors and many other places on both sides of the area. Also you can see all the bridges that connect Europe and Asia and everything during day light and night. On the Princess Islands tour we had also lunch on the boat which was great and the exploration of the 3 major islands was also very interesting, instead of being pressed from the time on the first island. It is an experience that you must not miss. The only thing that you must be aware of is not to ripped off from the restaurants or cafe shops on the last island. Better ask someone or take a look carefully on the reviews before you choose. Both tours are great and if you are planning to visit Istanbul then you definitely have to put it on your schedule. We also strongly recommend this travel agency for everything. Good, polite and helpful.

A true beauty. This is what divides Europe and Asia and what becomes the main source of energy for Istanbul. To enjoy Bosphorus , you could take a ride on it coupling it with a dinner and a show and the beautiful view along its bank. Time is crucial to reap in the beauty and my suggestion would be to opt for a night time ride to enjoy a true beautiful visual delight.

Strategic stretch of water. Surprisingly the water quality was far better than I had imagined it would be considering the amount of shipping traffic that past through in the course of a day to and fro the Black Sea.Fishing seemed to be a popular pastime, and a source of income no doubt. Traversed across to the other side via small water taxi, dodging container ships! Although we didn't do a cruise (plenty of options to choose from) it would definitely be a great way to get a different perspective of the city and its many waterside attractions.

Take a Cruise...you will remember it for Life. The key is to be a little adventurous. Dont worry about buying the cruise packages, etc. Study it up a little and go to the local ticketing office at the dock yourself. They mostly understand English, and will be able to get you want you need for half the price. I recommend the 2 hour cruise, which has a Hop-on Hop-off option. The ferries run pretty much on the hour, so if you feel the need to get out and enjoy a part of the city, you can. Super clean ferries too.

Nice to view the sites from the water. We sailed up the bosphorus on the cruise ship. You can appretiate how far Istanbul stretches on both sides of Europe and Asia. The ship passed under the bridges with very little room to spare. A good photo opportunity too.

you want to see this. It is the traditional separation of the sea of Marmara and the Black sea. Too many bridges over it today, to read about it years ago, it sounded much more interesting. Great place to take a boat/excursion on.
very relaxing. Enjoyed every second of it. Went across the Bosporus, taking all the sights in. Felt like I'm on some film set. So much to take in. Very relaxing break.

Great way to chill out in Istanbul. If you want to chill out for an hour or so in Istanbul, I would recommend going down to the water at the Galeta Bridge area and do a boat cruise on the Bosphorus Strait. We had a delicious fish sandwich lunch on the waterfront and then caught a boat for a hour or so cruise past fabulous Ottoman palaces and buildings.The sea breeze was a very welcome respite from the heat of Istanbul.We did not do one of the "tourist" cruises but one that only cost a fraction just along from the fish sandwich restaurant.
Definitely cruise the Bosphorus!. You must see Istanbul from the water! You see two continents from the sea, and view amazing palaces and mosques and the fabulous skylines of Istanbul.

Could Have Been Great. The views were terrific, however I can't say the same for the Tour Company we had. We made a wrong choice on a half day cruise combined with a half day land tour and spent much of our time tied up in traffic. Not a good experience we should have booked a full day Bosphorus Tour instead. Our tour guide had to stop for breakfast and then at the end he deserted us on the way back to the hotels (the bus driver dropped him off on a corner near his home).
bosphorus by night. You have to dine and see the show on the boat by night at the bosphore. Plus seeing Istanbul from the boat by night is so wonderful.

Magical. I'm amazed how the traffic has increased on the Bosphorus over the years. It is and will always be the soul of Istanbul. It's a never ending source of activity. It's chaos and calm in one.The views from either side are so spectacular they beggar belief.
i think this is must thing to go. beast way to to explore is to take boat trip on Bosphorus strait, than you can see much more as if you walk on shore.
East meets West. Had a cruise down the Bosphorus; such a wonderful experience knowing that one side of it is on Asia & the other in Europe! Beautiful mosques & palaces line this strait.

Take a ride on the Bosphorus!. Do not take a Tourist Tour Boat , I know they are all over plying there trade.But at Eminonu Peer.You can take a regular ferry. You can see Locals getting on and off. Have some chai(tea) and enjoy the Asian and European side.

Boat tour is the way to go.... Took a boat tour trough the Bosporus the short 2 hrs.Started at sultanament boat area, and went all the way up to the old fortress, just from the water, It is very nice and educative to see all the things you should go and see on land, but you can enjoy them from the Bosporus...very nice experience and not too expensive just 9LT if you have the "museum pass"

Relaxing and interesting. I took the half day afternoon Bosphorus and Black Sea cruise Oct 11, 2014 and found it very enjoyable - was picked up and returned to my Guesthouse, lunch/drinks/fruit on board, and English guide all for about $50 - well worth it! Boat ride only way to get true magnificent comprehensive view of great city divided by two continents! Only disappointment I was served wine without notice that it was an extra rather high charge.

Between continents. I didn’t take a real Bosphorus Tour but, nevertheless, I crossed the Strait. I went to the Eminonu Pier, to the first terminal that I spotted, I used my Istanbulkart – very convenient way to travel by public transportation means in Istanbul – and I embarked to the first ferry that stopped there. My destination was Kadikoy, on the Asiatic part of Istanbul. The goal of that day was to explore the area, so I didn’t came back by ferry. So, I was for a while between continents. It was a good opportunity to take nice pictures.

Do It!. We were not going to take yet another boat tour, but so glad we took this one. The scenery, buildings, homes are interesting, but one gets an idea of the enormity of Istanbul and the imbalance of haves and have nots. Well worth the money and an hour and a half.

Go for the Long tour. Go to the pier and buy the ticket from the window. It is only 25 TL for return trip and only 20TL if you have a valid Museum card.It is well worth it and at the end of the onward trip,they give you 3 hours break. You go up the small hill in that village and you have a fabulous view of black sea.It starts at 10.35Am and finishes at 16.35hours. It is almost a day tour and if you have time take it and you will not regret it.Do not entertain all touts who sell you the tour by private tour companies for 70 Euro etc.

Great way to spend an afternoon. I enjoyed this boat trip despite this cold weather we experianced.We took a tram to the harbour area and just bought a ticket for a boat ride on the bosphorus. This obviously does not include the guided tour but way more cost effective than paying exorbitant fees to tour guides. Tip: Tour guides really try to rp you off, so do your homework before hand.

Lovely way to spend a couple of hours. We enjoyed our boat trip on the Bosphorus, it was good to get away from the tourist crowd for a couple of hours. It is a great way to see some of the magnificent palaces and summer houses of the rich and also get close to the huge containers et.

Between two continents. There is no other place than here that you can see two continents too close too each other. It is also full of history. It is one of the single places in the world that you have to see

Great experience!. You can't go to Istanbul and not take a trip on the Strait. There are a lot of people that will run you over trying to sell you tickets for the boat trips. They are more expensive and promise 2-2 and a half hour trips but don't deliver. We were advised to look for the Turyol boats. We walked straight to their ticket office, paid 12TL per person for a 90 min trip. You don't have to book beforehand as there are a few of the Turyol boats. The boat itself is clean and spacious. You can buy tea, coffee and snacks during the trip and it goes close by the main sites next to the water for beautiful photos.Take a jacket as it can get cold.

Unique experience of natural beauty blended with history and architecture. You should not skip a boat tour experience on the Bosphorus Strait if you are visiting Istanbul. You will see many historic and architecturally impressive mansions, palaces and 2 bridges of Istanbul within the lovely setting of the Bosphorus. If you have a budget, it's best to get a guided tour so you can listen to the stories behind the buildings and other monuments. As Bosphorus is not a river like it is many European cities, it's blue color is an addition to the beauty of the boat tour. It's wider with many hills and a natural strait. You will not regret it!

The Bosphorus. Definitely a wonderful way to take great photos of the approach from water to the incredible city of Istanbul. We took a ferry across to the Asian side of the city. And, we also went on a dinner cruise one evening. The area is spectacular!
Lots to see from the water. There were many places to see along the Bosphorus Strait. We enjoyed all of the palaces and sites on this trip

The best views. Great value for money, shoes you areas and building you will not see much better than the bus tours which cost 90 euros each.
Leave several times during the day great if it isn't raining however make sure you have a rain coat if going from September onwards. Fabulous don't miss out
Must visit. We came upon a Turkish boat and paid the equivalent of £3 each for a superb couple of hours.No frills but just an outstanding trip to remember.

Great way to see Istanbul. We took the Bosphorus Straight boat tour on our own. Walk to the Galata Bridge, walk underneath and there are tour boats there. We paid $20 tl ea. for a two hour tour. Nothing was explained on the boat, so grab a city map or cultural map from your hotel to take along that will assist you in knowing at what you are looking. There are beverages on board. A jacket is recommended depending on the weather.

Cruise and refreshing air. Fresh air without disturbing odors .. oxygen enters directly into your lungs ... enjoy the views on both sides ... considering the price of the trip is very simple and does not exceed 10 TL .. better if these trips complement its way to the Black Sea .. There is no water on the ship, bought some and took them with you

A Cruise of the Bosphorus - Journey of Two Worlds. I have been on the Bosphorus Cruise on several occasions but my recent cruise is a reminder why. This is one of the world's great waterways, strategically & historically. You get a better look at both sides of Istanbul - Asia and Europe. You get to see the Rumeli Fortress, built by Mehmet II in 1453 to facilitate his successful conquest of Constantinople, as well as the last palace of the Ottoman sultans - Dolmabahce. In addition to historical and geographic things, you can see two modern suspension bridges: Bosphorus and Fatih Sultan Mehmet II. So you can see Asia & Europe, historical and contemporary, side-by-side. Remember, the Bosphorus is a watery highway with lots of traffic each day. But the cruise is worth it.
Unique experience. Take a boat tour and you won't regret it! Or just take a walk and sit in one of the many cafes and restaurants and just rest your eyes on the sea!
Unique Place in the World. Bosporus Strait is the link between Black Sea and Marmara Sea, a cruise ship will be must when visiting Istanbul.

Visit Istanbul from the boat. You'll get the all in one visit through the best buildings, palaces, bridges and terraces of the shores of Istanbul. And the best is that you're sitting yourself between Europe and Asia.

Connects Europe to Asia. Beautiful cruise , you can see Imperial Gardens / Ciragan Palace Hotel / Beylerbeyi Palace. Good time to visit before October as it tends to get very cold Nov onward , matters a lot to people like us from a tropical climate.

It is one of the must seen places. I do live at the Bosphorus, i do have the view 365 , and get never bored and used to the view. Every day and season it's beauty changes, it's charming like a pearl, it is placed in asia and europe, thats why it's also very exciting, you can enhale mystism, history and different cultures at once, but you have to spent at least 1 week to see all the beautiful places

Wonderful trip!. We took the ferry which cost all of 25ytl each for the round trip - an absolute bargain. We went to the end of the strait and spent a couple of hours at the village at the end. We climbed up to the ruined castle and then went back for a delicious fish sandwich. It was off season so we were accosted by numerous restauranters trying to get us into their restaurants. They have to make a living so didn't mind. We had coffee and pastries and watched a particularly forward one at work - he did manage to coerce some so it does work just not on us!
A different view. Nice to see some of the sites from a different perspective. You need good weather to do this but then it is a nice experience.
great view. I would recommend to spend a night in a hotel Close to the bosphorus for one night to fully experience it.

Worth going on a cruise. You can purchase a cruise tour at the port which will take about two hours going up and down the Bosphorus Strait. It's a good way to see Istanbul from a different angle and also see the Asian side. It's a relaxing and peaceful cruise. There are food and drinks for purchase. It does get crowded, specially on the upper deck.

The Pearl of Istanbul. Definitely a 'must-see' when you visit Istanbul. You can take a boat trip along the Bosphorus. It is worth seeing because of the many splendors it has to offer. What's more, it is one of its kind, dividing the city and connecting two continents. If you don't like boat tours, you can enjoy the beautiful view sitting in one of the hundreds of cafes on either side. My favorite place for a great view of the strait and a great reasonably priced meal to accompany it is 'Ortaköy'. It houses a beautiful late Ottoman mosque and is very close to the foot of the bosphorus bridge. So, those interested in photography will have a great time there. I'd say make sure you pay Ortaköy a visit. You won't regret it.
Wonderful sea side. I liked the short boat visit you see the banks from the boat and the mosques appear from there with the trees very nice visit.
nice. Take the ferry and it is as good as tour that is hawked on the square a nice way to see Konstantinoypoli by see. go until the black see

Four Hours Was Enough. We did a 4 hour Bosphorus guided boat tour and it was very informative. We saw many interesting buildings and scenic spots. There are various lengths of cruise times available. 2 - 4 hours is plenty of time to take in the Bosphorus. By the time 4 hours went by, I was ready to get off the boat.

Bustling Bosphorus!. What an array of boats, ferries, tankers, container ships.The whole Bosphorus is dotted with them but still wide open.And bridges a plenty along its whole stretch with different uses for each. Motorway, tramway,metro bridges and the marvellous Galata Bridge swarming with people fishing along its whole length.

Amazing experience. One must visit this cruize ride to explore istanbul from SEA...! it's just amazing and awesome...!
Cruize were preity good and guide inform us each and every places by annoucement...!

Istanbul Ferry Ride. Stayed in Kadikoy on the Asia side and used the ferry to Eminonu a few times, worked out at about 2.50 lira each way, really cheap.When in Istanbul I highly recommend you buy a travel card, you can load it with lira at most bus depots and ferry terminals, saves a fortune on buying individual tickets, you can use the card on the ferry, buses, trams and some trains.

Great evening on the water. I was in Istanbul for a business meeting and took an evening dinner cruise ride along the strait. Unfortunately, it already turned dark when we boarded and would wish to get chance to see the city from water both during day light and night. Despite of that, it was still a very enjoyable trip. The cruise went under the bridges that link Europe and Asia, went by different architecture along both side of the water lit up at night. It was very nice and peaceful. We enjoyed Buffet dinner and belly dance during the ride, and some passengers also danced with the performers at the end.
Save some money. Take the ferry and it is as good as tour that is hawked on the square.There is a short one and a long one so it depends on your time.

Istanbul from the water. Take one of the many cruises offered at the ports to see Istanbul from a different view. It is well worth it!We booked a tour through our hotel which took us through the Spice Market, and then on a 2 hours cruise of the Bosphorus. If I did it over again, I would have gone directly to the port and bought the cruise tickets myself for a fraction of the tour cost. The views of Istanbul and the coast from the boat are spectacular. Highly recommend doing this while you are in Istanbul.

Seafood lunch on the Bosphorous. I took the govt ( two anchor funnel next to the Galata bridge) ferry day trip and enjoyed a most pleasant seafood lunch. The three bridges crossing the straits are particularly impressive, and a bonus was the submarine and frigate which passed us. A great day out.....again, doing not a great deal. But then I was on holiday!

A great way to see the Istanbul. While most travelers get to experience Istanbul by walking the streets, taking a cruise down the Bosphorus is a different perspective. A nice relaxing time to take in all the sights that Istanbul has to offer.
A Great View. A interesting venture if you happen to visit Istanbul. The cruise was wonderful with lot of interesting places that keep camera clicking.

Just another waterway. We sailed up and down the strait on a Celebrity cruise. I was not overly impressed. As far as I was concerned it does not compare with the Panama Canal (I know the Panama Canal has locks) and certainly does not compare with riverboat cruising say the Rhine.

Not to miss the Cruise Tour. Great experience. One must take this cruise tour of 2+ hours (in the afternoon) during your Istanbul stay. It covers most of the details of the city and Europe and Asian aspects of the history.

Take a break. It's not a bad little break to jump on one of the many ferries or boats and go for a relaxing trip around the strait, especially in the heat of the day, you can just relax in the shade of the boat and enjoy a drink. Some nice views as well.

Bosporus strait. We took a tour boat ride on the Bosporus to the second bridge. What a fascinating way to see Europe and Asia from the boat...your will pass many interesting places and sites on the way. This is a must do when in Istanbul .
Great view. Great view either viewed from my hotel room at Ritz Carlton, or sailing in from a cruise ship (which I also enjoyed). The latter is amng the est sail-in I have ever seen.

Took the cheap ferry. We took the cheap ferry across to Kodakoy which was great. Ferry has a great view, nice tea and relaxing. Just costs the same as the bus. Get the istanbulcard for public transit. We went to the Asian side, walkeda round the markets, ate lunch... prices cheaper in Asia
Cruise on It!. We enjoyed the dinner cruise on it. Food was average but the entire experience was memorable. would like to do it again.

A real highlight!. We took the long ferry cruise by Şehir Hatları up the Bosphorus to Anadolu Kavagi (on the Asia side; the last village before you reach the Black Sea) and can not recommend it highly enough. It truly was a great experience. We got to the dock just after 10:00 for the 10:35 departure, and there were only about 25-30 people ahead of us. This was on the first Wednesday in October. Weekends are supposed to be considerably more crowded. To make the most of the cruise, I strongly suggest either taking a good guide book of the Bosphorus or renting the audio guide at the dock. This is a public ferry and there is no narration during the trip. Regardless, I am sure that you will find this an excellent experience and a highlight of any visit to Istanbul.

Excellent Cruise. if you are short of time take the cruise than the bus tour as the bus usually gets stuck in traffic. The cruise was for 2 hours. The price is variable and negotiable, I paid 30 T lira some paid less and some more. Never pay in Euro as it is always higher.The views are breath taking and it covers the whole stretch beautifully. The commentary is matter of fact and to the point. "this is the blue mosque, the goes to this is the galata tower etc etc"". A little bit of story or explanation would have been better. Luckily I had my guide book for reference.It can get quite cold, so better get covered up warm. the phot opportunities are endless. I will not miss it for anything else.

One of the greatest ferry rides in the world. I usually write long reviews but there is no need here. It's pretty simple. My recommendation:Take the local ferry from Üsküdar to Eyüp (aka the Golden Horn Route). You can also hop on near Eminönü or anywhere in between. The entire ride takes around one hour and costs around USD 2. Along the way, you will see both the Asian and European sides of Istanbul and the skyline along the famous Golden Horn. This must be one of the greatest ferry rides in the world, right up with the Star Ferry in Hong Kong and the ferries around Sydney Harbour. Don't miss it!The alternative is to pay anywhere from USD 10 to USD 50 for a more formal cruise focusing on the Bosphorus, but I was very happy with my USD 2 option.

good but dirty. its good but very dirty. its crowded with too many tourists, also a very strong fish smell. this area is surrounded by many meat and fish shops, hence too many crows and other scavengers also dirty the place... over all not great
Must-do. We took a boat ride in the evening. they took us well up and down the strait, and all the monuments looked beautiful in the lights, especially the bridge with the twinkling lights.

Take the boat ride. The Bosphorus Strait commands Istanbul. You can see the Asian side from Istanbul and you can drive across the bridge or take a boat ride.The boat ride is something almost everyone does. It is a narrated two hour ride down the Bosphorus and you can see many other areas of the city as well as mansions, etc. Snacks and Turkish tea are available on board.

Do A Bosphorus Boat Trip. We were just walking past as the boat was about to leave on a cruise on the strait, paid got on and had a great time, fantastic chance to photograph sites from the water. A must do!

Great view of the European side of Istanbul. An evening dinner cruise on the Bosphorus was a great way to view the city at night. The bridges are spectacularly illuminated and the view from the boat was amazing. Highly recommended.
Gorgeous. Its an experience.... one side Asia & the other side Europe.Cruise on the Bosphorus....looking at people fishing on Galata bridge....its truly an awesome experience

Wonderful vistas. Whilst we were lucky enough to cruise the Bosphorus on a Black Sea cruise, it is well worth taking one of the many local tourist trips on offer. Fascinating scenery on both European and Asian sides of the river.

Yes, the Cruise is Worth the Time. For some reason, I found it unclear in all of the reviews and travel guides on what the options were for doing this trip. Bottom line, just take the traditional ferry long cruise run by Sehir Hatlari. Leaves at 10:35 every morning. Be there 1/2 hour or more early to find ticket booth and wait in line (probably longer in summer). No need to reserve ahead. Don't bother with the audio guide - the equipment is terrible and frustrating. Just read along in whatever guide book you have. When you get to the end, they give you 2.5-3 hours to lunch and explore. Plenty of time to hike to the top to see the amazing view and eat lunch. Sit on the left/west side of the ferry going up and the left/east side of the ferry on return. If it's a nice day, this trip is definitely worth the time, assuming you have at least 4 days in Istanbul. On a 3 day trip or shorter, consider taking the short version or one of the private/faster tours (more expensive).

Nice way to spend an afternoon. Took one of the Turyol boats from Kadikoy for a 1.5 hour round trip on the Bosphorous. Only 12TL per person, plenty of room to sit either inside or out. Snack bar on board but no need to get up as waiter came round at regular intervals with tea, juice soft drinks crisps etc. No alcohol though!All in all great value and lovely sights.
Take the water tour. The Bosphorus cruise is definitely worth the money, but I recommend the 2 hour cruise. I suspect the 4 and 6 hour would be a bit dull.
A relaxing boat ride. We took An hour boat ride which was very relaxing and gave you a good idea of how well developed the river is.You get to see a lot of beautiful houses
Istanbul Cruise. No trip to Istanbul is complete without this cruise...relaxing and historic at the same time. Get a view of the Golden Horn and the Bosporus.

Floating between the continents. The awesome aspect of being over the Bosphorus is the feeling of having two continents on each side, something that can be experienced in only a few places on the globe. We did a guided tour and the guide gave us lots of historical information about the buildings, palaces, restaurants, islands and posh homes on each side of the river. This included the real estate prices of some of the properties and the nightlife in Istanbul. The beautiful city must be once viewed from the Bosphorus, it just gives a different perspective. There are multiple cruise options available depending on the time and money you want to spend on the experience.

Amazing experience. A friend arranged for us to take a cruise up the Bosporus Straits, and it was an amazing experience! To know that you're straddling the continents of Europe and Asia is an interesting concept. The sights from the water are also very interesting. We were lucky that we went in the late afternoon, so we were able to see things in the daylight, but on the return trip, the sun had set, so we were able to see the structures and bridges all lit up, and they were beautiful! I'd highly recommend it!!

Great Tour. The whole experience was perfect. They try to sell the tour for 20 Turkish Lira for 2 hours however, try to haggle it to 10 Lira. The guy will offer you Turkish teas without asking for money in the first place however, be wise, its not free and its 2.5 Lira each :)

Disappointing Cruise. We bought our cruise on the first day we arrive. Big mistake coz it costs us too much at 25 Euros for the both of us.The operators are usually around the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia. Only later we knew there is actually a cheaper fee of 12 TL for a similar 2 hour ferry trip and 25TL for the one up to the Black Sea. The only thing is, you will need to go to eminonu to get that service which is about 3 stops away from the sultanahmet tram station. Anyway, the operator that took us , the ferry was reasonably small and tend to rock more when the sea gets choppy as many speedboats and other ships use the same route. The explanation given by the tour guide was also unclear. We just basically enjoyed the given view as it is beautiful. So avoid the blue cruise if possible, if not haggle with them the price because it seems that they give different prices to different people.

A place that you must visit. I visited Istanbul on a cruise ship and stayed for 2 nights but the highlight was the ship sailing out of the Black Sea between Asia and Europe through Istanbul if you get the chance it is amazing
Waste of time cruise. This cruise is a waste of time. All you get to see is buildings and the 2 bridges from the straits. Traveling by vehicle onto the bridges would have been more memorable.

Feeding the gulls. Travelling on the normal ferry boat from Kabatas to Princes' Islands and back, tossing pieces of bread and biscuits to the numerous gulls behind and alongside with a mixed crowd of older and younger and children. And seeing 3-4 dolphins in the middle of the journey - a beautiful experience.
Wonderful river cruise. I enjoyed the cruise down the river on a private rented boat. Very peaceful, the scenery is beautiful, but be sure to bring a jacket as it gets chilly.

Busy Strategic Seaway. One of the sights of Istanbul is sitting and watching the endless parade of ferries, cargo ships, barges and cruise ships in the Bosphorus, no wonder Winston Churchill had designs on it in World War One. Cruising up and down the Bosphorus is also a great outing with lots to see on either side.
Beautiful. The most beautiful view ever... Istanbul is breath taking!! The boat trips are everywhere to be taken and I recommend always to do it at the end of afternoon...

Bosphorus Ferry. Very old ferries, Wooden benches, not particularly comfortable.
However, the views of the Waterfront were great. We spent the
three hours at Andula Kavagi waiting to go to back to Sultenhamet but we passed the time wandering around. If the weather is nice I would recommend it for seafaring travelers. If you tend to get motion sickness, take a dramamine.

Enjoyable. We did a 1.5 hrs boat ride in the Bosphorus, Very interesting to see all the stunning building along the Bosphorus.
Its a very leasurly way to see the bustling life
Loved it. One of my best tours in Istanbul. Was a pleasant 3 hours boat ride where you can see the Asian and European areas of the city.

The historic Bosphorus. Such an important waterway that links the Black sea with the Marmara sea. Very historic and beautiful strait straddling the continents of europe and asia with villages/ places along its banks rich in culture and history.

The boat ride was fun. We went on a 2 hour trip which was quite long enough to see the varied buildings along the shore - always good to get the perspective from the water. We joined a group near the Aya Sophia, where people were handing out leaflets. It worked well and we were led down to the shore to join the boat. We enjoyed a cup of tea on the boat - which was full of families enjoying the public holiday.

Do the boat cruise. There are plenty of 1 or 2-hour (or longer) cruises up the Bosphorus, which take you along the European shore first, under the big suspension bridges, and then down the Asian side. Great views of the hills, palaces and villas, and old forts. I went from Kabatas pier though you can also go from other ones. I'd avoid taking the guided tours and do it yourself much more cheaply. I took a tour with Plan Tours (Grey Line) and had to wait around for 1 1/2 hours before a 1 1/2 hour boat tour - the tour also included a short bus ride up the Golden Horn and a visit to the spice market, but what was billed as a 4-hour tour was actually only 3 hours plus 1 1/2 hours waiting around before the start.

An Amazing Journey in Bosphore. I had ride the boat of Sehir Hatlari from Eminonu, for the long journey which last for around 5 to 6 hours. I also got one electronic guide which was a must to understand what you see and the history of the place. The journey itself in the ship is amazing and the view is astonishing. I do advise everyone who got to Istanbul to ride and enjoy the nature, history and the food.

Short Boat Tour. We went for a 1.5 hour tour with Turyol. We just turned up and paid at the office. Make sure you pay at the office - don't be tempted by people offering you tours at the quay side - the price will be more. We enjoyed the short tour with no audio guide. Talking to fellow travellers, the all day cruises and audio guides were not good value.

So many jellyfish!!. This time of year the water is glutted with jellyfish. The Bosphorus boat tour was a perfect little two-hour trip, great for sightseeing from the water. The man who was narrating our tour was a treat, and I got to taste some interesting teas as well! Get your camera ready, and watch for the jellyfish!!
Boat Ride. Took a boat ride on the Strait. Nice to see all of the mansions that used to be part of the aristocracy of years past.

Amazing. As part of an organised Insight tour the cruise for the afternoon on the Bosphorus was an amazing introduction to beautiful Istanbul.
A perfect start to hear the history & see the sights & sounds from the water.

Pleasant lttle cruise!. One can see a lot of lovely things from the boat: palaces, mosques also the Asian part of the city, very fascinating!
A relaxing time after the visit of central Istanbul which can be very busy!

Wonderful Asia plus Europe. A ride on the bosphorous gives you a view of the asiaside and Europe side skyline.
You feel good to see two continents joined by 3 bridges spanning them.
It is glorious for photography.

Ferry ride. One of my favorite experiences while enjoying our visit to Istanbul, Turkey. I am from Northern CA and many people have said that the city reminds them of San Francisco. Well, once you are on the water, I would have to agree! There is a bridge that is a similar style to the Golden Gate--and the Turkish hillside is so green a beautiful! Stunning views all around!! You must get out on the water to experience the panorama.

If you ever visit Turkey,must see. We driove over THE bridge, stopped at the highest point and got as close as possible and Each and everything view was amazing. THE European and the Asian Side. Take a cruise if you have THE time. Visit THE Starbucks at Ortokoy , on the top Floor you can sit and enjoy THE view of the boats passing by.

Packed like sardines.. During our stay in Istanbul my girlfriend and I definitely wanted to take a ride on the Bosphorus. As we were exploring Istanbul on the square between the Blue Mosque and the Hagia Sophia we were approached by several people selling such trips. We decided to go with a short tour of approximately 2.5 hours and got a deal of only $10 per person. However, as we were enjoying the walk to the ferry and taking in the sites around us, we failed to notice the crowd that was gathering in front of us to get on the boat. By the time we noticed we were at the back of the crowd and when we finally boarded there were no seats left on the deck. My advice. Definitely take a tour of the Bosphorus but consider paying a little more to take one of the other ferry operations. The pamphlet for the operator that we went with says Grand Boat Line with Goldenhorn. However if you go for the cheaper option as we did make sure to get to the front of the crowd so you are among the first to board, otherwise you will be standing for the duration of the trip.
Beautiful !. Crossroads of Asia and Europe with much to see on either side of the Bosphorus. Must do boat ride if in Istanbul!
Between two continents. Seeing the Bosphorus Strait was an unforgettable experience. It was fascinating to travel from one continent to another in a matter of minutes.

Yes! Take the ferry. We had read the ferry was the best way to go and it certainly suited us. Some reviews complain you have 3 hours turn around at the end with nothing to do except be drawn into the tourist trap. For us it was the best part. We walked up the hill( yes, it's a pull but gives you an excuse to eat baklava) to the castle and found a table overlooking the blue, busy Bosphorus and ate fresh fish and drank a beer. Magical! By the way, a tourist tip...the toilets here were spotless.

Mansions & Palaces Galore. We had a fabulous way up high view from our cruise ship but there are regular Tour Boats that you can get on. It was amazing to see the way the Rulers and mega wealthy lived in these giant waterfront properties. It seems that many still do and you can only but dream.The massive 2 bridges are fun to sail under, especially on a huge cruise ship.

Cheap and cheerful. This may seem a strange title, but you will be bombarded at other sites by touts offering you glossy brochures for overpriced boat trips (your hotel will also offer these). A better suggestion is to take yourself down to the harbour side where you will find any number of more local operators offering day or half-day ferries up the Bosphorus - for 15tls, not 40 euros! The benefit of going on a cheap and cheerful trip is that you will get a great mix of people locals and visitors, there will be a bar/cafe on board for drinks and snacks, and you wont get pestered with daft photos and souvenirs - and you'll see exactly the same as everyone else paying through the nose for the experience.
Sailing through history. The grandeur of the city is perhaps best appreciated from the sea. Worth learning a little of the history of the Muslim conquest of it to appreciate what a feat that was.

Bosporus cruise is a mustg. There are long and short cruises, depending on your desires. There is a publicly offered cruise near a tram stop by the Galatea Bridge. This is much more reasonable trip than the ones for which you will be given fliers.

Beautiful boat ride. We did a sunset boat cruise along the water and it was beautiful. It was a nice and refreshing change to see the city from a different view. You get to the Blue Mosque and Ayasofya from the water which made for a nice photo. You also get to see how the rich live with their huge mansions along the waterfront. You also get to travel underneath the suspension bridges which also make for nice pictures. It was worth doing a boat cruise for the different change of pace and to get out of the crazy traffic.

Awesome Seafood and Wonderful Views. If you do not take a ferry ride on the Bosphorus you are missing out. It sports lovely views of the city and bridges. The seafood under the Galata Bridge is also not to be ignored. Just please negotiate with the waiters trying to draw you into their establishments and make sure you have noted down the prices they agree on and no service charge if you can swing it.

Great day trip. I booked long Bosphorus tour that went all the Black Sea. We saw lots of palaces and summer homes along the edge. The final stop near the black sea was a cute little town with a former castle nearby. Do hike to the top to get a great view of the Bosphorus and the Black Sea.

Just the facts, ma'am. If you have the time and the weather is fine this is a pleasant and entertaining 2-3 hours. The 'half day' voyage just goes up to the second bridge and back. The boats are actually ferry boats - partly enclosed, partly open. There is a modest narration of the sights. You may save time and money by simply taking a taxi to one of the various piers which offer 'Bosphorus cruises' and getting your ticket at the pier. The tour agencies, which pick up at hotels, waste a lot of time driving around, trying to 'connect' all their customers to the correct buses at one point before proceeding.

Take a Half Day Cruise. Our hotel, the Basileus Hotel, booked this for us. This was worth it. When you get on turn right as you go upstairs and sit on the right. This way when the ship turns around you will be on the best side for seeing the sights.
Ferry ride. Took a ferry down and back. Saw lots of houses,restaurants and hotels. The straight is busy and can be chilly. Everyone needs to take a ride down the Bosporous.

Go for a ride on the Bosphorus. We went on a 1 1/2 hour cruise up the Bosphorus Strait which was beautiful. Sit on the right hand side of the boat for the best view. Also get on early so you can choose a seat on the outside.

Beautiful views. We took a boat trip on the Bosphorus and it was a wonderful way to see both the European and Asian sides, as well as to see the small towns and architecture outside of the historical center of Istanbul. We would have loved to have done the longer tour which went out to the Black Sea, but simply didn't have the time. The shorter tour, though, was a wonderful opportunity to see the the sights along the coast - including many mosques and the Dolmabahche Palace - from a perspective that is visible only from the water.
Amazing. a view that you will never forget about, all the places seen from the see are ancient and historical and breath taking, i loved the Bosphorus trip and enjoyed it to the max

Great boat trip. This was a great way to sight see but rest our tired legs. We went on the trip at 4.15, it lasted 2 hours and at this time of year meant we saw the city as the sun was going down. On the return trip we captured some fabulous sunset pictures. It's a great way to see the palaces, quite often the nicest side of the holdings are on the riverbank.

Take the evening cruise down the Bosphorus. We took the evening cruise... the sites illuminated at night are beautiful. We had a wonderful time on the 2 hour boat ride. Unlimited wine was served as was very tasty food. The guide has some friends on board and the music was all American. People were dancing and they also had a belly dancer entertain us. Do not miss this! What a great time.

Swift Waters. Best to do your research, and pick your tour. We just went by trolly, and were of course buttonholed by a tour rep. The tour was good, just two-hours, and no explanations. If you have time, do the full six hours, get to the Black Sea, and understand the strategic importance of this international waterway.

The Bosphorus. Took a boat ride up the strait which separates Asia and Europe, beautiful coastline mansions, mosques, groves and restaurants.We had a terrific bright sunny day, you can buy drinks on board and enjoy the scenery.
Worth a boat trip!. Cruise down the middle of two continents, Europe & Asia whilst taking in the historical and cultural melting pot that is Istanbul.

4 Hours. Take a private boat trip up and down the Bosphorus, we were at the Black sea entrance when we turned arround, a grteat way to see more of the area with no walking, if you canot go private there are plenty of ferry boats going arround, hop on, hop off

Passing between Europe and Asia. While there are day trips which will take you through the Bosphorus Strait, the best way to see and experience it may be on a cruise ship. We were fortunate to go through twice on a recent trip. The views are amazing and some of the structures along the way are very impressive.
wonderfull relaxing. nice view from the sea and relax ,good tour around the principal site and the bridges and also you see very well the asia side

You have to take the boats on the Bosphorus strait. We did not take the boat tour all the way to the strait but we still took the boat that took us from Eminoniu to Eskobar (Asian side) then back to the European side to Kabata. It only took the 'IstanbulKart', the way to travel (Tramway, metro, bus.. and boat!) with no hassle in Istanbul. The city from the water is a must!
Fabulous views. Apart from its symbolic nature straddling the two continents you get wonderful views, either from the water or land.

A must! Where Europe meets Asia.. Take the cruise or the ferry over to the 'other' side of the city. One foot is in Asia (eastern side of the city) and the other is in Europe.Beautiful cruise (any of them, same sites after all) and interesting history.
Busy Waterway. The only thing unique about the "river" is that it separates a city into 2 continents. Other than that, it is just a very busy waterway with many many boats and ferries.

Nice walking. If you like to walk alone ,have a lunch and go to the shops as much as you like and choose what you like - then it's good place . Because here you will not feel bored and lonely) you will feel active and tired of walking and looking in a while)Don't forget to eat typical sweets- it's really tasty there.

Historic water trip. Was a bit confused about what boat was going where but one with a map on aboard outside listing attractions it would pass and the direction it was going was helpful as was the price for 90 minutes TL10. Nice big boat with soft drinks available and toilets.To get good seats up on top it is advisable to go onboard at least 20 to 25 mins before.Lots of palaces and a fortress to see before going under the big suspension bridge, It all felt very historic just being on the water where so many attacks on the city were foiled for so long.
Beautiful View. You must take a local boat cruise to see one of the most beautiful water ways....but I saw it on a cruise to Black Sea.

Romantic???. We were told that a cruise on the Bosphorus was romantic and that there were lost of views to see, we obviously chose the wrong day.It was a grey weather day with a long walk from the blue Mosque down to the (huge) river, you could get lost down these side streets.We finally boarded like a herd of sheep and got our seats (They are Not bookable), and set off, it was very much like a standard boat trip up any river but with the occasional old grey building on the riverbank, the price for and drink on the boat was high so take water and snacks with you. When you get back you are left to find your own way from the boat to the town centre, just follow the others, i wouldn't do this trip again though.

Boat trip. Took a trip up the Bosphorus. We had a guide who was extremely informative. The trip ended with a coach trip to Pierre Loti viewpoint. The views over istanbul are incredible. Descent wasby a small cable car.
Nice boat trip. A strait that separates Istanbul to Europ side and Asian side. Take a boat from Eminunu and enjoy the trip. Very nice. Restaurants and coffee shops in all the coast.

Wonderfull way to escape the crowds. We just took the first avail starits tour which was oly 10lire each. It only went to 2 nd bridge before returning but did give us a lovely contract to the city streets. The water is always great way to see a city.

Boat trip. We walked from the hotel throught the park, to the Bhospuros, about 40 mins, and took a boat trip, very comfortable on boat, a little cool in april so take a jacket.
Enjoyed the trip .
romantic. it cannot get better than walking beside or cruising on the Bosphorus. We really had a wonderful time in day and night.
Great day out. We went as far as we could and had a lovely, interesting but relaxing day. Great way to see many sides of the city and outskirts.

A relaxing time away from crowds. We took part in a cruise along the Bosphorus with a guide. He provided us with a lot of information about the buildings that were along both the European and Asian side of this waterway. He was also able to give us interesting information about the history of Istanbul and how monitored traffic along it in days past.There were some tremendous views of the bridges that span it.I think that with a good guide book you could make this trip on the local ferries in a cheaper fashion than we did.

Enjoy half day on Bosphorus. If you want to enjoy the landscape on both shores of Bosphorus you need to take a half day for this trip. Sehir Hatlari is the company that makes this trips every day (is located near to galata Bridge).The price is 20TL and audio guide is 10TL including a map with all the attractions on the shore.It takes 90 min each way with 3 hours spent at Anadolu Kavagi the ending point.

You may want to do this first.... and get your bearings on the city, or the two sides of Istanbul and where everything is located. What you can also see is the 'new' palace the sultans built on the riverside once they decided to leave Topkapi Palace. There are many other historic buildings, bridges and houses along the way. The one we went on was an hour and a half long and only cost 12TL each. Well worth it.

When in Istanbul, you got to visit this area~. When in Istanbul, Turkey, you have to visit this area! Just beautiful!!! We were here in May and the weather was just wonderful, took a ferry/boat ride for approx. 2 hrs with a private guide. You will lose yourself in the scenery and never want to leave!

Strategic waterway. i have heard much about theBosphorus over the years so it was very interesting to take a cruise along it. The city of Istanbul now stretches many km along it, dizzying prices are paid for real-estate, but this busy waterway leading to the Black Sea has a charm about it. the cruise was certainly very interesting and enjoyable.

Great cruise. The cruise is a great value for money. Time and money well spent. The cruise was for over 1.5 hours cruising along both banks of the Bosphorus Strait which were lined with numerous historical buildings. You have great views of the old palaces and also give you a glimpse of the Black Sea..Highly recommended

Magnificent view. It is a grand harbour/strait connecting Europe and Asia. The busy voyage with ten of ten vessels acrossing the piers. It is easy to see the 4 bridges blocking linking the 2 sides and several landmarks dominant the skylines. Take the cheap commuter ferryboats for 2 or 3 times. You wouldn't disappointed.
great way to see the shore line. The audio guide was not worth it and you don't actually get to see the Black Sea, but overall it was a great experience

magnificent. I am settled in NY long Island and there are lots of brigdes that connects NY & NJ also between Manhattan & Long Island.
I mean bridges are maybe the same but Istanbul's Bosphorus is like a vision from heaven .
I feel silence also the history .
I like this city .
Loved it. Enjoyed our walk from Blue Mosque to Grand Market to bridge crossing the Bosporous across two continents. A must-do for any visitor!
Simply a boat tour.. Would recommend smaller private trips over the large local ferry to get better photos and views of the shores on both sides.
Good boat Cruise. Great way to see the Asia and European side of Istanbul and all the historical buildings along the shore.

must do at least a half day cruise if visiting Istanbul. Best way is to get to Kabatas or Eminonu ferry terminals (booth easy by tram (get an Istanbulkart to speed up travel process plus really good value). Kabatas has a hop on hop off half day cruise which is great value at 15TL pp. Run by ‎Dentur Avrasya it operates every hour from about 12.:45 and stops at about four stations on the European and Asian sides and last about 1 hr 40 if you dont get off. Also has a fairly manic waiter offering orange juice , toasted sandwiches, Chai (Tea) etc at you seat for a modest price (have change or he just rounds up to the nearest note with a "tip"!!) The local ferry operator ‎Şehir Hatları operate similar tours out of Eminonu which also came recommneded and their is also ‎TurYol boat but cant vouch for them. The tour shows you some splendid castles and buildings generally on both sides of the Bosphorous and goes up European side past second bridge and then back down Asian side. Ideally sit on Left hand side top deck for best views but it is open to weather from sides and can get chilly on poor weather days. Seats are fairly rustic but Ok for a couple of hours. Maybe get off and have lunch at far end and get back on one of next hourly boats back.
Must do. Don't buy off street vendors, go to the docks area yourself and it is much cheaper. Ensure there is a commentary.

Turkish life and communication. On its banks there are many great palaces , mosques and common people's houses, while through its waters flows the commerce of goods and people travelling to and from the Black Sea.

It is where the two Continents Meet. This is another absolute must!!! The view is simply breathtaking. Make sure you enough memory in your camera to snap those amazing shots!! A whole morning or afternoon can be spent there if you love photography!
Take a boat trip. Excellent time to relax and see the shores of both sides of the Bosphorus. We stopped and had lunch in a town near the Black Sea, which the ferry would not go into.

Great Views of Historic Sites. Take the Sehit Hatlari ferry cruise. Great value for money and you wont regret it! Take it from Eminou to Anadalou Kavagi and have lunch at one of local restaurants, reasonable price. I think they run in summer, & spring
3 Day visit to Istanbull. This mini cruise speaks for itself. The pass and go under all the bridges is an experience in itself. A well worth trip on anyone's itinerary

Endlessly Interesting. The Bosphorus is endlessly interesting whether seen from the shore during the day, an Istanbul restaurant at night, a public ferry or a private tour boat. My personal preference is the public ferry in the evening as the lights are coming on ashore: the minarets, the office buildings, the apartment blocks. It is a wonderful contrast and I look at some part of it every time I come to Istanbul.

Beautiful - Get a Speedboat Tour. I'm not sure how else you'd see it! hah! But a speedboat tour (2 hours is plenty) gets you up and back, and you can see the range of internationally-overpriced-mansions and castles that face the strait. Plus, it's so much more convenient than trying to hustle onto a ferry and not actually see anything up close. You don't really need a tour guide ... but most places aren't going to let you leave without one on the boat ... so make sure to take advantage of them and ask lots of questions!! :)

The bospherous cruise. we used the Sehir Hatlari cruise, it was well worth the money, the cruise was about 3hours in total but we stopped off at a fishing village for 3 hours, all in all it took 6hours.Get there early and sit outside the breeze and the view are breathtaking, this will be missed if sat inside the cabin. The recorded tour guide machine didnt work

Gorgeous!. This is by far the best way to experience this amazing city! Major sites on the water on both the Asian and the European site. The boats leave from Eminonu pier which is an experience in itself. Since this is such an attraction, there waste a ton of different boat tours, all differently priced, so pick one with more Turkish passengers than tourist, costing 10 euro, the is no need to pay more, the experience will be no different.
A must see!. Try to cross the bridge at night (the one with the lights) and look down! I get chills just thinking about the view!
Worth the boat ride down the harbour. I never seen soooo many ships in a harbour in all my life. Really cool to see. It looked like the harbours in WW2. Except they werent battle ships.
Gorgeous!. The bridge and the entire strait is a site not to be missed, very beautiful and truly breath taking :)

Take a boat ride to relax and see both sides of the world. The Strait of Bosphorus is one busy waterway separating Europe from Asia. There are lots of boat tours and when we got to the waterfront, were hustled into one for a pretty cheap rate. Little did we know it would be hurry-up-and-wait. But we were not in a hurry. The boat was old and after several vans full of people over an hour finally filled it, we were off! The trip was adequate and we got a great overview of both sides of the Strait. We returned to the dock and were on our own about sundown during Ramadan. The walk back to our room was even better since everyone came out and celebrated by feasting. A great experience to witness by western visitors!
