Good Fun.. We had a half day cruise here and just loved it. The tour guide's descriptive commentary was very informative and clear. It was a beautiful weather day and I was able to easily get some great photographs of a range of historical buildings along the way.
Trip between two continents. It is worth to do that trip if you have more than two days because there are many monuments to see in the city
The boat trip. It was an amazing trip on the boat. It takes you through the European and Asian side and the views are spectacular.

Nice to cruise on. My husband and I took this cruise which was about 2 hrs long up and down the Bosphorus. it's a great way to see the sites from a different perspective and to see both Asian and European sides of Turkey.It's a nice way to relax and enjoy Istanbul without all the haggling from shopkeepers.

2 hr trip was great. We took the 2 hr trip with the municipal ferry boat line. Used our museum card to get 25% off the already reasonable 8TL fee. The boat left at 2:30, and was uncrowded. We bought the audio guide which was ok but could have done without.
A must in Istanbul. Cruising on a chartered boat is a great way to experience this huge city from another perspective. And to get inspired for further studies. Do it, please.

Nice few hours of great sightseeing. Find a reputable boat company to embark....Great way to see all the major sites from water vantage as well as both Europe and Asia sides of city. Inexpensive and pleasant way to tour for an afternoon.

Oxford?. Karadeniz Boğazı to give the gr. Bosphorous (English translation: Oxford) its proper toponym, is serene, vital and interesting. Recommend reading Orhan Pamuk's 'Istanbul: Memories and the City' first, especially his newspaper cuttings on the cars flying into the water. It is peaceful, but can be punctured by bouts of excitement when some ships/boats play chicken with each other. The water is majestic and one feels history without being overwhelmed by it. 1 hr trip? More? Can be. Depends on anyone's itinerary. We did 1 hr but I could happily have travelled longer.
Amazing views. When you visit Bosphorus Striat or stay in restaurants and cafes with view of it , you can imagne how people relax in this busiest city ( Istanbul )
Nice afternoon cruising the river. Youdont need the long tour, pick a 1-2 hr option, is all you need. Watch out for the tour offering you food (its not free).

Book a boat tour. We booked a ride on a ferry, taking us along the river up to the entrance to the Black Sea. Relaxing, and a great view of the city from a different perspective. We stopped long enough to enjoy lunch along the river, then headed back to Istanbul.

cruising on the bosphorus. This is what i needed after a busy day sightseeing, a boat trip on the Bosporous, how could anybody ever get tired with looking at all the traffic on the water, also to be able to view the Asian side and the European side. The fish supper eater under the galata bridge rounded up a very enjoyable holiday.

You do need some 3 hours or so.... Worth the effort to see the summer houses on the banks of this mighty strait. Some remarkable architecture with spectacular views over the Bosphorous. Mainly for the wealthy!

Beautiful boat ride and views. We experienced this sea on our friend's private boat. It was very lovely, relaxing and beautiful. We stopped across the sea at a delicious turkish yogurt shop which was well worth the detour. We then went to Princess Island and spent a couple hours seeing the sights and having a delicious late lunch. This is a must sea (pun intended) when in Istanbul. Well worth the time, and it's very relaxing and scenic too.

Take a boat tour ... this is a must. head down to the port across the road from the spice bazaar and jump on any boat for a cost starting from about $1.50 aus. This will give you an hour and a half n a boat in the waters of asia and Europe and viewing Istanbul from a total different perspective.

1.5 hour tour. We took the hop on/off tour. It was very hard to find. But once we did (and I'm sorry - I can't explain how we eventually found it), it was lovely. We never got off - just enjoyed the ride and views.
great to cruise along. we arrived in Istanbul via a cruise ship. What an introduction this is. Also enjoyed a night dinner cruise which gives a different perspective

Up the river. Oh wow, what an amazing trip. We took a 4 hour tour up to the Bosphorous on a large tour boat. We had a guide who pointed out all the amazing mosque's and old castles. Refreshments were on board and we had coffee etc. No alchol on board. As we were witing for the boat to dock there was a man on a boat selling cooked fish from his boat, really amazing. The people on board were from from all over the world and we found their company very enlightening. The further up the Bospherous you go you can see all the different cultures and check out the amazing houses with their own private boats. A really must do.

An interesting relaxing day. We took a full day tour. We were picked up and dropped off at our hotel, easy! We enjoyed four stops throughout the day:- Maiden's Tower, Ortakoy Mosque, Kucuksu Palace and Poyrazkoy on the Black Sea. At each stop we were given plenty time to absorb the history and ambience. The cruise was very relaxing and you get to see plenty of Istanbul, sailing close to residential areas and passing Rumeli Fortress. Our commentary was excellent too. Lunch was casual, BBQ ed chicken with a Meze plate and drinks, wine could be purchased. At the last stop there was time to swim. We chose to walk around the village but you have to be fit to do so as it is a very steep climb. The Mosque was beautiful as was the Palace, so much history! A memorable day and a different perspective of Istanbul.

A simple Boat Tour. Take one of the large tour boats. Be sure and pick up headphones so you can see and hear what are the significant things as you pass by. Also you might consider sitting outside on the Shadyside of the boat. The larger boats have refreshments but they tend to be a little more expensive. Consider taking your own bottle of water to keep hydrated.
amazing do not miss!. amazing views...great food places near. away from it all! I visited the Ciragan Palace and it was absolutely amazing. you can see the asia said from the Europe side.
Take the boat tour. Narrated boat tour of many of the sites along the Bosphorus river was 12 TL and went by many of the sites of Istanbul

take the cruise. Don't book a special tourist cruise, just jump on the standard one. Cheaper and authentic.very friendly staff and fellow travellers. We whizzed about several times and enjoyed it. Even in November the weather was warm and sunny. Cups of tea kept us going a 1 L per person :)Convenient and cheap - consider it even after the metro goes in!
Massive. We took a boat ride an enjoyed the palaces the tower and the bridge. Refreshing since it was very hot that day. Met very nice people

Fantastic little cruise. As in all river cruises, the best part was it was really quiet and breezy. the trick is to find the right spot on the cruise so you're not in the sun. I think the cruise at sunset would be a better one than in the day.

Do the trip!. When in Istanbul, you can easily do a local ferry trip on the Bosphorus, it really gives one a better sense of this gateway between Asia and Europe. You can also see much of the Bosphorus on a ferry trip to the Princess islands, 1 hour away.

Family Cruise. The cruise we took was a little "shady". We should have shopped around a little more. There weren't enough seats for everyone in the covered area of the boat (and it was cool and raining). I didn't feel that the boat was the safest vessel either. I wish I could remember the name but I can't. I advise you to shop around and maybe get a look at the boat before booking a cruise.

Pleasure cruise. A cool ride on a ferry to see the sites of Istanbul's city harbors is a pleasure on a hot day. The Bosphorus is a working river, with many cargo ships sharing space with ferries and pleasure cruise boats. An excellent time to relax and enjoy a cool breeze and a cold drink.

A must for every istanbul visitor. You have not seen Istanbul, if you do not take a boat ride along the Bosphorus. It is just breathtaking! If you have time, take the big ride that goes all the way to the opening of black sea. But there are pleanty of choices.....from just a shortt tour that lasts an hour, to hop on hop off tours where you can visit some historical palaces, to dinner tours in the evening. Just ask your hotel reception what is being offered at the time of the year. Just do not miss a boat ride along the strait.

Bosphorus Strait. Both my hotels looked over this area and I did take a boat trip of about one and a half hours on the Bosphorus. Surprisingly, it was really enjoyable although the boat became quite crowded.A good photograph opportunity, and a way of seeing parts of Istanbul from the water.

Beautiful and cheap..... It's 4 Lire ($2) to get on a water ferry.... Hop on and go to Asia, get a sandwich and walk around and go back.... Very easy if you have the Istanbul Card, well marked and everyone was helpful.... Takes maybe 10 minutes to cross... There are lots of people pushing the Bosphorus Tour which is 40 lire ($20) for all day hop on and hop off water travel... We didn't do it but I saw the boats... I think it would be worth it. IMHO.

Bridge across forever. Imagine being at the crossroads of the East and the West, and at the hub of the city's commerce. Whichever way you choose to do it, a cruise down the Bosphorous is a must-do. We did a night cruise and were rewarded with a burst of fireworks as we passed under the bridge! Remember, whatever they say, it's first come first served on board, so make sure you charge ahead on deck to grab your seats.
Beautiful city views. Took a night tour under multiple bridges, saw great mosques, castles and lots of exciting things. If you like being on the water, this is a must!

Boat Cruise. we took the cruise up the Bosphorus and took some good photos from the water of the City - the trip takes over 2 hours and goes as far as the Eastern side and bridge - a little long but enjoyable - dont get tricked into thinking it is a seated ticket - its first come first served on the boat and a long walk from the ticket desk near Hafia Sophia

Use the ferries. We were besieged by polite requests to book a Bosphorus cruise but a more flexible and authentic way to see the strait is to use an Istanbulkart and any one of a number of ferries. Very cheap with wonderful views of Topkapi, Blue Mosque and Galata Tower

Take a ferry!. We loved riding the ferries across the Strait with views of both sides of Istanbul. Worth doing for a relaxing time and rest from all the walking. You can use the IstanbulKart Transit pass for paying all ferry tariffs.
Must do. simply take a ferry from eminou and you will see the city in a different way - this is an inexpensive way to travel on the bosphorous
Cruise of a lifetime!. A cruise on Bosphoros is almost like a tour of the whole city! It is one of the best cruises you would ever embark on... totally worth it!

A Great Boat Ride. We took the 2 hour boat ride and it was a wonderful trip. Just seeing the buildings and such as you cruise along is worth the price of the trip. Lots of ships of all kinds out on the water and you get a good sense of how busy and important this port is.

Cruise trip. Travelled on a cruise to Istanbul up the Bosphorus.The approach to Istanbul is out of this world!. The sun shining off the domes of countless mosques and the constant excitement of river traffic.

The beautiful border between Europe and Asia. This strait has been open since the great flood (which filled up the Black Sea. Istanbul is on both sides. There are bridges and ferries to take across, or take to view all the palaces on its shores.
Catch a boat for about 10euros. 2 hour boat ride for 10euros. great time to sit and relax whilst taking in the views. Your between 2 countries at once!

So quiet, with warm breezes and bridges lights... Located at the border between Europe and Asia, Bosphorus strait defines Istanbul.. makes it be what it really is... If you are there, don't miss taking a tour of the strait by boat.. There are many options.. Cruises or the tours offered by Turyol.. In the night, a cruise is just amazing... In my opinion, it's a must-do in Istanbul!
Busy, Busy, Busy. The Strait is full of all kinds of action. Great for just sitting and watching all types of boats, etc. float on by. A great waterway to transfer through to Asia/Europe.

Take the 2-hour cruise to admire the old city architecture. What kind of trip to Istanbul would not include the cruise over Bosphorus Stait, the main artery of the city? The water is deep and amazingly clean given the amount of traffic, tons of ships of various sizes make their way around, the sun is high, the wind is gentle, and your lungs are taking in the freshest air possible. Some boats also provide dinner and entertainment on the Bosphorus cruises, but we prefer the regular daytime hop on-hop off cruises.

TREAT. The trip along the Bosphorus gives a real good overview of the history and the outlay and critical places to be visited. I will start with this if I was a new visitor. The trip is affordable also for the normal traveler. The historical knowledge conveyed and the area covered exceeds the price paid in reward. You do not get to realize or note some of the important the palaces without being part of this trip.

Cruise. We recently visited Istanbul and the highlight of the trip was a cruise on the Bosphorus, we took a boat to Kadikoy on the Asian side and from there we took the cruise, it was wonderful and must not be missed if you visit East meets West.
Gorgeous and enchanting!. We did a boat ride on the Bosphorus and we loved it. Different than what you usually see in other big cities with the big freight ships cruising by!

Must do!. You should definitely walk through bogaz , the joy you will have will depend on where you walk. In every side or district you go, you can go the the sea part and walk through, locals do their regular walk for sports or pleasure generally around areas where they live, most popular touristic places are ortaköy (be careful look at the menus before having a seat by the seashore)

ships. If you are a ship watcher this is the place to be, lots of ferries and day cruising ships to spend time on , i even saw a russian sub going through the straits to the agean sea, you can walk across the straits over bridges or take a tram or boat, lots of fish restaurants etc

Worth to visit. I think one of the best experience in Istanbul cruising in Bosphorus Strait .in one or 2 hour you can visit most of Istanbul's attraction in a glance !! go to it in night and feel the coolness of environment.it was relaxing for me . if you be kind of person like to participate in group dancing and eating and drinking you can find some of tours especially for this.

Take the Ortakoy tour. Take the tour from Ortakoy which leaves by the dock on the left side of the mosque, every hour! It's affordable, and a lovely 1 hour boat ride from bridge to bridge. Tea is served. You won't regret it :) I go every year, and look forward to it.

Scenic cruise. As we had limited time in Istanbul, this was one way to see the Strait & its sights quickly. We travelled late afternoon which made for lovely sightseeing on the return journey at dusk, with the city lights. Recommended, a good trip for the price.

History and relaxation. What a beautiful way to spend a couple of hours! This boat ride was memorable as landmarks lined the banks and seeing both Asia and Europe in one sitting is also unique! History and relaxation mixed into one.

great 2 hour boat trip. if you get the chance take a boat trip on the Bosphorus and view Istanbul from a different perspective.Boats leave around 1pm for a 2 hour round trip which is relaxing and informative with a commentry.

Okay but you could see almost all you needed to on the Ferry to the Asian side. Realistically this is a very heavily promoted tour but it is all seen from far away and although it is interesting it is too quick and you miss a lot. Some of the properties along the Bosphorus straight are very expensive and some expansive. I personally wouldn't want to stay along it in a hotel. It is something that is worth doing should you wish to orient yourself during your stay in Istanbul.

Beautiful views. We follow a very good advice from tripadvisor comment and took the Tyrol boat, same price as Sehir Hatlari, but a boat leaves every hour. In 1,5h you can see all views of Istanbul attractions and also the beautiful shore and great houses on both sides of the strait.
nice trip. a nice slow boat trip up the straight to the under the Bosphorus bridge and up to the second suspension bridge about 2 1/2 hrs

Must do!. Did a 2 hour (10 lira I think) cruise up and back on the Bosphorus. It was really pretty watching the coastline go by, seeing even more ancient buildings, the mosques from a distance and the Istanbul skyline(s) - both sides. Definitely a nice place to be on a stinking hot day! I am glad that I didn't do the long 6 hour cruises however as I was a little pressed for time. Seeing it at this price was a great way to tick the box and not blow the balance :)

Busy waterway. I love ships so what a great place to see ships of all types and sizes ply the treacherous Strait. Next trip I will schedule a day cruise and see the whole Strait from Med to Black Sea.

A jewel in Istanbul's crown........ A trip on the Bosphorus is a welcome change from the hustle and bustle of the tourist attractions. You can take a public boat for 5 Turkish lira each way and the boat stops at 4 different islands located in the Bosphorus. The last island is called the "big" Island and there are several beaches you can spend the day at for a cost of between 15-25 lira. The island can also be explored by hiring bikes or in horse drawn carriages and was so unexpected to find this in istanbul. A wonderful experience and I would definitely recommend this to anyone visiting. The boat trip takes about 1.5 hours each way to the big island and approx 45 minutes to the first island.

Take a boat ride. The Bosphorus cleaves Istanbul in twain and separates Europe from Asia. Take a boat ride up and down this beautiful waterway and view cargo ships passing to and from Black Sea ports. You might even see a Russian warship heading out to the Mediterranean. Even more interesting to many will be sights along the shores of both continents. Among those will be the great Rumeli fortress built by Sultan Mehmed II on the European side in support of his successful campaign to conquer Constantinople in 1453. You'll also see the great modern bridges that now span the Bosphorus and connect the two continents and the two sides of Istanbul. Overall, you'll have a great time. Go for it.

A must do!. If you are in Istanbul, this is a must do. I wouldn't recommend taking one of the cruises, a 10 Lira boat or ferry is more than adequate. If you take the ferry you'll be able to get off at some points, walk and have a bite/beer. If you take a cruise, keep in mind that they don't stop (unless you book a ridiculously expensive one, 30 euros) bring some snacks and drinks (they don't sell beer!).I recommend you simply arrive at the galata bridge (on the side where the spice market is) and check out what the boat options are, there are plenty to choose from, we paid 10 liras each for a two hour trip. Enjoy!
Family holiday. Cruise in what ever form is a must. The houses, old palaces, the bridges and the forts are well worth seeing. The city goes on and on and is a must see from the water.

One of highlight of the trip. You have to take a cruise on the Bosphorus Strait when visiting Istanbul. The scenic cruise goes past beautiful buildings, diverse waterfront, luxury developments, a few bridges. Definitely one of the nicer short cruises, with a great view to enjoy.

Water way between continents. Flanked by Europe and Asian continents its well worth a cruise down the Bosphorus .
Some of the private homes are spectacular as is the mix in old and new buildings plus the Mosques and minarets make thios city unique. The fact that is straddles 2 continents is extra special .
Nice way to end a day of touring. A relaxing way to see different areas of Istanbul and what you might like to visit after passing by.

Phenomenal.. If you visit Istanbul you have to take a cruise on the Bosphorus Strait. It take approximately 2 hours and is very touristy. I did the sundown cruise. You are going to see many palaces and other sights. Loved it a must see when in Istanbul.
the trip is wonderful. never miss it... the cruise along the bosphorus is a unique experiment, seeing the different parts of istanbul from water.

Worth the trip. I did the full day cruise from Kobatas to a palace and fortress on European side and then stop on the Asian side at the Black Sea for a swim in the afternoon - the views from the straits are beautiful and worth at least a short ferry ride if not the full day!
Boat Trip. Take a boat down the river Bosphorus to truly appreciate the diverse and beautiful buildings that make up Istanbul
took the short cruise. We took the short cruise, private ship, that goes to the second bridge. Definitely buy the tea from the hawker, it's delicious!

Just wonderful. You can do all kinds of cruises for all kinds of time periods. We did one for about 2.5 hours and it was just right for us....went up the Golden Horn past the Galata Beidge and up past the two bridges on the Bosphorus.... The guide was informative and we really enjoyed it...cost about ten dollars each

Interesting but don't expect too much. Took our lead from Tripadvisor and stuck to the 1.5 hour trip. It was along enough and got a taste of the sights along the Bosphorous. I would urge anyone going to Istanbul to do the trip - your choice how long as it is really part of the tourist "package". We used Turyol on recommendation of our hotel - a couple of Lira more at 12 Lira but boats apparently are bigger and wallow less in the straights. Who Knows but they were efficient and did the job for us
Don't miss. Could spend days watching life pass by ... Wonderful to see life on and around the strait enjoying watching locals and tourists enjoying themselves.

Bosporus Strait. A nice boat trip that will give a view of Istanbul from the Bosporus Strait with the exclusive homes and establishments. The length of the city of Istanbul is 120 Km long and 50 Km wide. The population of the city is about 20 million.
a lovely river cruise. We took a 90 minute cruise from Kabatas up to Fatih Bridge - a must do on any trip to Istanbul, with beautiful views on both the European and Asian sides

Boat tour to Prince's Islands. It is well worth spending the money to take the boat tour to the Prince's islands. The view of the Bosphorus is absolutely gorgeous and being on the water was incredibly relaxing. There was a little time for sight seeing on the islands and it was possible to ride in a horse drawn carriage as well. Lunch was served on the boat, when returning from the islands. I had taken a cane, and it was a little tricky to embark and disembark from the boat at some of the ports, but peope were very helpful. It required climbing a narrow staircase to reach the upper deck of the ship. There were people from all around the world on the tour, including families with young infants and young children. The tour was beautiful, fun, extremely relaxing and very memorable.

take a boat trip along the Bosphorous. The ferry boat rides are cheap and last about an hour to the end of the Bosphorous to a small fishing village that has many fish restaurants of excellent quality. I would recommend the boat trip for the sights enrolee and then I would eat at one of the restaurants and return to Istanbul some hours later. A great day out.

Cruising the Bosphorus Strait. Our family enjoyed our 90 minute cruise on the Bosphorus. The experience was significantly enhanced by our private guide. I pre-arranged our guide a few weeks prior to our visit to Istanbul, and he was well worth the cost of $200 US per day. The cost for the Bosphorus cruise was insignificant, just a few dollars per person, and the taxi took us to the Asia side of Istanbul. The guide pointed out significant buildings, bridges, Ataturk's private yacht, museums, and gave historical notes. During the ferry ride, the servers bring around Turkish tea (1 lira each) and inexpensive snacks (also around 1 lira each). After the cruise, I would recommend eating fish sandwiches at the floating restaurant, just a few lira for a delicious local fare.

Beautiful!. If the weather is good, and you have a good guide like we did to point out the various buildings, it's an informative and relaxing trip. It gives you a different view of Istanbul than you'll see in the city as the Bosphorus is lined with mansions, some castles, and other beautiful buildings.

Plying the Bosphorus. Took a ferry over to the Asian side of town, just to say I got to be on the Bosphorus. Took a walk among the shops and restaurants there, then came back, in the midst of a thunder storm-exciting and dramatic!

Really can't miss it anywhere in Istanbul. If you are in the city chances are you will be along the Bhosphorus Straight at somepoint during your trip. I would suggest taking a Bhosphours cruise to get a nice view of the city. The water there is such a nice blue color.There are also many water taxis that take you to many points along the Bhosphorus.

Relaxing away from the hustle of Istanbul. We chose to do the hop on hop off Bosphorus cruise starting from Kabatas tram station. This was about a 2 hour round trip for 15tl and allowed you to hop off at any of the stops and catch the next ferry. This was much cheaper than other Bosphorus cruises and did not eat into the day.

Recommended!. We chartered a boat for our group to really soak up this site. A good couple of hours were spent on the boat sipping hot apple tea and marveling at this body of water and the architecture on both sides. Definitely add this to your list of experiences.
cold and wonderful at xmas. this area is completely interesting with plenty to see and understand with all historically changements since a long time religous andothers

A lovely boat rip. We took a boat trip up the Bospherous to the Black Sea, with lunch included. it was well worth doing, and we had a wonderful day out, seeing all the wonderful houses and scenery up the Bospherous.
Nice way to rest your tired feet. We found the "public" tour boat. Great value for the 2 hour cruise. (one intermediate stop). Buy the audio guide to enhance and explain the sites.

A beautiful waterway. We were with friends and rented a boat for a couple of hour ride up the strait. Great sightseeing from the water and an lovely way to end the day. The boat dropped us off at a lovely sea food restaurant right on the water, so many to chose from.We also took a ferry to the asian side the next day. So many great views of this city from the water.
wonderfull. a great attraction in the wrong country, this phenomenal geographic treasure should belong to a european country, too bad

Excellent cruise. We booked the full day cruise, which was actually a 2 hr tour and tasting at the Spice Market and a mosque. Then, it was off for the 2 hr cruise. Very informative - if the weather is right! Then we went to an included lunch on the Asia side, so much food at the highest point at a posh restaurant. Then more of a city tour. All in all 5 star. Note: everything in Istanbul is negotiable. Reflecting on the tour, it was worth the lunch and full day. Negotiate for it!

What a wonderful place to sit and take in the world!. This strait is simply awesome. Dividing Europe from Asia. Watching the activity of the cargo ships, the multitude of yachts. Strolling along the parkways and people watching. A great place to while away the day and evening with all the bright lights and the light show on the bridges spanning the Bosphorus. Amazing!

Try to go when the weather is good. We took a boat tour for a couple of hours, one of the best I did in Istanbul. We bough some food and drinks on the pier, but you can also get it on the boat. If the weather is good, THEN THIS IS A MUST.

Take a six-hour tour!. We really enjoyed the boat tour. At 10:00 from Eminonu Pier we went to the Black Sea. It was a pleasant relaxation. Then we landed for an our-two in the coastal village. We went up to the hill with the ruins of an ancient fortress, then had dinner in the coastal fish restaurant, and then again on our boat went back to Eminonu.

Do It Yourself. No city can be seen better than from the water and you get a real sense of Istanbul from the water not to mention great photos.Each round trip tour takes up to 2 hours but usually around 90 minutes. Tour operators charge around €33 per person but you can do this for yourself for around 15 Turkish Lira person a fraction of the price. Just go down to the port where there are literally dozens of boats don't worry about language barriers just hand over your money and climb on board. Closest metro station to the boats if Halich or something similar. Don't be ripped off by the tour operators. None of the boats serve alcohol

Excellent and relaxing way to view the sites. We decided to see Istanbul from the Bosphorus, and we definitely do not regret it. We chose to do the locally offered cruise (we saved money for the same thing offered by sales people on the street). The cruise that we did lasted for 3 hours, and was well worth it. It was nice to see the sites from the waterway, and great way to snap some wonderful pictures. The cruise wasn't too crowded, and finding a seat near the railing was easy. It was also nice to see different parts of the city than the area we were staying in.

Afternoon ''cruise. 'Booked' this little jaunt through the hotel. Picked up on time and delivered to the ship. The commentary given by the young lady was well delivered and informative. Food and service by staff was good. Downside greedy passengers wasting food.

Go on your own. I did a Bosphorus boat tour with a group, but could have saved time and money if I did it on my own. The tour guide did point out sites on the shores to us, but there was a recorded speaker on the boat that provided the same information. I was hoping to get to see the Black Sea, but was bummed that the boat turned around a few km before we got there. Also, when we disembarked the boat we took a minibus back to the center of Sultanahamet. It took an hour in traffic, but would have only taken 10-15 minutes either walking or on the tram.

Lazy way to pass the day. A half-day trip on the boat was perfect for me. Just enough time to recover after some hectic sightseeing in the city. Perfect R&R opportunity while taking in the spectacular views. Loved the fact that I got to swim in the Black Sea!

Take a tour. You should definitely take a ferry or a private tour around the Strait, that way you can see much of the City on a go... The bridge itself is magnificent, especially at night when it's lit up... Take some time, go to Kabatas, have a tea by the Dolmabahce, by the sea while resting your eyes on a glorious Istanbul...

Boat trip. Definitely worth a trip on a boat. Lots of boats to choose from at reasonable prices. We took a 2 hour round trip 12 lira (£3.50). Downstream for about 75 mins with lots of views of palaces, mosques, bridges, hotels, etc.Gives you an impression of just how large and spread out the city and it's surroundings are. You come back a bit quicker to arrive back where you started 2 hours earlier.You can see the bridge that links Asia with Europe - you go down the Euro side and back up the Asia side,Lots of other trips and ferries to catch.The strait is probably the busiest stretch of water we have seen, with a constant stream of vehicles, big & small. In any 5 minute viewing period you can easily see over 200 vessels going back & forth, from massive ocean liners to small 2 people crafts, as well as hundreds of tourist boats.Well worth a boat trip or just sit down and watch the mayhem!

dont go cheap.. we went for a cheap no-name brand tour. 15 Lira pp. sold to us on the boardwalk at Sirkeci.boat trip was 90 minutes, from town to the 2nd Fatih Sultan Mehmet bridge, and back.no commentary at all on the boat, which made the experience extremely dull. we should have spent a bit more and gone for a luxury cruise.

the place to escape to on a hot day - or anytime. many options to ferry / cruisego to the departure point of your choice and buy the ticket there - a scalper charges u EURO 20! the ticket a the ticket office is 15 TL

Cruise along the Bosphorus. I had an excellent trip along the Bosphorus river in December 2012 and again in December 2013,excellent view of Istanbul from the vessel, which also served very good Fish menu along with Turkish wine etc. Over all the trip is worth against the money paid.

Istanbul visit. We just took one of the normal Boats across the Bosphorus,the ride was over half an hour to the so called Asian side of Istanbul.It was an interesting trip and see lots of this amazing City from the Boat,The ride back was much shorter.

Exciting ferry trip. Take ferries from emininou terminal and visit Harem with its barracks and Florence nightingale museum or Uskudar with its cafes. Both on Asian side. Tickets only 3 tl each way and the skyline of old city stunning especially at dusk.

Definitely take a Cruise. If ever there was a place to spend an hour cruising with really interesting things to see, then this must be tops. We were lucky to have a mid-afternoon tour in beautiful sunshine and the city was looking its very best, with palaces and interesting places all along the shoreline of both the European and Asian sides. Plenty to see and definitely worth it.

A good walk. If you fancy a long walk with kids after a long flight this is a nice place to do it. There are ships to see for the kids and if they run ahead of you you can see them. Apart for when you reach one of the boat terminals then it gets crazy. The sound of the water is very soothing for me.

cruise the waters of history. Firstly take the 'big bus' to get an idea of the city and the waterways and bridges and the location of the quay. Then take a normal ferry to anywhere, sit back and enjoy the experience - a great way to get the true feel of the city - Enjoy

Great!. This is just a nice thing to do in Istanbul. If you drive through the bridge you will see the sign entering asia/enteing Europe. Can take local ferries or do a private tour aroung the harbor. It is just beautiful!
Worth a half day. Join the parade of tour boats as the travel north on the Bosphorus, up the west side, down the east side. A nice break from the hectic city sights.

Great way to see the sights. We haggled with the many operators offering Bosphorus tours and went on a boat for 10TL. It wasn't the most luxurious boat but it was definitely worthwhile doing for 90mins we got to see many of the sights along the coast and there were many palaces by the sea. Great way to rest and get some sea breeze in the summer heat.

Busy waterway. Take a boat tour of Istanbul and you see the beautiful homes, embassies, castles and mosques. Go under 2 huge bridges and see all shapes and sizes of boats all going somewhere. This gives a unique view of the city that brings Europe and Asia together.

Beautiful place and eye therapy. A very beautiful place to see, walk , the scenery is really magical and with the two sides of Istanbul and all kind sod ships around. A ship trip to Asia side of Istanbul is availbe and it is so cool. Near the post, there's is a couple of restaurants and coffee shops, the food is soo cool. We loved it

Sights of Istanbul via ferry up the Bospherus. Great way to see another view and side of Turkey, by ferry. We were warned that the specially marked Bosphorous cruises were over priced and a little to kitch and to try and catch a ferry that locals would use, think Star Ferry over to Kowloon side. We found this in the form of Sehir Hatlari ferries. When coming over the Galata Bridge from Galata, it is the first dock on your left beside the Galata Bridge. 12 TL gets you a return 2-hour cruise and it goes a decent way up past the second large bridge up the Bosphorous. We found this to be ample and enough to see a great vista and taste of Istanbul. We were advised that the full 90-minute each way longer tour is a waste as the town they drop you off at for 3-hours for lunch doesn't warrant a 3-hour stopover, so for time pressed travellers it is a full day away on a cruise. Whereas 2-hours was just enough time for us. We understand that the locals who stand on the harbour and entice you to do a private cruise, have a job to do and probably provide a different standard of service. But we were happy with our cruise. The surprise for us came on the return leg when the ferry docked at Ortakoy, which we didn't know it would and was letting people off. It looked like a nice port and so we too got off. We had wanted to head to the Four Seasons for a drink on the river and knew it was nearby, so it was a great way to round of the day sipping cocktails in their lovely surrounds. Four Seasons is about a 20-minute stroll south. But Ortakoy itself has no shortage of bars and cafes by the water.

Ferry on the Bosphorus. My husband and I took the ferry for two hours and found it to be interesting as well as a good rest from nonstop touring. Seeing the grand house and the palace from the water is most enjoyable.

Ferry nice. We opted to take the public ferry across the Bophorus from Kadiköy to Eminönü. Okay, we didn’t get the commentary but the ferries were far more frequent, less touristy and way cheaper and still gave decent photo opportunities. Other public ferries are available if you wanted to explore further upstream. Only complaint was there were no signs to say you were entering / leaving Europe / Asia!

Take a boat ride.... Get on a 2 hour day trip ride on the Bosphorous while you are in Istanbul to see lots of locals doing the same thing and to get a bird's eye view of all there is to see in this lovely city.

Yes! Do a river cruise!. What a great way to see this city! There are so many beautiful houses, Mosques, castles, and grand palaces that you would miss if you didn't see them this way. It really helps to get an idea of the actual size of Istanbul.i found it a relaxing way to get away from the crazy traffic and just sight see. It was fun to stop on the Asia side and taste the local yoghurt they are famous for.

Take a cruise. We took a cruise organized by our hotel. It was a great way to see both the Europe and Asia sides of Istanbul. The place is so huge. The bridges that span the two continents are so "WOW."

Europe on one side and Asia on the other - Unique. Its an hour long cruise with a scenic view of both the East and the West. Turkey sits between two continents, and the architecture is quite different on both sides of the strait. We were a group and hired Dorak Holdings to give us a guide,- Ufuk. He was super in going into details about each and every thing we cruised along. Hired a boat only for us 12 people, though it could have taken more. Very relaxing.. we kept it for the last day just before taking the flight back home.
Attractive boat ride. Take one of the round trips from the Kabatas piers - it gives you a view of the lower end of the Bosphoros with a sight of some of the palaces and mansions built on the bank.
Exciting. This place makes you feel fresh and rich culturwise. Historic area that connects 2 worlds.It|s a must-see if you visit Istanbul.

Worth a Day. The Bosphorus is the life blood of Istanbul. Take either the public ferry or the Hop-On-Hop-Off ferry to fully enjoy it. I would suggest leaving it until the end of your visit, or when you have had enough with the museums. Relax and enjoy the scenery. It's spectacular!

Great experience. This was a great experience, but try not to do the public ferry. The travel agencies (we used Vantage) have smaller boats that aren't near as crowded and it is worth whatever the difference in the price, believe me. Tour lasted 1.5 hours.

Private Boat tour. We had a private 2 hour boat tour of the Bosphorous arranged by our tour company - sophistacated travel. Our boat was very nice and comfortable. It was a blue yacht. The company had several others in the water. I am not sure about costs but this appeared to be preferable to the public boat tours with the sticky plastic chairs. We took a public boat to Prince's island which was perfect.

Crusing through is the way to go..... Experiencing Instanbul from the water, versus the land, is the way to go! And sailing from the Aegean Sea up through the Dardanelles, into the Bosphorus and then up to the Black Sea was a wonderful experience!

Fun Boat Adventure. We spent an afternoon cruising up the Bosphorus Strait to the Black Sea. Our hotel arranged the cruise and for 35 Euro we got transportation between our hotel and the port, lunch and a four hour guided cruise. The tour guide was licensed and very knowledgeable. A great way to spend an afternoon in Istanbul, particularly if you are traveling with children.

Loved the Bosphorus Cruise. Warning, you will be overrun in Istanbul by people selling you Bosphorus Cruises (no exaggeration) and a rip-off as well! We followed the TripAdvisor recommendation and took the Sehir Hatlari (government owned yellow/black logo) from Eminonu (just get off the tram and its right there) - short cruise 2 hours for 10 TL. It was a bargain and the cruise really gives you a great perspective of where everything is. The winter times (until 1 June) were 13h00, 14h30 and 15h30. We also took the other TripAdvisor recommendation and went to the loo before going in the cruise! One other thing is that the other cruise company boats generally look a little more shabby and are very small so not as steady.It is also really close to other attractions like Galata Bridge (fish sandwiches) and Spice Bazaar so a very central tourist location.

The 10L boat trips are good but there's a great walk too. There are loads of cruises that go from near the old bridge and cost you 10TL for an hour or two. Wrap up warm even in Summer! It can get a bit chilly. Also it's well worth doing this if you have time. If you go past the Istanbul Modern Museum in the direction away from the bridge to the Sultenahmed district after about 10-15 minutes you will get to a park and a strip of cafes and street vendors on the strait. It's a great place to relax and buy a really tasty fresh fish sandwich for only 6TL.

Little pricey but worth it.. At 25 lira for what is at most a boat taxi ride up and down the bosphorous its a little expensive but the ride is nice and it gives good views of some of the palaces that lie on the banks, a 25tl ticket gets you an outbound and return trip regardless of which stop you get off so i recommend staying on the boat until the last stop which is just short of the black sea as it doesn't take too long and has great places to eat.

Yes it is a major waterway but not a standout. We caught the ferry near galatay bridge. 25 to each to anadolu kavagi and return . Trip is interesting if a bit long and it is a great waterway but not a standout. Anadolu kavagi was nice to have waterside fresh fish lunch and climb to the castle above what's great views ad bar/coffe shops.

Wonderful views. We went on a 2hr cruise from the New Mosque area up to Fatih Sultan Mehmet Bridge,just past Rumeli Fortress on the European side & came back along the Asian side. A very well spoken English speaking guide talked throughout the trip, which could be heard all over the boat. There were 2 decks, the lower deck was enclosed & the upper deck open, with a cafeteria as well. The photo opportunities were never ending with all the beautiful palaces, mosques, castles, bridges & grand hotels that we passed. Fantastic views of the Dolmabahce Palace, the Ciragan Palace (now a grand hotel), the Ortakoy Camii Mosque & Rumeli Fortress. Apart from these places there were the most gorgeous river side houses, some of the most expensive real estate in the world!
A beautiful area. We had a couple of hours cruising this area and seeing the city from the river is amazing. A must do.

Take a private yacht tour. We took a 2 hour private yacht tour with a group of 12 and it gave us a great overview of Istanbul. The homes on the waterfront were interesting and it showed me the beauty of Istanbul that had been lacking in my previous tour.

take the public ferry. The ferry ride is comfortable and a quarter of the price. No PA system blasting you in multiple languages either.Take most of the day to the end of the line, have an icecream or lunch, and then a beautiful ride home.

Always beautiful and interesting. Bosphorus is one of the main foundations of Istanbul that makes this city so likeable and interesting
Best is to catch a boat tour and go between the quaint villages nestled in Europe and Asia

Take a tour, but don't take all day. Taking a tour of the Bosphorus Strait is definitely cool, seeing both the European and Asian sides of Istanbul is interesting. However, the trip that we took left us 3 hours in the Asian side with hardly anything to do! After checking out a nearby castle and some views of the Black Sea, we were bored within the first hour! A tour of the Bosphorus without stopping for hours probably would have been better, and left us with more time to see other things elsewhere.

Asia/Europe. The Bosphorus is the 32 km long north-south strait that joins the Sea of Marmara with the Black Sea in Istanbul, and separates the continents of Europe and Asia. It runs right through the heart of Istanbul, past the Istanbul Modern Art Museum, several Ottoman palaces, at least two fortresses, forested hills, and shore villages with Ottoman architecture. A cruise on the beautiful waters is the best way to see all this and absorb the story that is The Bosporus.

It could be breezy. We were on Bosphorus Strait boat tour at the beginning of May. It was cloudy and breezy day. Most of the people were not dressed for the occasion and had to spent all the tour inside the boat. Only a few had s warm gears and enjoyed the tour from an open deck.

Just Do It.... This is a really nice boat trip to do in your trip to Istanbul. You have several sailing options from boat tours, to private to takings a normal ferry. But if there is something that you can't miss is feeling the wind of the Bosphorus in you face. Thats unique.What I recommend is taking a return trip with a ferry to the asian part, spend sometime there and come back. You would do two things for the price of one. Go and enjoy!!!

Skip the tour, take the ferry. We took the ferry to Asia in the morning on accident, 30 minute cruise there, and 30 min back. Only cost 3L each ($1.50), We than took the Boshporus short cruise in the afternoon for 10L each ($5). Looking back the 30 min ferry ride would have been enough, but both were quite nice.Avoid the folks on the street trying to sell you a tour, just go straight to the Şehir Hatları booths.

Take a boat ride. A ride down the river leaves you feeling the ime3nse size and grandeur of the city as it is so spread out not to mention the palaces and mosques you pass and the bridges and the Turkish flag flying in the wind everywhere.

Good but too long. The cruise was excellent to begin with, it is a fast track tour of all the sights and attractions along the Bosphorus. But beyond a point it just gets boring as it was too long. The cruise was rather crowded and the restrooms were not very well maintained.

Half day golden horn and bosphorus. We did a half day tour on the golden horn and bosphorus. It was great and very relaxing. Beware of the booze cruise (they are the one who sell their ticket very cheap) we saw some with very loud music and loads of people on the boat. We did the cruise with senkron travel agency, they picked us up on time, were friendly, buffet was ok, lot of people on the boat but not too much and no loud music.We stop at anadolu which is supposed to be a fisherman village... more of a tourist trap to me. Nothing compare to Kalekoy when you do kekova tours in Kas. We didn't like the village, but loved the cruise.You NEED to do the bosphorus while in Istanbul!

Relaxing Afternoon Activity. A Bosphorus cruise is the perfect way to unwind after spending the morning going from one historical site to the next. Don't fall for the hawkers selling you 15 euro tickets - stick with Sehir Hatlari. They're the official ferry operators and a 2 hour cruise costs only 10 TL. The ferry was huge with plenty of seating available (for the best views, get a seat away from portside). There isn't anything dramatic about the sights but it is quite lovely to watch people go about their lives on the shore and to admire Istanbul's old and new architecture.

Great views, great fun. 6 of us took a guide and private tour on the Bosphorus for one morning to learn more about the history of Istanbul, view the city on the Asian and European shores and look at the beautiful buildings from the water. Fabulous.
Nice trip. This was a good 2hour short trip up and down the bosphorus any longer we would have been bored. Only cost 10lira each roughly £3 via the government boats

Cruise the Strait. The are a number of tours on the Bosphorus, some expensive and some very economical. We did not take a guided tour and just wanted to see the sites. You can catch a boat in Eminonu area for 10 TL and the trip is about 1 1/2 hours. It is well worth the time.
Half day to Black Sea. yeah, it was good but we were advised to take swimming kit only to be told when we got to the Black Sea that it was too cold ... on the plus side we did see lots of dolphins.

Relaxing cruise away from the city noise!. We took a Bosphorus cruise all the way to the last stop and back. At the end of the strait, there is a Roman ruin which you can explore on foot. They give you 3 hours to do so and have a lunch there. The ruin sits on top of a hill and there are a few restaurants up there. If you would like a lunch with a view, that is where you want to go. Nice to overlook Black Sea from the ruin. The cruise is relaxing away from the city noise. It is highly recommended.

Symbolic value. Like the timeline in Greenwhich, this has a sort of symbolic value of dividing Europe and Asia, prompting questions about Turkey's place in Europe. We opted to walk over the river and though it was actually very hot at the time of day, it was great fun. Might be nice to try at night.

Great view of the city. This is a great way to see both the European side as well as the Asian side. It's a good 1 1/2 hr boat cruise and listening to the history from the tour guides. You can easily book the tour for this, most tours offers the same city options for the same price.

A must for all!. The bosphorus is the water body that separates Europe and Asia, it is also the usp of Istanbul, making it the only city to lie amidst 2 continents. Beautiful view and wonderful winds...

Private evening motor cruise. We booked a motor boat cruise and on our evening, the Bosporus water and wind were strong and somewhat choppy and cool. It is worth doing to see the fortifications and view most travelers saw before the bridges and tunnels were built across. The channel is both deep and wide and you do feel you are crossing continents even though the Asian side is primarily residential.

the unforgettable strip of water--the bhosphorus strait. you just HAVE to see this lovely water body-its unforgettable--the clear water, the cool breeze...a cruise in this area is a must.you must hop on and hop off at each stop and explore--the food, the sights, the environment.and when you pass under one of the bridges--its like you are part of history.to feel that you are in between two different continents.i was so very excited!!

Ferry ride up the Bosporus. This is a terrific way to see the sites along the shores on both sides. Cruise past the old forts that guarded the strait, very the old palaces, Kempinski palace which is now a hotel and the most expensive on in Europe. However, dine at the hotel by the Bosporus and enjoy their Turkish buffet. About 190 euros per person. Don't miss this boat ride, you'll see sites that you would miss on foot or in a car
Boat Tour. Great choice of stops and lovely trip to the Black Sea. We were too early in the year to swim....some did but the water was really freezing.

Istanbul from the Bosphorous. We bought our tickets for the boat cruise from a street agent near our hotel and had to find our way to meet another agent near the Hippodrome. There wasn't a clearly marked kiosk to look for. We just had to keep asking until we found the agent. From there we walked with a group to where the boat was. The cruise was guided to some extent. It was very interesting to see Istanbul from the water. Drinks & snacks were available on board. The tour was approx two hours which was a little too long.

A Marvelous Experience. For anyone visiting Istanbul, a cruise on Bosphorus strait is a must. We were fortunate to enjoy two such cruises - a morning cruise and an evening dinner dance cruise. Both experiences were memorable. Because of its long history, both sides of the Bosphorus strait are full of immaculate constructions. Beautiful residences coexist with palaces and ultramodern skyscrapers. Because of hilly terrain along the coast, one can see all the marvelous constructions along the entire hillside clearly, while cruising near the shore. The view of beautiful blue water dotted with myriads of cruise boats and ships was spectacular. At night, the view is almost surrealistic, with gleaming light emanating from the buildings. It seemed to me like millions and millions of gems on display along the entire coast. We enjoyed a mild and very pleasant weather during our evening sojourn and soaked in the view from the deck of the cruise boat. I strongly urge my fellow travellers not to miss this experience of cruising on Bosphorus strait.
Wonderful way to see the city and skyline. The tourist boat was a great way to see the city and to get a little bit of a sea breeze and coolness. Highly recommended.

Stunning views and amazing history. Bosphorus is where Asia meets Europe. The views here are simply breathtaking! You can't miss Bosphorus. It depends what sort of trip you are on and what sort of personality you have. If you are the romantic type or you are on a honeymoon, you would like to spend at least 2 hours here just sitting down and relaxing!

The amazing touch of Istanbul. The Bosphorus is a very important part of any trip to Istanbul due to its sheer Geographical importance. A cruse on the Bosphorus is a splendid experience. It is a 2 hour ride that takes you along the coasts and its amazing view. Carry a map with you to understand what is what and enjoy the experience.
Great river. Great area, busy with boats and traffic, can do trips, go over the bridge, just sit and watch it all happen
Amazing view. A really must see while you are at Istanbul. There are plenty of restaurants facing the strait, so you should not miss the opportunity; the Clock House is a good option.

Fantastic half day out. A great afternoon getting some fresh sea breezes to cool the heat of the afternoon and a fantastic photo opportunity to get some great views of the riverside palaces and properties and to get right underneath the intercontinental bridge. On our tour we also combined this trip with a visit to Pierre Lotti and took a brief cable car ride back down the hill side. Great ice cream at the cafe at the top. An excellent afternoon and great for photographers and sight seer's in general.

Highly Recommended Change of Pace Attraction. Forget the more expensive tours and catch the standard passenger ferry that stops six times up and down the Bosphorus Strait. Tickets can be purchsed right next to the Galata Bridge and the ferries leave about 3 times daily from that port. The cruise up the Bosphorus Strait was very relaxing and offered beautiful views along the shoreline. The final stop will allow you approximately 3 hours to stretch your legs before heading back or stopping at any of the quaint fishing villages along the way. It was a highlight of our trip to Istanbul!

Short cruise is good enough. Nothing extraordinary.... like any other river cruise, which are a dime a dozen in Europe.Just do a short evening one, more for the sake of doing the same & ticking it off in your itenary.
Travel by water. Catching a ferry is cheaper than bus!id recomend going by boat to Eyup Sultan. You can also go on a cruise but it seems to go on forever.
LOVE IT. It is beautiful and I couldn't stop watching all kind of ships and boats of all kind wandering around. This is some of the most amazing part of the world

Recent Ferry Ride. Well, this has been one of the world's centers of maritime commerce for centuries, and still is. A ferry tour lets you see both the Asian and European sides at the same time and is a fun way to get a glimpse of both old and new parts of the city. Definitely worth a two hour ferry ride!

Ferry from Europe to Asia. Even if you just stand on the Galata Bridge and just look out across the water to both sides of the city, it is still an amazing sight, However I would recommend taking the Bosphorus Boat tour, there are plenty of companies doing it and enough touts trying to convince you they are doing you a great deal, but we took the Sehir Hatlari which is the Government run tour, so best priced. You can't miss the entrance its under a big shelter by the riverside. Try and sit by a window or the front or back of the boat so you can see everything, and choose a similar seat for the way back so you see both sides of the river. Once on the other side visit Castle Ceneviz and try one of the many fish restaurants til the boat is ready to depart.

Take a ferry. We had read reviews that suggested taking a public ferry for a trip on the water. A waiter at one of the local restaurants helped us find the right one and we had a two hour trip for about 10 lira each. From memory it was a ferry from where most of the ferries take off from, close to the blue painted bridge (opposite side to the Galata Tower). Sorry I can't be more specific at the moment, but once you are there, it should be easy to work out.

Breathtaking. The Bosphorus is breathtaking, and we loved watching all the constant to-ing and fro-ing of the many ships, from the ferries and sea buses to the cargo ships and gigantic cruiseliners. The yellow legged gulls and flocks of 40+ Eurasian cranes were pretty special too.

Ferry that takes you between two continents. It's a totally different and yet interesting and relaxing experience !! A way of seeing the Strait that connects two continents: Asia and Europe. Visiting the city will never be enjoyable and satisfying unless you take the Bosphorus ferry.. You will love it!!

Book a cruise. Went for a cruise almost up to the Black Sea. We saw a lot of Istanbul and town near by and heard a lot of stories. There was lunch served at the boat and it was one of the best meals I had in Istanbul
Tour. Difficult choice between the hop-on-hop-off or the great tour. The stops of the last aren't that special unless you want to visit Beylerbeyi. So if you have time; go for the grand tour.
Lovely way to relax and view the city.. Take the strain off your feet and let the boat take you down the Bosphorus, to admire the sights of minarets and lovely buildings, set if blue sea and sky.

BEAUTIFUL!. We took a ferry along the Strait out to the Princes Islands and you get an incredible view Istanbul from the water. Looking at the Old City and Beyoglu, you can see some of the major sites of the city (if it's a nice day, take a panoramic picture of the shore -- it's incredible to see all the mosques/towers/bridges of the city from the water)!Well worth $5 TL!
Take a relaxing boat ride. Great views from the water of some of the landmarks of Istanbul and I think they would have been spectacular at night too.

Take the boat trip. The boat trip from the Galata port is arguibly the best way to know the different neighborhoods and check how it was to see Constantinople from the sea. The trip goes all the way down the Ottoman fortresses that blocked the Bosphorus during their warfare with the Byzantines.

Relaxing cruise. Last time I was on the Boshorous Strait,I saw dolphins! They were swimming alongside the passenger boat that I was on.I just like to catch the commuter and local boats and go backwards and forwards,sometimes getting off,sometimes not.The first time that I was in Istanbul,I went on one of the tour trips,mainly to see where else I could go or get off.Since then I have just got on any ferry that's about to leave.The views from these boats is breathtaking and you see far more from the sea.A trip is not to be missed.
Great boat trip!. We took a really interesting private boat trip up the Bosporus Strait, with loads to see on our three hour trip. Passed impressive buildings, bridges & historical sights.

Great photo ops for very little money.. I really enjoyed all our ferry boats trips. We took the regular public transportation ones and for 3 TLR (not even £1), we got to see the beautiful city from the water. We crossed twice to Asia, one to Harem and one to Uskudar. We went up as far as Balat and Besiktas on the European side. Destinations are well displayed. Once you pick your, in most Piers, you will have a booth that will charge you the fare.There is a cruise for 12 TLR that seemed very good too. It takes 90 min and we didn't have that much time hence why we kept using the regular ferryboats but this one also looks like an incredible deal.Once on board, very nice waiters offer tea, sandwiches, etc. You also have a bar with larger selection in case you are hungry/thirsty. Be aware of the waves if you are on the lower deck outside. You might get a bit of a splash.

Nice boat trip. We took a so called "Short cruise" which was 2 hours and found that to be sufficient. Some nice sights (palaces, villas, bridges). If you have a Muzeum Kart you get 25% discount off the already quite reasonable price. No restaurant, but they sell coffee, tea and snacks. Good view of Istanbul.

A nice break, and a beautiful view of the city. The state run boat was equivalent to $5.00. It was two hours, and you saw an amazing view of Istanbul. It was a nice break from site seeing, and there were drinks on board, as it was hot. If I had to do it again, I would go at night, as I understand the views are fantastic.

Bosphorous Cruise. The views of the european and asian side are quite good. I would suggest that instead of taking a cruise take a tram to eminonu and from there you can get cheaper local cruises which charges only about 10-15 liras.
very interesting boat trips. Make a boat trip on the line connecting Europe and Asia and see many fascinating views from both sides of the strait, intermixing ancient and modern buildings.

City boat short ride is a nice break. provides a nice view of both European and Asian side of Bosphorus, some great architectural views, and a nice way to rest tired feet and get some cool breezes on a hot day.

Nice but a bit boring. I didn't find it exceptional, was nice to see a part of Istanbul from the water but would not do it again and would suggest you to only go if you have enough time to spend in the city. Tip : you have people selling you the 15 euro bosphorous cruise everywhere, so not buy that ! They are tours operated by private companies. ehir Hatlar? is Istanbul?s official ferry company and you could go for a tour for 10 TL which lasts an hour and a half (and not 2 hours like they claim)

A must do! (even locals do it). Take 2 hours on one early afternoon and do at least a short tour on Bosphorus. It costs only 10 lira (17,5 lira with audio-guide included). You can enjoy wonderful sights, learn something new about the city and just relax.I highly recommend it to any tourist! There were also many locals during my tour, who said they just take it as a relaxing thing to do on a Sunday afternoon.

Esssential to understand city history. Whether you take a daytime sightseeing cruise or a dinner cruise, seeing the Bosphorus, down to the Golden Horn, is a must to understand how city people lived in the old days and the geopolitical importance of Turkey today.I've heard mixed reviews of the quality of tour narration and dinner food, but my experiences were both very good.

Istanbul from a boat. You really get a beautiful view of the city of Istanbul and the very impressive bridge that joins Europe and Asia. The bridge is a brilliant piece of engineering and well worth a trip up the Bosphorus, along with all the other interesting sights you can see from the boat.

Inexpensive Tour and Boat Ride. My son and I took the half-day ferry ride and it is one of the great bargains. You get to stop in at multiple destinations throughout the city with sites and food - the freshest seafood in one spot, the best crepes in another, fruit markets in another, and great wandering. All in all, it was a wonderful highlight.

Great to be at the border between Europe and Asia. Fascinating to see how much more the European side is built up and where one finds all of the great buildings (apart I suppose for the Fort of Asia which is opposite the Fort of Europe) as you go further towards the Black Sea you find the European side has lots of resorts whereas the Asian side has some wonderful mansions on the banks of the Bosphorus. The DK tourist guide to Istanbul has a chapter devoted to travelling the Bosphorus and we found it really helpful in identifying the landmarks from the Military Academy to Egyptian Embassy and the various palaces. A note to UK readers, we took the book (and it's superb map) from the local library which helps stop our bookshelves from being too overloaded. The Lonely Planet pocket guide is also helpful.

Istanbul from the water. We took a two hour cruise on the Bosphorus for 10 Turkish Lira and were not disappointed. You can see so much from the water that you dont see from the road and there were numerous photo opportunities, really a lovely way to pass the time.

Fantastic and relaxing way to see Istanbul from the water. Fantastic! We took the 2 hour trip, which makes a stop at Ortakoy both on the way out and on the way back. The boat cruises close to the Asian shores on the way out, past the first 2 bridges and then cruises along the European side on the way back, so best to sit on the right/star board side to get the best views.

Bosphorus Cruise - never miss if you visit Istanbul. Istanbul strait is a 31 km long large natural seawater passage between Black Sea and Marmara Sea dividing Istanbul into two major districts...European istanbul and Asian Istanbul....yes , this strait has two continents each side. Both fronts, face from Europe and Asia, set up wonderful valley-like views very enjojable from each face and from the sea on the boat. There are multiple alternatives to take a boat cruise on the Bosphorus...but I suggest you go Ortakoy at first, take a free walk all around Ortakoy. Cafes, restaurants, street sellers selling unique handmade ornaments and bijouteries...silver and bead necklaces , bracelets and so on... Then you can visit one of the most beatiful mosque of. Istanbul located on the seaside on Bosphorus. You can also visit a church, and a sinagog in only 50 meter proximity of this mosque. After your Ortakoy walking trip, I suggest you take the short boat cruise tour departing just other side of the mosque. They start every 15 minutes. Boat departs from Ortakoy, sails northward by very close to seaside of European front , returns after passing second suspension bridge (Fatih Sultan Mehmet bridge) and follows seaside of Asian front. It takes 2 hours to see those wonderful facades of two continents facing Bosphorus. The boats are large tour boats at size of 100 to 200 people and don't worry they are safe.I have taken too many of those Bosphorus tours as a local of Istanbul. But if you are visiting Istanbul and have limited time, I recommend Ortakoy for both walk around and taking a boat cruise.Those tours are good for family with children, singles, couples and group of friends.

Take a half day boat trip. The Bosphorus is the life blood of commerce in this area of the world.... take the trip just to see the commercial shipping action. Most cruises have English language speakers narrating and identifying the palaces on the shoreline. You can relax and just take a few pictures. The boats can be noisy, don't sit near the PA system without earplugs. Snacks on board are not cheap, sneak on an energy bar if you think you will get hungry. Seating can be outside or inside... and you can move around.

Truly stunning. We took our tour with the Sehir Hatlair, they have a kiosk where you can get a discount with the muze pass (we got 20%) which meant our ticket for a 2 hour cruise worked out to about £13 for 5 of us. Which was fantastic value for money. The cruise is fantastic, there is so much to see on this 2 hour cruise, the Rumelil Fortress is one of my favourite sites on the tour. The boat is comfy, plenty of seats and drinks and food are sold on board too. Well worth doing this trip. Look out for the Sehir Hatlari kiosk as some of the tour companies can cost as much as £100, so shop around beforehand.

Amazing Views - Don't Miss!. Board a ferry, or book a cruise on the Bosphorus Strait - you won't be disappointed. Views are absolutely stunning, the water is so blue, and it's a nice relaxing experience away from the hustle and bustle of Istanbul streets. Surprising that the strait is full of jellyfish - you can see hundreds of them!

Take short Bosphorus Cruise. Don't leave ISTANBUL without doing the Cruise Tour!Ignore all the people selling cruise trips on the station and in front of attraction ,such as Hagia Sophia and Blue Mosque.Look for public company Şehir Hatları ticket sale office, it is under the Galata bridge, very close to Eminönü tram station.For 10 TL you can go on 2-hour tour (7.5TL if you have valid museum pass) which is quite enough to enjoy beautiful costs and see almost everything you need to see (Longer tour is 25TL,you spend one and half hour crusing to Black sea,than you wait in local village for 3 hours, and go back to starting point ).Inform yourself about attraction you can see along the European and Asian cost!

Chance to take it in. A Bosphorus Strait boat trip sure enables you to see the vastness of this ancient city! About 2hrs (1 way) and you get to cruise from both Asian-Eurpopean sides with guide pointing out significant buildings, etc. Great way to sight-see and relax after all those walks!An opportunity to check out your possible future Istanbul Real Estate!

Don't take a tourist ferry. We did the long Tour, Government run ferry, with our own guide book.Don't sign up for an expensive trip.We went to the second last stop, walked around the town and then found a restaurant with a great balcony where we sat for most of the afternoon, drinking a lovely Turkish Sav Blanc and watching the boat traffic up and down to the Black Sea.What a great, long day.
take a boat trip. The boats that shuttle along the Bosphorus make a great addition to your Istanbul visit. Not too expensive and they offer a different perspective on the city.

Interesting boat trip. Lucky to have a private boat provided by our tour company, with tea and coffee provided. Bit chilly and windy but good views of both sides. Large tankers moving through can make it a bit choppy!
Bosphorus Strait rich in History. Explore the Bosphorus Straits and understand the rich history behind this remarkable gateway between Europe and Asia...

Almost full day - must do if wheather is nice. This is a must do if you have a few days and the wheather is nice. We took the Ferry/Bosperus tour : http://sehirhatlari.com.tr/en (25% discount with museum pass). Downside was that there was an huge line to get tickets, so you may want to check out if you can get tickets online, and you’ll have to be there early if you want to have agood seat with a view on one of the decks. We were lucky, but if not you maybe better off with a commercial cruise (can’t tell). If money is less of a concern you may want to hire your own boat.It’s a real bargain (there’s also may more expensive alternatives) and will take you most of the day (until 4PM). It goes almost until the end of the Bospherus. If you get off at the last stop you’ll have 2 hours or so. Skip the restaurants in the harbour and climb to the top of the hill, where there’s a fort where you have a great view. There also a few restaurants with magnificent over the Bosperus. We took the first terrace, eager to get a good seat, not realizing that there’s an even better view/restaurant further up the hill. Food is reasonably priced.

Good, cheap 2 hours sightseeing. Ignoring the many 'guides' offering various packages, we took the regular 2 hour tourist ferry (only 10 TLira round trip) from Galata bridge up the Bosphorus. They provide a Points of Interest map, but as their is no on-board commentary, you'll need to have access to a guide book.We feel we should have got off at Ortokoy on the return trip as the harbour, cafes, mosque etc looked very interesting and the area is only a short way back to base.Avoid weekends, Turkish holidays and grab a seat early or you'll be stuck in the middle of the boat.

Keep you eyes open for all the jellyfish!. We took a boat tour on the Bosphorous Strait while visiting Istanbul. Looking down in port, I was surprised to see thousands of jellyfish! Ranging in size from 2" to almost 12"!! Yet, the tour guide did not even mention them! We enjoyed a 90 minute tour along the waterfronts of this important waterway. Well worth a visit.

Great trip. We did the afternoon four and a half hour tour. This included lunch which was very tasty - shame about the c;ouds of smoke from the BBQ at the back of the boat. Very interesting trip - fantastic views.

Breezy Day Trip. We took the Hop ON-Hop Off Boat tour and enjoyed it. We got off several times to see the Palaces, and for lunch. The views were great of the bridges and all the ships. Great value and a wonderful way to enjoy the views of the city.

On my "must do" list for a 3-day visit. A three-day visit to Istanbul should include some kind of water transportation on the Bosphorus. That was my agenda on my way to Istanbul and I felt confirmed in that afterwards. One option is to do a guided tour, which I'm sure is lovely--if I would have done that, I would have wanted to make it all the way to the Black Sea. I went with a water taxi to the Asian side, which takes just 20 minutes and is how many locals do it, even though the Metro makes the same journey only underwater. If you do this, it's cheap and you still great a great sense of the landscape of the city and some great views of Topkapi, Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, city walls, etc.
raw3a. we had a great time during our tour, we explore the both asia and europe , the big houses on both sides are amazing, you feel the glory of old istanbul

I took the short tour. I took the short tour from Kadikoy on one of the ferries, it was relatively cheap, go early and get a seat on top by the rail and you will have good photograph positioning, and remember that you will see one side on the way up and the other on the way down. Many beautiful mansions and historic sites to see. The Ortakoy Mosque is on the left as you approach the first bridge, and Rumeli Fortress is on the left as you approach the second bridge (where the ferry turns around).
Scenic and pleasurable. This "cruise" came at the end of our tour and we certainly saw Istanbul from a totally different perspective. Beautiful and enjoyable.

Evening guided boat tour. Seeing Istanbul from the Bosphorus gives you a unique look at the city, one you do not get from land! We purchased our tickets near the Blue Mosque for a 2 1/4 tour beginning at 7:00pm. Loved seeing the city in lights!

Relaxing but not all we expected. We made the mistake of booking a Bosporus Trip from the hotel and we were picked up in a Bus. To be honest we spent a lot of time in that bus, most of it in traffic jams. Then although the trip was interesting, it did go around the old city as we expected it too. Therefore my advice is to walk down to were the boat trips go from and make sure you get one that also goes around the old city!

Uniquely Istanbul. This is not like a canal you'd expect to see in Venice, but the Bopshorus has its own unique charm to it. No wonder the residents are so passionate about the value it adds to the city, as well as mutual feelings awe and nostalgia. Join the locals and go for a leisurely stroll along Bosphorus on a sunny Sunday morning. Most popular areas to do are the Bebek - Emirgan or the Sahilyolu (Asian side) districts.

Get on a boat!. Everything in Istanbul revolves around the Bosphorous! You can spend hours just watching the shipping work its way through and there are countless restaurants on its shore to choose from. Try and make time for a boat trip but avoid the touts flogging the "tours". Its so easy to do your own thing. Just buy a ticket and get on a boat!

See Istanbul on a boat trip. This is a great way to get a really good idea of how Istanbul is laid out. You can go from the old city to the new city to the Asian side. You get to see a large number of palaces and old buildings, as well as the Bosphorous Bridge, Galata Bridge. It gives you a much better perspective of where to go once you are on dry land.

Beautiful day and night. I highly recommend to walk along the Bosporus during the day, and then take a cruise in the evening. The buildings look so different at night when they're all light up and during the day, along the entire strait, it just buzzes.

A great two hours tour. After advice from the Hotel staff where we stayed ( Elanaz) we opted for the official two hour tour starting at 1pm and for 10 lira per person it was excellent value and a great way to see both the Asian and European side of the Bosphorus straight
A walk through history. A beautiful angle for seeing many of Istanbul's monuments and a chance to appreciate the Asian side also.

Value. The Bosphorus Strait is full of historical interest on both the European and Asian sides. Well worth doing the boat trip and the cable car trip. Try to avoid the "fashion show" which the organised tours try to end on unless you want to experience the attempted hard sell of leather clothing.

Sail to the Black Sea. Take the 4 hour your to the Black Sea -- the 2 hour tours are horrible. Go with a real company linked to your hotel -- they have a big investment in satisfaction, since the hotel earns a commission, if their customers are not happy, neither is the hotel! Stunning views, surprisingly good food for lunch.

Hop on a cruise to see some nice views. I've enjoyed the Bosphorus Strait on one of the cruises offered at the port - my husband and I opted for the short one lasting 2 hours. I found it quite interesting to see many of the famous sights from the seas and it was fascinating to watch how the buildings on the shore change in their style. And if you only imagine millennia of history that happened right in this place!
