Beware of tourist companies - they are robbers )). Don't buy tours - the prices start from 15 euros, while you can buy a ticket to see Bosphorus for 10-15 liras at the pier. Don't miss a chance to try balik ekmek - fried fish with bread, they sell it near the bridge or an old man sells it across the bridge - at the market. Have a glass of salep if you come in winter - Bosphorus is full of life and you really feel alive there.

Highly recommended to get a ferry boat to fully enjoy of it.. The Bosphorus Strait, literally amazing this channel that separates Europe from Asia, you can admire it from many points of the city, but if you want to get a better view of this beautiful landscape I highly recommend it to cross the channel with a ferry boat or a mini cruise, in every corner of the city there are organized tours that take tourists on trips of 1 to 2 hours up and down the Bosphorus, a thrilling experience as a culturally rich, it's exciting to navigate between the two continents.

Beautiful Boat Trip. We had planned to do this 'if we had time'. Thank goodness we did as it was excellent - left Gelata Bridge and had 2 hours going up to the Bosphorus Bridge, the Ataturk Bridge, passing the Dolmabahce Palace and Maiden's Tower. We saw this trip advertised in hotels/tourist offices at Euro 25 pp, but we just turned up at the quayside and paid TL 10 (3 euros) direct to the boat operator.

had a wonderful ferry ride. had a lovely ferry ride. if you're here only for a few days and can't see everything i recommend taking the bosphorus ferry. u will pass all the major historical monuments outside the city centre, like dolmabahce, topkapi, florence nightingale's hospital, ciragan hotel, the bosphorus bridge. our tour guide ozgu voluntered to explain the sites bcus she knows the captain. very informative and funny. a great trip for kids as well. hot beverages are provided

Worth every penny. We went on a regular cruise for about one and a half hours along the Bosphorous. It was very relaxing and quite an eye opener. The best part was seeing the wonderful bungalows that line the river side. Homes of millionaires but one better than the next. I know where I would like to invest my money no sooner I have some!
On a nice day, wonderful view of Istanbul. What a wonderful way to see Istanbul from another view, at the same time learn about the different buildings and areas. Would definitely recommend.

Stunning!. See it from any side, any point and the view would be awesome. It is a picture perfect istanbul.A boat/yacht ride across the strait might be touristy and sound cheesy but is definitely worth it and not to be missed.

nice trip. We went on a 1,5 hour-long boat trip on the stream. The view was wonderful in the aftrenoon. we were floating back as the sun was setting, it was fantastic the city in that aftrenoon light. The other fantastic experience was the feeling that you are between two continents. It is a nice program after a tiring tour in the city centre.

A cow crossed the strait?. It took time to understand what was the lireary meaning of this word! But we took a ship ride at night and the city looked really colorful. The trip was very well organised with brilliant display of local dance and songs. The tourists were from almost all continents.

A boat tour on the Bosphorus is a nice way to spend an afternoon. We heard that a boat tour up and down the Bosphorus was a different way to see Istanbul. So we booked a boat tour through our hotel for the afternoon and were not disappointed with all we saw. We cruised up the European side to the second suspension bridge crossed over and came down the Asian side. There is much to see, old Ottoman Palaces, beautiful homes and a lot of interesting ships, boats and ferries traversing the Bosphorus. We had a delightful time on our cruise and we would recommend it for a different perspective on seeing Istanbul.

Incredible Istanbul. Cruising on the Bosphorus with Europe on one side and Asia on the other, linking the Black Sea and Marama the Aegean, enjoying the magnificent view of the city, the forest and beyond, you can't help but instantly fall in love with this amazing part of our planet.

Get your bearings. The ferry ride takes quite a while, but is relaxing and interesting. It helps you to understand the geography of Istanbul. Next time you watch movies filmed in Istanbul, you will recognise the locations that have been used! It is very beautiful and inexpensive, so I recommend a boat ride.

Not that complex, but great ambience and worth the dive. Not much to see inside past the initial view of pillars, water and fish. No art and besides two medusa heads little ornamentation. That said, great ambience, lighting and mesmerizing view lost myself for 45 minutes there while doing very little. Should be perhaps a little cheaper given how much it offers (depending on what upkeep costs really are.)

The Bosphorus connects Europe with Asia.. The Bosphorus is a large waterway with shipping, pleasure craft and ferries. Two bridges span the Bosphorus in Istanbul. Literally, millions of people cross the Bosphorus, daily.
Fantastic. We were very fortunate to arrive off the ferry at sunset. The minaret silhouettes look amazing against the fiery sky.

Wotta sight.... This was one of the best sights in Istanbul.....the blue waters rippling in the winter sun.....quite a feeling.....made for an interesting day on the boat.......lovely sights on either side...must go back a third time....have not had enough...

OK ride. we took short Bosphorus tour (2 hours) and to be honest we were a bit bored. I would prefer to take boat one way to see great views, bridges, building, city from the water. But once you there I would prefer to take a bus tour back to see one of the sides of the Bosphorus. Return trip was no fun.
In the middle of Asia and Europe. Lovely, but a cruise more than 30-40 mins can get boring. I go some of my best pictures on the Bosphorus cruise.
beautiful!. I went by boat...and it was very chill and cheap! Drink a tea while you feel the beauty of the views...

Sight of the sea so welcome. The sea is great, the boats on the water looks like a taxi service on wheels, You can cross with a ferry boat for 3 Turkish lira or do a 2 hour trip for 10 Turkish Lira. It wa great doing the 2 hour trip.We then (only my husband ) had a fish sandwich consisting of bread, salad and a fillted fish for 6 Turkish Lira - he said he was very happy having the sandwich.

Exhilarating. A boat trip on the Bosphorus is a must. Not only does one see the sights of Istanbul from a different perspective, but also the turbulent waters of the strait lend a sense of the historic protection it has afforded the city. Imagine our surprise to see a Turkish submarine surface alongside our tour boat!

Must visit trip. We had heard a lot about this trip and were going for advance booking also but timely advise by a close friend saved us a lot of money.Advance booking could be upto 50Euro but on jetty,we got tickets for 10 Lira each(hell of difference).One hour trip in which you go around the strait,enroute see TWO bridges connecting Europe and Asia(3rd under construction).Scenary on both sides is superb with many hotels,palace,bunglows on the bank.A must visit when visiting Istanbul.

Europe vs Asia. it was a 2 hr ferry ride through international waters which divides istanbul. On one side, you can see Asia and other is Europe. Its simply unbelievable that thousands of people travel across Asia (asian side of Istanbul) to work in Europe and at night they travel back.The Bosphorus straight ride was full of information. With cool winds moving across, it was a nice change after walking around istanbul for 2 full days.

The Straight Separates. We are perplexed and excited to see a rare phenomenon - the continental plates of Asia and Europe separated by the Bosphorus Straight. Had only see it at school during boring geography classes. But this is the real thing - amazing, and not to be missed.

Wanted to swim across but the wife said no way!. Well for January at least it was a sunny day and not too cold so the ferry ride was nice from the topside deck out in the open. Buy some of those dried up bread rolls from the vendor at the dock and feed the birds, they go nuts just like in that Hitchcock movie!

Two hour cruise was enough. We decided not to take the all-day cruise, as the lengthy midday stop in winter did not appeal. Instead we went for the state-owned Şehir Hatlar company 2 hour cruise at 2pm (December), to just beyond the second Bosphorous Bridge and back. We were outside on the back deck all the time, wrapped up and not at all cold, having waited in line for 30 mins. before departing: the only minus were those later arrival passengers who then pushed in front of the seats we managed to get, and seemingly oblivious to (or ignoring) that fact that they were blocking our view. But it happens everywhere – best to recognise that if you want a view, the seats at the back are of no real use at all – the exception are the outboard end of the seats down the sides of the boat, where no one can stand in front of you.We didn’t hire the audio commentary guide, as we had a good guidebook, but others may wish to – you do this immediately inside the admission barrier just before getting on the boat, although that might mean you miss the best seats in the rush of those bypassing the audio rental booth.Very good value, and a great way to understand the geography of Istanbul.

Wonderful way to see Istanbul. We chose to go with the long running Sehir Hatlari. For 25TL you get a 6 hour return trip (full cruise). A 3 hour stop off for lunch (up near the black seas) where you can have fresh seafood on the waters edge. The best view is from the back left of the boat. At the end of the day we chose to get off at the last port (Besiktas) and walk through the Asmali district back to old city.

Cruising the Bosphorus - perfect day out. To see what Istanbul is like for real Istanbulus, the best way to do it is to take public transport - and the ferries up and down the Bosphorus are an ideal way to experience this.The locals use ferries like Londoners use the tube, and we spent a very happy day (at a cost of about £8) on a full day cruise up and down the shore, along with commuters, shoppers and locals out for the day. Pick up the boats from close to the Galata Bridge - there are several routes to choose from - and then pick your seat...On board, there's a café serving chai, coffee and soft drinks, as well as snacks, and you get to see a great slice of real Istanbul life as you power up and down the waterways. Do it!

Fabulous. Enjoy from a tour on a boat up both sides. The architecture is amazing, palaces, museums and stately houses all around. Returning to Eminonu gives you a beautiful and atmospheric view of the old part of Istanbul. Totally worth any money to travel along it.
No Istanbul trip would be complete without a cruise on the Bosphorous Strait. Had a great time on a beautiful day. Tip: go with a reputable ferry company, like the one run by the state.
Not a con!. There must be 500 men scattered in the Sultanahmet area trying to sell you boat trips. Do it. It's not expensive and it's a city to admire from the water.

Very Pretty. The Bosphorous is a great place to see - very interesting, with lots of local flavour. There are the fish restaurants, the fresh fish sandwich sellers by the road, as well as the beautiful waters of the strait itself. There is plenty to see, from fishermen to jellyfish and dolphins!

Ferry Spanning Continents. We took the ferry from Eminonu to Kadikoy. It was more relaxing to walk around the Kadikoy side, as the restaurant hawkers were much less pushy than in Sultanahmet. The night light view of the two mosques on the ferry trip back was very atmospheric.

Cold but worth it. It worth deadly cold in december though in the city it was't so freezing, so be prepared to it. I took 1,5 hour tour, and felt not quite i well satisfied by it. If u traveling in warm season take the longer tour maybe 2 or even 6 hour

Loved it. I loved this area and around the Golden Horn at the Galata Bridge. There was so much energy around this area and beautiful views of the Bosphorus. Also go to Bebek and Osterkoy (think that was the name!) they are on Bosphorous also, beautiful views.

Freezing sea wind, but amazing view. During the winter, if you take the Bosphorus cruise you might want to wear some thicker clothing as the wind is much cooler when the ship moves. but the view is too beautiful to be missed. and luckily we have the bright and sunny weather to help warm our freezing hands.

Fulfill childrens wishes and this trip will stay in my daughters memory. I did a boat tour on the Bosphorus in the sun, with my 8 year old dauther and I'm sure that and the fishermen on the galata bridge at departure, will be what she will remember from the trip to Istanbul. We were followed by many seagulls who seem to take profit of being fed by tourists. We could see the coastline during the 2 hours trip to the 2nd bridge and back on the wealthy coastline of the asian side of Istanbul, no wonder some people takes on them the cumbersome bridge trip every day. The bridge no 1 is amazingly slim and passes close to old palaces on the border of the bosphorus

Trip on Bosphorous. On a clear day this a great way to spend a few hours. You can take a local ferry and see the sights or take a cruise.
The houses on either side of the river offer a range of architecture. You see all kinds of transport on the river. Refreshments are available on most boats.

Amazing. Travel the way locals do.. Take the boat the locals take. Costs less than a US$1. It travels to various locations on both the European & Asian side.
Bring a simit (bread) on board and feed the hungry seagulls and other starving birds which would dive at the morsels of food you throw. Quite an experience.

Enjoy a Tour of the Bosphorus by Boat. The Bosphorus divides Europe and Asia and has lots of history along it's banks. From the remains of the Romans and Constantinople to the Ottoman Empire and it's palaces, you do not want to miss the lovely views from the strait. I recommend getting on a boat near the Spice Market (Golden Horn area) and taking the tour down to Bridge #2. You won't regret it.

Just do it. Eventhough it was early November, we still had a very nice tour on the Bosphorus. I would do the trip again, if I came back to Istanbul. Which will happen, as we have not seen all the areas we want to see. Only a weekend there, which was way too short, but will come back with my husband.

The Continental Divide. Not only he Bosporus Strait is such an important waterways linking Asia and Europe, countries surrounding the Black Sea rely heavily on ships passing this narrow strait for access to the outside world. As such its importance in world commerce cannot be overlooked.

Europe and Asia separated by water. This is a must see / do attraction. The feeling of knowing that you have Asia in one side and Europe in the other is amazing. You can really imagine everything that happened in this location many and many years ago, all the trade, disputes, goods, people and everything that once passed thru these waters!I have done it at night and during the day - both very unique experiences and worth doing it!

Love this waterway!. Travel across the Bosphorus is a beautiful, short ride. The views of both the Europe and Asia side are fantastic. Crossing the Bosphorus each day is one of the highlights of visiting Istanbul.

We do not get tired of it. We have cruise along and across the Bosphorus Strait many times ! We have done it by ferry , we have cruise along it from the Black Sea once and he other way twice and we have done it once on a boat trip starting in the golden Horn to the second bridge on the european side and coming back along the Asian side at sunset . Even though it is more expensive , this is the way that we preferred to view it ! Anyway you choose to do it , it is a beautiful sight !
Outstanding Views. The views are outstanding. Don't purchase pricey expensive tours. Take a public ferry and see the sights. I was amazed at the beauty.

spectacular scenery. Since I was running in the Istanbul Marathon crossing the Bosphorus was the highlight of my race. The view was a sight to behold and the pristine surroundings all contributed to a wonderful view. Blue skies, blue sea, sunny weather, it was just BLISS. Also made history by running from Asia to Europe !

Nice boat trip. We decided to go on a boat trip down the Bosphorus. We went to the eminönü tramstop and walked in the direction of the galata bridge. Dont go for the boat trips that people offer along the way. If you get the public ferry (the office nearest to the galata bridge) you get the best value for your money. It is 25 TL for a day long trip to Anadolu (a small place near the black sea). An audio guide is 15 TL (however this does not work very good). You can sit inside or outside on the top deck. During the trip you can see all the nice houses across the Bosphorus. In anadolu you can stay in the village to eat some fish in the restaurants or you can climb the hill to the 14th century castle. The views up there are stunning. You can also see the black sea from there. After 3 hours the ferry leaves Anadolu again and heads back to Istanbul. Overall a very nice day trip.

The city from an unusual angle. Hire boats take you from the Golden Horn up to the second suspension bridge. Up one side of the strait and then down the other. On the waterside there are palaces forts and modern houses, many very expensive. The boats are comfortable with refreshments and toilets.
What a view?. Incredible panorama. History meets the modern age. Asia meets Europe. Pure drama, singular beauty. Could sit under the Galata Bridge and soak up te view and the atmosphere all day!

Take the ferry, you see the same things. The hotel tried to book us on a 35 euro trip but we'd read TA and decided on finding a ferry trip down by the Galata Bridge and we're glad we did this. It was a big ferry boat, would have taken maybe 300+ people but today on a cold December day, no more than about 50 people. A very energetic man kept bringing round cups of tea, orange juice, food etc, very inexpensive and welcome. The sights were good as well. The ferry trip was on 12 lira and takes 1.5 hours. We took the one just beyond the 3 ornate boats selling fish sandwiches, on the Golden Horn side of the Galata Bridge.

2 continents in twenty minutes. We did not have sufficient time to take in a whole Bosphorous tour so instead opted for the public ferry service over to the Asian side. Simply walk down to the terminal on the waterfront, use a kiosk to purchase a ticket (something like TKL 3 (US$ 1.50)) and wait for the next ferry. they run every twenty minutes. easy walk on. a man comes around serving hot drinks and snacks - nice on a cold day.

nice sea trip. I took a boat tour ,around 12 liras, it lasted for about an hour where I passed by the buildings located by the Bosphorus,some are new some are old but the common thing between them is that surely they belonged to very rich people in Turkey, try drinking hot chocolate during the journey, it is calming.BTW U WILL NEVER be able to HEAR THE RECORDED GUIDE VOICE

Great Escape With Wonderful Scenery. We took the tour run by the ferry service that goes almost all the way up to the Black Sea, then climbed to a castle for stunning views. happy that the boat was heated in the winter, and the homemade local yogurt from Kanlica was an added treat. Definitely recommended.

Wonderful trips on the water. We went on the Bosphorous twice - once on an evening trip with our conference group - wonderful views of the building lit up and the bridge - and once on a public ferry which gave us great views and a free map to tell us about the buildings we would see,Don't be conned into buying an expensive tour (touted in all the tourist spaces) - rather go down to the docks near the Galata Bridge and find a ferry for only 10TL
2 Continents... A city , bye 2 Continents , unbeliavables..feel intresting..everytime change the Color of Bosphorus... a pearl bye this old city , non stop Civilization over 8500 years..
Bosphorus trip. Excellent ~ I enjoyed every moment and the tour guide was amazing. Was wonderful to experience Turkey by drifting on the river.

Travelling around Istanbul. The traditional way of navigating the Bosphorus Strait by ferry has now been enhanced with the construction of the Marmaray Metro project. The two main terminals are Uskudar (on the Asian side) and Sirkeci (on the European side). Travelling to Kadikoy can be achieved either by remaining on the Marmaray Metro and travelling either by bus, taxi or foot or via the ferries (the preferred option).
Smooth sailing. Okay, it wasn't a sail boat, but the ride was smooth. Gives you a chance to see both sides of the straight. Nice palaces and castles to photograph.

Do the day cruise.. The night cruise serves up a decent dinner and bad wine options. That's what you get for an "all inclusive" package. Opt for a day cruise to enjoy good weather and a complete city tour overview.

Boat Ride. We took an evening dinner cruise on the Bosphorus. What a great time. The food was just okay but what fun we had. One side of the boat is looking at Asia and one side is looking at Europe. The night was clear and the city was sparkling. The wait staff was fabulous and the entertainment was FUN. Corny? Yes! But there was definitely a little magic involved as well. I would highly recommend a night cruise. Don't go for the food go for the experience.

Relaxing attraction. This 1,5 hour trip takes you along both sides of Bosphorus. For about 3 EUR it is great option to see city from the sea. You can get tea/coffee on board. Boat is anchored next to the Galata bridge

Bosphorus Cruise a Must!. It is a must to cruise the Bosphorus Strait if you make it to Istanbul. It is an all day adventure which we enjoyed tremendously. We went in June, 2013, and the weather was perfect.

Must do boat trip. Fantastic way to view the sights of Istanbul. Dont buy tickets off the people pushing the trips but go straight to the ticket office which is on the side of Galata Bridge just past the fish boat restaurants.The tour is the same and it is a fraction of the price. it lasts over 90 minutes and there are announcements as you go past points of interest.

Take the short cruise!. We had planned on taking the all day cruise, but our hotel staff said we'd see enough on the short (1.5 hour) trip, It was just the right distance, with all the "highlights" pointed out & a brief history given. The boat got close enough to the shore for us to take some great photos. They served tea, juices, snacks, etc., but we'd had breakfast before we boarded. The walk over the Galata Bridge to the boat terminal was interesting with all the fisherman & locals selling their wares. No one was aggressive.I would recommend this, unless the weather is bad.

Gives a total perspective. many visitors to Istanbul only see and corner of the city in the 'old town' corner. Cruising up the Bosphorus provides another dimension to this huge and diverse city, that includes old palaces, forts, new bridges, houses and of course the Black Sea. It really placed this city onto perspective for me and the time on the water was calming and away from the hustle and bustle. Top it off with a fish sandwich when returning to the wharf!

Strength of Istanbul lies in Bosphorus Strait. Nicest view of Istanbul is from Bosphorus. There are different Bosphorus cruises, during the day and night also. Most of the visitors like the best this option to see Istanbul - both European and Asian side. Views are spectacular!

priceless. When in Istanbul be sure not to miss a 1,5 hours cruise on the Bosphorus! The seascape is worth every cent and most ships also serve Turkish tea and coffee on board, which is great especially during the cold winter months..

Great views!. We took a 90 minute cruise on the Bosphorus as part of an afternoon tour from our cruise ship in the port of Istanbul. It was late on a Sunday afternoon when we boarded our cruise boat from the unusual boarding station, located in the grounds of a Customs depot, not far from the port of Istanbul. The cruise took us through the heart of Istanbul and travelled a few kilometres in the direction of the Black Sea and under some major road and railway bridges, before turning and heading back to the starting point. There were a number of very interesting sights to be seen but the most fascinating part of the cruise was to be on a waterway which separated the two continents of Europe and Asia, with both continents clearly visible on either side of the boat. The onboard guide provided an interesting and entertaining commentary as we travelled up and down the waterway.The aforementioned were the highlights of this short cruise. Unfortunately there also some lowlights. As we set off from the quay, the onboard guide attempted to go through the safety briefing. His attempt to demonstrate how to put on a life-jacket in case we needed to evacuate the boat was laughable because he had no idea what he was doing. The boat had two decks and as we boarded, we were ushered along with most other passengers, to the upper deck. This was fine in that you were provided with a good vantage point, to take in all of the views but there was no shade of any type and the sun was quite strong. There was also a problem with the diesel exhaust smoke from the boat's funnel constantly blowing over us and at times during the cruise, this became quite unpleasant. As part of the tour deal, all passengers were entitled to either a free soft drink or an orange juice during the cruise. If you wanted a beer, a wine or spirit, you had to purchase them from the onboard bar. Unfortunately when the crew members brought around the complimentary drinks, they were warm and the soft drinks were flat - hardly refreshing.In summary, the highlights outweighed the lowlights. It is certainly worth taking a sight- seeing cruise on the Bosphorus, to take in the views of Istanbul from a unique viewpoint.
Take the Boat. We did the 2 hour boat tour and it was well worth it. The scenery on both sides was beautiful! Worth the money & the time. Have fun!

middle of 2 continents. We took a sunset ferry from the European side along the Bosphorous, going we stayed close to the European side, went under the bridge connecting the 2 continents and returning we past the asian side, seeing the glamouous yallis.The driver of the boat played local disco istanbul music which was strange. But it went well with the video we were capturing. we also took the water taxi (public ferry) when going to Princes island on the last day. Took a horse ride round the island, as no motor vehicles are allowed there. It's cheaper to use the public ferry than the cruise ferries, but check their timings. It's amazing to see the locals come to the mainland for all their shopping and then return by the last ferry back to the islands.

Europe and Asia - one under each foot!. Took the ferry from Istanbul to the asian side, and a bus back across the bridge sanning the Bosphorus. An intriquingm highly recommended trip for those with a little adventure in their blood.
Romantic cruise. Don't forget to have a small cruise to Bosphorus. You will never forget about. Take your camera and enjoy the view! Best time before sunset, so you will get more nice pics!

Once in a lifetime!. Although there are many beautiful cities with amazing seafront segments or riverside banks, the Bosphorus is a unique experience in itself. The best way to enjoy it is to catch a boat and cruise along it taking in the views from both sides namely Europe and Asia. You can catch one of the city liner boats leaving from Eminonu (but these are just a few times during the day) or hop on a smaller boat leaving Ortaköy these are much more frequent but only run during high season that is May thru September.

Enjoy it ;). Take a short trip to enjoy looking at beautiful Istanbul from the Bosporus.There are short trips(an hour or so) for as little as 12.5TL!!! I thought it was € or maybe dollars!! So enjoy th short trip with your beloved ones in the heart of the Bosporus.

Full day tour. Catch the ferry at Eminönü at around 10.30 on a sunny day. Enjoy the criss-crossing up the Bosphorus. Get off at Anadolu Kavagi (final stop), walk uphill to the old ruin and enjoy the view of the Black Sea. Then lunch at the harbour, a stroll in the small village, and then back. Don't forget to keep your return ticket. Back in Eminönü 16.30. A memorable day!

See Turkey from both sides. When in Europe, that is what you do. You ride the hop on hop off busses, you take a boat cruise and a river. In our instance, we had a private guide that took us onto a age old boat all the way to the golden horn. He then took us up with the cable car to look at graves as well as a beautifull site from above. Definately every cent (and minute) worth our while!!
Basque in the glory of east meets west. A wonderful thing to do when in Turkey. cruise along this waterway and be transported to Turkey of yesterday. look for the jelly fish in the water

Boat trip. Bosphorus boat trips- good value for money- provide execellent lunches on full day tours anad take in all the sites- our guide was great-knew so much and answered all questions with patience and interest.

Do it. Take the all-day ferry with the 3-hour layover at the fishing village. Climb the hill - NO WAIT - look for a rare taxi and get right up the hill to the fort and have lunch. It's a LONG, STEEP walk.
Straddling two continents. Beautiful sunny day,to cruise.Just very relaxing,and enjoyable,the sights are great,and just the thought of being between Asia,and Europe,amazing!!

Gotta Cross the Strait!. If you visit Istanbul, don't fight the urge. Take the 20 minute ferry, across the Bosphorus Strait to the Asian continent. If for no other reason but to say that in one afternoon you were in both Europe and Asia. Great fun!

Fabulous Trip. Went down to the boats by the bridge, picked one and jumped on. Its cheap at 15try but make sure you pay in Lira. Sometimes the boats hang on top get more passengers so you could be waiting 30min, pick a boat nearly ready to leave. Also, unless its very hot bring a jacket as it does get breezy out there, you can always buy a turkish tea (5try)onboard

Magnificent Views of both the Asian and European sides.. The trip up and down the Bosphorus was simply fantastic. You get to see the variety of architectural buildups from ancient to modern including the latest skyscrapers beyond the hills from the water front. The view gets even more spectacular during and after sun set, when the entire Bosphorus is lit up from the both sides.

Take the ferry from the dock. This a beautiful little cruise, we took the two hour one, where you will see the European side and then the Asian side. Well worth the money. A handy tip would be to ensure you get the Tram to the docks and there you will see tour guides who will offer this cruise for only 15 Lira which in UK is only £5! Absolute bargain.Be sure to take a jacket or jumper as it gets rather cold on the sea but some beautiful views to snap shots, on board they sell Turkish Tea and snacks which made our day :-)
Loved it. Did a cruise on the Bosphorus Strait, great scenery along the shore and we had great weather on the day. A great way to view the mosques and the fortresses.

STUNNING and BUSY. it makes you feel so little...and at night it is really something you won't forget easily. Boats at any time sailing back and fot=rth the european, the asian and the "old" Istanbul....

A Great "In Country" Experience. We took the cheap local ferry up in the am, hiked up to the ruins at the top - what a view! - then had lunch at an incredible restaurant dockside (wish I could remember the name!)Rather than take the ferry back, though, we took a local bus back down the Asian side at the suggestion of our landlord. We got off in one of the towns and had fresh yoghurt and made friends... what a cool experience that was. At the end of the bus route, we took a short ferry back.If you enjoy getting out and away from the tourists, be sure to do the bus back.

Glad we took the cruise. A relaxing way to spend a half day is to take a cruise. We enjoyed having a guide. It was more expensive than a ferry but was simpler as we were picked up at hotel. If we had ;more time we would have liked to explore further with ferries.
Wonderful cruise, but wrap up warm. What a perfect way to capture all the beautiful sights of the city, but in cooler months be sure to wrap up warmly!
Bosporus cruise :(. Was disappointed as I expected a lot more from the cruise. It was pretty standard one but you get to see the Asian and European sides. And they never take you till Black Sea :(

Buzzing with life!. This is one of the main reasons for the unique character of Istanbul from the enormous cargo ships making their way into and out of the Black Sea to the busy ferries plying their way across it. I could just sit all afternoon with this view in front!

Day long trip along the Bosphorus. The full day trip along the Bosphorus is well worth it. You buy your tickets at the booth on the old city side of Istanbul and hop on the ship for a 10:30 to 4:30 trip, with a three hour stopover at the mouth of the Black sea.The shores of the Bosphorous are lined with beautiful homes and palaces, which make for a visually stunning cruise.Once at the mouth of the Black sea, you stop in a small fishing village with tourist trap restaurant. But keep walking up the hill to the centuries old Genoese castle ruins. It's a steep hike, but worth the tip. You can stop near the top for a bear or tea at one of the restaurants. The view from up there is quite nice.

Bosphorous at Istanbul. The cruise on Bosphorous may not be much different from a local river cruise, for example in the backwaters of Kerala or a boat ride to St. Mary's Island in Udupi, except for the hundreds of historical monuments dotted through the banks on both sides from 12th century to 21st century.... If you have a good guide, its a nice tour. Even otherwise, you may enjoy going through a historically important water way that carried the greek soldiers for centuries together.

Bosphorous Strait is Worth Seeing. We explored Istanbul with the help of a friend who had been there many times. He recommended that, instead of taking an expensive, tourist-oriented cruise, we take the local ferry and see the same sights for the grand total of $1.00. Actually, we took two ferries, one to the Asian side of the Bosphorous, and another back. We went at sunset, and were able to see the beautiful sights along the shore first in the pinks of dusk, then the night sky lit up. They even serve coffee, tea and pastries on the ferry. If you're on a budget or just on a tight timetable, this is the way to see the Bosphorous Strait.

One of a Kind Cruise. The Bosphorus straits connects Asia to Europe. Cruising along the straits gives you a good view of Istanbul from ports to ultra expensive hotels to universities, minister's office, etc. Enjoy the boat ride which crosses a few bridges. Superb to just sit back and relax while enjoying the lovely sight.
Take a cruise. A cruise on the Bosphorus is the only way to really see the houses of the rich and famous that line its shores. It is also a lovely relaxing time.

All day cruise. We enjoyed a scenic trip down the BOSPHORUS, though it was cool and cloudy. we opted for the 10:30AM ferry that stopped in an Asian town for several hours. there we had lunch and found some better priced souvenirs than we had seen in Istanbul. I especially liked the necklaces made by the village women.

The ferries are a wonderful to tour the city and now you can take the Maramary subway line under the river. We made sure to take the recently opened Maramary subway lin to and from the Asian side of the Bosphorus. It was fun watching this historic event/infrastructure enhancement become the must attraction for the multi-generational families. To the see the proud tears in the grandparent's eyes as they shepherded their grandchildren is a sight I will remember for a very low time.
Beautiful. Must see if visiting istanbul especially on a sunny day. I took the ferry which was 3 or 5 Lira and rode it the entire way and back. Great picture opportunities.
River cruising. Fantastic value for money on this 2 hour trip. Great weather, good pictures to be had and excellent service in the bar

Unforgettable Experience. I will remember this cruise for the rest of my life. It was a great ride and the views were incredible, but there was something else I’ll remember more. On the cruise, I was sitting next to a Turkish girl around my age who was visiting Istanbul. We talked the whole cruise about our lives, what we had in common, our families, school, music, and more. At the end of the cruise we exchanged emails to keep in touch. We still talk to this day and the Bosphorus Strait Cruise was an experience I’ll never forget!

Amazing nightlife. I took a dinner/dance cruise the first night to see the city from the Bosphorus at night. Wow, even on a Sunday night the city was having a party! The river was alive with night clubs, hotels, Restaurants, palaces all lit up and people every where having a good time. There were fireworks, and search lights lighting up the sky. I also took the ferry to the Asian side the next day, this was a great way to appreciated the size and wonderment that this huge and amazing city has to offer.

Take a boat ride!. It is a must see passage. The shores of the Bosphorus Strait have beautiful old and new houses, fortifications, the 'New Palace', etc. If it isn't a beautiful day wait if you can. There are two suspension bridges and below is the newly opened tunnel...dreamed of since the days of Leonardo da Vinci. It is one way to large ships so there is plenty of room for all the boats that ply its waters.

Take some time to sail it along. The Bosphurus is one of the most strategic geographic accidents in the world. It's a narrow strait where Europe meets Asia and Istanbul is beaultifully nested there. So don't waste the opportunity to sail it, either in a cruise or even only taking a ferry as a local would do...

Beautiful views over the Bosphorus. For those with the time, it's worth taking the walk behind the Blue Mosque along the promenade facing the Bosphorus Strait along Kennedy Cd towards the Golden Horn. Once around the corner of the Horn, there will be a park called Gulhane Park on your left. Walk into the park and immediately to your left will be a footpath heading up the hill. There a Turkish Tea Shop there with the best views of the Bosphorus Straits. Interestingly enough, I was the only tourist there with the majority of the customers young Turkish people enjoying the sunshine.
Really nice. overall it was nice but after you have seen it there isn't really much to do afterwards so it was ok i guess.

the most essential tour. if you stay in istanbul just one day you should make this tour, do not leave istanbul without this tour. it is more important than others. take kapadash or ship from well known district aminonu pay 12 turkish lira ohwawo you will see a lot

Great to do on a sunny day. There are numerous companies that offer a Bosporus cruise, but the least costly and most interesting way to do this is to use the public ferries. They depart not far from the Spice Market. Just read a good guidebook before you go ( we used the Rick Steve's one) to help you fully appreciate what you are seeing and where you might want to get off to explore sights on land. The sailing provides a beautiful view of the Dolmabaci palace and landmark bridges as well as some other palaces now converted to upscale hotels ( complete with helicopter landing pads). Just the experience of sailing through these beautiful waters is worth the fare. Go up top to get the best views.

Lovely trip whichever way you go. We took the public ferry, which leaves from Eminonu twice a day and stops at about 4 towns on the way before arriving at the village of Anadolu Kavagi, which is the closest to the Black Sea you're allowed to go. They leave you here for a couple of hours before the return journey. There's a short, steep walk up to a ruined 14th century fortress, which has good views, but you can't get near the building, which is fenced off. Other than that, there are some tourist stalls and a lot of simple fish restaurants and ice cream sellers. The fish lunch by the water was good and fresh, but the town felt pretty artificial. It might have been more fun to stop at one of the bigger towns on the way, and one of the tourist cruises might be just as enjoyable, depending on what you want out of the trip.The public ferry was definitely a tourist boat, rather than a trip for locals (it was a public holiday when we went and there were only foreign tourists on board).If you want to see all the riverside houses and palaces, I guess any of the boats will be as good - you can get an audio/headphone guide on the ferry.Oh, and remember to take loo roll on the ferry!

Gorgeous tour on the Bosporus. Beautiful October day. We loved the one and a half hour tour we took on the Bosporus, seeing both sides of the river, beginning to the right of the Galata Bridge. ( from the New District side of the Golden Horn)Used the Rick Steves Istanbul Guidebook section on the Bosporus to help us understand what we were seeing. Loved the variety of boats we saw…. from yachts to tankers, just so much fun.

Beautiful Bosphorus. From whichever side you look at it, it looks so beautiful. Travelling by boat, surrounded by its blue waters and seagulls flying at your reach, or on the shores looking straight across to either Europe or Asia. Fishing, walking, eating, or just indulging in its beauty - take your pick!
Super!. Had a beautiful cruise on the Bosphorus, the views, the maritime traffic, the history, the architecture, it's all there.

WOW!. Very impressive and stunning passing from Europe to Asia. Don't forget to take public ferry which is way cheaper than touristic ones.For full experience, take Marmaray train which goes under the Bosphorus, which can be found on the other side and for 2 weeks from now on it goes for free. Enjoy your stay in Istanbul!

Nice boat ride. We took a short (2 hour) trip which was very pleasant. There was supposed to be English commentary onboard but although we tried different areas of the boat we could not hear it. Very pretty views of the European and Asian sides of the Bosphorous.

Great boat trip. We enjoyed our trip on the Bosporus. We got to see many beautiful homes and some historical sites that we would never have seen by land. The Bosporus is lively with many different kinds of boats and ships. It is a wonderful way to relax and sightsee at the same time.

We took a TL10 river cruise - a bargain!. We wanted to take a river cruise and found ourselves at the waterfront near Galata Bridge with a chap shouting (literally "Bospohrus Bosphorus Bosphorus" down a microphone over and over again.So slightly wary we joined the cruise (£3 per person!!) and spent 2 hours heading up to the big suspension bridge on the European side and back on the Asian side.The secenery is amazing - a mixture of impressive wealth and ruined waterside buildings which would cost £millions if on our shores!Probably the best value of our whole trip. Do it (and take a jumper!)

An interesting perspective of Istanbul from the sea. We booked a tour through Arista who are located in the heart of the SultanAhmet district. A coach took us to the ferry departure point. The cruise itself was about 1.5hrs long.Travelling along the Bosphorus Strait will certainly give you a view of Istanbul that is not accessible from land. Taking a good tour guide will certainly enable you to gain a much more detailed understanding of the significance and history of key building as you pass them. The only downside is the cost of these guided tours when you compare them to the price of the ferry ticket purchased on its own. In theory you could take a public ferry on your own at a fraction of the cost. The tour guide agency appear to add a significant mark-up to the price.

Worth every penny.. A wish come true for me… to cruise up the Bosphorus with blue water of the Strait and watch the two continents speaking to each other. It can also be treated as the history and culture tour. The trip was a as wonderful as it could have been. Cost is TL25.00 return, well worth every penny. Best would be to reach there half an hour early to get a seat of your choice.There are many fish restaurants for the tourists but a bit pricey. You can also but cool drinks and some snacks on the board.

One of the highlights of the whole tour for my husband. We spent a lovely, lazy afternoon, sailing down the Bosphorus, between continents. The buildings, on either side, are beautiful, with fantastic architecture. One member of our tour group celebrated her birthday with a surprise cake.The sun was going down, as we returned, so the Blue Mosque & other buildings, made an impressive, atmospheric silhouette in the half-light.

Cruising the Bosphorus. This was a long-held dream - to cruise up the Bosphorus with all the history and culture involoved. The trip was a wonderful experience but a few pointers worth noting:at this time of year (Autumn) there is only one boat leaving from Eminono per day and that is at 10.35 am sharp. Best to be there no later than 10.00 in order to get a good seat. Cost is TL25.00 return.Secondly, the final destination, Anadolu, where the ferry stops for 3 hours is a bit of an anti-climax. It is very touristy with many so-called fish restaurants who serve up rather pricy but really standard fare. Our choice would have been to hop off at the 3rd last stop (number 6 on the guide) called Sanyer (?), a lovely looking place although without the view of the Black Sea that Anadolu may offer. The ferry trip is far more comprehensive than the other so-called Bosphorus tours that only take you as far as the second bridge. Oh and be sureto take along something warm, especially at this time of the year as it gets really chilly on the water.

here is how to buy the tickets..... the river is a must do and its really easy to hop on hop off the 8 or 9 ports both sides of the water.two choice 1 offical tour or 2 public ferrythere are endless numbers of tour operators , best to buy tickets at the harbour, they cost 25 TL for an all day hop on hop off ticket, and tour guide talking over the radio... get a seat upstairs for the views. On the second stop on the Asian side you will see a huge seafront restaurant, right on the water at the small harbor, its a cool place run by the police, and its open to the public.... it was just fab.PUBLIC FERRYthe public ferry is really cheap about 1 euro ,or 3 TL, it is a single journey for east to west, you but your ticket from a machine, and it gives you a red token that allows you through the turnstile barriers onto the ferry,,,we did both trips and both were fun.....the ferry gives a sense of reality and the tour gives the history etc either way or both, you have got to do this.oh the shops are cheaper on the asia side....if you see a shop D and P selling perfume buy some, really top quality at 10euro a bottle.

It is a small world. Ferry boat round trip from Eminonu, T£25 return, well worth every penny. Glide upon the turquoise waters of the Strait and watch the two continents watching each other. The interest points abound, the folding map you get with the ticket does pinpoint the main ones, but a good guide with photographs and a good pair of binoculars would provide further surprising riches. Having disembarked at the Black Sea entrance, in Asia, do not succumb to the entreaties of energetic restaurant PR men, but walk for two minutes and get on the local bus running down the coast (Istanbul travel card works for payment) and get off at Kanlica, a pretty fishing village with some rather splendid high-gated villas on the outskirts and a delightful Sinan mosque. Have a good fish lunch and catch the ferry back to Eminonu at 15.40.

Great afternoon activity. Join a Bosphorus tour and spend a few hours cruising up and down the strait. Here's the deal... To participate in a tour on a larger vessel purchase tickets from the ticket offices near Galata Bridge rather than vendors with signs - this will also ensure a seaworthy boat. The tour I attended did not announce or point out any attractions - it was very enjoyable by more like a ferry ride than a tour. So, read up on the attractions beforehand, follow along on the free maps available at the ticket office, or pay for the audio guide. I did the second. Bring binoculars for a chance to spot porpoises and seabirds (i saw both) and bring a sweater or jacket. Even a hot day in the city can be very cold on the water. The muze pass also gets you discounts with some companies so ask when buying your tickets.
Day trip. Take the normal ferry leaves around 10.35 , travels for 1.5 hours up the river. Stopover for 3 hrs then returns at 3. Great value and awesome picture opportunities.

Essential boat trip. Try the ferry which travels part of the Strait, dropping and collecting passengers. It's a good way to see more of the city, especially how the modern buildings exist beside the well known historical attractions.

A must when in Istanbul!. This is a fab cruise1 Just catch to local ferry dont pay high prices for a tour! It stops at a few villages along the way and the last stop was the best, a beaut little village will a small and quaint market. Trip leaves 10.30 am from Istanbul and returns 4.30 pm. Its a great day out1

Take a boat. You cannot visit this city without taking the majestic tour up the Bosphorus, it last for about 2 hours and is so cheap about £3 per person, we picked a beautiful sunny morning and got the best views of both the european and asian sides. If we had enough time we would have also taken the evening trip.

Trip between the continents. The boat trip I took there was lovely. I loved the color of the water,I've never seen such a shade of blue elsewhere,it was like ink. It's wonderful to travel between the two continents. On one side you see Europe and on the other - Asia.

Interesting. I had no idea there was so much history to the various suburbs along the Bosphorus. Amazing to see the small cross strait ferries weaving in between the humungous container ships. It's a watery Piccadilly Circus! Do also walk along the shorefront from Dolmabahce towards the cruise ship terminal....the locals lounge around and the kids play in the water.
Very relaxing. Try to get a cruise on the Bosphorus, but buy the tickets in the harbour. It's much cheaper. We paid €11 for 2 hours on a boat and it was great.

take the city ferry. we were staying on the Asian side of Istanbul @ Sumahan on the Water. while they had a launch that would take guests across to the European side, we wanted to explore the little villages on both sides of the Bosphorus. So we took the City Ferry; we boarded @ Cengelkoy and just went up the strait, stopping at a little town that it interested us-- Kanilca, the yogurt making capital of Turkey. Our plan to take a later ferry back to Cengelkoy didn't work. So we hopped on a bus, it was the wrong bus--going towards Anatolia not Istanbul. Got off the bus, & another kind Istanbullis put us on the correct bus back to Cengelkoy. An adventure!! Istanbul has lots of them.
Bosphorus Cruise. It is well worth a cruise along the Bosphorus. we only did one for 1 1/2 hours, but saw all the marble palaces on the water front. It was an interesting tour.

All Day Boat Ride. Took the all day boat ride and it was great. Our guidebook gave us as much information as we needed. High point was definitely the meal at the last town, where we had time to eat and hike. We had fried mussels. Wish I could have found them in Istanbul.

Nice place. this is again something that you will get to experience when you are there in the city. A stroll along this place will give you a good flavour of what the city is all about. Take a night dinner cruise, if you get the option .

We Always Love a Boat Trip. We always try do a boat trip on the local river if possible. Istanbul is such an amazing city that you can only completely appreciate it if you have seen it by water. We did a 3 hour tourist boat trip and it opened up a new picture of the city, the Bosporus, Istanbul’s history and its current importance to those countries that front the Black Sea.

Fun boat cruise around the bosphurus. We took a boat cruise around the Bosphorus strait. It was a great way to view istanbul city. The cruise offered dinner which was not that good. However they also offer fun traditional shows and dance performances. They also put music for people to dance. The bosphosrus straight cruise is a "must do" activity in istanbul.
Unique experience. dont forget to cover, and if you do, they'll provide you with blue scarfs at the door. it was a spiritual experience.

very beatiful. bosphorus strait was really beautiful and the historical places that are neat it like palaces and musium and mosques are really beatifull and fantastic. you can take bosphorus tour with boat to see it
Bosphorus of a thousand shades !. It was absolutely heavenly, especially the yacht cruise on the Bosphorus. The belly dancers were stunning and the view of the shoreline was truly unforgettable.
Worth two hours of your time. We took a two-hour cruise and it was a wonderful way to see Istanbul. Very relaxing and interesting.

A great site see. Take the boat tour around The Bosphorus. There are lots of things to see and enjoy on the waterway. Lots of different types of boats on the waterway and many architecturally different structures along the way.

Great boat tour. We took a tour of the strait and it was great. The ship was a little pushy on buying drinks and snacks so I could have done without being asked 5 times if I wanted to drink some tea. Overall, the strait is a must see!!!!

Restful Cruise. We chose the FULL DAY cruise because we wanted to go as close to the Black Sea as possible. Loved the long, restful cruise especially after a previous FULL day of walking around the Old City with our private guide. The fishing village was enjoyable and the restaurant that we chose was sooo good. An excellent meal. Some of our group went on the hike up to the castle area. Beautiful.
Cruising between Asia and Europe. The 2 hour cruise on the Bosphorus is worth the cost. The views are excellent and the boats I saw very safety conscience. Will do this cruise again

Romantic, Important, Beautiful. The Bosphorus Strait is what makes Istanbul Istanbul. Linking the Black Sea to the Sea of Marmara and Europe to Asia, the Bosphorus contributed greatly to the rich and varied history of this great and ancient city. At first glimpse the ages, including those of of Jason and Medea, Byzantium, and Constantinople echoed through my head. It is interesting to take a sightseeing boat trip of the Bosphorus, but my favorite experience was the ride on the public ferry from Karakoy to Kadacoy at sunset. From the strait one views Sultanahmet as a silhouette that features the shapes of the old city, especially those of Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque.

Beautiful waterway, and lovely bridges.. Went on a cruise at 1800, so was travelling in the day and also the evening. Would have preferred all day we think, to see more, however the lights were lovely, and especially the bridge that changes colours with the lights when dark.

See Europe and Asia at the same time.. The Bosphorus Strait is beautiful, busy like all of Istanbul, and integral to the economic future of Istanbul. On both sides of the Straits, business takes place, and old and new live side-by-side. There is so much to see in this historic place, and it is all connected by the Bosphorus Strait. You can cross it on a ferry, fish from it, and walk along it. Beautiful.

Take the short tour. There are two options from what we could gather. The first, roughly two hours, stay on the boat trip up and back to see the City from a different perspective. The second is a 6 hour trip including 3 hours in a small fishing village. We took the first option at the suggestion of our hotel concierge as 3 hours in the fishing village is too long. 12 TL or about $7 each for our trip.

Unforgettable. I guess if you're short on time, you have to plan these things and get the most out of your two, four or six hours but if you have the luxury of not needing to be somewhere else tomorrow, then hop on any of the boats at the quay-side and just relax as you get transported not just to Asia or the Black Sea, but back about 100 years. These boats are magical, and everything you see from them seems to sparkle as you pass. You don't need to be going somewhere, just take in the view before you, sip the tea that's just been poured for you, listen to the musicians playing in the background and then start feeling sad that you're not at work. The work ethic got me again after five days - I had the flight booked so couldn't delay - but if someone challenged me to pass a month doing nothing, I can't think of any better location than the Bosphorus.
Incredible. The views are amazing crossing the Boshorous by boat to think this is one of the most traveled waterways in the world and the water is incredibly blueShame on New York/ Jersey
Beautiful. A must see. So beautiful, so different.. If you are on a business trip with very little time in your hands and you want to " taste" Istambul, this would be a unforgettable way to spend it

ONE HOUR CRUISE. We did a tour on a private motor boat on the Bosphorus Strait taking in the beautiful scenery on both sides. You get to cruise past some of the most luxurious Ottoman Palaces and see the Rumeli Fortress. Well worth the trip.
Fantanstic cruise at night. You must must must do the cruise at night and feel the euro-asian bosphorus bridge! its breathtaking opportunity for all photographers

A wonderful diversion. We just hopped on the regular 1.5 hr cruise ferry at Eminonu, the one where the usher keeps yelling "Bogaz Bogaz Bogaz". They depart often, and the cost is 10 lira each, paid to the usher. There's tea and juice served on board. Many bring food and sesame bagels. I'd recommend to bring some source of information on what's on the sides of the Bosphorus, so you can read about things as you pass them.One and a half hours seemed just right. The ferry stays close to the European coast and goes non-stop to Rumeli Fortress and the suspension bridge, then makes a turn and heads back staying close to the Asian coast. Departure at 5.30 pm proved to be a perfect timing: the sun was low and cast golden light on the European side, then we saw the sunset hues on the way back, and landed amid the night illumination.

Ferrybost tour is recommended. We took a ferryboat tour going to Black Sea. It takes one and half hour and drops at some points, but we didn't get bored. We drank CAY, simit and KANLICA Yoghurt on the boat.

AMAZING TOUR. Love THE BOSPHORUS TOUR we took by boat . IT Was a 2 Hours and we saw both European and Asian side . Cost WAS 35 liras per person . You can see all historical sights . Take the 1PM tour as it is chilly with the tour that leaves at 4pm
bosphorus. since byzantine it is a dream view area... you must visit both at the day & night.. there are many restaurants.. if you prefer night clubs ortakoy area & su island are best locations..

A Must in Istanbul!. We took the Bosphorus cruise while visiting Istanbul in late Sept 2013. It turned out to be one of our favourite attractions during our trip. This cruise allows us a glimpse of both the European and Asian side of Istanbul with some historical sightseeing spots along the strait. After reading the various options of taking the cruise, we decided to take the advice to stay clear of the private tours and take the Full Bosphorus Tour with the traditional Sehir Hatlari ferry boat. The cruise was inexpensive, cost TL25 per person, from Eminonu to Anadolu Kavagi (a fishing village) on the Asia shore and back to Eminonu. The 6 hour cruise included a 3 hour stop at Anadolu Kavagi (the stop is a must if you take the full day cruise). During the stop at the fishing village, we first hiked to the Fortress (the walk is quite short about 20mins but certain stage can be quite a tiring climb), enjoyed the view of the Black Sea. Although there are many restaurants by the shore, we decided to have our lunch at the hill top restaurant to soak in the wonderful view. We then had our coffee and dessert at one of the cafes by the waterfront before boarding the ferryboat. What an unforgettable Bosphorus tour! We were glad we set aside the day to take the full day cruise!

A lovely way to relax. If you have the time take the six hour cruise along the Bosphorus with the city ferry. It's a lazy way to spend the day and to view the European and Asian sides of Istanbul. It's a much cheaper option than the shorter tour group options.

Little cruise. Take a boattrip on the river and enjoy the beautifull views. Tickets are available in offices and the boats itselfs, drinks and snacks aboard. We cruised for about 2 hours, both shores.

A Trip to the Fishing Town of Sariyer. Bought one-way Sehir Hatları ferry company tickets from Eminonu to Sariyer (10TL each). Wonderful sights all the way up the Bosphorous. Wondered around the waterfront and inner streets of Sariyer, enjoying the relative peacefulness compared with central Istanbul. Had lunch at Pide Ban restaurant, Dereboyu Caddesi, in central Sariyer and enjoyed their good food as well as watching their Turkish clientele doing the same. We were the only foreigners but made very welcome. Caught bus 25E along the western shoreline back to Istanbul. That gave us not only a different perspective of the Bosphorous, but also a close-up view of life on the shoreline. Bus took us as far as Kabatas terminal. A really enjoyable day trip.
Don't miss this. The bosphorous at night, go to the fish restaurants under the bridge, breathtaking ... The lights, the movement on the river, cll to prayer ....

Private Cruise- Priceless. I had the great pleasure of scheduling a private tour of the straits, and it was lovely. The staff treated me like royalty-- beverages, food, and kindness. I learned much about both the historic areas on the straits as well as the new architecture. It is gorgeous! I now understand why the real estate on the Bosphorous is so high. Magical!

To relax in Istanbul .... There are quite a few boats that go up and down the Boshorus, and it is a really nice way to get off your feet for a few hours and enjoy cruising up the strait. These don't make it all the way to the Black Sea, but the views from the strait itself, as well as the sites along the way, make this an enjoyable outing. Avoid the guys at the mosques trying to sell you tickets and just go the piers by the pedestrian bridge across the horn and you'll be able to get a ticket easily.

Forget the Tours. Take the Ferry.. The tours that the hawkers try to sell you are not as long yet are three times more expensive than the 25TL ferry. It moves at a lovely leisurely pace passing all the wonderous sights that the Bosphorus has to offer. During winter there is only one trip per day leaving at 10.35am but you want to be sure to be there at least 45 minutes early in order to secure a good seat, I recommend the outside seats on the top deck. The trip takes about an hour and a half in each direction and allows you a nearly three hour stay in the delightful village of Anadolu Kavagi where restaurants, coffee shops, ice cream and souvenirs await you. I predict that you will end up thinking that this trip was the best £8 you can spend in Istanbul, the hawkers trips only go as far as the bridge and cost nearly £25.

Awesome views in killer autumn weather.... A walk along the Bosphorus is a great way to unwind from the historic tourist track. Highly enjoyed my time along the waterfront watching the locals catching fish.
Don't Miss a Cruise on the Bosphorus. Whatever you do do not miss a cruise on the Bosphorus, a highlight of any trip to Istanbul. The views from the water are magnificent.

So much fun. We decided not to take a commerial boat with 100's of tourists on it so we headed to the fishing area and found a small boat that took max 8 people. It was totally worth the extra 15lira! 100lira for 2 hours and Ersin was such a fun guide. Stop at the shop on your way down and buy some beers and snack to take with for the ride.

Cruise Ship Perspective. We passed through the Bosphorus Strait on a cruise ship on our way to the Black Sea. If you are on a cruise doing this make sure that you are on deck for the experience. If you are transiting into the Black Sea be on the left hand (Port) side of the ship to see the Blue Mosque and St. Sophia. Also look up as the ship passes under the two bridges and make sure that you have a mast in view. There is more clearance than there appears to be! Just be on deck in time to see the city of Istanbul come and go as you pass through the Strait - a great experience.

So much to see in a two hour trip!. We chose to take the ferry by the Galata bridge (it was 25 TL for a 2 hour trip). It was absolutely stunning. We saw mosques, the Galata tower, the Istanbul business district buildings, a Turkish submarine (!), Leander tower to name but a few. There were plenty of photo opportunities. It was the best £8 we've ever spent. The price of tea and snacks on board were very reasonable.
go bye boat for a tour.. Wonderful sights from a tour boat..about 2 hours is plenty of time. Homes, forts, church's and mosques all along the route. History is so important here.
Nice for all. Cross bosphorous by a nice cruising boat and see europe and asia around ..Also visit Pierre loti hill

A trip between two continents. We took the morning trip from besktas . It was only for about 10 $,but it was the best 10 $ I have ever payed . The bosphorus is like magic with it crystal waters . It makes u feel that you are crossing alsearat towards heaven . After this lovely tour we left the vapor on the Asian part of Istanbul ,then we took the bus and started to familiarize ourselves with this very beautiful and still virgin part of Istanbul,for it is still not that much known by tourists. We had lunch in uskudar ,then we returned to the European part of Istanbul by boat. I recommend this trip to newly weds for it is very romantic .
Yacht trip. We hired private yacht from 4 seasons at Bosporus ...lovely 2 hour sail on the Bosporus where you get a sense of the sheer size of Istanbul & you get to see all the lovely waterside homes

Research before you go!. We were in Istanbul for a short while and planned our Bosphorous tour for the last evening, unfortunately the Government tour was already over by then.It is apparently the best and cheapest available.Do your research on prices and routes before you go because some tours charge 50 - 75 Euros and I think it may be a bit much.There are also last minute tours till about 7 pm if you go to the jetty, which is what we took, it was quite enjoyable, a great view and nice weather.

Real historic. I think it is most strategic location in history as many countries dreamed of acquiring it. S there were many wars for it and along teh strait.It's a must see and enjoy in Istanbul as in addition to historical stories and points, you'll see an strait which seperates two continents and one city. WOW.

Go at night. We opted for the simple one and a half hour "taxi" tour. It was only $10 each and fabulous. It was dusk when we departed and dark when we returned so you could see all the wonderful lights of Istanbul from the Bosporous.

Lovely tour. We had a lovely afternoon on the Bosphorus. Great views of the city. It is a 2 hour trip and very reasonably priced. There is also a 5 hour trip that leaves once a day in the morning. We thought the 2 hours was enough, but I think you get up to the Black Sea with the 5 hour trip.

Take the Public Ferry it is a bargain!!. This was our second time in Istanbul so we knew that the public ferry from the Galata Bridge to Kavagi was a bargain at 25 Lira (£7.80) instead of the £20 - 30 charged by the commercial tour cruises. Any decent guide book or even the leaflet provided by the ferry company is enough to let you know what the various sites on the route are. Once in Kavagi climb the hill to the castle first to get superb views of the Bosporus and Black Sea. The restaurants on the hill are cheaper than those in the village and tend to be less crowded.There is a shorter 10 Lira ferry trip if you do not have time to spare.

A must boat ride. From the boat you can see the city of Istanbul from a totally new perspective. I took both the two hour trip on a cold and rainy day (great day for photos) and the 4 and a half hour trip to the Black Sea on a sunny and warm day. The views along the European and Asian shores were always enticing. The only part I did not like was getting off the boat at the en of the trip.

Just go. We went in a half day guided trip, but should have rather dine a full day on the public ferry. There is a real sense of history sailing down to the Black Sea, past castles and fortresses. The houses along the shoreline are lovely, and the views of Istanbul, coming back in the evening, were amazing. A must do

Beyond belief such a busy waterway.. This is an old and very ancient waterway which is very much alive and bustling with water traffic from nations world wide. The bridges on the Bosphurus connecting the two continents is extremely busy as well. Many interesting and historic places along the way. 4-6 hour boat trips are readily available at prices from as low as about US$20 per couple.

Easy to use ferry system. How to best enjoy this:Go to one of the ferry places (around the Galata bridge) and simply board a public ferry over to the Asian side. There are ticket machines which will take coins (!!) and are easy to use. They give out a jeton to be used at the gate.  For those of you reading this who are used to the latin alphabet: Everything is well signed so it is extremely hard to do anything wrong.If weather permits stay outside on top and enjoy the view. Wonderful picture opportunities. Or enjoy the hustle and bustle on the strait. Enjoy the asian side for some time (food and drinks much cheaper than on the european side) and take a ferry back. Waiting time max 20 min on most ferry lines. And best time to ride, in sunset when the lights go on at the great mosques. A must do in Istanbul.

Europe Asia - a moving experience. Yes, this is a great piece of geography - it packs a punch to be between two continents and to see the enormity of Istanbul, 20m population, spreading as far as the eye can see right across the horizon, and topped by the inevitable city smog on a hot day...but the views are really awesome. Forget the over-priced candle-lit Bosphorus Cruises - just take a ferry across to the Asian side from Kabatas or better still take the Princes Islands trip - that's terrific, though I'm told the islands are hideously busy in peak season. We loved this in October on a perfect day. A great way to escape the cars and crowds of the city.

A bargain--and a great view of Istanbul!. This is one of the all-time great travel bargains. For a US dollar or so, you can cross from Europe to Asia in just a few minutes. Wander around on the Asia side, have some street food or ice cream, visit the Greek Orthodox church, and soak up the ambiance. Beautiful views of Istanbul on the crossing.

Be prepared for large crowds and don't bother with audio guide. We went to buy our round trip tickets at 0900 and glad we did as the line up started shortly after we got there. Thinking we were early we got a good seat inboard only to realize that 15 min before we were to leave everybody started exiting to the boat alongside us....didn't know why but we were changing boats. There were a lot of people and so not use to rubbing elbows for the whole trip. I bought an audio guide but it was so noisy on the boat that I couldn't hear what was being said. The places being pointed out by the audio guide had gone past prior to being mentioned. So save your 10 TL and just admire the scenery. When we got to Anadolu Kavagi we thought we would eat first then walk up to the castle. That was an experience. All restaurants want your business as tourists are their business. Be prepared to be persuaded into a restaurant. A word to the wise, not sure about all restaurants but the one we went to charged us for things we didn't intend to order and wanted to charge a different price then was quoted. My suggestion is if you want to see the castle - go to it first as there are places to eat at the base of the castle. A steep walk up but worth it for the view

4 hour tour. We took the four hour tour which was very nice. We saw both the European and Asian sides. We learned so much about Istanbul and the famous buildings through the tour guide on the boat. We were also able to swim on the Black Sea. Quite a treat although the currents were terribly strong- almost too dangerous
Bosphorous cruise. Whatever you do take the night time cruise ! The night shows the city all lit up, plus you get to see both continents on one ride, the old and the new.

Spectacular place to cruise. We passed through the strait on a cruise on a beautiful sunny day. Many famous historic sites are located near the strait and are easily visible. This passage between Europe and Asia is a memorable trip.

Take the Ferryboat. A nice view of both the European and the Asian sides of Istanbul.You will see Ottoman palaces,centuries old mansions and see where the who's who of Istanbul live and party.A pleasant way to spend a couple of hours in the afternoon

Take the short tour for best value. Took the tram to the last stop and bought tickets for the 1-1/2 hour tour up to the second bridge and back down along the Asian side. Cost was less than $10usd each, which we considered a bargain. You see the rest of Istanbul without cosumeing the whole day. BEST VALUE

Such sights!. This was really a highlight. To see the numerous palaces lining the banks of the river, and the fortress' is spectacular. Such a nice river boat cruise and a perfect way to see Istanbul.

relaxing. it is always nice to see a place from the water and the trip was ok but nothing to write home about. good to see different places as instanbul is so big and so busy you just cant get round to see it all. it was relaxing though.

for a quick impression a good start. There are dozens of people selling trips on Bosporus and it is worthwile doing so. It gives you a quick impression of the city, like you do the Hudson river trip in New York you do the Bosporus in Istanbul.Try to get a boat with a good PA, we had one with a lousy PA and did not understand anything what was said, but the views on the buildings are just great.
Beautiful views. We loved our ferry ride on the Bosphorus. This is something everyone should do if visiting Istanbul. Next time we are going to the Black Sea.

Take the ferry NOT a tour!. We went for a tour with ITR......chaotic, expensive, not much commentary and a waste of money. No one seemed to know which bus we should get on, where we were going, what time etc. Of the 4 hours we paid 35euros each for, we only spent about 1hour actually cruising. The only bonus was a trip to the Spice Market, but you can do that yourself.Do yourself a favour and go on the ferry!

VIP - Paris. i loved it! it just looked so good...all the top cars are there and lots of classy people.i felt like a famous star...and happy.the air was clear, the view of the Bosphorus with the green mountains around it. it was amazing.white yachts....the food! i didnt wanted to leave this place. wish i would have a villa over there...so nice and relaxing it was.

night scene of the Bosphorus. They told me that the sun set over the Bosphorus was beautiful., but we got to cruise the strait after dark. The traffic getting to the pier was murder. They said stop and go traffic was very typical along the water front. Our group of 65 booked the whole boat, which could probably seat 100-150 people. It didn't take long to get out to the strait. Both the European and the Asia side were all lit up, some were even colorful. One can see the domes of the mosques, lights shining up the minarets like round caps decorated with spearheads. Fortresses and palaces up the hills along the water front were lighted up too. The bridges crossing the Bosphorus linking the 2 Istanbuls (Europe and Asia) were all decked out in color lights and changing colors too. It was a drizzly night of October 1, and I told myself that I should have worn a heavier fleece vest under my rain coat.. The water was calm, and the boat/ship had a covered upper deck which made the cruise more enjoyable. It was a good cruise.

The only place u can be in Europe an Asia. The only place u can be in Asia an Europe at onetime.beware there are lotsa guys trying to sell u Bosporus cruise,some are fake and some are genuine.its beta to take from your hotel or a reputable company.they promise you food an when u get aboard u have to pay.otherwis excellent cruise

Beautiful ferry ride. Very scenic view on the 2 hour ferry ride that cost only 10TL each. It was very windy and I was glad to bring my jacket. It covers most of the important areas in Istanbul. The guy on the boat came round with a tray of tea which many assumed was included but then came round to ask for 2TL each.

Bosporus cruise. Definitely cheaper to go down to eminomu and get on the hop on hop off boat 12 lira($6) as opposed to tour guide who wanted $40 US. Boat has recording of all stops and stuff along the way. Awesome views of dolmabache palace from the water. Just being able to it Europe and Asia in one day was a total thrill. Must do thing in Istanbul

Must do boat trip. A boat trip on the Bosphorus is a must do on a visit to Istanbul. There's a range of options, from very cheap public ferries, to reasonably priced private boats. Some offer full day trips, others half a day and some 1.5 hours. If you are short of time, the 1.5 hour trip will show you the most interesting part of the strait, the first few miles out of the city. There are lots of beautiful historic buildings and more modern ones on both sides of the strait. The half day trip goes almost all the way to the mouth of the Black Sea. It turns back just before the entrance to the sea, despite the brochure claiming that it goes TO the Black Sea! Well worth doing, to see the architecture and the busy sea lane full of tiny fishing vessels, huge container ships and even more huge cruise liners. We even saw dolphins frolicking in front of a cruise boat.

Historic Waterways. Once you appreciate that you are on a body of water that is steeped in history, you will enjoy the trip tremendously. I tried to imagine what the shore would look like when the Greeks founded Istanbul.The trip affords a magnificent view of the Dolmabahce Palace, and Rumeli Citadel (a medieval castle). We thoroughly enjoyed the relaxing ride - well worth the effort.

Beautiful body of water. You hear stories all the time about the Bosphorus and think it is a huge body of water. It is really not that wide of a waterway at all.
