great boat trip. went on a one and half hour round trip it had commentary but this was hard to hear. however there was refreshments available on the boat and it was very pleasant to see the sights from the water.

Get to know other views of Istanbul. We took the Turyol ferry on the left side of the Galata Bridge. The ferry departures every 30min, the tour lasted 1h30 for 9TL. The tour also includes comments of the attractions in english but unfortunately the audio system didn't work very well. In any case, the views are amazing and you get to see other sides of the city, especially at sunset.

One of the great waterways of the world. Best seen. I went on the Bosphorous ferry tour (£10, 2 hr 15, leaves 3 x day outside Aga Sophia). Very good way to see Istanbul, Anatolia and the golden horn on the deck of a ship. Highly recommended

The most beautiful sunset... Its beauty is accessible to everybody to enjoy sitting on one of the numerous benches along side it.. The water changes colors several times a day and is peaceful to just sit, "breath", listen.. and watch the boats, the birds, the sea and the sky, as well as the people strolling alongside...
Cruise :). Also don't miss cruising the Bosphorus , it's a great way to see the sights and castles on the side of the waters ... It's just 12TL for almost a 2 hour trip ... Enjoyable

explore the city on the sea. on our previous trip we tried the uskudar ferry which was not touristic but interesting.this time we found a phosphorus tour at eminunu for one hour 10 tl and was very nice specially it was the best place to pass the evening gap between checking out our hotel room at noon and taking our flight at night

A nice day trip. We took the ferry up the Bosphorus to the Black Sea. The ferry stopped at several ports on the way, on both the European side and the Asian side. We spent about 3 hours in an Asian fishing village for lunch, but we climbed to the old tower first and were glad we did! It's a tough climb and many were exhausted after it. But the view of the Black Sea is worth it. Not much else up there except the view. Back in the village, we had lunch at one of the waterside restaurants. Nothing special. The ice cream from a sidewalk vendor was great, though.

Using the Ferry. For very little money you can catch a ferry across the Bosphorus. You can also pay rather more and go on a cruise. Either way don't miss doing this while you are in Istanbul. It is enormous fun to just pile on an ordinary ferry with all the locals and go to the other side. There you can walk about have some coffee and travel back again. If you go on a night cruise take a jacket, it gets quite cold out on the water.
The Strait pulls you in and mesmerises you. It reminds me of Hong Kong. Tons of ferries crossing the strait, other boats also for fishing or sailing. We even saw dolphins in the river.

Took the ferry. Don't see the huge attraction.. We took the 2-3 hour ferry instead of the pricier, longer tour as recommended by our hotel. Ferry itself was fine. Onboard food and beverages weren't expensive. We saw several palaces on the way and the Bosphorus bridge as well as views of the city. It was a nice time but I think it's very overrated as a must see/do. There are much more interesting things to see/do elsewhere.

Fantastic views of Istanbul. On one side of the river is the Asian continent while on the other side of the river, is the European continent. Where else on Earth would a person be able to view this? There are plenty of spectacular views of Istanbul from the boat cruise. In addition, we got to see some very expensive properties on the river front.

To the Black sea. We took a cruise along the Bosporus to the Black Sea to see Istanbul from the water. Interesting sites to see , lunch on board and , all in all, a nice afternoon.Traffic in the New part of the City is horrendous, but we saw some of the New City on the way to the boat.
Bosphorus. Split between Europe and Asia - old and new Istanbul. Several bridges cross the strait and many fishing boats, as well as cruise ships at dock. Restaurants and shops all along the strait.
Real Blue Waters. a short trip on real blue waters made me refresh my minds about nature and beauty.The ships and staff are helpful.the islands are so nice and clean.

The best way to see the city. A boat trip on the Bosphorus is not only cheap, about £4 each, but an excellent way to see the city. Istanbul is vast, crowded and noisy and spending 2 hours on the water gives you an opportunity to take it all in but in a peaceful environment
Boat trip. Take the 2 hour boat trip to the Bosporus bridge to view European and Asian side of Istanbul, cheap 10 ytl.

Wonderful scenary!. The scenary you see during this cruise is awesome!! Beautiful houses, boats, sea!! It is quite long, 1:30hr? 2 hrs? we got off at the last station, there wasnt much to do there, a small village. I think we had around 1 hour to see the place and then get the ferry and head back to Istanbul. It was enough time. Be aware of the expensive restaurants there near the water. Their prices are way too high and the food isnt at all worth it. We ate grilled chicken file and grilled seabase fish and they tasted like water. Their prices were high and they charged so much for a bit of bread and water they served along with the food. They didnt even let us decide how much tip we wanted to give the waiter! They added it on our bill which pissed us off. If I were to go there again, I would definitely buy something from Istanbul and take it with me. A doner or some other sandwich. The "seafood" there wasnt anything special, believe me! Take some food with you and walk around the village.

Beauty of Istanbul. While I did not care much about the boat company we went with (Blue Brothers) the cruise was very nice. It gives you a window to the rest of Istanbul - which, if you have time, you must definitely visit. It appears to be very different from the Old City side and is very scenic. I wish we could've gotten off on the other side.

Boat Trips. The Bosphorus is a scene of constant movement, there are both tour boats and ferries to take you around the Istanbul area. As I was there partly on business I used the public transport system inculding the ferries its faster than taxis and if you buy an Istanbul card great value.

Great views, on good weather good 1.5 hour pastime. The boat deaparts every hour so be ontime!!! Better get there 15 min before to get a good seat. I found that it is better to sit downstairs (inside) and open a window to get the pictures, than stay upstairs on the open (it is windy in any case and to me the messed up hair doesn't look too good on the pictures, besides it is a bit chilly because of the wind)They serve tea, orange juice and snacks (not included in the ticket price)Get a tram or taxi there because there is no parkingOn the downside:1) if you take the boat from the European side, don't panic, the boat first goes and picks up people from the Asian side and only then the tour starts.2) The advertisement says that info is provided in English during the tour but in fact you cannot hear anything legible because of the quality of the tape and the noise in the boat - so just relax and enjoy the views
You shoud do a cruise in bosphorus. I highly recomend a cruise in bosphorus. Gives you a better idea of the city. and you can see a lot of palaces in a way that by foot you couldn't

Bosphorus Cruise. The Cruise is very relaxing. Took a lot of pictures. The scene scenery is lovely. The vendors sell Turkish tea and cofee and some eatables too if you are hungry. Standing on the deck is good fun. Loved it.

Could Be Fatal. Ironically, this turned out to be the most dangerous part of our trip to Turkey. We went on a Two Continents & Bosphorus tour, and a Bosphorus cruise was part of the itinerary. Our tour company was Tourista and the cruise boat they took us on was marked with their name. A few minutes into the cruise, we noticed a smokey smell on board, then some smoke rose from the lower deck. All the passengers started freaking out and evacuating to the outer parts of the boat. We could hear the crew argue in Turkish and they wouldn't let us know what was going on, other than that they will dock as soon as possible and continue the cruise on another boat. Throughout the whole ordeal, our guide kept on talking as if nothing was happening. One passenger started panicking for real after some time passed and we were still in the middle of the water. I looked out the boat and realized that, not only was it cold, but a whole bunch of jellyfish were circling the waters. Formulating an emergency escape plan in my head didn't provide me with any comfort under those circumstances. Death by frostbite, and a swollen jellyfish bit corpse was not the way I wanted to go. Still, I think I had it easier than the family with a baby and a toddler. My main worry actually was that the boat would explode and we'd be toast. All of a sudden, jumping ship didn't sound that bad. The lesson to learn here is to be very careful when choosing the operator of this cruise. The cruise itself was very nice, but our trip was tainted with this bad experience. We eventually docked and changed boats. The second one was safer and a lot nicer. I recommend that you go on a Bosphorus cruise while in Istanbul because you won't be able to see the coastal side of the sites along the shore unless you're on the Bosphorus.

Worth a boat ride. Do not take the expensive tour boats. If you are a budget traveler, it makes sense to take the local tour boats for 12TL (when we visited) without commentary. You can use guide books to read about the sights nearby. Its a pleasant 90 minute ride that will take you near the asian side as well.

Boat trip with surprisingly beautiful scenery. Don't take the private boats that are sold alongside the quayside, it is far cheaper to take the official city run boat. The boat is definitely not the height of luxury or comfort but worth 25L for 6 hours. We had a very nice late lunch before going back to the city. The banks of the Bosphorus are lush and verdant with gorgeous houses.

Do the short tour. Having read lots of reviews it is best to get advice from your hotel. We were told which tour to select and where to get on which was perfect for us. I think often people get on the wrong tour and then are disappointed. lots of snacks were available and tea. Beautiful historic sites at every turn sit on the Asian side as you get the best views.

A Bosphorus Trip is a must do. Make it the 90 minute trip.. As others have said it is so easy to go to the boat area and buy your ticket at 12TL for a 90 minute trip, first up the European side of Istanbul and then back down the Asian side. This trip is worth doing. Sit on left side of boat for the photos. We didn't have a sunny day so any photos had a very grey sky. A nice sunny day with blue skies will give you some great photos.

do your own thing. Really enjoyed this experience, we did our own booking at the docks with the local boat company, less than half the price of the touts. Perfect for an afternoon following seeing the sights, put your feet up and enjoy the views. Have a fish sandwich before you embark, go where the locals are buying from.
Another trip to take. This is a fantastic trip, well worth taking. take your camera and the long lens. not expensive, just turn up at the cruise terminal, buy tickets and go.

wonderful 1.5h cruise. Don't take upper deck - it'll be either too much sun or wind. Go down instead and sit on a side of a boat. It is warmer outside and no wind at all. If you order turkish tea keep an eye on your empty cup - it can easily slip and break.

not great. many boat rides on offer. WE decided on one through Bosphorus Tours, pushy tour guide who didn't deliver. Shuttle meant to pick you up after tour, it was not there so we had to walk back (not the end of the world as we were able but if we had smaller children or those with walking difficulties it would have meant getting a taxi). No information given about the sites on route. I would not recommend<
So beautiful!!!!. Bosporous cruise was sooo cool! I loved seeing the palaces, castles, fancy houses, bridges, etc without the traffic!
A trip by boat up the Bosporus strait. Interesting trip by boat but do take a map with you as you may not be able to hear the commentary over the boat's engine noise.

Breathtaking cruise. I had no idea how colorful, varied and gorgeous was Istanbul's waterfront. Palaces, schools, ministries, mosques and luxury residences spreading from the waterfront and up the lovely hills. Very lovely experience.

Dinner cruise on the strait. Part of our prepaid tour of Istanbul included a dinner cruise on the Bosphorus strait onboard a large boat called the INCISU. Not sure if they do open bookings because they can take about 75-100 people. Our group was about 50. The sights were very nice with the city in the background and views of large estates and palaces on the waterfront. I think it is about the only place you can take a picture of Europe and Asia at the same time.There are a number of smaller operators of tours at reasonable prices so I would take one if you have a few hours open time.
Nice little cruise. Do the cruise privately. Don't go with the touts. Walk down to Eminonu and do it yourself you will save a fortune.

Best BBQ fish sandwich ever!. By the Galata bridge there is a fish market (not sure if it's every day - we went on a Sunday). If you walk through this, you are in an almost scrubland area that has a few casual outdoor cafes and several men cooking to order BBQ fish sandwiches with tomato, onions, salad, herbs and peppers in lovely crusty bread. We bought some and took them to a cafe where we bought a drink and sat for ages watching the river. These now have a legendary status in our minds and I'm sure we will forever be trying to recreate them!

Bosphorus tours. Lovely trip, though I'd recommend just doing an hour's trip rather than the half/full day trip. As much as the scenery is lovely, you're a bit captive on the boat, with not much else to do.
boat trip. a very interesting experience,. would not recommend eating on the boats, but the views and historical interest make this very worthwhile.

Enjoyable scenic ride. A cruise on the Bosphorus strait is very enjoyable and very scenic on a sunny day. It can be as cheap as 10 TL per person (lasts 1 1/2 hours). You will find the sign along the Eminonu Peer.Go straight to the boat, you don't need an agent for booking. Just hand over 10TL and hop on. It doesn't have a guide, but I don't really think you need one. (You will probably forget the names anyway). But, the visual beauty, you will remember for a long while. You will see the Galatta bridge overhead (which connects Taksim and Sultanahmet), You will pass several beautiful mosques, villas of the wealthy along the coast, Universities, palaces and the military school. We took the cruise closer to sunset and the water shimmering in the sunlight was a beautiful sight. If you look close enough, you will see millions of jelly fish just a few feet under water, which is clear enough for you to see through. The current is quite strong and you may feel your vessel rock a bit. However, if the boat is big enough, you aren't likely to feel sea-sick. For pictures, definitely, the upper deck is better. You can go out to the balcony on the lower deck, but you will be hiding the view from the other passengers inside. Carry/wear a jacket as the wind is chilly.

Crossing between 2 Continents. Travellers can easily hop-on and off into many ferries that available at the pier near the Galata Bridge.Nice views in the middle of the strait, as we can see whole Istanbul especially Sultanahmet with its Blue Mosque & Hagia Sophia.

Great way to see the sights. A cruise on the Strait provides views of the city that you otherwise wouldn't get. You'll see all the major mosques from the waterside but, as you sail up towards the road bridge linking Europe and Asia, you will also pass some stunning old and new palaces.There are also some incredible waterfront properties of the very wealthy. Our guide told us several well-known pop and movie stars live along the Strait - but as they're Turkish, you probably won't know them. On the return leg, you sail pass the Military School. Our guide appeared to take pride in informing us that Saddam Hussein and Col. Gadaffi were both graduates. We found that paying the cruise charge in Turkish Lira was cheaper - 70 lira for two, Money really well-spent.One word of warning - the breezes on the water can be strong and cold, even on what was a warm and sunny day onshore. If you want to take photos, you'll need to be on the open upper deck. So, take a jacket or prepare to get cold. Also, if you book your cruise from one of the company staff who frequent the main square beside the Blue Mosque, be prepared for a bit of a trek down the hill to the waterside. Might catch elderly unawares.

Would recommend on a beautiful day. If you are short on time in Istanbul, this is a nice cruise but I my recommendationg depends on the weather to be honest. My first suggestion would be to take the shorter (2 hour) cruise versus the longer one. I don't think you need more than that. There were some great sites on the river, but my enjoyment came from riding the ship on a warm day with the wind in my hair and the sun shining (and a welcome break from all the walking). I believe that if the weather was not great I would have enjoyed this a lot less. Yes again the sites from the water are beautiful, but in a city like Istanbul with so much to do I think it could easily be skipped.

Get one with a guide. Our trip didn't have a guide. We were using Google maps to try and determine what we were looking at. The trip was about 1.5 hours, but it felt a bit long towards the end. A bigger boat will be much better as I started fealing really sea sick towards the end and it was getting really chilly on the deck of the boat.

A MUST see place. Imagine visiting Istanbul and not going to see such a beautiful sight. The cruise, the water, the houses, the hills, the bridges, who could ask for anything more?! You will feel so relaxed and a great way to spend time with family and friends!

One of the most beautiful in the world. Been to most of the most beautiful cities in the world. Boshporus is not comparable to them. Very beautiful, inspiring and peaceful. After taking a boat trip along, you will love it and never forget.Try to take the boat tour from Eminonu on weekend morning (09:00 and 10:00) of Sehir Hatlari (Municipality). Eat fish at Anadolu Kavagi.
Beautifully Blue waters. Was a scenic boat ride and clean boats and lovely water ! Well organised and not overcrowded. Good tea onboard.

Definitely worthwhile. The Bosporus rivet cruise took 2 hours and was one of the highlights of our visit to Istanbul. There was lots of interesting historical buildings, palaces, etc that would have been missed. It was also a very relaxing way to see a lot of Istanbul on a beautiful sunny day without all the crowds and queues.

Bosphorus cruise. Took a morning cruise of the Bosphorus. Saw beautiful homes and buildings, the bridge where the Bosphorus runs into the Black Sea and the skyline of Istanbul with the mosques. Haziness seemed to hang over the city. Cruise at dusk might make for awesome pictures.
Cruise. The 3 hour cruise up the Bosphorus is a must. The views of the city and both the European and Asian sides are spectacular.

Take the ferry up the Bosphorus!. Traveling on the Bosphorus Public Excursion ferry is fun, easy (from Eminonu dock), and cheap. Wonderful sites along the way of Asian and European sides of Turkey. Disembark at Anadolu Kavagi, have a snack, wander and hop on the return ferry. (The ride is about 90 minutes each way). A "tea boy" offers drinks throughout the trip but bring snacks to share with fellow passengers...a good conversation starter. Highly recommend unless weather is bad (you still can go but would have to sit inside). You can also take a bus back to the city, or combine taxi and bus.

city tour. i took the long bosphorus cruise (2 and a half hours), we saw everything on the edges and a guide on the boat was talking about each and every monument, and its history. it is very nice however i found it a bit long, and it was very cold on the boat

One of the world's great views. Missing the Bosphorus when in Turkey is like missing the Chicago lakefront, or the New York City skyline, or the Golden Gate in San Francisco, or the Mackinac Bridge in Michigan.A boat tour, tourists and all, is worth it here. Many people come to the area and only visit one side. That might do for your first visit, but do yourself a favor and visit both sides.Also, do like the locals, and guess (sometimes out loud) about what the boats that seem to traverse in the evening are actually carrying.
A must!. The bosphorus strait cruise is the top highlight of Istanbul and certainly not a miss. Prefer the extended 5hrs cruise along the entire strait until Black Sea.

Nice way to spend an hour or two.. Beat the heat, check out the nice homes, somewhat Cannes looking boulevards, and some cool old palaces along the water.No this is not a tour of the Seine at night, but for 12 Lira its a very reasonable way to see some pretty water front.

Fantastic and opulent. The strait goes on forever, just palaces and summer houses, forests and forts. If you do a "full cruise" make sure you understand the plan of the trip. No one on our boat spoke Engish so after questioning the staff we got off at the wrong lunch spot - bus ride back not as fun as the boat ride we paid for!

Istanbul Trip. During winter is very cold to sit by the edge of the ferry. A good guide is important but the audio guide is a good substitute. Was brought to a leather shop later and persuaded to buy some leather goods. Nice material but I'm not sure if the price is right. Despite what they tell you, the price is negotiable.

The Mighty Bosphorus. I'm sure that it has all been already said so I would simply say "do not leave Istanbul until you have cruised the Bosphorus" and in fact you should do it as soon as you get there to give you a perspective on the city. But be warned - things can happen on the Bosphorus !!!!
The origin of the city. The city was founded because of the trade beween Asia and Europe. The Bosporus is the narrowest water strait beween the continents.

Magnificant. I was privelleged to have enjoyed a private cruise of the Bosphorus Straight and also had a wonderful view from the top of the Intercontental Hotel. Both only served to compliment the other.

Take this tour, NOT the "10 Euro Boat Tour". The "10 Euro Boat Tour" is a scam. Boat is small, so very crowded and uncomfortable. You feel every wave. Noisy, especially below deck. On the top deck, you get smoke from smokers. And its freezing. Overall a terrible experience. Better to take this boat instead, or one from Turyol.

Walk from Europe to Asia. Experience the sights and smells of the salt water from the bridge and tell your friends you walked from Europe to Asia as you pass over the bridge from one continent to another! It's worth the time to experience the fishermen catching their fish.

Exciting. You need to take a ride on the Bosphorus, separating Europe and Asia. It's cheap and well worth the ride. Sit near a local who speaks a little English, as there are so many sights to identify along the way. Our 2-hour cruise was more than worth it.

Nice trip to do!. There are a lot of excursions, I recommend the one that leaves from the Golden Horn, reaches the second bridge and returns. Is a two hours trip, is incredible to see Istambul from the Bosphorus. Kabataç, Ortakoy and asian coast. Something to do!

A nice relaxing boat ride. The Bosphorus tour is very nice and interesting. However, I would recommend not using the hotel directed tours. Instead if you self book from an agent and meet them at the port, it would be a much better use of your time. Traffic is terrible in Istanbul and therefore using the trams are much more efficient. Also I would only do the Asian bit of the tour, as the full day tour is rather boring and repetitive, particularly if you plan on visiting the landmarks yourself.

A trip full of pleasure and romance! The MUST!. I did it 3 times and it was always great!!! ALWAYS! Once, I took my girlfriend and her brother with me there. We went to the Eminonu first. Then, we walked to the Spice Bazaar and bought some fresh Turkish Delight. After that, we returned to the embarkment, got our tickets for 10 TL(sometimes they are 12TL, depending on the ship-both are good) and got up the ship. It went right on 16:00(they go every hour sharp) We got into the warm salon, because it was February. The weather was sunny, but cool. We drank some hot Turkish tea for 1TL a glass with the sweets from the Bazaar and looked at the window. We saw some old palaces, we passed by, some Mosques, some big ships and little fisherman boats... When we got close to the Bosphorus Bridge, we became impacient to make photos. We went out to the open deck and made some, then we stood there for about half an hour, watching nice views with Rumelli Fortress, with some beautiful villas and chic boats, with palaces and bridges around. Then, we returned to the salon, took some more of hot tea and watched the sea and seagulls, flying around. We passed the famous Maden's Tower, deviding the Europe and Asia. By the time we approached Istanbul from the sea near Topkapi Palace, Sirkeci, Eminonu and Galata, we saw one of the most breathtaking sunsets in our lives!!! We went out with our cameras to the open deck again and made a pile of shots! It was about 10minutes of real passion! The sea was all around and we were going at the high spead towards Eminonu and Galata Bridge! We were really happy that very moment! That's why I love this Bosphorus tour! Usually it takes about 2 hours, but it's always worth of it. You can get close to many attractions like palaces or Mosques from the sea side and it is simply outstanding! You can not compare it to any other tour in Istanbul, I believe. It's just UNIQUE! That's why I advise it to everybody as the MUST! Enjoy it!
Lovely for a boat trip.. We had a lovely boat trip, taking in all the sights & landing on the Asian side. Worthwhile excursion to do when in Istanbul, especially in good weather.

cruise on the Bosphorus. a nice trip to do for almost a big part of the day, startin gat the Pier, near Egypt Spices market you can go on a cruise on a big short of ferry boat, 25 lire per person, is something like 12 euro, leavin gat 10.35 h in the morning but be there a bit before because if you want a place in the sun , there is a lot of people..at 12.10 they stop at a little city where you go off board and have a nice meal , best is fish and at 15.00 the boat leaves, gates open at 14.30 so be there is you want a good seat in the sun..around 17.00 hour back and good for a quick visit at the spice market , check out because museums and markets have different days they are not open, don't let you be fooled to do a bosphorus cruise from guys in the street you will pay at least 5 times more...

Essential experience. Good value (TL10) for a 2 hour cruise to see palaces and other sites along the coast of the Bosphorus. A commentary would have been nice but it wasn't important to me, more so for my wife!

Asia to Europe or reverse?. Absolutely a must to see. Interesting to see from the boat, that European side actually looks more Asian, and Asian side is more modern and looks more European. Certainly, Istanbul is a huge city, and trip down the Strait gives you an understanding how big and diverse this city is.
Bosphorus cruise. A can't miss. Incredible views of most all of sights, including some that could not easily be seen any other way. Just bring a jacket, even if warm out.

Take a cruise. Beautiful views from the water. Take a cruise up past the bridges north to see Rumelihisarı castle. Busy waters, giant tankers passing close can be intimidating! The cruises have cafes inside so you can enjoy a tea or coffee during the 1.5 hour ride. A cheaper way to see the water is on any of the ferries that cross hourly.

7.5 TL for 2.5 hours. Wear a coat! We visited the last week of April and while it was a pleasant sunny day, the speed of the boat and the wind off the water made it unbearably cold up top. After moving inside it was a pleasant ride. The architecture of the grand houses along the shore were amazing. If I did it over I would get off for a break at on the the stops and catch the next boat back. What a bargain
From Asia to Europe for 3 Lira!. Try doing that from anywhere else in the world! Great views great people watching, just do the ferries don't pay for a tourist tour, do it yourself.

A super trip. We spent a very happy two + hours on a boat on the Bosphorus. Very interesting with the houses either side - we went up on the left and came back on the right. A very enjoyable trip. We just booked it from one of the people on the shore. A must do trip. It was a bit chilly when we did it, so make sure you have something warm to put on.

Bosphorus cruise. Ferry trip was well worth doing and we had lunch in Asia at a harbour side restaurant called Baba's. The Blue fish, salad and beer after a walk up the hill to see the local castle was fab.The audio commentary is worth having if you want to get some background info

Take the ordinary ferry not the tourist boats. There are many ferry boats at Emininou near Galata bridge offering short or long cruises. We took the 25TL long cruise [approx 10 euro] leaving at 13.35. The ferry is a bit grubby and you can't go outside, so get there early enough to get seats at the side. This is a working ferry, so no commentary or free food. Buy a fish sandwich [balik emtek] at Galata Bridge before boarding. The ferry calls in at several small towns along the way ending in Kagia Anadoulu. You can stay for two hours here and have a nice cup of coffee and a few beers before heading back. Great views all the way and well worth it. We arrived back around 1815. The tourist cruises may be more luxurious, but you get what you pay for.

took a double decker bus. lovely day. easy way to see the city with the top deck of the bus open for pictures. Headsets had narration in about 7 languages. You got two days for the price of one so we took their tour around the Golden Horn the next day as well. Don't know the company but they are a hop on, hop off that started at Blue Mosque area

Great way to see things farther away from tourist center. A Bosphorus tour, especially the official city one, is a really great way to get a picture of the city of Istanbul from a unique perspective. On a good day, you can really enjoy going past the famous sites of the city: European style palaces, the great Bosphorus bridges, castles, Ottoman houses, and more, for a very reasonable price. Really though, avoid the expensive private tours and just take the public boats: either the full Bosphorus tour, or even the public ferries that hop from port to port (the schedules can be found online, it takes a little planning). Yoros castle at the end gives you a view of the Black Sea and there are lots of fish restaurants there. Along the way you'll see people fishing, boats passing by, and neighborhoods buzzing with activity on both sides. Close to shore, be sure to look out for huge groups of the famous jellyfish.My personal favorite stop along the Bosphorus is Kanlica on the Asian side. Absolutely the best Yogurt in Istanbul - served with the kaymak (clotted cream) still on top and eaten with powdered sugar. There is nothing like it, really - nothing!Also, if the season is right (mostly spring and fall I believe) you can see schools of dolphins swimming up and down the strait. Keep your eyes peeled, sometimes it's only three or four but sometimes it's dozens!

Bosphorus cruise was great. There was nothing about the cruise we did not like. The boat was comfortable and the guide was very informative. We enjoyed the traditional Turkish dancing on board.. How they managed to stay upright on the choppy waters was amazing

Excellent Cruise. Travelled through Bosphorus strait on the well known Bosphorus trip. Started from Kabatas and ended near a village close to Yoros Castle. One and half hour cruise was a treat on both outbound and inbound trips. The beautiful architests of Istanbul were worth seeing in day and well lit up at night adding beauty to this trip. Both the Boğazici and Fatih sultanahmet bridges were worth seeing during day light and at night when lit up. An hour break was given which we consumed by a long walk till castle. Traditionally cooked fish is a good option to satisfy your taste buds when off the boat and walking around in the small village. A good sunny day would be a better option with return journey close to sunset. Overall an excellent boat journey.

A must do if your touring the area. Avoid the expensive cruise tours and small charter boats by using the multitude of public transport ferries, 3TL to travel per hop. It is certainly worth the time finding out how the jetton token system works as 3TL is the standard price on the tram or ferries. To get a true feeling for the area do journey up the Bosphorus Strait there is just so much to see and experience

Bosphorus Cruise. Early April is early Spring in Istanbul and the weather was very chilly on this boat trip. Dress warmly and sit back and enjoy a couple of relaxing hours away from the hustle and bustle of the city. Beautiful views of all the magnificent historic and modern structures that line the Europe and Asia shorelines.

Take the ferry for 3TL. Take a 20 minutes ferry ride across the Strait to Uskudar (Asia!) from Eminonu for 3TL. For a ticket, buy a token from the machine. If you're not sure which boat to take, there's an English speaking information booth at the ferry terminal.

Delightful couple of hours on a cruise. A must do. Forget going with a tour. Just go down to the docks near the Galata bridge ( Eminoun) and hop on a short circle cruise for about 10 Lira - Autumn price. Seating is great and for 2 hours you see so much. It only stops twice and you can hire headphones for a commentary as you board if needed. No fumes no fuss and they sell drinks etc, on board.

Must-do Activity for any Istanbul Visitor. Seeing Istanbul from the Bosphorus is something that every visitor must do while they're visiting. While on the Bosphorus, you'll be able to view different parts of the city and a variety of landmarks from the water within a relatively short amount of time. It's also a great photo opportunity with some shots that you can't get any other way!There are plenty of cruise options available to choose from. Most hotels have a suggested cruise but you should also explore other options on your own. There is a cruise tour available for whatever your preference is. You can book boats of varying sizes and tour lengths ranging from a couple of hours to an all-day affair.Ferries are also available which pick up and drop-off at different areas within the city. Locations will vary depending on the line you choose. This may be a more desirable for those wishing to explore the city on their own and also get a taste of the Bosphorus in a less-touristy fashion.

Bosphorus beautiful. The busy waterway is stunning with historic busildings all along its length. Its especially awesome at night. We dined on the Galata Bridge spelbound by the lights and twinkling on the water but engrossed by the ferry activity.

Took the cruise and loved it.. We took the cruise and loved it, we cruised then departed the boat and had 3 hours to tour around and had lunch at a lovely cafe on the waterfront. While cruising we were able to see many sites that we would have missed just driving on land, many more mosque, palaces and colorful small fishing boats. The trip was well worth the time and fee.

A must do ferry ride up the bosphorus. You can choose from various ferry options, from a 2 hour trip up to a full day trip. You will journey between Western and Eastern Europe seeing bridges, palaces, castles etc.

A Cruise on the Bosphorus is part of the Istanbul experience. We took a short cruise on the Bosphorus, boarding at Galata Bridge. The cost was 10 Lira per person. Our cruise had no commentary - we could overhear that some boats did provide a commentary which might be helpful. Our Lonely Planet guide gave good information on the main sites. It is definitely worth having some information on the buildings which line the straights to make the most of the trip.As one of the unusual and unique topographical features of the world, a cruise is definitely recommended.

Best way to appreciate Istanbul. Any cruise on the Bosphorus gives many perspectives on Istanbul. We went right up to the village of Anadolukavagi, which takes two hours by boat and walked up to the Yorus Fortress. Then back to the city by boat - well worthwhile to understand the effect that the strait has had on the city.

Turkish Night on the Bosphorus. We took a cruise on the Bosphorus which consisted of excellent Turkish dinner and Turkish entertainment. It took us up and down the Bosphorus and they explained the significance of each of the monuments we saw on the way. It was kind of cold but still was a lot of fun.

Where Asia meets Europe. During our two week stay In Istanbul. we had many opportunities to cross the Bosphorus, since our hotel was on the Asian side, while many of the major attractions are in Europe. Ferries make the crossing every few minutes during the day. There are also tours that vary in length. The longest goes as far as the Black Sea and back. The ferries are much more relaxing than the two major bridges that also cross the Bosphorus. A subway is being built to connects the two sides, but it is not yet finished.
Relaxing boat trip. Good just to relax among the bustle of Istanbul and see the city and passing water traffic of all shapes and sizes - a must do in Istanbul

Use the ferries to get around. The ferries are so easy to get around the Bosphorous Strait (very fast to get to the Asian side), and also interesting to see places of interest from the water. The views are really good and I would recommend going on it, even if you only go the once, it is very memorable.

Whatever you do in Istanbul, take some kind of river cruise!. Don't worry, there are several options when it comes to getting yourself floating on the Bosphorus, without swimming in it. Firstly, there is the long cruise that usually leaves the European side (usually close to Galata Bridge) and goes up to the Anadolu Kavagi on the Asian side. This takes most or all of one day and have heard mixed reviews about it. I wasn't bothered about the Asian side, as I've been to Asia and I didn't fancy a whole day trip. I just wanted to get on the river for a couple of hours and see the city. So, firstly I looked at one or two cruises that seemed to go up and down the river and all were more or less the same thing. However, I noticed that only one went into the golden horn and under the galata bridge. Sounds silly, but I really wanted to do that, as I felt the golden horn had some nice stuff to see and I'd miss some of it if I just took the usual trips up the Bosphorus. I found the cruise quite by accident when walking back to the Hagia Sophia from Topkapi Palace. Sales people advertise cruises in the street and you can find some good ones. This was the only one that went under galata bridge and I booked it for about 15 euros. 2hrs long and some really good memories of the city. VERY glad I did it! Just one thing to remember: The boats can look quite old and be in fairly tatty condition. I was a little apprehensive, but none of them looked great, so it wasn't just mine. Again, use your common sense and maybe check out a few before buying tickets. You can go down to the port close to galata bridge and see before buying. You will find lots of people at that port trying to sell you their cruise, so just compare routes and prices and see what one you're comfortable with. Whatever you do, DON'T leave Istanbul without doing even a short cruise, as it's really worth the effort.

Gorgeous marble buildings everywhere. I visited Istanbul on July 2011. Bosphorus is definitely an interesting place. It connects the European and Asian sides of Istanbul, both sides of which are littered with beautiful architectures everywhere. It's best take a cruise to fully enjoy what the strait has to offer. Heard the cruise is better at night, which I didn't experience myself but I can say for sure that the daytime cruise is worth every single lira.

Great experience. At first I thought it was a typical touristy activity cliché for the sake of cruising along Bosphorus. In fact it's a lot more than that. The views along the river of both sides are spectacular. It also gives you some ideas of where else to explore outside the city centre. However, the final destination (A. Kavagi) is probably not quite interesting at all, apart from climbing up the hill to see the skeleton of the castle. Some other stops like Sariyer seems more interesting, but I didn't get a chance to pop down. I reckon it's well worth the experience whilst in Istanbul.
Cruise. Take tram to Kabatas station. You can buy tickets and catch a boat opposite the station, It works out a lot cheaper than through a tour group.

Use the IDO Ferry from Eminonu Ferryport for your trip. Lovely views. I did the long trip (25.00 TL) and the boat is a bit of a rust-bucket but safe. The boat stops on the Asian side where you can have lunch.

Wooooooooooows !. Can not say more than big wow ! It is must do trip ! I did it twice and I think if I visit turkey again I will repeat it .. Views are Breathtaking ! Really wonderful ! Do not miss it !
Beautiful sights.. Take a tour of the Bosphorus on a boat, it's worth the cost. Day views would be better, but night cruises offer dinner and views of the lit up bridges.

Great Views and nice relaxing setting. We took a boat trip from the main pier in the old city up the Bosphorus strait, I advise do the short journey which is two hours as we thought this was long enough, also we dont reccomend gettting the audio guides as they are like Sat Nav devices and ours didnt work properly, ended up refering to our guide book which was much better! A must do excursion whilst in Istanbul!!
Beautiful. We did a boat trip around the Bospghorous, the views are breathtaking and the houses on the waters edge are mind boggling. The place is steeped in very rich history
Beautiful views. Better not to go for long cruises... They get quite boring after a while... A short cruise ideally 2-3 hours is the best to enjoy the scenery..
strong emotions. take a Vapur from Eminomu to Kadikoy,the asian side, i can't describe..everyone can get his own nice emotions..
Wow !. One of the most beautiful water ways one will see anywhere in the world. Must take a cruise ( government ones are best) to appreciate both sides of the straits. Fantastic indeed
Bosphous Strait - a must see. A two-hour sightseeing boat trip should be good. If you have time, take another trip during the evening, it will be total different experience.

A Fun Diversion. If you are deciding between this ferry ride and the Blue Mosque, choose the Blue Mosque. If you are choosing between the ferry ride and the Grand Bizarre or Spice Market, choose the markets. If you are expecting some earth-shattering amazement that one shore is Europe and the other is Asia, you may want to set your expectations a little lower.While the views are great and the river is geographically significant, the cruise on the Bosphorus is a nice sight-seeing tour, but anything beyond that is just hype. We had a great time on the boat, and would do it again, but don't expect to be amazed by this trip. Instead, get a nice seat (unless the boat is visiting the Asian side first, make sure you sit on the left side of the boat, otherwise you will only be looking at water or straining to look over someone else's shoulder the entire trip), buy some Turkish Tea and enjoy the ride.If you have young children with you, they may get bored...although probably not as much as with some of the other attractions you would have already drug them to.Disclaimer: we took the TurYol ferry, a 90-minute round trip tour. The destination ferries may be a different experience.

Great to see the Black Sea and Asian side of Istanbul. Really enjoyed the ability to sit back and take in the views along the Bosphorus. Very affordable at $25 Tl per person for round-trip. The last stop A. Kavage, provides a hilltop with castle remains that affords some great views of the Black Sea. The port also offers some great seafood!

Breathtaking view!. Our hotel suggest us a bosphorus cruise all day trip and it was very nice. Our tour included a morning cruise passing by the Golden Horn at the Marmara Sea and to the Bosphorus strait. After the cruise we were taken by mini bus to many atractions and crossing to the Asia side of Istanbul.

Well worth it!. A lovely afternoon trip on a sunny day in April on a beautiful boat with a knowledgeable guide. Really gives a great oversight of Istanbul, the areas and the people and buildings from the water. As a side show the dolphins were following the boat. The only down side was the length of time spent picking up folks from different hotels and waiting but the actual boat trip at 35 TL was enjoyable and good value.

Fantastic Scenery. Cruising the Bosphorus (Bogaz) is a unique experience. When you are in the ferryboat, you can enjoy seeing both sides (European and Asian) and the bridges linking them. In addition to that, different islands (Adalar or Princess Islands) can be observed, and all in the same view! You don't need to turn your head or to stare, everything is available, amazing!

a nice change of scenery. After walking and touring all of the sites of Sultanhamet, the cruise is a nice change where you can sit and just take in your surroundings. It does give you a great perspective of the layout of the city. We opted to take the long route which leaves from just beside the Galata bridge at 10:35AM and takes about 1.5 hours (including a few stops) to reach its last stop Anadolu. There you are given 3 hours before departure to walk up to the castle, view the city and the opening to the Black Sea, and enjoy a nice lunch (with views of course). It was also great to sip some Turkish tea during the trip.

Fascinating area, and worth a boat trip. No matter where you choose to look out across the Bosphorus - whether from Galata Tower, from the Asian side, or from a waterside cafe, it's difficult not to be awed by the significance of the this strait.We took the city authority Sehir Hatlari Bosphorus Cruise up the the Bosphorus, which we really enjoyed. We got the audioguide, which gave plenty of information about the many buildings and monuments en route. We took the full cruise to the northermost town before the Black Sea, Anadolu Kavagi, spent some time there, and returned shortly afterwards. Keep your eyes peeled en route, as you might even see dolphins, as we did! They have two options this Spring – a full cruise for 25 TL which departs from Eminonu at 10:35am, and between April and October also from 1:35pm, and takes about an hour and a half to reach Anadolu Kavagi. Yoros Castle is a 20 min walk uphill from the town. Boats return to Eminonu at 3pm, and in the summer additionally a bit later at 5pm.Alternatively the short cruise is a 2 hour round loop starting and ending in Eminonu, leaving at 2:30pm, and costing 10TL.

The strait that makes Istanbul so special. I was lucky to enjoy terrific weather on the boat, the city looked very beautiful on both sides of Bosphorus. It is a nice way to feel the sunshine and understand the former grandeur and vicissitudes of Istanbul. I took the half day cruise arranged by my hotel, which gives you opportunity to wander around several off the beaten track sites along the shore. In my opinion, the places we visited were a bit underwhelming, and for the price (80+ lira per person), the guide was not really informative. Just hop on any boat in Eminonu port, it's much cheaper and offers the same views.
Even with kids this is so-so. River tours can be over-rated and I thought this is one of them. Look for boats on other side of the bridge (tukloy?) from the spice market.

Ciragan Palace Hotel Veranda Lunch and Bosphorus view. It is wonderful to look at the Bosphorus while eating lunch on the veranda of the Ciragan Palace Kempinski Hotel. We had a lovely lunch with delightful waiters. Then we went for a most pleasant walk on the grounds which are adjacent to the Ciragan Palace. The Palace was closed that day for a special ceremony but we could see the setting on the Bosphorus during our walk.
Amazing. You need to visit the Bosphore on a boat! The view is amazing!I liked it,there wasn't bad things and I think that's all I can say

Asia - Europe. This is the strait which connects Asia and Europe..Blue clean..very busy..Thousands of Cruises..Small, Big..Pvt and so..Bosphorus Cruises will cost you only 5-6 USD per person.Local Chay (Tea) only 1 TL (half USD/25 INR)..Must try..The Jelly fish at Cruise station will attract you. At the entry gate..must try the Kabab..Street Kababs..Tasty one..

What's a Little Rain between Continents. This was a fascinating boat trip between the continents of Europe in the West and the East -- in a persistent rain. The pictures are not brilliant, but the mental images are fine.

Lovely cruise for a beautiful day!. The Bosphorus is something we've always read about, and cruising on it was perfect for seeing lots of palaces, fortresses, bridges and mansions. Our day was cold and rainy, but it was still interesting!

Sailing at Easter. We spent a couple of hours on the straight on a gorgeous day, first up the European side and back along the Asian side. It helped us get to understand the city, its location and so forth.
A Must Do!. If you're visiting Istanbul, you have to spend some time on the Bosphorus. It was winter when I went, but I still enjoyed a trip that took me between two nice continents...
Simply unforgetable. Simply breath-taking. Try to squeeze in a 90 minute boat ride. Have a drink and enjoy the scenery. This is the best way to see Istanbul.

romantic. Cruising the Bosphorus, it's amazing to think that one is astride two continents: Europe and Asia. The silhouettes of the mosques' domes during sunset is magical. No wonder many recent major films have come here : Skyfall, Taken 2.
More magic of Istanbul. Where Europe meets Asia. A lovely body of water lined with beautiful mansions but I particularly like the rows of local men angling from the bridges
Wonderful.. Really good value for money! We enjoyed it so much we did it twice! Gives the feet a rest after walking the sights of the city.

A long trip that's just ordinary. Didn't enjoy it much as the cruise is a bit overrated in my personal opinion. However it is a good way to see the side of Europe and Asia from the sea and just enjoy the view from your boat.
take the Bosporus cruise. A one hour cruise for about $7 is well worth it . the Bosporus from the boat is different and extremely nice .be there as early as possible as these trips are very popular

Brilliant. I crossed this culturally significant strait on a sunny day where the sun was shining and the Bosphorus a glittering brilliant blue. Looking at the the strait that separates east and west was pretty amazing and I was struck by just how simultaneously large and small the world was.

Beautiful boat ride lets you see both continents. This is best seen by boat. The boat ride is beautiful especially as you see both the asia and europe sides of Istanbul. You can either book a tour like we did or if you don't mind being random, you can turn up to the boat harbour and buy tickets for much cheaper! We only realised this when we arrived and saw that tickets can be as little as 12 TL.

The only way to get a full experience of Istanbul. If you travel, as we did, out of season, you'll find many of the key palaces and monuments are closed. This is the only way to see them, but more importantly to get a true sense of the unique spread of Istanbul across two continents. It's also the only way to truly appreciate the might of the Rumeli Fortress, and the Ataturk bridge.

Makes for a wonderful stroll. You can either walk along the Bosporus although not always next to it or you can take one of the many ferry boats (1,95 TL) that go from one side to the other to enjoy the Bosporus Strait.
Its a must trip. Its a must trip totake cruise We took a cruise with fee 12 lira.. You can see how beautiful istanbul is...

Not the best choice for a cold cloudy day. We did a 10TL boat trip (1.5hr) down the Bophorus. I can imagine how amazing this could have been on a warm sunny day. We were fortunate to have a pamplet to figure out what we were seeing. I wish it had been narrated. But GO... if you made it to the Bosphorus, you should give it a go!
Bosphuros by boat. I highly recomend a trip by boat to the Bosphorus Strait. We can enjoy another sight of Istambul city, its monuments and the huge traffic of this important strait.

Nice views, but long waiting. Having a cruse around Bosphorus strait was a great experience. It's a admirable the sensation of sundenly finding yourself below the bridge that links two continents. The down points was waiting too much until the boat guys gather suficient people for the cruse (around 1 hour+).

See all the boat options.. Just mind the boat you are taking to make the Bosphorus excursion. In my case I took the first they offered me and there were no explanations. I spend 2 hours in the boat watching amazing things but as it wasnt guided (not audio neither) I do not know what I watched.

Relaxing. Please take a boat trip on the Bosphorus. Also, be sure to sip some Turkish or Apple Tea offered by the staff while boating. There is an intercom system telling you what you are seeing but I could not hear it that well. Look for the dolphins in the water! Don't get nervous over all the boats. The captains seem to know their way around even though it looked chaotic to me.

Great views, can be windy. Nice two hour tour along this superhighway for tankers and ferries. Did it in March, with overcast skies and cold winds. Nevertheless there were plenty of places to escape the winds and snap pictures while listening to the running monologue of what we were seeing. Gives you a different perspective of the sites along the straits and how fun it is to watch those container ships bear down on you and the choreography between the ferries crossing, the tour boats and other ships going up and down and across. Ship does offer some refreshments for purchase.

Sailing into Sarantium. First read Guy Kay's great historic fiction-fantasy novel - "Sailing into Sarantium". Then take a cruise of the Bosphorus. TurYol is the easiest company to use. Large outfit. Very reputable. Official ticket office on the south south west side of the bridge, just west northwest of the bridge. Cost = 12 TL. No need to respond to touts on the street who ask you if you are looking for a Bosphorus cruiseCruise itself was interesting and you pass close to many interesting riverside buildings from the Ottoman empire.A very nice change to other kinds of sightseeing. Would be a cooler spot in the summer.

A must to see when the weather is beautiful. On a sunny day, it is a must to do when you are in Istanbul. We took a 3-hour cruise with blue tours (20 EUR) on the Bosphorus and had a short stay at Beylerbeyi.

Nice way to spend a day in Istanbul. We took tram from Taksim to Eminonou to take the Ferry for Bosphorus tour, the return ticket costs each 25 Lira which was inexpensive way to enjoy the tour. The Ferry is quite big - good for someone who has boat sickness like me, i felt absolutely stable the entire journey. The ferry left at 10:35 each morning and will stop at Anadolu Kavağı (a fishing village with great seafood) after about 1.5 hours. You get to see both European and Asia side of Istanbul, we saw some dolphin swimming on the surface of the ocean during the return tour (was nice surprise). On the ferry they serves you Turkish tea for 1 Lira.At Anadolu Kavağı , we follow the advise , i.e. to check the return schedule (which says 15:00), it is enough time to enjoy the little village, we went up to the top of the hill (30 min trek up to the castle- nice view there). then we had seafood lunch at one of the restaurant there, the price are quite fair (we didn't make any bargain), seafood were very fresh and inexpensive in my opinion. On our return at Eminonou, we walked to Spice Bazaar whcih we enjoyed the type of spices and tea in tousands of stores, really a great experience.Bophorus boat tour is a relax way to enjoy Istanbul if you are the person who doesnt mind to sit in a boat for 3 hours in a day.

Bosphorus Cruise. Ignore all the touts trying to sell you tours. The state ferry company, and other private boats sell circular 2-hour cruises for about 10-12 Turkish Lira. The private boats go from the left side of Galata Bridge on the Eminonu side. Walk along and see which boat looks the most seaworthy. The state ferry gos from the right hand side of the bridge. This cost 10 Turkish Lira and was great. The boat is large, and has n open top deck, but the lower deck is quite comfortable when its cold outside. It has toilets which get a bit grim towards the end of the trip.
Trip to Asia. Just a short hop across the bosporus to the Asian part of Istanbul. What a pleasent trip. I enjoid the leasurley sea voyage with all the commuters.

Really enjoyed it!. There are many option to sail the Bosphorus, but if you go to Eminonu embankment there is a cheap, 10 lire or about 5€, option that takes you for a 2 hrs trip. We were lucky as the weather was great and we enjoyed a relaxing experience. Many beautiful views and great for taking pictures!
Dynamic & Vital Waterway. Well traveled waterway offers many possibilities for exploration. Ferrys run across every few minutes, sightseeing cruises all morning and afternoon.

Cheap and relaxıng. Chose a ferry costıng 10 lira per person. It was almost 2 hours
wıth no onboard commentary. Lıght refreshments avaılable at reasonable prices.
Would need to take a map to get maximum benefıt from the sightseeing.

You must get out on the water!. If you are visiting Istanbul you must take either a boat tour or a ferry -- only then will you truly understand the city and its history. Rain or shine (or 5 degree temperature!) -- you will love it and not regret it.

Anytime. Always, anytime, ay weather....it is always beautiful..
Vessels passing by...
Birds flying over....
The breeze...
Restaurants...
Walkways...
Parks...

Lovely trip on a sunny day. The trip itself is lovely - because of the nature and the special feeling the water, sparkling under the gorgeous sun, gives you. However, if you find a better way to do the long itinerary than the official Bosphorus tour - do it! It's nothing for the price you pay - they sell as much tickets as they can, no consideration whatsoever that people will be smashed and not fit afterwards (consequently, this affects the experience). They bring you to the last stop and leave you there for more or less 3h which is a time lost if you don't have enough time in Istanbul. The remains of the Byzantine castle are very nice but nobody takes care of them, it is horribly dirty around and the only thing locals are interested in is how many restaurants to open in the vicinity so that they can attract the wandering tourists and get their money. More expensive than some places in Istanbul and literally nothing else to do but a short visit to the castle. So, def do the trip down the Bosphorus on a nice and warm day but if you can find alternative and more flexible ways to do it, don't hesitate :)

Great on a sunny day. On the hotels recommendation, we used the public boat. The company is called Tyrol (sorry about spelling) and it cost just $12 liras. Our 5 year old was free. The boats go every hour and the cruise takes about 1.5 hours. I suggest going early so you can get a seat along the rail. It wasn't very busy on our boat but I suspect they can get crammed in the summer. They sell tea and orange juice on the boat and the staff come by frequently. There is no commentator or guide so bring your guide book or just relax and enjoy the views. We were lucky to have a pod of dolphins swim by us. There are also many jelly fish in the water. We also recommend to have a fish sandwich when you finish the cruise. For 5 lira you have a great lunch of fresh fish in bread with lettuce and onions. Delicious!

Great way to see the city and get out of the crowds. Take the 1.5 hour standard cruise, lovely and restful. Most cruise boats go from the foot of the Galata bridge on the Spice bazaar (SW) side. We spent 15 TL per person, about USD $8 each

Sunset at the Bosphorous. One of the pleasures and the most dramatic scene in Istanbul is watching the sunset standing at the Galata Bridge along the bosphorous.The silhoutte of the skyline with the imposing mosques, the bosphorous and the ferries merged together to form a melancholic atmosphere. Melancholy - is one of the most used and favorite adjective of Istanbulians, for some reason.Many tourists are taking this beautiful opportunity to take pictures of the place with the sky getting hues of orange colours. Go to the end of the bridge near the fish market in Karakoy.

A location connecting Old Asia to Modern Europe. Visiting Bosphorus Strait either from the coasts of Marmara Sea or on the boats crossing the Strait inspires even ordinary people. Many poems can be find in Turkish about Bosphorus Strait describing the live nights and the oriental life floating in its waters.

East is east and the west is west.... ...and never will the 'twain meet...or is it? The Bosphorus cruise was another beautiful and unique geographic experience as this is the place where continental Europe meets continental Asia.On one side you can see clear asian landscape. On the other, European buildings, churches and palaces...fabulous.

Cruise on the strait. istanbul weather is very changable very quickly 5 mintues it very hot then when on the boats it suddenly freeze lucky i had my trespass coat with me and Scarf. It was March and we decided to cruise around open air along the Straits for nearly two hours. many beautiful houses, university, palaces, bar, cafe etc along the straits. See the structural bridges Not for people who are easily seasickness as can be rough ride.

Take the non so touristic tour!!. I was glad that by chance I did not go to the very hectic cruises they sell on the street, and even heard over pricing. So: go to Kabatas (first station in the blue line) walt about 10 minutes in direction towards Dolmabache (sorry for the spelling) and from there go to the ticket office. I spent for 2 persons 12,5 Lira and no harassment of sellers to buy tickets.Enjoy, it is nice to seat down and relax!! They sell cookies and drinks on the boat also. But if you want take your own also. No smelly things please, jijiji.

Do it!. I took the all-day cruise out to the entrance to the Castle and the entrance to the Black Sea. It was a windy, cold and cloudy day but it was still one of the highlights of my Istanbul visit. If you don't have a whole day, I would definitely recommend the two-hour cruise or just taking a ferry to do it on your own schedule.
great cruise. I highly recommend the Bosphorus Cruise. It was a great value, a 6 hour trip for 25 TL. The photo opportunities were outstanding even on a cold and rainy day.

No time for a cruise, take the ferry. If you don't have time or don't want to spend hours on a boat, then take the ferry from Eminonu to the Asian side and back again. Less than 2 lira each way, for the 20 minute ride (depends on route taken) There are still some good photo opportunities. Take some bread with you as the seagulls fly along side the boats and catch bits of bread thrown to them, be brave and hold a bit in your fingers and they fly down and take the bread....I still have all my fingers. A small stall on the ferry offers tea and a few snacks.

Where 2 words meet. Out of all my experiences in Istanbul, the boat ride on the Bosphorus was the best. We took the short Bosphorus tour on the Turyol ferry for 12 Lira for 1.5 hours. The ferry starts from the Eminonu pier near the Galata bridge. Always go at least half an hour before the ferry starts so you can get a good seat. The best seats are on the top deck near the back of the ferry where the view is not obstructed and one can get great pictures of both sides of the Bosphorus. There are beautiful palaces,hotels and private homes on both sides touching the water. One important note is to always carry a warm jacket as it gets very windy and chilly on the boat as there are strong winds over the Bosphorus. We went in March end and it was a sunny day but got very chilly by the time we reached the second bridge. They serve warm tea and biscuits on the boat for a charge (1 TL for tea). I would do this experience every-time I visit Istanbul as you get to see great views of the famous skyline of Istanbul that has captivated many great writers and painters throughout history.

Disappointing. Took the short ferry ride(2 hours) with one stop to pick up additional passengers. The ride back was a repeat so I spent it inside the ferry. Wished I had taken a ferry with stops to disembark and see some of the sights along the way and back.

Relaxing ride. I took the bospherous trip with my family. Its a 90-min tour. Tor name was bezak tour. There was an english guide. Very informative. Recommended when uve almost given up for the day walking. Priced at 15 euro each adult. Children below 6 free

Crossroads. The Bosphorus marks the crossroads of the World, north to south and east to west. It divides Europe from Asia. It is a hugely important waterway and the route for the Russian Black Sea fleet to the rest of the world. Take at least a two hour trip above the second bridge and back, and if you have time, take one that reaches the Black Sea. Just realise and appreciate the history and the importance of this sea way.
Do a ferry ride. Best 3 lira tour in town. Go cross to Uskader or all the way up to nearly the Black Sea. All much fun and worth seeing.

Impressive sights. If you do not want to spent a lot of money for Bosporus travel you could simply take a fairy for a round-trip. It will cost you max 3 liras per person. However fairy does not go to the bridge(

Use the Ferries !!. Nice boat ride, lovely views, and the little thing about going from Europe to Asia and back !!There are tour boats, but the ferries are regular, and cheap, plus you get to mix with the locals !!

Bosporus. From Kabatas to Istinye. Drive and walk the Bosporus .Karakoy, Ortakoy, Arnavutkoy, Besiktas, Bebek, Istinye. You will visit Dolma Bachce Palace, you will drink cafe and cay in Chilai, Bebek and in the end wou will visit the Istinye Park (Mall). Don't forget that

Bosphorus on a sunny day. If you can, choose a sunny day. We decided to go as far as Sariyer and then bus back to Istanbul. It was a lovely experience, the fishing village of Sariyer was quaint and we sat outside and ate fried fish a huge salad and a beer in the sunshine overlooking the fishing boats. Bliss!We then caught the bus 25E passing through Bebek which looked really glamorous with expensive looking villas by the waters edge. Then on to Ortakoy, not the place I had envisaged, far too sophisticated! Finally back to Eminonu and then the tram home. a great day out!
take a boat tour. such a scenery!bridges connect europe with asia...what more can you ask for? take a boat tour and try to imagine the great history behind this place.
Not very exciting. We took a boat trip down the Bosphorus. It was nice to get perspective of how the two sides of the city developed but was quite a long trip for not much variety..

Strait Up Beautiful. Like Budapest's Danube, the Bosphorus separates the city of Istanbul. Either direction you go towards the Black Sea or the Golden Horn it is a relaxing day on the water! A half day tour or the ferry it's lovely.
Vibrant Bosphorus. Brilliant sights with excellent ferry service! One of the local people pointed out to the historical buildings along the way so it was even more enjoyable!

The memorable Ferry trip. It is sometimes hard to do something again that you remember very fondly, but I repeated the Bosphorus ferry trip with very special friends for their first day's experience in Istanbul - a beautiful crisp, sunny day. For a mere 25tl each - from the Sehir Hatlari terminal nearest the Galata Bridge, leaving at 10:30 winter or summer, we had a fascinating trip looking at the lttle ferry wharves, the great sights of the Dolmabahce and Ciragan Palaces, the Bridges, the seaside villas, the boats and the ferries. The old ferries might not be offering five-star comfort but have loads of character.There is always something to see along the way. We jumped off early at Sariyer, and had a wander and a bite to eat before catching the ferry again on the return leg, and caught a fabulous sunset.

Between Black and Marmara seas, between Europe and Asia. This seaway is wonderful border between flowering coastal lines. The Bosphorus connect deep blue water of Black Sea with azur and more warm water of Marmara. My soul was float through the heavens together with seagulls.

Time to take in the history, geography and relax. There are many 'traders' trying to get you to take their boat and trip. We chose one of the large tourist boats and had a 2 hour trip for 10 Turkish lira each, which was outstanding value. The trip afforded us views of many of the historic buildings and riverside frontages. It certainly allowed us to see parts of the city we would not have done otherwise. After all that walking it provided a real opportunity to sight see and rest at the same time, so i recommend going in the afternoon after a busy morning.

Do not buy tickets online...deals to be had by water. The straight is amazing, the sights are unmatched but we found when looking online prior to our arrival the prices were very steep. Once here there are people selling tours on the straight extremely cheap and the ferry is also a another great option for those on a budget. If you are looking to spend over $75 you could have a private tour on your own boat do not be fooled buy online sales there is so much more by the waters edge to take advantage of

If you need to rest your feet. A 2-hour cruise on the Bosphorus Strait (which you can buy impromptu from the centrally located Eminonu docking area) is a good option if you need to sit down, rest your feet and breathe some fresh air... but it is little more than that. Pick your cruise carefully - I didn't, and mine did not include any explanations of the sights whatsoever.

Cruise the River!. Bosphorus Straight is rather famous with lots of scenic/historic buildings up and down the strait. If you have some spare time, definitely take a cruise up and down the strait. It is a nice rest for the feet and a memory worth making.

Tea and seagulls. Galata bridge: Don't be discouraged by the waiters attacking you to sit at their cafe. Sit anywhere with a view during sun-set and enjoy a tea listening to the gulls and watching the fishing lines going up and down in front of you... Bosporus strait: Catch a boat going back and forth with the locals going home..

Short trip but no guidance. We ewre advised by the hotel to take the 90 minute trip up the Bosphorus which took us up to the second bridge crossing from West to East, and gave us a glimpse of the Eastern side. The trip length was ideal and, although you were unable to hear any information being broadcast from the speakers, it was still good to get out on the water and get a different perspective.
Take the 25 Lira cruise. The cruise takes you out to Yoros Castle and lets you wander around for a couple of hours before returning. One of the highlights of our trip.

Lovely trip up the Bosphorus. You can get a ferry which does a round trip up to a village near the northern point. There you can spend your time eating or climbing to the castle up a steep hill to see the views - which can be hard work in thew hot sun. You can get drinks/food and a good view at the restaurant's on the way up. It is worth the trip to view the places on the shores - maybe best to take binoculars. Get the tickets in a kiosk to the right of the bridge, but go early to beat any queue.
Lovely. Get the boat trip from ortakoy (probably not spelt right) and it takes you up and down) really nice, we saw some dolphins too!

the best cruise ever!. SO much to see...do not close your eyes even for a second, otherwise you''ll miss an architecture, the bridges, the sea gulls, the homes, the cami...spectacular water, spectacular view..awe inspiring!

Do the 90 minute short trip.... ... which still feels about 60 minutes to long. But a good way to see the city from afar, drink some cheap cay (1 lira each) and get some fresh air. Tours with Topkapi run hourly from 10 - 16:00, and cost an astoundingly cheap 12 lira. For more fun, watch your fellow passengers. At the start of the tour, everyone is jostling for a seat on top with the best view. By about half way through the cruise, many people will have retired to the cabin below. Strongly recommended to have a 5 lira fish sandwich on the same pier - delicious and made fresh on the fishing boats.

Relaxing...do it on your own.. What a relaxing and enjoyable day. We did the long tour (1030-1630) from the IDO operator. I would avoid the group or private tours which seemed a bit pricey and too controlled. It was mid-march so off-season crowds. We simply picked a nice day went to the IDO ferry pier and bought tickets about 30 mins before the cruise. Pick a spot (inside or outside) and just relax. A bit of an "attack" by restaurant operators as you disembark - but it's their livelihood. The food (seafood) looked fantastic! We did not eat in a restaurant, we just bought a doner for a quick, cheap bite. If you want to climb up to the caste, just follow the signs and the dogs. A friendly group of dogs followed us up. The walk could be a bit strenuous for some, and slick if wet. As you get closer to the castle - the stairs get challenging as well. But the reward was worth the effort- a flawless view out to the sea. Overall, the cruise was like taking a trip far from the big city - without really going very far.

History in front of your eyes. This must be one of the most interesting waterways in the world from biblical times, through medieval times, wartimes and to modern times this is redolent in history and an interior artery for a city of character and interest.

Boat Trip. We took a day trip arranged by Ibrahim @ the hotel. Good overview of the Bospherus & Golden Horn. Really got a sense of the size of the city which is huge. Excellent value for 60 tl which is about £24 and included a pleasant lunch. Could have done without the "fashion show" at a leather emporium but hey, they're in the tourist business
Gorgeous View. There is nothing like having a glass of red Turkish wine while sitting on a veranda watching the ships sail through the Bosphorus where 2 continents meet!

Worth a boat trip. We were lucky with the weather and an incredible sunset. We left on a boat trip up the Bosphorus at 4.30pm and were treated to an incredible and stunning sunset on the return leg into Istanbul, with the skyline set against bright organges. About 90mins duration we just stayed on the round trip but were glad to have seen a little bit of the strait outside of istanbul central.

Beautiful views!. We took the tram from Sultanahmet to Eminonu to get to the Galata Bridge - it was so worth it! There is something so tranquil about the sea, that even with a busy crowd I can get lost within the moment. The views of both sides of the city are amazing and it is a unique experience walking the bridge to the other side (btw when we got to the other side we took the Tunel to Istiklal, which was a cool little experience).There is also so much going on in Eminonu, including the tourist sites of the Spice Bazaar and New Mosque. A visit to the Bosphorus ended up being a really fun side trip from Sultanahmet District!I'm landlocked back home, so I take advantage of any chance to hang out by seas and bridges!
Simit to the seagulls. For 3 Turkish lira get on a ferry to kadikoy and enjoy the crossing, great views both ways. Istanbul is built on and separated by the sea so its the nicest way to get around

It is a MUST to see it!. Peerless view, you can feel one of the most intensive cultures here in İstanbul. The shadows of Ottoman Empire enhance the glittery silhouette of modern İstanbul, you should see & feel it!

Like a zoo.. Walk along this straight on the Golden Horn. There are lots of animals living in the rocks, dogs and cats. Very cute animals. But do not walk there alone. It can be dangerous. It is where that New York woman was murdered last month. It felt really safe though, just walk it with a friend, in the day time. Early morning was perfect.

Must do!!!. In a two or three hours cruise in Bosporus, you will be able to see all versions of Istanbul. Poor houses, mansions on the see, high towers, mosques, ancient monuments, modern bridges, mosques etc. In a few words, you can see the exact point where East meets West. Very highly recommended, especially with tur yol cruises.

Wow. The Bosporus helps turn Istanbul from a fantastic city, to the best in Europe for a long weekend. It does to Istanbul, what the sea does to NY. The tourist boats are great, but I do suggest taking the normal ferry from Europe to Anatolia. Now, if you want to propose to your dearly beloved, can there be a better place on earth than the maiden tower in the middle of the Bosporus. Other than T5 Heathrow where I proposed to my fiance! :-)

Magnificent Views. We went on the Bosphorus cruise, by taking the tram and got off at Eminonu, the ferrys run regularly everyday and are very easy to catch and cheap too, it cost 10 TL which is about £3.00 pp. If we had booked with a tour operator it would have cost about 30ER. The cruise lasted about 1-2 hours there was plenty of seats and drinks and snacks were available to buy. The scenery is so so beautiful.. along the Bosphorus, we could see Istanbul on both sides of the continents Asia and Europe and famous landmarks too, it was fantastic a must see attraction.

A lovely way to spend a few hours. If you have a couple of hours spare then think about doing this. There are numerous trips departing from the Galatea Bridge and be prepared to haggle, the usual price is 10tl per person for a two hour cruise.(March 2013). The cruise takes you up one side of the strait and then over o the other side. You see some lovely historic and modern buildings. Also this must be one of the busiest shipping lanes in the world, cruise liners, tankers, trawlers , small fishing boats they are all here. Makes great viewing

Amazing views. Take a trip on by boat or an open top bus to really get a good view. It is fabulous seeing both Asia and Europe on one trip. If you love photography then this is a must as the sights are so beautiful.
