Magnificent Panoramas. Very pleasant and inexpensive way to take in the panoramic magnificence of this area. The harbor is very busy but boat traffic glides seamlessly amidst the apparent chaos. Can be a little chilly on the water - bring light jacket.

Great if you take the ferry, avoid tours.. The Bosphorus Strait is a great body of water and a must see while in Istanbul.Take the ferry and it will cost around 12 TL. DO NOT bother booking it with a tour like we did.Over priced and lack of information is what was provided on our tour.Istanbul is a fantastic place where most places can be visited on foot and no guide is necessary.Add this one to your trip.

Just Ace. Apart from being herded like sheep to the embarkation jetty the trip was excellent, about two hours, to see Istanbul from the water. to be sailing between Europe and Asia, beautiful palaces and to be part of the frenetic waterway. Not to be missed.

A must to see. We actually were not planning to do the trip as we were on a few days break. However we we by the waterfront at about 2.30 and made a quick decision to do the 90 minute cruise for the amazing price of 10 lira. It gives the city a completely different prospective and you see bridges, palaces, and mosques plus the fishing villages along the shore. Also a rest for tired feet. Its very photogenic but do wrap up warm on cooler days.Will be back to take a longer cruise one day I hope.

Busiest water way I have ever seen. I have been to many water ways, New York Harbor, San Diego and San Francisco, Norfolk and this is by far the busiest harbor I have ever seen. It is amazing the volumne of ships and boats that use this section of water way.Lovely ferry ride is a MUST do. Cost is around $10 US and you see palaces and mansions all along the ride.

Transited as Master of a ship. Lovely houses on either sides
Historic monuments and green mountains were the things I liked.
Beautiful sunsets and tourists on small ferry's make the place very lively.

Do a short trip. We did a 90 minute trip cost 12TL which was enough to get a sense of scale of the strait and to see many of the fascinating buildings along its bank - any more might be a bit much. Watch out for touts - they may quote prices in Euro - which is much more than in TL

Take the ferry!. Although they look confusing, the ferries are the way to beat the traffic across the straights. there is also an information booth nearby, with people who speak English, and can help you with getting on the right boat.

best tour. This is the very best way to actually see how big this city is. We did the all day tour and we were very happy we took the time to do it. There is much to see along the route and a fabulous castle to walk up to on the 3 hour layover before heading back.
Take a cruise!. We did a memorable, private sunset cruise down the Bosphorous with many friends. It was beautiful and gave us incredible sight-lines of the city. Highly recommended to all.

Dolphins, and Seagulls, and Beauty, Oh My!. Cruising the Bosphorus is a must for anybody traveling to Istanbul. You get amazing views of both the European and Asian sides of the city, ancient and modern structures alike. I also saw about 20 dolphins during my last cruise - it was perfect!

enjoy the Istanbul view. I took the tour arranged by Baris of Hanedan Hotel. Love the boat tour! amazing view from the deck. We mixed with the Golden Horn tour as well. At the end, we went to Pierre Loti to have our coffee at the top, it's just A M A Z I N G. . .
grandiouse. this strait between europe and asia is grandiouse but nothing more. the boat trip is boring one since you can not see the shores close. bringes are interesting but nothing else

AMAZING views, see both Europe and Asia. You MUST take a Bosphorus boat ride. They're very cheap and last about 2 hours. They take you all around the European side then on the way back you see the Asian side. You get to see many monumental structures such as the Palace, and you pass under the Bosphorus bridge. Highly recommended.

a must to do in Istanbul!. Orhan Pamuk writes eloquently about the Bosphorus Strait in his childhood memoir - and I find its resonance by taking a half day tour along the strait. Don't get lured by the other operators trying to get in your way offering a much shorter tour which costs so much money (ranging from Euro 10 to 25!) instead to go to Eminönü pier and catch the 10:30am tour for as little as 25 TL. It's a 6-hour tour (3 on the ferry, three on a fishing village on the Asian part) but it's totally worthed! Since we stayed in February, and the weather could be cloudy, rainy and cold, so we consulted the BBC weather forecast for a bright sunny day! The audio guide is helpful and comes cheaply (5 TL).

Unforgettable cruise. That is a must of your stay in Istanbul. If the weather is nice, it is very enjoyable to benefit from the sun on board of a boat. You will admire wonderful palaces and typical wooden houses all along Bosphorus
overated. we did what most sites recommended, we took the 90 min ferry up to the faithe (?) bridge and back. Not much to see but a pleasant journey non the less.

Unique view of Istanbul. Istanbul is truly huge & you catch a slight glimpse of this on a Bosphorus cruise. It's easy to take & accessible by the main tram line that runs by the Grand Bazaar. Right across from the Egyptian (spice) market, too.

Bus Trip to Asia. Went on the open-topped bus over the Bosphorus bridge to the Asian side. Shame it was so cold that day as we did not get out of the bus. There are headsets with guides in about 8 languages to tell you exactly where you are. I would prefer to go in summer when its hotter!!

Take a guide book and the ferry. The Bosphorus is laced with multiple ferries operated in conjunction with the public transport system in Istanbul. Get yourself a travel card and it costs 1.95 Turkish Lira to travel on ALL public transport links.
Way cheaper than the tour boats which you will be hassled to take.

Very good cruise and a pleasant way to spend most of a day in Istanbul. I found the cruise to be quite an enjoyable trip. In its entirety, it lasts about 6 hours (and costs 25 lira); about 3 hours of the trip is cruising up the Bosphorus and back with a 3 hour layover on the Asian side.The cruise portion provides some very good views of the European and Asian coasts of the area. The layover in Asia presents a good opportunity to hike up to to Yoros Castle and view the Black Sea; the rest of the town is mostly restaurant hawkers (I don't eat seafood, so none of them appealed to me).I think the audio guide rental is well worth the additional 5 lira cost, though you will be required to submit additional money or an ID card as a deposit (which you will receive when you return the device).

Worth a boat ride. If you have time just take a ride in one of the ferries thta cross the strait: they are cheaper and more interesting than the tourist boats. Forget about the so called fish restaurants under the Galata bridge: they are just crap.

Quirky and atmospheric. Overpriced, as many things are in Istanbul, but interesting. The piped music and mood lighting help with the ambience (unlike the shrieking tourists paying 10 lira to dress up like Sultans and harem girls, for photos).

A must-do. First of all, in English it's simply "The Bosphorus."The Bosphorus is the main feature that makes Istanbul what it is; without it, not only would Istanbul have much less scenic beauty, it would also have little reason for its existence. I think the best way to see the Bosphorus is to take the city lies cruise that leaves from the Bosphorus Quay (BOĞAZ İZKELESİ) in Eminönü and goes up to Anadolu Kavağı, where you'll have time to walk up to the Yoros castle and enjoy the green and view of the Black Sea. Down in the village, there are lots of fish restaurants covering a wide range of prices and atmospheres. Also try the lokma, deep fried "donuts" drizzled with syrup, available at the stands near the waterfront. If you don't have all day, you can take the shorter (1 1/2 hour) tours on smaller boats that leave from nearby the Bosphorus Quay. The tour only goes as far as the second (Fatih Sultan Mehmet) bridge, but you'll see the most important areas including Rumeli Hisarı and Anadolu Hisarı, the castles built by the Ottomans at the narrowest point.But if you have time, you should also take a bus or taxi if you're feeling flush, up to some of the charming villages on the shores. On the European side, Arnavutköy, Bebek and Emirgan are nice; you can also visit Rumeli Hisarı. On the Asian side, Kuzguncuk, Beylerbeyi, Çengelköy and Kanlica are beautiful, with lots of old Ottoman homes. Anadolu Hisarı is also pleasant but rather small with few dining options, and the castle there is not open to the public though you can look in through the gate. I hear there are plans to open it eventually.If you have time and the means, one of the nicest places is Anadolu Fener, at the very end of the Bosphorus on the Asian side. It's a quiet, even sleepy little village overlooking the Black Sea, and there are several relaxed, informal fish restaurants there. But it's quite a haul up there and the value is more in the rural nature of the place rather than historic sights.
Pleasant day cruise. An interesting way of seeing something of the country outside Istanbul. Impressive buildings and bridges, but no climax to the excursion. Nice on a warm day?

Unusual place. It's not just a bridge, but a district with a walking space, plenty of restaurants and point for fishermen. In the restaurant you could taste the freshest fish and good turkish beer. And if you pass the Strait to Galata side, you will see the very old-school fish market with small cafes, where local people have their slow dinner. The prices are the cheapest in the city and place is so "alive"!

Lack Charachter. While the history of the Bosphorus is fascinating and the splendour of the buildings emphasised the Ottoman cluture, the waterway itself is a little uninteresting.it was however amazing to see the magnificent and very expensive private homes as well as the historical buildings and forts.This tour gave mixed feelings.

Great day out. Terminal is the closest one to the bridge if you get off at the Eminolu tram stop. 25TL for round trip. The 10TL tour is 2 hours out and back with no stop so choose carefully.The 6 hour Ferry pretty was pretty empty which was great and the regular circuit of the waiters selling tea (1TL !!!) and coffee was entertaining. Flogging yoghurt before we arrived at the place that makes it (2.5TL) was real salesmanship and different. Audio guide fit 5TL at the port was definitely worth it (they need 100TL deposit ) and easy to share one between two. Anadolu Kavagy at the end was OK. Bit of a walk up to the castle (ruined and you can't get in) and on a day when it was 11 degrees C took 25 minutes and made us pretty warm. Wouldn't like to do it on hot day - but would probably got a taxi up! View is worth it for 15 minutes then back down to the port to wrestle with restaurant touts. You are their only trade so expect it. We had a fine meal in one of the sea front places but were very clear on what we were being charged for fish. Prices are mostly per kilo so if something is 75TL on the menu the fish you point at may turn out to cost 110TL. So couple of mazes, grilled fish and salad, two beers - 80TLThe boat makes the trip though and the view of summer houses, towns, castles, bridges, multiple boats from ferries to tankers to container ships and the various stops makes this a very relaxing 6 hours.
Loved It !!. I loved the ferry rides to Uskudar and Kadikoy day and night great views very cheap a must in everyone's schedule when visiting this city
Take the ferry - a cheap tip to Asia. The public ferries a cheap and frequent. You get a good view of the city. Take a walk on the Asia side of the city.

Best day off in Istanbul. This is a must do. Take a Ferry all the way up to Black sea and back to IST later in the same day.Avoid crowds and do this on week days. Make sure to arrive early at Ferry entrance, if you are interested on running for a seat at the top floor.Well I could not and therefore I had mine inside at the entrance floor, but decided to stand for the whole trip looking at the scenario supported by ferry's rail. It was the best thing!Observe crew, people in and out every station. Carry food for seal gulls (Smit) and taste Kalinka yogurt.Later on, be prepared for an uphill walk for a castle that is not open to public visitation, but pays for top observation spot. Get a spot to a nice meal for lunch! Prices are not fair.
Boat trip. Took a boat down the Bosphorous, best way to see the city and the mosques, past all the lovely old houses, worth doing!

a must do. the 1 day cruise to the bosphorus, reaching the gates of Marmara sea, was one of the great moments during my holiday. the journey is nice and comfortable, on the boat there is a coffee bar.go on the hill to see the ancient fortress and have lunch at the spectacular terrace of the restaurant. muat be done with nice weather conditions

Fantastic cruise. We took a boat cruise to bhosporus. Lovely views on both sides of the river. The trip was good we did a lot of shopping in buka Horus . Very reasonable prices. The food was good . Good trip

Simply enchanting. This is absolutely what someone must do when in Istanbul!You can use the Istanbulcard, it is really inexpensive to get one of the frequent ferries to the Asian side.Arrange to be en route during the sunset when returning from the Asian side.Th traffic is dense with large cargo vessels passing fron and forth of your ferry.Get a tea (chai) if in winter and you are in the external board.
Go fish. This is the place to see hundreds of fishermen al day and night fishing, you can find there all you need for that and they do fish.

Orientate yourself on this short cruise. Take a cruise from the far side of the Galeta Bridge - takes around an hour and a half and enables you to orient yourself in this vast city. Dress warmly if you go in winter - there are seats inside but it can be chilly. We wore winter coats, hats, scalves, gloves.

Lovely cruise on a sunny day!. Enjoyed the boat ride (half-day) and the weather was so good (60F at the end of December). Wish we had a whole day cruise to check out the Black sea. However could see the Marmara sea shimmering in the distance

2 continents. 2 land, 2 continents, 1 city , stunning.
cruise along by the ferry , watched the birds fly over our head.
start the cruise from Istanbul Asia or Istanbul Europa and getting back, both are awesome.

Between two continents. Crossing the Bosphorus Strait is a one-in-a-lifetime experience. To start with, you'll find yourself between two continents while in the same city. Taking the boat, you will marvel at Istanbul landmarks, many of which can only be enjoyed from close this way. The Bosphorus Bridge, the Maiden's Tower, the Rumeli Fortress, the Dolmabahce Palace and other sights will pass before your eyes giving you an insight of different historical periods. Beautiful buildings of various styles will catch your eye. The - what seems to be - infinite blue and the company of seagulls all the way will make you wish this journey has no end.There are many options available:- A cruise that goes up the Strait. Cost: around 12 TL. From Eminönü and Besiktas ports.- A ferry to the Prince Islands crossing the Sea of Marmara as well. From Kabatas port.- A ferry bus to the Asian side (Haydarpasa, Üsküdar, Kadiköy). Cost: 1.90 TL (you can also  use your Istanbulkart). From Eminönü, Karaköy, Besiktas and Kabatas ports. This is the cheapest way to cross the Bosphorus and visit the Asian side areas. I did it  everyday! Couldn't get enough!Make sure you cross it at least once at dusk or later. The sights are illuminated and it's simply magical!

Interlude on the water. Took a 2 hour cruise up to the second bridge on a regular ferry which gave our family a good idea of how busy and important the Bosphorus Strait is. It was amazing to be able to see two continents at the same time, see locals fishing from small boats amongst the busy freight ship traffic and the historic buildings and castles

So relaxing. I crossed the Bosphorus on a ferry going to the Princes Islands and that was great especially coming back after sunset and taking pictures of Sultanahmet sites from the boat. But one day I decided to just sit in one of the coffee and just asked for a bottle of water, I sat there in the sun, enjoying the blueness and very soft noises around me. No body chases you or bugs to order more stuff, you can pick a "Semit" if you want but they leave you alone to enjoy. Cost 1 TL (60 cents) value is infinite, That was life.

Ferry nuff!. We took a two hour trip on a small tourist ferry for 15TR per person. A wonderful and inexpensive way to get a real perspective on this city of three parts and a great opportunity to identify what sights you might wish to explore more closely.

Relaxing. For 25 Turkish Lira, why not? The tour boat was pretty comfortable and modern and you always felt very safe. It would have been nice to have a guide explain what you were seeing and there is a lot to see. I am sure the history would be interesting as well but who knows?With all the tour boats coming and going, why not drop you off and let you hop on another? It is less than a two hour tour so there would be plenty of time.Still a rock-bottom price and well worth the couple of hours plus it was no trouble to get to-and-from the docks. Lots to see, shop and eat around the docks so it fits in nicely with your day.

Try to take it @ a sunny day. It was a great trip, although we took it in a rainy & cold day, I enjoyed watching the colored houses on the Bosphorus bank, some stayed inside the boat to avoid cold & rain drinking hot Turkish tea or coffee, but I preferred to stay outside in the boat taking photos, the scenes are undesirable. This trip was a part of the whole tour for 25 euros including the Teleferic & the bus for & to the Hotel...Enjoy…

Take a boat tour for a great view of Istanbul. The boat tours aren't inexpensive but are worth it in decent weather. The views of Istanbul from the Bosphorus are unmatched. Our tour, combined with a hop-on, hop-off bus city tour in the morning, also included a trip to Pierre Loti cafe for more great views and a cable car ride down.

a trophy for the traveller... europe to asia..!! for a £1.00 you can take the ferry to another continent..historys ghosts in every direction..multiple stops and board points..only a note of caution.. the health and safety police would a heart attack here..but the whole chaotic , real life manner of the trip is intoxicating..fantastic..
Boat Tour. Found it a very useful way to understand the geography of Istanbul. Really cool to see the remaining wooden houses and palaces along the shorelines

Take your own ferry trips rather than a tour. Rather than pay 25TL plus for a tour we used our Istanbulkarts to pay less than 2TL for rides on the ferries, we went from Emenuoi to Uskadar on the Asian side where we went for a coffee and a cake, far cheaper than in the tourist bits and we took an evening ferry to Kadikoy for a meal where there were no tourists and we got to see the Istanbul skyline at night but do check for last ferry times, its a long way back otherwise!

Istanbul Modern for a great view. The modern art gallery Istanbul Modern has a very nice cafe, not cheap but well worth it. You can sit out on the terrace (we did even in December) and have s fantastic view of the Bosphorus Strait.

A cheap and atmospheric ferry ride. Catch the local ferry that criss crosses the Golden horn. It's 3TL and takes about an hour to go from Eminonu to Eyup. Lonely Planet's directions to the ferry stop need improving, but with a little inventiveness you can get there by following the directions. The ferry leaves once an hour (on the half hour in January, 2013). It has a tea shop, WC, sheltered decks. It is a great way to see the Golden Horn and much cheaper than the packaged boat trips with their bored narrators.

I could ride the ferry all day!. You step on a ferry, you cross to another continent, you step off. The wind blows, seagulls fly alongside hoping to catch a bite of bread, and you can drink a tea while you watch the city around you. A must do in Istanbul!

Beautiful Bosphorus. The living, breathing heart of Istanbul and its a working waterway, not just a tourist attraction. Stand and watch the ferryboats come and go - locals use them to commute, but there is also a great trip up to Anadolu Kavagi. It takes a couple of hours but once there you can walk up the hillside and see where the Bosphorus opens out into the Black Sea. Before the boat returns you have time for a tasty meal - great seafood.

Breath taking.. Best way is to take the boat trip till the northern end "Anadolu or Rumeli Kavagi". You can then have your lunch in one of the fish restaurants and relax. Do not forget to take your camera with you.

On a sunny day, this cruise is just the ticket. I did this on my first day in Istanbul when it was sunny and warm. It was a nice orientation to the layout of the city and offered great views from the water. I took the cruise that stopped in Andalou Kavagie on the Asian side of the city. It offered a great walk up to the old fort. I also took the bus back to the Old City. I would only recommend this for the super adventurous. But the advantage is that I was able to get back a couple hours faster than the boat and so I still had plenty of daylight to see some more sights in the historical core.

This what you need when you visit Instanbul. All you need to see and find is there.! All the most famous monuments are there. The central market ( Mega Bazzar) is there. and all the rest very close. The train will help.
Good. Great views. Great photo taking opportunities. We had a guide that taught us a lot and made the whole experience come together
river trip. We did this ourselves and saved loads of money as the tourist excursions were costed in EU, we went on a local boat with Turkish tourists, to the Black Sea and back.

Beautiful Sunny View!. it's amazing how the bosphorus strait split the same country half european and half asiatic!the view it's amazing, especially if it's a sunny day, the Bosphorus Cruise is not bad, but nothing unmissable, in any case I suggest everyone to choose the short one, 2 hours are enough, especially if your stay in Istanbul it's not a long stay!enjoy your trip!Fede&Bryant

do this on your stay. A short taxi ride away from Taksim is this lovely strait. Sit , relax, have a cold beer or glass of wine and watch the crowd pass by. 20th Jan 2013, temp was almost 20 Celcius. Traffic can be a problem as short distance but took us almost an hour to get there. Still worth going. Almost like a beach atmosphere which you would expect down south in bddrum / dadalmam/ marmaris.if ure lucky, find a balcony view overlooking the sea. On the Sunday, I was not that lucky.Enjoy!!!!!!!!!!!!

The Beautiful Bosphorus. The Bosphorus Strait tour is a must do activity in Istanbul. In other words, the Istanbul trip is incomplete without a ferry boat trip along the Bosphorus. The view from the Bosphorus strait of the old buildings on both Asian and European sides are just breath taking. The Bosphorus bridge view is also an essential part of the trip. You must take a picture of yourself with the bridge in background. Because the bridge is the symbol for connecting Asia with Europe.
take a camera and a hat. superbly scenic vistas and a wonderful light quality make this a photographer's dream come true. Windy though- take hat, gloves and a scarf!

Very Magical. The strait separates the European part of Turkey to the rest of the Asian side of Turkey. We did a Bosphorus Straight cruise on our last night in Istanbul and LOVED it. The Bosphorus Bridge is beautiful at night and the cruise takes you underneath the bridge. Very very magical. A must while in Turkey.
Wonderful. Most special place on the world with its historical buildings, sailing boats, colourful trees, deepblue water and of course various seafood restaurants.

Must be done. The trip up the Bosphorus gives you a good idea of the size of Istanbul, and good views of the different architecture along the way, including watching the busy waterway and passing under the vast bridges linking Europe and Asia. The all day cruise leaves from Eminonu and stops long enough for a leisurely fish lunch at the village of Anadolu Kavagi

I travel it everyday. the bosphorus is the most beautiful and full of magnificent things to see. You can learn about Istanbul and experience what it is like to live here. You will see modern, ancient as well as very old. There is everything here to see and its a great experience. I have traveled the bosphorus several times in my 8.5 years of lving here.

Take a Day Cruise! Beautiful Sunset!. Loved the Day Cruise. We went mid afternoon and the sunset was glorious on the way back. I must have taken 75 photos, each one better than the one before!Historical sites, Fort, Hunting Lodge, University buildings, Discos, including one island one, wealthy homes, going under the bridges! I was a warm day and for most of the time we were on the top deck. Later, as it cooled off, we moved inside a lower deck.It was wonderful!We did a dinner cruise on the Bosphorus Strait but it was not so great--entertainment was lousy--too loud, seductive belly dancer, loud singers, etc.
boat ride. good ride on the bosphorus, but was quite cold and quite windy the day we all went so not a true reflection

get a boat trip and enjoy. we had a boat trip, and they made it very enjoyable with music and a bit of a dance. the views are great, on both sides of the river and you get to see the size of the city and all its history.

WONDER of the world!. Bosphorus strait is my favourite place in the world. Except traffic, crowded and noise in this city, Bosphorus athmosphere is worth to live in Istanbul. On weekends you can just take a walk in seaside or have a breakfast any of the cafes' nearby sea! And you can find a lot of local barrowman, you should try chestnuts, simit and Turkish tea!
should come and try use the boat in the strait. it's a strait between europe and asian area, all the architecture and building is well preserved, and good view
lifetime pleasure. Looking at the history everyday, what a precious gift to live in this city. A must do while alive for sure. Two continents, two personalities

Good. I was just lovely, but the fery we took, took us from the strait and back almost the some route, so it kinda was boring on the back to Eminonu.But you just have to try this. Try taking the shortest fery route, because it is so hot in summer that you would get fried sitting in the sun.

RIDE INTO THE PAST. The ride through the straits takes you from the oceans of the world, through the Mediterranean, and into the Black Sea. What momentous strife it took place to control the straits becomes evident as you glide through.

Take a ride along the Bosperus Strait.. You really mustn't visit this area without taking this trip. There is Turkiye on one side and Asia on the other. So much history and culture.... I highly recommend it!
Great, cheap cruise. Great option, very cold in winter, but a very enjoyable trip. Avoid taking photo's of people taking photo's of people taking photos of people feeding seagulls...

ADORED!!!!!. I loved everything about this trip!I wasn't that excited to do a boat trip as I made the same when I was in Paris in Bateau Parisien, and didn't quite like it, it was boring! so you can imagine what I felt when I was doing the Bosphorus trip!But I WAS WAY WRONG!!!I loved it! No I adored it! and let me tell you the day wasn't a nice day, it was cold and blury and almost about to rain,,,, and still I loved it!Imagine if it was summer with beautiful blue sky!!I will go to Istanbul again and will do this trip again! DEFINITELY!

East meets West. Eminonu is the tram station to alight and you walk across to this amazing sight. A bridge connecting the East to West, Here is the unique opportunity to step from one continent (ASIA) to the another (Europe)

different view of the city. Took a boat trip from Eminonu. 2 hour trip for bargain 10 Turkish Lira. We were lucky as it was sunny, mild and beautifully clear affording fabulous views of the city.Take your camera!

Gliding for memories. I had the chance to enjoy a boat trip during the evening with a wonderful dinner...amazing.the view is wonderful and you will not forget the feeling of travelling in the middle of two continents...Wonderful apartments and hotels on the shores make your trip memorable.the lighted bridge will be a nice appointment in the landscape.When the night cannes, the blue and the pink Basilica are a wonderful silhouette on the horizon.

take a boat tour!. We did 1/2 day tour, but full days are available too. Wonderful sights to see! Generally a stop at a palace is included. Met wonderful folks on the boat and on the tour. A great way to spend 1/2 day. Well worth it!!
Where two continents meet. The views looking from Europe across the strait To Asia are fantastic. We walked over the Galata bridge and had a great fish meal in one of the many resturants there

Take a private tour.. One one of our recent trips to Istanbul, we took a private boat tour of the Bosphorus. There were 8 of us on a small boat. We had tea as we sailed up and down the Strait. Around us were all types of ships--NATO ships, small fishing boats and larger ferries. A very busy strait with great views of both the European and Asian sides of Istanbul. A must do!

Pleasant ferry ride to stand in two continents. You'll want to be able to say you did it, of course, if you travel to Istanbul. How many other opportunities will you have to stand in two continents while staying in the same city? But really, it is just a narrow bit of water.We decided to skip the expensive dinner cruises. We took the bus across Boğaz Köprüsü and then wandered along the Asian shore, waiting until dark before taking the ferry back from Kadıköy to Karaköy. The ferry is very nicely furnished and much nicer than most public transport. You can buy tea, or go outside to watch the lights of Kadıköy fade and Eminönü come in focus. The illuminated Unkapanı bridge is nice to look at. It is a smooth ride, not too long and not too short. Both ferry terminals are well-lit and the area immediately around them feels safe enough.Note that the ferry uses a different type of token than the subway, and you can also not use the same type of pass as on the bus. The ferry tokens can easily be mistaken for coins.

Short cruise is the best option. There are two cruises on the Bosphorus: short (2 hours) and long (6 hours). The short one is great if you don't have too much time. Both banks are appealing in their own way.

Take a cruise on a ferry. Well worth a cruise (for 5 TL) you can hop on or off at a range of Islands and explore each at your leisure. Princess Island, at the end of the line, is worth a visit - take a horse and cart tour of the island (70 TL for 1+hrs) then tuck into a nice meal at one of the many restaurants along the shore line of the main town.

A must do !. A city just looks a bit different from the water. Taking a boat trip around the Bosphorus Strait is a must to be able to see Istanbul from a different perspective. The trip I went on was 2 hours, and I'm not sure a longer trip would be great, but maybe. Very enjoyable and worthwhile.
must visit. you can have Bosphourus tour from Ortakoy and Eminonu. It is my the most favourite thing to do. you can see both sides of strait and take great pictures.

Beautiful!. Definitely take a boat trip with a guide who can point out all the wonders along each side-Europe and Asia. We went by day and then again at night when we spent New Years on the water under the bridge at midnight watching the countdown and then the fireworks. Perfect.

Bosphorus Strait. I took the afternoon bus/boat trip from the tourist office and really enjoyed the experience,it really helped that I had a really good set of binoculars to appreciate the stunning architecture on both sides of the river,and when it got a bit chilly on deck,a hot Turkish coffee in the snack bar was a little taste of heaven.

Enjoy a tour and a rest at same time. If you are suffering jet lag, this is a terrific boat tour to take. The views are breathtaking. Certainly plenty to see and photos are plentiful. We took some snacks with us although you can buy. You can get off the boat at spots they have marked but we waited til the half way point to get off, get a drink, stretch our legs and then re-boarded to enjoy the trip back. It was a great afternoon event to enjoy and give ourselves a chance to relax and work off abit of jet leg.

great views of the Bosphorous. Took a Boat tour down the european side and back along the asian side, great views of magnificent architecture, palaces, mansions etc,not to be missed even in unclement weather.

Got Lost intially, but enjoyed it!. I initially ended up on the wrong boat! I didn't use a tour operator and went directly to the port, the good people in turkey mostly lack english skills, so i guess they ended up putting us on the wrong boat! Anyway on the other side, we ended pickup up the right Bosphorus cruise boat and enjoyed the ride! the views are nice, the breeze is coal and just nice to watch the ocean go by and to view both sides of this beautiful city! You can't miss this if you're in Istanbul highly recommend it. I can't recall how much we paid, but it was pretty cheap when we went directly to the port, compared to what the hotel and tour operators were charging us.

Beautiful Cruise - a MUST DO. After reading Orhan Pamuk's "Istanbul", I've had a fascination with the Bosphorus. It was winter, it was cold, it was WORTH IT to be on the water. Go to the ferries at Galata Bridge. Go to the Turyol ferry stop and take the 90 minute tour. It costs 10 TL. I think it leaves at 10:30 am. In the summer, there are more departures. We also went to Kadikoy from the Karikoy ferry launch on the other side of the Galata bridge (you can also pick up the Kadikoy ferry from Eminonu) - it takes 25/30 minutes...also fantastic. The Bosphorus coast is amazing and seeing all the activity on the water and in the air (so many sea gulls!) is incredible. If you're going to Istanbul, you can't miss out on the heart of the city - the waterways.

Relax and enjoy the views!. This is a fantastic way to see the city. Relax and enjoy the different views of the city from the Bosphorous. Either just cruise the strait for the pleasure of the ride or use this as transportation around the different parts of the city. A must do
took a boring cruise. I've seen rivers before. This was another one. Trip was long, got cold outside, went inside, was drafty. Got hungry bought some doritos that tasted like hot dogs. Fail.

cruise the stait. booked an evening cruise with the hotel.. good evening out for a decent price... buffet spread was ok.. more salads than mains available.. but the food was good...
entertainment was generic.. traditional turkish music and dance, belly dance, and short magic show for the kids...
good facts/info by the tour guide about the stait and the building around it...

Another view of this amazing city. I would recommend a full day tour in Bosporus Strait by boat.
This way you can see the city from another angle. Old colorful houses. very expensive modern houses, palaces, prestigious schools, bridges connecting the European and Asian sides etc.
Great Views. Gives you a great view of both the European and Asian sides of Istanbul. Brings you close to the seaside homes and also gives a nice perspective of the hills around the city.
Amazing. The boat journey was long and informative. The guide was a wealth of knowledge on history and architecture. Thoroughly enjoyed ourselves. Highlight of our trip so far.

A nice outing. We spent a day riding the ferry up the Bosphorous to the Black Sea. It was a good chance to see more of Turkey when we only had a few days in Istanbul. There was a nice town we stopped in for lunch, though my husband and I were disappointed to find the much-raved-about lookout closed to visitors when we arrived. If you only have 2 days in town, I wouldn't make this a priority, but if you've hit your other major spots in Istanbul, definitely take a tour on the Bosphorous for a relaxing day. Stop-off in Istanbul's New District to get a feel for the lively, modern side of Istanbul. But make sure you leave in time to catch a ferry back to the Old District (if that's where you're staying). Ask a friendly person nearby to help you out!

Beautiful, but a better option for warm weather. It's common sense that the best time to visit the waterfront in a city is during the late spring or summer. However, a trip to Istanbul any time of the year would be incomplete without visiting the Bosphorus. I was recently in Istanbul with a friend and took a long walk along the Bosphorus (about 3 kilometers) on a Sunday afternoon. It was freezing (it actually snowed about a meter while I was there), windy, biting... but beautiful. It amazed me how few people were walking along the boardwalk, however I took full advantage of the peace and quiet after spending several days in the chaotic Sultanahmet district. If you decide to go for a stroll in this area in the off-season, keep your eyes open for fishermen camped out among the rocks. I encountered a few camps of elderly men playing board games and making tea over a small fire while fishing- it definitely felt more "authentic" than the hoards if tourists in the historic center. Next time I come to Istanbul, I will definitely make sure I visit the Bosphorus again- but this time, I will come in a warmer season! PS. If you are dead-set on going on a boat tour of the Bosphorus, make sure you compare prices and look for reviews of the experience. I tried one company with my friend and was highly disappointed (and ripped off with the Euro/ Lira conversion)!
Nice. Nice boat ride and tour. If you go July its very hot and sunny on the top.Great opportunity for nice pictures.

Magnificent view and evocative atmosphere. Try and visit the crazy expensive Ciragan Palace hotel for an exquisitely presented coffee on the terrace and then wander around their beautiful grounds with the most amazing views of the strait.

East meets West. Travel on the ferry boat from Kabatas to Kadıköy harbour and it was truly worth it. What an array of beautiful buildings along the banks. Really special indeed.Will repeat the journey if i am in Istanbul again and the sun is shining. I guarantee that it will be even more magical.

Liquid Love. If you ask 1000 locals in Istanbul what which place in the city they love most, 1001 of them say "the banks of the Bosphorus".
Yes, indeed! No matter, if you stand in Kadıköy harbour, in Kabataş, in Ortaköy or far northwards in İstinye ... Bosphorus is best!

Worth the trip. Taking a ferry trip up the Bosphorus gives a good overview of the whole area and the chance to see a variety of impressive buildings along the shoreline. The public excursion ferry (only one at 10.30 in the winter though) gives the chance to hop on and off at different points; the private ferries go a shorter distance and do not stop. All are good value. Don't miss the mackerel sandwiches sold on the quay side when you return!

Must, must, must take a boat trip!. The views from the Bosphorus will be my wonderful memory of Istanbul. There are many boats offering 'cruises' on the river, take your pick! All of them have the same views, but there does seem to be a BIG difference in the quality of boats......... We managed to pay a very small amount for our trip and when I saw the boat I understood why! As it was later afternoon we sailed back to the setting sun and were rewarded with scenes of the sun setting behind the many minarets of the old city. Makes me sigh in contentment as I type this. A visit to Istanbul is not complete if you don't get out on the river!

Peaceful Atmosphere. This is a buisy corridor, for freight coming and going to the Black Sea. We went for a river cruise all the way to Anadolu Kavagl and there were places that were just unbelievable to see. A ferry ride to the Asia side, and it is so different, as no one hassleing you, The Madens Tower. If you take the time to just sit and watch, you can see freighters, fishing trawlers, cruise liners,ferries to and from the Asia side and maybe a navy vessel. Very peaceful atsmosphere.

Bosporus!!!!. I visited Istanbul with couple of friends and my mother, we had a huge list of MUST DOs and one of them was Bosporus. We were advised to book this tour buy our friend who lives in Istanbul. We took a boat and enjoyed sailing through the Bosporus for couple of hours, we had lunch on the European side of Istanbul. The trip was amazing, we all enjoyed it to the max.

Cruise not to be missed. Took the public ferry cruise that went north along the European side and down by the Asian bank, complete with audio guide and quintessential chai. A lovely scenic exploration of the numerous historic sites, pashas, villas along deep blue bays, with a 3 hr stop over for lunch at a quaint/touristy fishing village.

BEAUTIFUL VIEW OF ISTANBUL. Took a ferry on the Bosphorus, it was really nice, don't go to Istanbul without taking a ferry ride. We went to the Asia side by ferry which was really nice, different and quieter than the Europe side. It was great to see Istanbul from the water.

Take a Ferry. If you go to Istanbul a ferry ride is a must. my husband and I opted for a cheaper one and WOW!!!! It was aweome, we saw so many beautiful sites and buildings and a man was selling a nice potato peeler on our ferry. I cannot wait to take my kids on lots of ferry rides this summer, they will love it!

Aquasome!. Guess no Istanbul trip is complete without the Bosphorus cruise. We chose a guide operated tour that took us to other attractions as well. The cruise was splendid and was accompanied by a dance show and a small skit, which was cute to watch but offered nothing by way of a story or script. The cruise coverage was pretty standard taking us to the Asian side of Istanbul and then continuing by bus. The best part of the cruise is the ample opportunity for photographs and being able to view the numerous landmarks of the historic city. I imagine the cruise to be better enjoyed in the summer months.

On a retired sailor's wish list!. I always wanted to visit Istanbul and cross the Bosphorus to Asia.There is a regular Ferry service to Kadakoy on which you can use the Istanbul travel card. A great chance therefore to view all the shipping transiting the Bosphorus!

MY WORST NEW YEAR EVER. first, the bosphorous cruise is real good enjoyment..........but...!!!!beware of bad timing ..........and be informed what you get .......i went this cruise for new year eve....it was terrible as much as you can imagineso my advise dont take it in the rush time like new year, eid muslim festival and national day of turkey......the tourist company promised me a hotel pick up, then they call me to go to taksim square for a pick up where i waited for 3 hours in the chilling cold weather ......to be picked up by the wrong bus ( the bus talk my tourist company by mobile and they said yes it is our bus!!), accordingly we arrived to the wrong ferry port and the company advised me to take taxi from kabatas to yenikapi ferry port so i did but in the middle of way ( after 3 minutes )they called again and advised to go back kabatas port because my ship already moved, so i went back to kabatash, waiting in chilling weather again to be picked after 30 minutes by another boat not my boat.....and got the ( lst minute extra guest bad service ) and when that bad part on the boat finished , no bus accepted to take me home because my tourist company was not there..... so i walked my way back to hotel with my wife ( we are 50 years old ) from kabatash port to middle of istklal road, that road was of of crazy drunken people at 2.00 am i reached my hotel with maximum difficulty and by a miracle.so my idea in the rush time like festival time don't take this tour and don't believe the tourist company promise simply because they cannot meet that promise even if they try the best......all you can get is a treatment like a ( herd of sheep ) at best and you can be forgotten or engaged in troubles with drunken people at worst.HAPPY NEW YEAR 2013

Sailing in the moonlight :). Instead of boarding one of those touristpacked charter cruises we payed for a private tour on a yacht. We had just exited a restaurant and were approched by a fisherman whom we had seen on several occasions, at all occasions he had been polite and sweet. He said that for 100 lira we could chart a boat (with him as captain) On our tour of the Bosphorus we enjoyed a full moon and watched the city from it's best side. We where even fortunate enough to see dolphins.
Nice boat trip. We decided to do the traditional trip on the Bosphorus but only one way to the top and then back by buses with different stops along the way. Very good one day trip.

Bosphorus. Lovely place, plenty of walking, get to go on the cruise if you can, well worth it. You get to see both sides of istanbul the tourist stuff but also the real Istanbul. Very educational also

Beautiful. I love watching the sunset from the Asian side as it goes behind the city and water. There is nothing more beautiful in the city. I've been here a year and can not get enough of its beauty.

Another view of the city. We book the tickets at Turyol desk (after recommendation of our hotel guest relationship), for 12 TL each we took a Bosforo boat trip for an hour an a half , that was really appreciated!
Views, Food and Shops. Great History with plenty of restaurants and shops. Good locations to catch a sunset as well. Plenty of good food and cold beer.

Very Good experience. You can buy a trip from your hotel, The best is to go to the ferry docks the last station on the tram (2-3 stops from Sultanahmet tram station), you will get cheap offers. we crossed on the ferry to the Asian side of the Istanbul. Ferries are every 5-10 minutes. This way you can see the Asian side of Istanbul. Ferry crossing costs the same as one tram ride. tram is quite useful in the Sultanahmet District. Buy a Istanbul card. This is similar like Oyster card in London . You charge your card and use for travelling on the public transport and ferry crossings..

Fun change of pace. My daughter and I spent 5 days in Istanbul. We enjoyed touring the museums and the cistern the first 4 days but on the 5th day it was nice to spend some time seeing Istanbul from the river. We took the 3 hour tour which was a good option for us.

Bosphorus cruise. You simply must do this by day AND night! The day time cruise is breathtaking as you see what you can not by car or foot. Seeing the river/city by night is majical. Take the ferry over to the Asian side for dinner, you will love it.

Where two continents meet. We sailed on the Bosphorous on a clear winter afternoon. The sky was a blinding blue, with wisps of white clouds floating lazily about it, and the sea was blue one minute and green the next. The sights on both sides of the strait were fabulous: beautifully-preserved greyish-blue palaces stood next to bright white houses with terracotta roofs, a stodgy little fort looked out on the waters from its perch on a hillock and boats of all sizes and shapes and colours sailed by, carrying tired but happy-looking children and men and women. Crowds of men lined the shore on the European side, angling for fish, shouting and joking and having a very pleasant time, clearly. The bridges straddling the strait have an elegant simplicity that is striking and the foam falling away from our boat as we returned to the harbour was the purest shade of white you can hope to see. One must round off this trip with a climb up to the Cafe Pierre Lotti. The views of the golden triangle from up there are gorgeous. If it is already dark by the time you are ready to head back to your hotel, take the cable car down, by all means. Even though it is a brief ride, the exhilaration you experience as you descend from the dark hill-top into the city's million lights is priceless! When in Istanbul, do not dream of giving the Bosphorous cruise a miss!

Must do. If you are going to turkey, You must do the boat tour on golden horn and bosphorus strait. The view of the city from the strait that splits the european side and asian side. I had taken a package tour which also included a turkish dance as well. The commentary about the palace, mosque, spice market was informative. Its worth doing.

What a great deal. Husband and i jumped on the 2:30 tour and we are so glad we did. It was a great way to spend 1.5 hours on a sunny Dec afternoon. It was very reasonably priced, 10 TL a piece. Saw sights from the water that we mow want to go see up close in our remaining days here.

Awesome cruise. It's not possible that one goes to Istanbul, and doesn't travel across the iconic Bosphorus strait straddling on two continents. Must travel by the cruise, to see the beautiful Bosphorus bridge which is lit up at night, and the beautiful landmarks like Dolmabahce Palace.

Amazingggggg. Such breathtaking views of Europe n Asia sides.We couldnor stop taking pucs.Such beautiful views and landscapes.Truly one of the most beautiful places on Earth.Loved Istanbul n its people

A nice day trip. In retrospect I would probably have done a 2 hour tour instead of a full day tour, the only difference being that you would miss the old Roman fortress during the 3 hour lunch break. It is a bit of a climb but a great view from the top, however prices of meals are obviously marked up (think 20-30 liras per person). A nice way to see Istanbul and made me realize how huge the city actually is.

Economical way to the Europe and Asian Side of Turkey. Cruising i think is the best way to navigate Istanbul, Turkey.You can see the Europe and Asian Side of the place, the 2bridges, old museums, buildings, etc.

Bosphorus Strait. We took a cruise on the Bosphorus Strait and it was such a wonderful experience. The morning was sunny but cool . It was a clear morning and we enjoyed watching the activities of the people in Istanbul as we passed by. I loved watching the people fishing on the bridge and at the waterfront. It was a wonderful sight. The buildings along the strait were beautiful especially the Domalbache Palace and the hotels. The bridges across the Strait were impressive too.

MUST DO THE CRUISE. To enjoy Istanbul you need to go on teh cruise -again we got our tickets for only much as 10lira in a covered cruise - It was super chilly and windy upstairs so settled inside the closed comfy windows.They served turkish tea too. You can see some amazing structures in their full glory from the sea-its like seeing ancient monuments popping up and prominent springing up from the modern recently built buildings.Its gives you a visual treat and ample opportunities to click great pictures.

Bustling area. This is a very picturesque area with a lot happening. Plenty of traffic and people fishing off the Istanbul bridge. Many ferry boats travelling between both sides of the city. Larger ships also traveling through this area. A great place to sit and watch all that goes on.

Outstanding views. Sailed through the Bosphorus twice as we were on a cruise to the Black sea, both sides have great views and if you dont keep looking to both sides you are bound to miss something and being on a fairly large cruise ship when we got near to Istanbul we were literally surrounded by dozens of pleasure and sightseeing boats

Speechless. Must for everyone visiting Turkey, not just Istanbul. Breathtaking view -360 degrees. We took the boat trip from the European side, sailed along most beautiful buildings, went under the Bosphorus bridge and on return it was along the Asian side. It was on a sunny December day, a day we will always treasure as words can't express how beautiful the entire area is.
Excellent way to enjoy Istanbul (both Asia & Europe side). Enjoy the cruise. The view was great and amazing. You will Cross the bridge, see the Turkey from Asia and Europe side.

East meets the west... No place on earth can give u this feeling were u see Asia on one side and Europe on the other....a must do on every travellers to do list in Istanbul,was very cold so we sat the bottom deck as kids would find it difficult,but they wanted to go outside...so we did it.....no problem at all.aslong as jackets and gloves are in place....

Do the boat tour. We did the boat tour of the Bosphorus Strait with Gate 1 tours. To see the summer homes of the sultans was amazing. It was interesting to see how these homes have been updated and put to a more modern use.
Take a boat ride. It was interesting to see both sides of Istanbul from a boat on the Bosphorus--a good way to see East and West.

Sheer opulence. We took the ferry cruise to Anadolu Kavagi and back to view the Bosphorus and glimpse the Black Sea. I knew we would see seaside villas on the way, however i didn't expect to see the number and size of some some buildings. Advise you take a reasonable guidebook that describes the more famous sites. The Kanicla yougurt is good, also the seafood at the turn around point. Climb to the top of the castle for the views.

Wonder of the world. There is no other view at any time of the year anywhere in the world watching the Bosphorus Strait with the ships and boats sailing past and from any point. I love the experience of just catching a ferry crossing with just sightseeing in mind and don`t care which point the crossing is. Just fantastic.

Worth the cost of a ferry just to see the city from the water.. If you just want to see the city from the water a ferry ride from the European side to the Asian side is only a few Lira. I took a ferry ride one evening just for something different to do (besides walking!) do it in the day and at night too. If possible, try to take a ferry at sunset and you will not be dissapointed.

Not overly impressed. We went on an afternoon cruise on the Bosphorous - really very average. We noticed that several folks had fallen asleep and we nearly fell pray to the same curse !! However, if in the area, the Spice Market (Egyptian Market) was fun and definitely cheaper than the Grand Bazaar.

Nice cruise. Very interesting way to spend a few hours without having to walk up and down the hilly streets.
To see some of the old ruins and buildings was a good way to see the sights for about $6.
Lots of history here.

The color of the water is magnificent!. You have to take a ride on the ferry, take a tour, crss to Asia, but definitely get out on the water! It is so beautiful. There is so much to see. I think I left a part of me there!!!!!

Nice to get out on the water. We were told that we could take a ferry quite cheaply and go back and forth to villages along the Bosphorous Strait, but we decided to pay more for a guided tour and have someone tell us about what we were looking at, and I think that was the right decision. It was worth it because now we know who built what and who lived here and so on, and there is so much history along the Straits.And it was nice to get out on the water and away from the hubub of the city for an afternoon.
10TL for a 2hr cruise. It was the highlight of our trip. 10TL for a 2hr cruise is excellent. Service inside the ferry is cheap too. Go 30mins earlier so that you can get a good place.

Beautiful views. We took a 'dinner cruise' that was fantastic. We had authentic foods and treats and a narrated tour up and down the Bosphorus. The views were amazing and you could see so much of the old and new city of Istanbul. Extremely pleasant way to spend several hours in Istanbul.

what views.. any time of the day the views are breathtaking, like the pictures! we went over the bridges. Galata, Fatih Sultan...Bosphorous and Araturk bridge...to Asia side and watched the boats on the Golden Horn area.....gun ships and submarines....well Putin was visiting>!

Two continents for the price of one boat ride-. For 2 1/2 hours, cruise the Bosphorus on one of the ferries you can catch at the docks. We paid 30 Euros for a half day tour of the city, and this was included. Narration comes over the loudspeaker on the top deck, as you watch the palaces, forts, universities, and bridges of Istanbul. We were able to see both ends of the Bosphorus, where it meets the Black Sea, and where it meets the Dardenelles. Between the old city on the European side, and the newer city on Asia Minor, the Golden Horn separates these. Small boats and large tankers cruise back and forth, and bridges are gracefully suspended above, shuttling thousands of vehicles across all day long. On board the ferry, you can buy snacks and coffee or tea, and watch the world go by, or you can stand in the bow in blustery winds and try to take pictures while your head spins, trying to see it all.

Historic waterway. Took 2 different cruises along the Bosphorus with the longer one stopping at a small village near the Black Sea where one had an hour or so to explore and enjoy a seafood lunch at one of several restaurants on the tiny streets. Both relaxing experiences and awesome perspective of the city from the water and impressive to se the dozens of large freighters passing through the channels.
Between Asia and Europe.. Going on the boat, you look to your right and you are looking at Europe. Look to your left and you are looking at Asia! And you know what?. They are both in Istanbul!

like a bus ride. We used the Istanbul card on the ferry, so it was TL 1.95 (70p) to cross the Bosphorus Strait from Karakoy to Haydarpasa on the Asian side! There is a local market not far from the port and it was full of life, even at 5pm! We stood and ate some mussles on the street (10 for TL3) and had a Turkish coffee sitting outside amongst the locals. The Asia side is well worth a visit.

Go on an organised cruise, or make your own way. An organised cruise is fine, though you can see a lot yourself on the extremely cheap water ferries. A cruise might typically take 2 - 2 and a half hours. A wwater ferry to the Asian side would take about 20 minutes.

Great day trip!. If you enjoy boats, history and food, take the public ferry from Eminonu to Anadolu Kavagi. The coffee's great on board, the views of historic buildings on shore are great, and the food choices in the destination town of Anadolu Kavagi are many!

Beautiful and worth the trip.. Anyone can avoid paying too much to cruise the Bosphorus. (We paid 35.00 Euros each, about US $47.00) using a guided tour with a tour group). Just go directly to the pier where the ferry boats are and it only costs about US $5.60 without a tour guide.

Teeming with exotica. The most spectacular joining of continents. It takes your breath, and your imagination, away. Ask your concierge about dining at a fish restaurant which boats you across to the Asian side. The trip & the destination will be memorable.

A trip between East and West. take a two hour sightseeing trip up the Bosphorous Strait to see how an amazing city has developed and is still developing. Look at the history. the architecture, the wealth and the not so well off all set out along the strait.

The Bosphorus is the heart of Istanbul. 1 1/2 hour cruise was delightful. ferry ride to the Asian side just perfect. Listening to the boats on the Bosphorus and Marmara Sea is essential to Istanbul. Good fish.

Historic waterway; use commuter ferry. To keep costs low and still experience the Bosphorus, just continent-hop on the commuter ferries, which are only about 2TL. Easy to find the port you want to head to, which line to get in, which boat to get on. Efficient system.

Worth the full day tour!. Do the IDO tour for 12TL. Entrance is right before the Galata Bridge on the right side. Ignore all the guys trying to get you to buy from them. They hike the price up. I got the audio guide but in hindsight would not get again. I like to photograph and video and it was just too much to try and hear it. Volume couldn't be adjusted either and it was just difficult. If you are one to sit there, though, it might work for you. Beautifully stunning views. Went to the end port at Andolu Kavagi. Climbed steep incline to castle and had lunch up there. Amazing view. After the climb and lunch, we had about 30 mins to spare before the 3pm departure back. Lovely use of a day's time and my lira. :)

Fun trip. Loved our boat ride, crappy weather though. They served tea and it was fun. You'll find inexpensive boat tours, recommend those if you can find a good deal. Would have liked a night cruise but we had a baby with us.

Istanbul at it's finest!. We took a day long cruise. The boat was a bit crowded so finding a seat on the outside was problematic BUT the views of Istanbul was awesome. You don't realize how big Istanbul is until you see it from the Bospohorus. We went out to the Black Sea to the Yoris Castle and back. Definately a must do in Istanbul!

take the ferry!. Cruising around the Bosphorus is wonderful on a pretty day in Istanbul. I highly recommend taking the ferry route from Emononu to Kadikoy at night to see all the buildings lit up, rather than spending money on an actual cruise.
A Must See. A full day round trip boat cruise of the straits all the way to the mouth of the Black Sea and back is a must. Fascinating and historical.

Great way to relax. There are many boat tours on the Bosphorus from various locations on the European side of Istanbul. Want to get away from the other tourists, then just use a ferry service and go to Kadikoy for a tea, and enjoy the Turkish people as they go about daily life.
Bosphorus tour. The only day we had showers of rain - but this didn't dampen our enthusiasm for this great tour of the Bosphorus. A must-see!

Must do trip. Bad weather did not spoil our enjoyment of this trip. Originally sought shelter in downstairs saloon, but drunken noisy revellers drowned out guide's commentary so we braved the wind and rain to stand on top deck. Enjoyed the wide range of architecturally interesting buildings on both sides of the river.
Bridges between two continents. Check out the fish restaurants, and try to walk over one of the bridges. Sometimes there are little carts selling fresh-caught fish fried and put into pita bread!

Gorgeous River - stunning just as the sun begins to set. Stunning views of Asia and Europe, the landscape seems to change everytime you look and at dusk and dawn the lighting against the numerous temples and mosques is breath taking.
Catch the commuter ferry instead of the sightseeing tours and criss cross over the river for magical views and photo opportunities.

Turquoise Waters - Chilly Breeze. The geographic and historical significance of the Bosporus can’t be overstated. Be sure to make time for a ferry cruise. You can drink cay (tea) inside, away from the wind, or go out on the deck and see the amazing houses and buildings on both the Asian and European shores of the straight.

Watch the life on the water!. I love cities with a lot of life on the water. It is great watching boats.... Cruise ships of all sizes on the water going up and down and back and forward. In addition there is the attraction of passing dolphins. Beware of fishing rods though. Fishermen seem to fill about every space they can find. This is great all year round!

Great Way To See A Different View of Istanbul. Cruising the Bosphorus Strait is interesting. A lot of old palaces, etc. converted to hotels or museums. A nice way to see the outskirts of the city. Very relaxing. Took the 1 1/2 hour cruise as part of an all-day tour in Istanbul. Nice way to break up and sight-seeing trip.

Quick trip along the Bosphorus. We did the 1.5 hour tour and it was nice. I enjoyed seeing some of the amazing real estate along the banks of the Bosphorus. Its also good to get a sense of how far this huge city extends.

Nice view especially when somethings cannot be seen. Istanbul is not the cleanest city like most other cities.
The last ferry tour will give you a nice view and worth for 1 hour tour.

Absolutely Superb. The best way to see Europe and Asia at the same time. There are many tour boats which offer a 1 1/2hr trip along the Strait and they follow the curves of the shoreline to give passengers the best possible views.Both shores are full of surpirses with small bays, harbours, palaces, castles, holiday homes and old Turkish wooden houses.Rather expensive but it is a must do on a visit to Istanbul.
Fantastic. Great view with lots of great restaurants. One can also take cruises up and down the strait, great experience..

two hour tour=just fine. We were on a long weekend trip to Istanbul. We heard many people talk about a six hour tour on the Bosphorous, We took a two hour one, that was perfect. They leave on the hour. I forget the cost, but it was 5 or 10 TL apiece. Any longer would have been too much for our limited time in town. Recommended. great views of the city and Bosphorous.

Evening cruise. We had an evening cruise on the Bosphurus with dinner. Really nice to sit and dine and have all the wonders of this magnificent historical city before your eyes. Do not hesitate to take a few hours to go on one of these evening cruises with the buildings all lit up!
Ferry ride. Had a great time on the Turyol 1.5 hour round trip boat ride down the Bhosphorus. Lots of new/old sites to see. Gave a great view of much more of this huge city.

Worth the time and money!. We simply love the view of the Bosphorus, its surroundings, the bridge, the castle, the houses overlooking Bosphorus and did not feel that our journey actually takes 3 hours (the longer version) to Anadolu Kavagi. The ferry only cost us 25 Lira and for the shorter trip (2 hours) they will only charge 10 Lira. Since I took the morning cruise, this will be my lunch spot, there are many restaurants but I have picked Baba restaurant that has the lovely sea view and many seagulls! The mezze were plenty, I love the stuffed mussels! For main dish, I would recommend the grilled fish. We went uphill to the ruined castle (a good exercise!) and took many photos of the scenic view from top of the hill where there is also a restaurant for you to rest and relax. We went back to our ferry before 3pm to return to the city. On the return journey, we sat on the left side to see the other part of Bosphorus and lovely scenery. Recommended to all visitors to just unwind, relax and appreciate God's gift and creation. Lots of postcard photos can be taken from the ferry journey!

Good but time consuming. I took the tour of the Bosphorus Staits and thoroughly enjoyed myself. Who doesn't like a slow ride up to the Black Sea and a warm sunny day? The Rumeli Fortress, Yalis, a chance to see the rest of Istanbul, and a delicious fish sandwich for lunch.

2 hour cruise with audioguide. liked - good boats at fair price, 2 hours round trip so not too long, clean and well organised. audioguide at 15lira was worth it, includes earphones and gps function. disliked - not setting off on time

Expensive. We had an afternoon and wanted to see take a boat ride on the Bosphorus. If you want to just ride up and back it is not expensive. If you want a tour, explaining what you are seeing, we were told it would cost 40 Euro person for 3 hours (including lunch) to get the ride and the tour. For $60 per person, we were not ready to do that

take a boat tour. you get the best impression by boat. 2 hours in total to the second bridge.take the boat near the galatabridge, 10 TL p/p. nearby the 2e bridge you will see beautiful houses.there is a lot of boat trafic.

Best way to see Istanbul. We took a trip down the river, there was so much to take in, this is the best most relaxed way to drink in this wonderful city. If I go back again I would like to take a night trip, I bet that would be even more magical.

Full Day: Bosphorus Strait, Golden Horn and Bus Tour - took the hotel's recommendation and what a great day!. My wife and I had a day to fill in while in Istanbul and based on the recommendation of the staff at our hotel, we had them booked a day long tour of the Bosphorus Strait and Golden Horn, followed by a land based afternoon bus tour of selected sights in Istanbul. The highlight was the boat trip which gave absolutely magnificent views of the various mosques, palaces and other atractions that can only really be appreciated by being seen from this historic waterway. It really shouldn't make a difference which firm you book with - any one of the main stream providers will cover the same spectacular sights. The afternoon was a bus tour which again took in some of the main atractions, this time from strategic viewing points such as hills overlooking Istanbul. This offered a diffrent perspective on what you had seen from the water and well worth it. The only down-side is the mandatory afternoon stop-off for a fashion display at a local leather goods outlets where the very obvious intent is that you will buy something. There was no real pressure, so that was a surprise, and the day concluded with a very strong feeling that we had made an excellent choice in how to spend our day. Highly recommended.

Cruise the Bosphorus. This is a "Must do" while you're in Istanbul. I've done it in the daylight and at night and loved every minute of both experiences. There are many boat tours weather you have a private party, need to cross the straight, or want to have dinner on a boat in the moonlight! Best time in Istanbul!

Try and Catch a Sunset. Top tip: - examine the ferry timetable and ferry hop around the Bosphorous. We took 4 separate ferries back and forth across the waterway. At roughly a pound a time you cannot get better value for money. If you time your trip with a sunset you won't be disappointed.
Europe Meets Asia. Must be seen - two continents and two seas - three if you take the full tour. Great waterway and very busy water traffic - use the local ferries - great for a cheap tour!

Don't miss it!. This cruise on the ferry is mingled with locals and tourists and shouldn't be missed. It is about 6 hours in length, but almost 3 of that is spent at the last stop before the Black Sea in Anadolu Kavagi. This charming village was perhaps my favorite memory of the trip. The hike up to the ruins was strenous but so very worth the view. Back on the ferry, they bring coffee and tea around continuously which is so nice, and there was plenty of seating inside or out. I wouldn't try going on the weekend if it can be avoided as that is supposed to be really crowded.
Amazing. It s really a very good journey aboard the bosphorous... It shouldnt be missed if you are going to visit turkey ;)

Superb. It is what I mos liked about Istanbul. First of all, this is one of the most important characteristics of the zone, it unites two seas, from there it comes the strategic importance. And second, it is simply beautiful. There are mansions and palaces spoted all along.

Wonderful history along a beautiful waterway.. Have stayed on the Bosphorus many times at a friends place in Emirgan with an amazing view of the waterway. The Ottoman palaces lining the shore on the Asian side, the Turkish warships sailing through the stait, little old men swimming in the waterway makes for a memorable experience.

A must see.. another amazing place . We did a 2 hour Bosphorus cruise. We saw incredible homes, private boats etc. The commentary was a must to be able to see everything. Even though it was a dull day we loved this cruise.

Excellent views of Europe and Asia. It's quite amazing sailing between two continents. I would say this trip is a must-see in Instanbul. You'll be able to view very beautiful landmarks like Dolmabahce Palace, other historic buildings like mosques, sophisticated hotels, fancy mansions and pretty houses, expensive yachts and important fortresses like Rumelihisari Fortress and Anadoluhisarı Fortress, the Beylerbeyi Palace and of course the incredibly turquoise blue waters of the Bosphorus.

Be selective of tour operator. Hotel suggested half-day afternoon boat tour of Bosphorus via Senkron Travel Agency (brochures in hotel lobbies). Toof the Saturday tour # ST-08 as it was at a discounted rate of 25 euros, including pick-up at hotel (they dropped off after the tour nearby). 2 -15 minute stopovers were part of the tour - not much time to do anything but buy a yogurt at Kanlica or take photos. onboard entertainment was staff performing local dances. there was also a tour guide speaking English and Spanish.After leaving the hotel on the bus, a stop was made to collect money and pick up the tour guide which seemed to waste some time. we were the last ones to get on the boat. on the return, we got back to the pier earlier than scheduled, by at least a half hour. so the advertised trip of 1300-1730hrs included the back and forth on the bus so we felt a litle gypped. maybe better to get to the pier on your own? PS bring your own snacks/drinks on board as what they provided was expensive and limited

Took a beautiful cruise, followed by lunch on shore. I was travelling with a tour group and this was an included activity. We had a lovely cruise and historical dialogue for almost 2 hours. Followed by a family style lunch at a waterfront restaurant. Istanbul is a great city to explore. Plenty to do and see.

No need to book a cruise, just take the Ferry. We did just take the ferry from Sultanahmet to the Azian side. No need to book a cruise, the ferry shows you the Bosphorus for only 3 Lira per person, one way. You have several ferry options, without the oversized tour guides.

Quick trip across the Bosphorus. We just took a ferry back and forth to say we crossed. Would like to take a more extensive tour of this area. Very crowded and busy with boats but still exciting nonetheless

A trip on the commuter ferry. I decided to just take the regular commuter ferry, as opposed to a cruise tour of the Bosphorus. Proved to be cheaper and more flexible ( I could get off and begin my return trip at whatever stop I wanted) Recommend going to at least the second bridge. Perhaps not a "can't miss", but pretty close.

Sailing between Asia and Europe. The passage can be purchased next to the Galata Bridge, and it's worth around 10 Turkish lira. They take you on a short cruise (around 1 hour) up the Bosphorus Strait and back. Do not buy it elsewhere, for they can charge you up to 8 times this price, for the same service!

Take the cruise!. Don't take the private cruises offered buy the hotel as it will cost you eur 70 for the full day cruise. Walk to the Eminonu pier by the bridge and catch the Bhosporus ferry for TL 25 round trip. It leaves at 10.35 am and returns at 4.25 pm with a 3 hour stop at the small fishing villagE of Anadolu Kavagi.

very busy. My partner and I got the equivalent of an Oyster card that works on ferries, trams and buses, and I am so glad that we did. You can go everywhere and anywhere on the ferries, we went out to the Princes Islands, we went over to the Asian side on one ferry and back on the roll-on roll off - all day every day the ferries zip to and fro and the commercial shipping makes its way up (or down - seems to be a one-way system) the Bosphorus.Take the cruise that lets you off at the last village for three hours. The genoese castle is worth seeing.
Cruise. This is a cruise you have to make. Do not go on this cruise without the audio guide. It is well done and very instructing.

Boat trip essential. I did the 2 hour cruise, which is enough, but the views are spectacular, of course. As a New Forest resident, close to Southampton, it was amusing to be sailing past the Oriana and Queen Elizabeth cruise ships lined up next to each other as soon as we left the pier. Shop around for the best deal. Ten lire (around £3.50) will get you a ride on a decent boat. Drinks and other refreshments are very expensive and unappetising, so get fed and watered before you go or when you come back. Pick a sunny day!
great. Just looking at this busy waterway is an essentail part of the visit. The ferries, fishing boats and liners bring it all to life.

Catch a ferry to the east!. Buy an Akbil, charge it up, and you can use on the buses and ferries. More than one person can use one card. We got the ferry to Uskadar, and had a good walk round and had lunch. We reckon it was as good an experience as being trapped on a tourist boat for a long time - expecially if you have children in the group with a short attention span. The sights of the shores are fascinating.

Add this to your list of attractions. We sat on the top seating area of a tour boat, and enjoyed our trip on the Bosphorus. The view of palaces, mosques, and large homes was very impressive. We watched a thunderstorm come towards us, and even with the eventual rain, the boat ride was a great experience, and helped to situate Istanbul for us geographically.
Amazing. Cruising the Bosphorus was an amazing experience, because there is the view from Europe in one side and Asia Minor in the other, something that is very special and unique.
Cruise of the strait. My cruise of the strait was wonderful as we sailed along by the big Ottoman palaces all the way to the entrance of the Black Sea.

FROM THE BLACK SEA TO THE MARMARA SEA. The Bosphorus Strait connects the Black Sea to the Marmara Sea. It is a very busy waterway; vessels of all kinds ply this route - from sea-going tankers, cruise ships,barges, ferries, sea buses to fishing boats of all sizes. A wonderful way to explore the strait is by a tour boat or a ferry boat. Turyol operates brief narrated tours out of the wharf at Eminonu. If you're on the Eminonu side, facing the Galata bridge, the ticket station for the Bosphorus boat tour- Turyol is on your left. Another way is to take a longer boat ride on the ferry terminating at Anadolu Kavagli. You will need almost an entire day for the roundtrip which costs 25 Turkish lira, roughly $15.00 per person. It is best to get on the boat in the morning for a leisurely pace and allow ample time to get out and eat lunch at one of the fish restaurants in the village. The boat leaves for Anadolu at 8:30, 9:00, 10:00 a.m. and 1:00 p.m. - but be sure to double check the schedule for any changes. This is a very relaxing trip providing a vista of some famous landmarks such as the Blue Mosque, Aya Sofya and the Hayderpasha Train Station (for eastbound international trains). There are lots of wonderful photo opportunities - as the boat leaves the Eminonu, seagulls by the thousands frolick overhead as if sending off the ferry with a joyous farewell. Seagulls follow the ferry as it makes its way along the strait, feeding on fish that have surfaced from the roar of the boat's engine below.. Here you get a panoramic view of Istanbul's historical old district from the Eminonu side, the Galata tower and the old buildings around it stacked like cubes upon a hill on Karakoy, and the two-level Galata bridge with hundreds of fishing lines spilling over. Along the coast you will see quaint villages, the shores dotted with restored old Ottoman wooden houses, once homes to the privileged & many of which have now been converted into guest houses and restaurants, some remain as private residences. The Bosphorus Bridge, resembling the Golden Gate Bridge, flashes its splendor at night. It is best seen from the seaside in Ortakoy.
