The bridge is equipped with a lighting system which flashes varying hues from yellow, green, blue, etc. throughout the night. It's a magnificent for nighttime photography. In Ortakoy, you can stroll around in the pedestrian zone, sit with a glass of tea or Turkish coffee in one of the seaside restaurants, or simply order one from the vendors around. Vendors selling all kinds of crafts, especially a wide variety of handcrafted items and costume jewelry abound.

Fully full! BEAUTIFUL!!! I LOVE YOU BOSPHORUS!!!!. i love everything about bosphorus and of course the bosphorus strait tour or whatever.. i'm very glad to know the city like ISTANBUL and to know BOSPHORUS!

Enjoy the Bosphorus tour on your own way!. You will enjoy the sun, the sea and the fresh air in this tour. You will pass by the most important places in Istanbul. It can give you a quick and nice tour. You can make this trip all around the Bosporus by 12.5 TL/person (7 USD). Just take the metro to "Kapatash" metro station and get out and pass the road and get your ticket for round-trip tour. But actually we didn't know this tip earlier. We have booked this tour with a tour agency. It takes you from the hotel and waste your time in the traffic and a tour guide describes you the famous attractions in Istanbul. It was so expensive. It costs us 35 euros/person to do this tour... So I advise you to make it on your own. You will enjoy so much and no need for a tour agency. Go with your travel map, guide book for the main attractive in Istanbul, travel bag and camera. For sure, you will enjoy. Have a nice trip!

Dividing the continents. The Bosphorus strait gives Istanbul a romantic feeling. I loved the part when I take the ferry across I am in a whole new continent. I bragged about it saying that I had Breakfast in Europe and lunch in Asia all in the same day!

what a place!. Never have we seen a water way as busy as Bosphorus. It worth the visit just to see that. Try and take a tour with commentaries (some tours don't give you any info). Also take walk over Galata Bridge and visit Fishmarket. And while you're there, try freshly cooked Hamsi (sardine/anchovy like fish) in one of the Fishmarket caffees - food at its simplest and the best.

Unwind on Day One. A great way to relax and get one's bearings in a very busy, divided city. Jump on any one of the Bosphorus tour boats that cruise the river for a few hours or a entire afternoon. We took a two-hour ride on a busy Sunday and it was the perfect antidote for a big of jet lag.

Where are the life preservers. We took a boat ride on the Bosphorus. The boat had trouble and we had to be towed ashore. The rocking and rolling of the ship was quite frightening. On top of that, we realized that we were never given instructions as to where the life preservers were. Lesson to self. Always know where they are before you get into a boat.

great views of the city. It is a must. don't go with the tour operators. If you are in Taksim, take fernacular to that place and do it on your own. Local transport is cheap and well connected. You will waste lot of time in the bus otherwise.
Great Views of Istanbul. We sailed through the Bosphorus and got fantastic views of the Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace and Hagia Sophia.
Fantastic!. We loved crossing from Europe to Asia back to Europe over and over again in 4 days :) Amazing geography!
Take a boat ride. We did a 2 hour boat ride and it was delightful! Great way to see a lot of Istanbul when you are on a time crunch!

A relaxing way to spend a day.. Take the long cruise of some 6 hours from the dock next to the Galata Bridge. It's a large boat and serves snacks, but you see the sites along the European and Asian sides (mostly European). There's 3 hour stop for lunch on the Asian side where you can not only have a decent meal at a restaurant, but also climb a rather short but steep hill to an old Byzantine castle for a wonderful view of the Bosporus back toward Istanbul and a view to the Black Sea to the east. Even though the strait is rather narrow, it can be windy and choppy. It was a very relaxing, interesting, and beautiful way to spend a Sunday.

We wanted a boattrip but not so long. We took the tram from Eminonu to Kabatas. Then a taxi from Kabatas to Ortakoy 20 liras. After some wine and lunch at the Cheese Cake restaurant in Ortakoy we jumped on a boat that took us thru the Bosphorus Strait and back to the harbour close to Eminonu Tramstation. Then we got to see more and didn`t have to spend hours on a boat.
Just get on one of those wonderful ferries. Great maritime environment - fantastic photo opps of Strait and Topkapi palace, Aya Sofia and bridges.
Strait. Good view from the palace. Wonder how the Turks managed to bypass the strait to take Constantinople.

Amazing boat ride. We took a tour along the Bosphorous Strait, it was really relaxing. The boat took us to the asian side and it made a stop. Even tough it was great, maybe the ordinary transport boat is a good alternative, since it gives you a lot more flexibility with time spent on boat, walking, etc.

Plan properly to enjoy. After sifting through the comments here, thanks to them we were able to enjoy our trip for our 6-hour Bosphorous Cruise. In a nutshell, here is my rundown:1. Wake-up early. Take the tram (3TL) and be there at Eminonu station around 9AM. Walk in the underpass going to the cruise area. You'll see shops that actually sells cheaper than the rest of the tourist areas around Istanbul.2. If you arrive early, buy the 2-way tickets (25 TL) and the Audioguide (5TL) before the line starts around 10AM. 3. Feel free to check and roam around. Visit the near by New Mosque across the street. Buy Water. Check the shops.4. Take the tram around 10:30AM. Earlier if you want a good spot at the open air desk on the top floor. Bring a book and a camera.5. Expect to be hungry since you'll arrive at the 6th stop past 12nn. Bring snack. 6. Once you are at Kavagi stop, check the schedule when the ferry will leave. 7. People will haggle for you to eat at their restaurants. Choose carefully and take your time. You can buy a fish sandwich nearby, and continue walking going to the top of the hill. There are overlooking restaurants on your way up, better places to eat.Suggestions for seafood dishes since Anadolu KavagI is technically a fishermen's village:- Grilled Fish - Lufer (blue fish) and Palamut (bonito), but get them where you think they are likely to know how to do them, and eat them grilled. The blue fish from the bosphorus is fresh and nice. Do not eat any other fish unless you can find john dory/st. pierre. They will bring a basket of fresh fish, you can ask them the prices directly to avoid surprises.- Hamsi - Black Sea anchovy, small fish crispy fried.This itinerary is ideal if you want to rest in between spending a day standing and walking around Sultanahmet area.Hope it helps you on planning your trip.

Row row row your boat. Loved the Bosphorus. Hired a boat for about 800 dollars for a whole evenings from 6 to 12. We had two local friends who ordered food from a restaurant and we docked and pgot in the food.

Good Way to Cool Off. We took a ferry up the Strait. It was a great escape from the city and it was cool on a hot day. The ferries ARE crowded however so be prepared to stand. We went up the Start all the way and stopped at a fishing village for lunch and a hike to the top of the hill where there is a fortress. Well worth seeing the city from the water-gives you a really different perspective

bosphorus worth it. it has great place to be in istanbul full of hotels cirgan , four seasons etc. the view is beautiful and a lot of coffee shops . yu dont feel like leaving the palace. only negative no tram so traffic jams.

Inexpensive, crowded boat trip on an interesting waterway. For the tourist there are many mansions and palaces. For the history lover, there is the experience and feeling of this crucially important waterway. For the casual observer, perhaps only Asian ports like Hong Kong surpass its volume of traffic. It is two hours well spent. We did not take the 6 hour trip as we doubted it is worth the extra time. Perhaps it is if you visit for more than a week.

A day trip. Try to go straight to the ido near galate bridge to buy the tickets before 10am. It's cheap and you may choose the good seats. 25TL for adult. 5 TL to rent the audio guide. The trip is about one full day for a full circle. Pretty relaxing trip. Do remember to take sunglasses as the daylight is pretty strong.

Not a night cruise. We took the night cruise with dinner and the dance. It was a full five hour commitment. We could only enjoy the dance and a few sights lighted up. I feel a night trip is not a desirable one, unless you have a lot of time to kill.

Just the thing on a sunny afternoon. We took one of the 2 hour boat trips up the Bosphorus on a sunny afternoon. The cost was 10TL each - great value. I don't know if it was waiting to get full - we arrived at 2.00pm and thought it was just about to leave and we were moored for another hour. However, if you like people watching, it was terrific!!! We were on one of the smaller boats and there were no stops. it was facinating seeing the city from the water. the houses and palaces sparkled in the sunshine. there were loads of other boats plying up and down and there was something to see in every direction. upon our return we had to moore further down the river than our starting point and the surrounding streets and markets were facinating and full of noise, people & colour.

So many sights to see. There is such a wealth of architectural styles...palaces, grand houses, old and new, ancient and modern. What a lovely way to spend a couple of hours. I still couldn't work out which was Asia and which was Europe though!

Take a boat ride. We took a 90 minute cruise of the Bosphorus Strait for about 9 USD each. We sat on top, in the open air, until clouds rolled in and it got a little chilly. It's a beautiful, interesting site and a way to relax before hitting the pavement again.
loved it. the bosphrus cruise is a great idea if you are travelling to Istanbul... its serene 1:30hr trip.. u also get to see the important structures around the Bosphorus..

Good landscapes and building structures while cruising. We passed beautiful landscapes and famous building structures (including the university where Gaddafi studied at!), nice breezy cruise - definitely must go during autumn/winter months to enjoy the fine weather.Have some apple tea while enjoying the scenery!

Not to be missed. We overlooked the Bosphorus Strait it was very busy all day every day, loads of boats coming and going. The coast line has loads of bars, cafes, restaurants which are really busy during weekends.

a must-do ...... A cruise up-&-down the Bosphorus is a must-do to ogle at the houses & buildings on both sides. Reminds me a bit of Sydney (where you have homes along the water) & also the Staten Island ferry ride (you'll know why when you do this)

Lovely cruise. Make sure not to miss taking a cruise up and down the bosphorus straight...Tip: take the full cruise by Sehir Hatlari for TRY 25/person from Eminonu docks to enjoy lunch at a fish restaurant in Anadolu Kavagi (northern most stop) before heading back down the straight to Eminonu.

Nice boat tour. Had a lovely two hour trip up the Straits, a great way to see some of the sites from a different angle. And for us also inspired us to go back again one day and see some other areas!Make sure to shop around a little, prices vary.

The heart of Istanbul. A beautiful body of water. Ferries only cross from Europe side to Asia side and vice versa. One a sunny bright evening we took the cruise up to the 2nd bridge and back along the Asian side. It was great.

Great view of the city. One of the best ways to see the city sights (from afar).... ignore the touts for the longer trips and go with the cruise boat closest to the bridge.... 10TL for 90 minutes... well worth it.

good view of the city. lots of ferries and tour boat options. We took a 2 hour tour for 10TL (optional audio guide for 5TL extra but you had to leave a refundable deposit or credit card). a good idea to see another aspect of this huge city

A beautiful ride. Another of istanbul's must-do activities is to take a cruise up the Bosphorous. They last approximately 1 1/2 hours and give you a wonderful glimpse of just how attractive this city is. Try and time it to coincide your return with sunset over the Istanbul skyline. Magical.

It completes your tour of the old city!. It is better to go on a medium size boat, so there is not that much people and you get to have a very good view of all the sights. The boat we took had a guide telling us about everything we were seeing. It was very good. They even performed two dancing shows for us.

The Boat Cruise. Its a must do for anyone visiting Istanbul. The views and contrast between Asian and European side is pretty noticeable and offers you comparison between our modern society and historic architecture. It offers you everything you expect from a boat tour. Views are amazing as well.

Day trip is ok, but 2 hour tour would have been good too. We did the full day trip and thoroughly enjoyed it, but probably should have got off two stops before the end. Lunch was a bit overpriced but the view beautiful. If you're short of time or don't fancy a whole day on the water, go or two hours to miss the Bosphorous is a crime.

Beautiful Trip. Got the ferry tour from Eminonu. It was the short one (2hrs, long one is 6hrs) with the IDO for 10TL with an audio guide for 5TL. It was amazing, so many beautiful sites. You could control the audio guide, so there was loads of information on everything. Avoid the private tours for €20. This could not possible have been better.

get on those ferries. This is the best way to see Istanbul - the service is excellent and easy to understand - really cheap and enjoyable way to travel around Istanbul avoiding the traffic.The 2 hour Bosphorous tour is very interesting and gives a whole different perspective on the city. To see these views in real life was such a privilege and joy and will live on in the memory
Beautiful!. A boat cruise is a must to experience the beauty of the strait and its surrounds. Relax and take in the wonders of this amazing city.

If you have done cruises earlier, nothing new. For first timers its not bad otherwise if you have done similar cruises earlier you can skip it easily and spend this time on something else in this vast city

Palaces and yogurt. A must is a cruise on the Bosphorus. Gives a great view of the buildings on the shore and you can stop on the Asian side ( I recommend a tour there) for delicious yogurt served with powdered sugar.

Take a ferry ride for sure. Combine this with an excursion atop the Galata Tower to really get a feel for the layout of Istanbul. We took the shorter ( 2 hour) tour, and it wasn't narrated, but we had studied the map prior to boarding and had walked around the Old City side, thus had a good idea already.

Treat yourself to a boat trip down this strait. For a few dollars, a trip along the Bosphorus is a must and a great experience.
Don't think about it. Just take any of the number of boats that offer cruises up and back. So much to see and take in.

Spectacular views, much history. We saw the straits of the Bosphorus both all the way to the Black Sea and back. There is so much to take in that it is worth and extended tour. It was both interesting and spectacular.

Seaway Freeway. Since the beginning of history, this waterway has been influential in shipping anfd remains so, today. The number of ships using the Bosphorus is quite overwhelming. Can only hope that there is no major disaster and subsequent environmental disaster to the waterway, given its importance in today's economic environment.

Take a Tour. Take a boat tour of the Bosphorus. It will give a completely different prespective of Istanbul. There are magnificent house to see, people fishing, swimming, playing. Boat clubs, restaurants.

we saw dolphins. took a touryol cruise. it was about 1 hour 45 minutes. it would of
been better if more info was given more information

Great views from the river. It is a beatiful river dividing europe and asia. You can take a local big boat next to the bridge with all the fisherman standing above the row of restaurants, for 12TL . The trip takes nearly 2 hrs, they sell cheap refreshments on board. The sights on both sides are amazing even if you don't have a guide book.

Commentated cruise. Reccomended by our hotel.
Part of a day tour of the City.
Very impressive visually from a historic and architectural point of view.

Underwhelming. We would not put this high on “must see” list. Taking the local ferry to the Dolmabahce Palace and catching the tram back to Gulhane Park would be my advice. This would give a good idea of the waterway. Then go back to the park and have tea on the terrace which affords a magnificent view over the Bosphorus.

A litteral bridge between Europe and Asia. Istanbuls's unique geographic location allows the traveler to go from Europe to Asia just by crossing one of the bridges over the Bosphorus Strait. The best way to truly experience the beauty of this natural waterway is on a cruise ship going between the Aegean and Black seas.

Go for a boat ride and a swim. Try to find a smaller boat that will take you up the strait and allow you to swim in the Black Sea or very near to the entrance to the Black Sea. Have gone up this four times and on the last trip we found a boat captain that would stop and allow the group to swim. And that was well worth it. The water is warm, filled with jellyfish and the view of the huge ships passing through the strait from the water is awe inspiring. Jump in and take the plunge.

DIY. Don't get sucked in by the tourist trap boat trips. Down at the harbour near the fish sandwich boats you can book a 90mins trip up the Bosphorus for 12TL. take your own guide book to ensure you understand what youa re seeing and enjoy the ride. You can even take your own "picnic" but the OJ at 2TL or toasted sandwich at 1.5TL are hard to beat.

excellent. well, what is there not to like about this.. the strait and bridge connecting asia and europe? the only one in the world! if you go to istanbul, this place is not to be missed! and the view is amazing as well!
Relaxing. I travelled on the Bosphorus Strait on the Den Den luxury yacht. The evening was perfect and great views of the city. The lights on the Bosphorus Bridge are amazing.

A two hours cruise for less than 5 â¬.... After a long walk in the historic centre and the Galata bridge, where we had se fish kebab, we decided to relax with a cruise and took the first available... Just 10 liras for about 2 hours, with lovely views of both the european and the asian side.

One of the busiest and best waterways of the world.. Loved the ferries. for just 3 TNL you can catch a ferry to almost anywhere on the Bosphorous. They run every fifteen minutes, all day and most of the night as well. They all have tea, coffee and soft drinks on sale so even the shortest journeys, you can refresh!

A nice way to start your Istanbul trip. We took a nice 90 minute cruise of the Bosphorus; lots to see, with a stop at the Spice Bazaar. You get to see the new palace, mosques and the Bosphorus bridge.
.....we got throught with the hop on hop off bus. Amazing view, we got from the european part of Istanbul to the Asian part. it's a long drive but worthy

Relaxing but not that interesting. We did the couple of hours tour for 12 TL with the Turyol tours to the west of Galata bridge. The price is good and the boat was fine apart from one stinky toilet. Beware the drinks that come around - yes you have to pay although they don't say that initially. There seem to be some commentary but I couldn't tell what language as you couldn't hear it on either floor. That being said it was nice touring up and down the Bospherous just chilling out looking at all the ancient and modern buildings. So if you like cruising and looking go, but if you like things a bit more action packed give it a miss.

Bosphorus Boat Trip Gives Great Views of Istanbul. We took a boat trip for 2 hours from Galata Bridge up to the second Bosphorus bridge. Well worth the £4 each, time well spent and quite relaxing. Plenty of views of memeorable locations along each side of the Bosphorus, give you a different slant on the city.

A walk along the Bosphorus. There is nothing quite like a leasurely stroll down the Bosphorus to watch and enjoy daily life. Everyone seems so calm and content with life. Don't forget to take the 2 hour ferry boat along the strait. Just sit back, relax and enjoy the scenery, old, new and in between.
Boat on th Bosphorus. This is one of the best things yyou can do in Istanbul...you will see everything around, the modern and the historic!!!

A journey up the Golden Horn. Find a smaller private ferry which goes a bit slower, but the crowd is smaller and the views easier to photograph.Amazing old homes and buildings along the way. I had no idea Istanbul spread out so much and into so many communities.
Beautiful. Take a ferry.. This is a gorgeous piece of water all along Istanbul. Take a ferry across or along to appreciate it. Walk in one of the large parks that line it.

Lovely boat trip. The Bosphorus is a charming stretch of water and you may well devote a whole day to it (if you have the time). That takes you to a place called Anadolu Kavagiou in 1,5 hours. Here you stop for three hours and walk up to the castle. Why? Well it's not too tough and from there you can see the Black Sea. Several restaurants for simple food such as köfte on the way down. There are needless to say lots of interesting buildings, bays etc to see along the way. Tea/coffe served onboard.

Great Cruise on a Great Day. The sky was blue, the sun was shining and we were down at the Eminoenue piers where there are plenty of boats doing the Bosphorus tours. We picked a nice medium size ship, paid the 10 Lira ticket charge and off we went. Wonderful to see all the beautiful historic areas from the water. The sea was calm, it was a delight. For three hours we were pampered with historic views.On the boat it was calm, but one could feel the activity on land. The tour went all the way back to the second bridge before it turned around back to the terminal. It lasted three hours and it was sensational.

Beautiful day at the Bosphorus. We did the big Bosphorus cruise, all the way to the Black sea. There is a three hours waiting time at the Black sea, which is great, you can climb to the castle, have a lunch and enjoy the beautiful scenery. Beware of the agencies, they charge 50 - 70 euros per person for the trip worth 25 turkish lira (ok, and another 15 lira for lunch - still more than twice the price).

Wonderful tour. This was a great outing which showed you how Istanbul joins the two great continents. We saw the Maiden's Tower on our trip and decided to dine there. It was the highlight of our stay.
Cruising the straits. Boats leave from the New Town port area. They go up to the second bridge accross the strait. The area is beautiful with several locations I would have liked to stop at.

Entertaining at night. We chose to take the 1.5 hour cruise at night and were surprised at how lit up the bridges and huge building were. The color from all of the lights almost lit up the sky. Because it was at night and we sat on the top, it was chilly (September) so wearing a wind breaker is advisable.

BEST VIEW EVER!. Only metropolitan that connects two continents in the world. You should go all the way to the Black Sea entrance of the European side of Istanbul and then come back from across the other side, which is Asian part of Istanbul. Follow the coastline, visit the amazing world class restaurants and see the modern side of this beautiful city. History, climate, food, beverages, nightlife, views, boat trips, culture and so on..everything is great about this city.

History and poetry books to life. Took a small passenger vessel from Kadikoy up the Bosphorus from the Golden Horn and back. One side up was Europe and back Asia. The Rumeli Fortress will grab all ages and the palaces, now hotels will please your visual senses. The dark red buildings are originals and the windows change shape by century.

A must do. Several boats available. Our boat cost 15 lira each for two hours with an informative leaflet. We were offered tea, water or beer and had a good viewing seat on the top deck. Very enjoyable with plenty of photo opportunities.

A super time on the water!. If you have limited time, go to Sultanahmet and then take a boat trip on the Bosphorus - you see buildings that you can't see from the other side and get a completely different perspective! It's wonderful!!! We were lucky, it was a balmy evening and was impressive.

One of worlds great seaways. This is one of the world's great ancient crossroads between Europe and the orient. Tourists love this waterway because it is so busy, with a sense of vibrant activity. Ships pass through daily from all over the world. There are fish restaurants on boats moored to the bridges. Ferries can be taken to islands and across to the Asian side. You are overwhelmed by things to see and do. Visit the Princes Islands. Eat out. Walk over the bridge and take in the sights before walking up to eat out or shop in Taksim Square. I stayed in Istanbul with my teenage son as part of our 10,000-mile cycle expedition from Ireland to Japan (book: Long Road, Hard Lessons). The Bosphorous Strait was a highlight of our stay. So much of our daily activity centred around it. The views at sunset can be outstanding. Bring a camera!

Easily forgot: the Bosporus angle. A visit to Istanbul has to include a boat trip on the Bosporus Strait. This is the most spectacular way to experience the location of the old capital of Byzants and the gate between Europe and Asia.

How to get around the Bosphorus.. To use the various ferries it is important to distinguish between the big boys - IDO and Sehir Hatlari - and the various (expensive) tourist oriented offerings.The descriptions of the ferries are sometimes confusing - IMHO a fast ferry is a catamaran,like takes you from Kabatas to Bostanci in 35 minutes! (IDO), but this description is used for far slower boats / car ferries.The websites of the first two mentioned are a mine of information - also if you are are interested in travelling under your own steam to the Princes Islands - Mavi Marmara (based in Bostanci) might be useful.Doing it like the Istanbulis is a lot cheaper than using the tourist boats from Kabatas.Points to note are that there are summer and winter timetables and that the fast ferries are used to bring commuters into the centre in the morning and away in the late afternoon.Akbils and Istanbul cards work on most of the ferries. (Akbils were still going strong in October 2012). Of course Akbils and Istanbul cards can also be used on the Metro / Modern trams / buses and work out far cheaper than jetons. (See the IETT website). Mavi Marmara has a website only in Turkish - Google translator works well on it.For the Princes islands there are Sehir Hatlari and IDO services (but sometimes at"odd" times for tourists) and the possibility of travelling indirectly via Bostanci.Bostanci is served by IDO and by TCDD (suburban railway from Hyderpasa) and by the M4 Metro from Kadikoy.The TCDD station is close to the ferry terminal - not sure about the Metro.The afternoon slow ferry back to Istanbul (Kabatas) by Sehir Hatlari from Büyükuda (biggest Princes island) is great on a fine day! Büyükuda is well worth visiting - no cars! You can hire a bike (even an electric one) or take a "Fayton" four seater coach. It's mostly a residential area for the well-off and is also a beloved day-excursion for the Istanbulis - not much in the way of foreign languages used by waiters  so bring your Turkish phrasebook! The TCDD (suburban railway from Hyderpasa) will take you as far as Pendik - there you can take a ferry to Yalova on the southern Marmara shore, and a ferry (slow) back to Yenikapi (Istanbul).(Line shut at Pendik in October 2012 - work continuing on the stretch to ? Gebce).Yenikapi seems to be the main IDO terminal and can be easiy reached by surburban train from Sirkeci / Iminönü - from here you can take fast ferries to some pretty distant destinations, but as they are oriented to the commuter traffic they are not aleays convenient for day trips(OK if you want to overnight away 'tho).When the "Marmaray" project is completed and there is a rail line under the Bosphorus - this will all change..A good reason to visit Istanbul again before it is!
Interesting water tour, Istanbul. Ship was easy to board (I'm on a walking stick) and views were interesting - palaces, forts from the middle ages, mosques, expensive homes.

All aboard for a great trip. You can take a long cruise of up to six hours but we were promised a two hour trip which we found to be just right. Take your own guidebook because there is no commentary but that added to the serenity. The sights were brilliant.

Amazing... Take Any of the Curises at Eminiouni, we have taken the 15TL 2 hour curise which was more than enough to view all the atractions along the strait. Make sure you have your camera to shoot istanbul from different angles..
A must. Differents option are available for a cruise on the bosphorus ranging from two hours to a day but it gives you a sence of the size of the city.

Beautiful and inexpensive. There are many options for visiting the Bosphorus, the best one being the IDO which offers a big cruise ship, a two-hour cruise and they charge 10 Turkish lire (about 5 euros) for it. Lots of palaces and things to see, the ferry leaves daily at 14.30. Beware, there are lots of crooks offering these trips with very high prices and really bad boats.

The strip of sea between Europe and Asia. The Bosphorus Strait is like a lifeline...it is the loveliest stretch of beautiful blue water that connects two continents, feeding both sides with visitors and goods . All day long, you can see boats bobbing up and down, plying from one shore to the other, ferrying people around on day cruises and night cruises. The day cruise is great for seeing the citylife on both sides and the night cruise is perfect for wining and dining on a cool, breezy deck and swaying to the rhythm of the belly-dancer on board.

Bosphorus, dividing the European from the Asian Istanbul. Take a halfday trip on the Bosphorus, which is not a river but a straight joining the Black sea with the sea of Marmara. So much to see, Maidens tower has two stories to it, come to Istanbul to find out all about it...James Bond also visited one of his Bond girls here...great time and well worth the money

Great views of beautiful homes. make sure you take a planned tour and not the local boat on a Sunday.. may be cheap but just toooo packed and not a comfortable ride.. so pay the extra and enjoy the ride!

One of life's pleasures!. To sit at Dolmabahçe sipping Çay and watching the world sail by is one of life's greatest simple pleasures.This rather exciting waterway separates Asia and Europe and has been to scene of a squabble or two but to grab a table late afternoon as the sun sinks away in the west is truly relaxing!!Time your visit for later afternoon and then head up to Taksim Square and wander down Istaklal caddesi to to Galata Tower. A wonderful experience!!

Lovely day on the water. We did the Bosphorus Straits cruise which gave us a great view from the water. The palaces and historic sites were breathtaking. The homes were incredible too. Beware the serving of snacks on the boat. We thought they were included until they came around after to collect money.

A great way to see a lot of Istanbul Quick... There are a huge amount of tour boats for a trip on the straits that connect the Meditereanian Sea and the Black Sea. The view is great and you can ride in an open top or the bottom. There were dancers on our tour. It was $70 for two of us for half of a day. We made a 25 minute stop on the Asian side for a quick bit of yogurt at a yogurt making place. Then a stop at a restaurant at Maidens tower. They called it a private tour. I think that just means that it isn't a public ferry, I think. We had about 30 folks on our boat, but it was by no means crowded.

délicious. You can to pick your fresh fish delicious ! You have the impression you are in Greece
Cannot go to Istanbul and not eat there once !
By the water so peaceful amazing so close to the madness of traffic close by...

A boat trip up the Bosphorus is a must whilst in Istanbul. If you want to give your feet a rest from all the walking and sightseeing that people do in Istanbul, then a boat trip up the Bosphorus is a great way to relax. Get a boat that includes a commentary so you know what you are seeing. You get to see both the Asian and European sides and learn about the houses and sights along the way. I went during the day so I could take photos, but it would be magical at night as well.

an enjoyable break from the crowds. We took a small boat trip up the Bosphorus and back again. This took 45 minutes each way and it was just perfect to be able to travel quite close to the shore and see the sights. We were provided with drinks on the way and it would have been helpful to be told in advance that these drinks would be charged for but that didn't spoil our pleasure.

Stunning!. The Bosphorus is a visual delight - A joy - A celebration. Right from the moment you get on the cruise (I took one and I believe it's the best way to see the Bosphorus) - you get to see the best hotels, palaces and beautiful houses across Asia and Europe part of Istanbul.Highly recommended you go during the mid-day or evening for the weather and light is best.I loved the sights of the palaces and small cafeterias across the Bosphorus. This place is really for the romantic! And on the Asian side, those mind-blowing homes and villas transport you to a world of luxury. I'll miss you, Bosphorus & Istanbul!

Take the night cruise. We took a night cruise, not one with dinner and ebtertainment, just a cruise up the European side and back down the Asian side, with commentary. Very interesting and really pretty, they really go all out to light up the sights. A good deal as it was not expensive and you saw everything.

Wonderful views!. The ferry ride down the Bosphorous on a beautiful sunny day is gorgeous. You have a great view of the beautiful buildings built on the banks, and if you are with a guide, you get some history behind them.
relaxing. Taking a boat up the Bosphorus is relaxing as well as fascinating to see the modern city dotted with ancient structures.

Do it for for yourself. İnitially, i thought i can skip it as we r gonna make several boat trips to asia and islands. One early evening we were tired but dint wanna go back to hotel. We took the short cruise, the one on the golden horn side of galata bridge. İ wont be able to describe the beauty: blue silver water, dolphines, birds, green asia and europe coasts, and the homes, i hope people living there realize how lucky they r. Do not miss this,,treat urself to a trip to heaven
Take the cruise. Istanbul is a tourist friendly place. We booked a cruise trip through walk about tours located just beyond the entrance to cisterns and enjoyed it.
Bosphorus cruise. Do not get caught out by the hawkers selling 25 Lira trips - just walk on to the green bridge and there are regular identical cruises for 10 Lira.

One of the treasures of Istanbul. Ride the ferries as much as possible. Those going to the Asian side are quick and frequent, give you fantastic views of the city, and take you into the maelstrom of the ship traffic. They go from many places and are easy to figure out. Short visits to the Asian side were lots of fun - Uskudar and Kadikoy.

you'll see bothe the Europe and Asian Side of Turkey. I did this tour on my last day of stay in Istanbul since my fight back home is still at 7:25pm. After Dolmabahce palace, i walked to the Kabatas port and there is a tour that lasted for 1hr and 15mins only, right time for me before heading back to the hotel and it costs me only 12.5 turkish lira. I sat at the end of the ferry and was able to see first the Europe side, the Bosphorus and the old bridge that connects Europe and Asia and when the ferry went around, I was able to see the Asian side of Istanbul which are mostly nice houses along the Bosphorus.

A great day out! Take a boat trip!. We went all the way to the Black Sea! We really enjoyed it, the guide was brilliant, very learned about the city. Great for recovering from all the hiking around the historic sites.

the busiest waters in the world. that is according to me the best way of describing the Bosphorus straight. It is so busy that you sometimes have the feeling that boats will bump into one another. The palaces along the straight are just stunning and instead of a Bosphorus tour, I suggest you travel to the Prince's islands. Beautiful day trip.

a long walk along the Bosphorus. I walked from Ortakoy to Rumeli Hisari on a lovely warm sunny day in September. Beautiful views, fresh air, lovely wide promenades starting about a mile after Ortakoy, and parks along the way. Not to mention good cafes and restaurants. A must do activity in Istanbul

I always thought the Bosphorous was a mountain range but I was very wrong. A majestic waterway which is not just wonderful to look at and be near but is awesome to travel on by ferry or cruise boat and even more magic to view from a roof top bar as the sun sets over this very busy waterway.

Good to be on the water!. We went on the ferry/cruise up the Bosphorus for Tl 25. The trip takes 6hrs because the boat makes 5 stops and then the final stop is A Kavagi on the Asian side. It is a lovely way to get a good view of some beautiful palaces, mosques, private homes and little villages along the way and my husband took thousands of lovely photographs. It was fantastic to be on the water away from the crowds of Istanbul but we would have preferred not to have the stopover at the end as there was not much to do other than wait for the return trip.

A must. I took the advice of previous reviewers and took the shorter Bosphorus specialist viewing trip. This was on a fairly big ferry and with about 2000 other passengers and at about $us4.50 for 2 hours represented very good value. There is a bunch of interesting things to see both on the shores and the strait itself but I felt towards the end of the trip that I had seen enough and that a longer trip may have become tedious.Refreshments were sold on board, there was a commentary although it was hard to hear on my outside top deck stern location, and I was surprised at how quickly the ferry emptied at the end of the trip.Tip - although a nice day of about 25 celsius, the wind-chill factor heading into the breeze made me feel happy about having my rain-jacket in my backpack.Tip 2 - for an alternative aspect of the Bospherus catch the inexpensive modern tram from the old town across the Galata bridge to the second last stop (the last stop is for the separate short tramway up to famous Taksin Square), walk across to one of the riverside cafes, order a drink etc and watch the passing parade of ferries, freighters, yachts etc. The giant QE2 liner moved past when I was there, heading up the Bosphorus into the Black Sea. A great way to spend a pleasant hour or so.

A great day on the ferry & fabulous views. We took a local ferry. Our day started well with a local entertainer/businessman demonstrating his products e.g. a waking cane with a light in its handle. The bread rings were fresh and later the yoghurt from Kanlica maintained its reputation for excellence amongst locals and visitors. We landed at Antalya K... and climbed to a ruined castle for great views of the Black Sea. In 40 deg C heat, we welcomed drinks and lunch with great views down the Bosphorus before our return on the afternoon ferry. We also took advantage of the commentary for YTL5 along with YTL25, its great value for money. The tourist cruises are shorter and cover less of the Bosphorus for more dollars/lira. If you can spare a day, then the local ferry with some tourist features is highly recommended. We enjoyed it so much that another day we took part of the trip to enjoy lunch at Kanlica and more of its wonderful yoghurt with jam. Icing sugar is essential as it can have a sharp taste without it.
coast. Very beautiful views of the region. Istanbul's most beautiful, the place to look. Liked, we want to see you again.

Fantastic tour. We did the Old Spice Market and Bosphorus tour which was great. Brilliant tour guide kept us in stitches with his sense of humour and his knowledge of the surroundings was really good.
Well worth th visit
nice nice nice. this strait that connected asian part to uropian was too much nice I liked it very very much also we smoked shoosha near it and enjoyed alot

Best way get a good overall idea of the size of Istanbul. The cruise was a great way to get an idea of the layout and size of Istanbul, as well as some great photos. If you can be on the Bosphorus at night it's especially nice. Be warned though, if you're not used to public toilets in Istanbul, the boat's not the place to learn (especially for women). It can also get chilly on the water in November so take a jacket.

Nice excursion. It is an excursion you can book yourself. You need to get a good map so you know what you are looking at. Try the 6 hour trip, most interesting. if you are not up to a solo, hire a tour, but do it.

Restful. We took the ferry/cruise up to A Kavagi on the Asian side to give ourselves a day of reduced walking. It was restful but sadly there is little to do at the destination but climb the hill to the old fort then decide which of the restaurants on the harbour to use for lunch. A very pleasant interlude though.
Must to see in Istambul. It is especially beautiful at night.There is a boat tour in the evening taking tourists to admire Bosphorus at night.The boats depart from Eminino train station

Do not go to Istanbul without a Bosphorus Cruise.. Definitely do no not leave Istanbul without a boat cruise up the Bosphorus. A 90 minute tour will do, but it's absolutely stunning. You can see beautiful mosques and palaces and in the summer it's a great way to beat the heat. I tried to plan ahead, but wound up just hopping on one of the tours people were peddling along the way. You can find one for 20TL and they'll serve drinks on board. I think no matter what cruise you pick, you can't go wrong. It's the beautiful real estate that counts.

Great Day Trip. We took the regular ferry (used by the Turks) all of the way up to the Black Sea. It's a 6 hour cruise, so be prepared. It cost us 25TL pp. There were about 5 stops between Istanbul and Anadolu Kavağı. If the weather is nice, sit outside so that you get to see several of the old palaces. There's plenty of seating and they also offer tea/coffee service, as well as a small kiosk for snacks. DO NOT USE THE BATHROOMS! They're just small holes in the ground, smell like urine and are incredibly filthy. Once you arrive at Anadolu Kavağı, you get about 2-3 hours to explore the town. As usual, there are restaurants as soon as you arrive and they're all trying to get you to spend some money. We walked up to the old roman castle at the top of the town. It was a pretty good hike up a very steep hill, so I would suggest wearing tennis shoes. You'll also walk through a small area with restaurants and souvenir shops. There's a small bathroom in the area, and I would highly suggest using this one instead of the one on the ferry.
Nice trip. Nice way to see both the Asian and European side of Istanbul. Well worth the 1.5 hours. Have a fish sandwich at the Tea House and visit Yeni Camii Mosque.

For 10TL's - You can't go wrong!. We took the tram to the Eminou stop, walked toward the water and hopped on a ship at the last pier called the City Line; it costs 10 Turkish Liras for a two and half hour trip, it’s well worth getting the GPS audio guide for 5 Turkish Liras. Tip: Take your camera and a long lens to get the best shots from the upper deck with Turkish Tea!

Bosphorus "cruise". Guide books do warn that taking a public ferry for 15 TL would deliver a similar experience. We should have paid heed.The tour we took (70 TL each) took us up as far as the second bridge. Our guide pointed out various expensive waterfront properties which are of no interest unless you are looking for Istanbul real estate and told us that that attractive Victorian buildings were former summer palaces of various sultans, really very little of note to see.The tour bus did pick us up at our hotel and also took us to the Rustem Pasha Mosque which was good but our time there was very, very brief, and to the Egyptian spice market. This did not add much value.

Great way to spend the afternoon. A beautiful way to see Istanbul from the sea. Make sure you stop for a spot of lunch at the quayside first and grab a traditional fish sandwich from one of the local boats. Yum
expansive. It's hard to believe how gigantic it is, until you start traveling on it. Even just a ferry tour across to the asian side, gives you a glimpse of the territory this covers.
Dividing 2 continents. That's what the Bosphorus does. Try the cruise or walk along the coast full of nice cafes and restaurants

No need to do a pricey boat tour. I took the tram to the Eminou stop, walked toward the water and hopped on a boat just taking off which cost 10 lira. didn't include any tour guide or lunch (although there was a snack bar and complimentary tea) but it served my purpose just fine. 2 hours. Not a ton to see from the Bosphorus except great views (and photo opportunities of the sites back in Sultanmet) at the beginning and end. But the water is beautiful and I always love a boat ride.

Cruise through Asia and Europe. Great way to spend a few hours and see sights around the bosporus.Don't take private tour. Check ido website for times for short and long tours. Cheaper and much more reliable.

Nice, relaxing boat tour. We took the two hour tour which was plenty. Our tour guide pointed out all the historical sights and was full of information. It was a nice way to see the European and Asian sides of Istanbul.
A unique chance to go through European-Asian border. Just go and see with your own eyes - no room for disappointment, here. It might be your only chance for a borderline trip, try it!

Princes Islands - the Highlight of my trip in May 2012. I went to Istanbul in May this year, which is a good time to go since the weather is mild, and spent a lovely morning on the Bosphorus.The highly informative, kind and humourous freelance tour guide, Tayfun Diker of Turista Travel Agency in Sultanahmet led a small group of us(7), including himself and another young lady guide on a private ferry trip to Princes Islands, about 20kms south of Istanbul.It was a bit difficult to find a window seat on the ferry but once we got to the largest Island, the scenery was charming, there was a surprise - no cars! We spent a tranquil morning on a chariot(horse drawn) topless carriage ride, eating home-made ice cream in the town square, mingling with the cats and dogs(even if they are strays, they are cared for by the municipality). The latter do tend to hare round in their cars - but this is about one every hour- they are the only ones allowed to drive a car on the island. The rest of the population walk, cycle or visitors ride on the open horse-drawn carriages. The day was warm and the views of the sea were pretty, with pine forests in which the horses ran wild when they were let free. It was a leisurely relaxed time, reminiscent of some places like Fresnaye in my home city, Cape Town. The fish lunch at a restaurant was ok, but then I'm not into fish. I enjoyed the sea breeze.

One of the first things to do in Istanbul. If you visit Istanbul then you should do the Bosphrus tour. If you do not do it you will lose a great opportunity to view Istanbul from the sea ! The ride starts from Kabatash on the European side, passing landmarks such as Dolmabahçe Palace, the four seasons and Kempenski hotels - where apparently there is rooms $ 5000 a night. You pass under the Boshporus bridge - the bridge that connects Europe with Asia. You then turn on to the Asian side of the Bosphorus. At the end of our tour we were taken up Camilca Hill which gives you ariel views of the city. The entire tour last around 90 minutes.

vaporetto. fresh air, wonderfull houses on seaside and you can see both continents : Asia and Europe !! Just take a vapour ticket from Eminonu and boat tour takes all day. You can have a lunch break at Anatolian Castle for few hours and catch return boat to Eminonu again..
Nice Cruise. It was nice to see a view of the city from a distance. You can manage to see a nice cross section of old and new. The cooler air was also a delight.

The waterway (and bridge) which separates Europe from Asia.. An incredibly vibrant and exciting waterway, apart from it's key link between West and Middle East it is the only shipping link into the black sea,

Sailing into history. we were approached on the foreshore by Captain Ali. Six for price of 5 @ 20tl each for 45 mins each way basic ferry trip. Perfect to simply take in the sights and sounds of this amazing city. Take something to cover shoulders from sun/cold. If you want the full experience check at Tourist Information by harbour as season almost finished

Take a cruise!. We really enjoyed our 2 hour cruise on the Bosphorus Strait. It was a great way to see the far-flung parts of Istanbul. The ship passes by the various waterfronts, giving good views of the Sultan's palaces, the lighthouse and the old fortification and walls.Be aware that there are "fake" cruises - next to the tram stop. you want to go under the Bosphorus bridge to find the real cruise ships just on the other side.
Great boat trip. It is definitely worth taking the boat trip along the Bosphorus and we stopped on the Asian side and came back over the bridge.
This is a must do water trip !. If you visit Istanbul then this is a must do water trip. If you do not do it you will lose a great opportunity to view Istanbul from the sea !
Busy with impressive ships. An impressive and constantly evolving site that keeps you entertained like people watching in a Paris Cafe.
Take a boat trip. Wonderful to see both sides of Istanbul whilst relaxing on one of the many "cruise" ships. Enjoy the difference between the Turkish and Asian side.

Sunset cruise. We took a private boat for a sunset cruise which was amazing. Just seeing all the boat traffic, from very small boats to huge barges traveling up to the Black Sea was incredible. Seeing all the palaces, mansions, historic forts, bridges was beautiful. We even passed by a wedding that was taking place. Very romantic ride.
A boat trip on the Bosphorus is a must. We did 2 trips at different times and it is a great way to see the old ~Palaces and the newer waterfront homes. It is a busy waterway but fascinating

A perfect break from sightseeing. Had a cruise on the Bosporous and it was just good to be on such a historic waterway. Cruise was OK went on a local boat, not the 10tl jam packed ferry. Sitting up on deck watching the sites of Istanbul go by was wonderful. Nice people too.

How to 'do' the straits. This gave us a break from the hustle, hassle and bustle of Istanbul. There are three options. Take the tram to Eminönü. At the south end of the Galata bridge, facing it, move to the right (east). 1) One option is to take a half-trip for 10 TL which you can do any time of day and get to see most of the waterside attractions as far as the Fatih bridge and back. Great value. Listen for the chant of "Bosporos ... Bosporos".2) The other is to get there by mid-morning (see http://www.sehirhatlari.com.tr/en for schedule) and take the trip further north to Saliyer or to the end of the line at Anadolu Kavağı for 25 TL - 3) Finally you can take a dinner, moonlight, booze cruise. Don't do it ... waaaaay overpriced.It is a pleasant break but not on a par with the famous monuments. If you are squeezed for time, give it a miss or choose 1).
waterfront excitement. This main economic thoroughfare is a must see. Have drinks at sunset at The Banyan Tree Thai restaurant/bar, next to the Radisson, near the Asian Bridge
A unique experience. We took a boat trip from the Golden Horn up towards the Black Sea under the two bridges that link Asia and Europe. Amazing and memorable.

A perfect respite from sightseeing. My husband and I took the Bosphorus cruise in the middle of our weeklong stay in Istanbul. After several days of busy sightseeing, we really enjoyed relaxing as we made our way on the beautiful waterway. The boat is comfortable enough, with a good snack bar and plenty of places to sit and take photos. We had a good guidebook with us, so could easily identify the historic sites along the way. It was delightful having a fresh fish lunch at the water's edge before heading back to the city.

Strait from the heart. We stayed right on the Strait at the Curagan Palace. The view is spectacular and the palace was 5 star. We took a boat at sunset to the Asian side. I would say that was anti-climatic. This body of water is always full of large ships sailing in both directions. The boat left us off at the area by the spice market. Everywhere you go there are crowds. I found it very excillerating.

Superb. Had a cruise on the Bosporous and it was just good to be on such a historic waterway.Cruise was OK but sitting up on deck watching the sites of Istanbul go by was wonderful and watching the red moon with nice people was good too.

A cruise up the Bosphorus is a must. When in Istanbul you must take a cruise up the Bosphorus. You commence from near the Galata Bridge at Eminonu next to the New Mosque. Arrive at the booking office early to get a good seat. Have your camera ready for many photo opps. Cruise by the Galata Tower, the Palaces, Mosques, towering bridges connecting Europe and Asia, Yalis, and townhouses and massive development creeping up and over the green wooded hills, restaurants, kids jumping into the water, red Turkish flags dotting the banks fluttering in the breezes.. Arrive at Sariyer, and bus to Kilyos where you can walk to the Black Sea and take a swim. Wonder at the amazing Bosphorus connecting the Black Sea to the Sea of Marmara - blue, breezy, and busy - a wind tunnel for Istanbul - so highly regarded over the centuries - a magnet for human habitation - you will see why!
Take a river cruise. It won't blow you away but it does show you how big the city is and how pretty the river is. Only takes 1.5 hrs.

Swim in the Black Sea. Our hotel recommended a private boat that took a full day and included swimming from the boat in the Black Sea. We had several stops which change slightly depending what is open that day, The very well informed guide gave us a commentary and it was a delightful trip which made a relaxing break from the major town sites. Not cheap, but we thought it well worth while, scenic and more varied than many boat trips.

Go for the 10TL 2-hr review. Honestly, there's no need for some fancy, schmancy private yacht kind of thing. The views are impressive enough as it is. Go for one of these deals (guys shouting "10 Lira! Bosphorus!" near the Galata bridge) and save yourself the aggravation. Also, take snacks if you'll want them (just coffee and soda available on board) and don't forget your camera - you'll get the chance to see the Asian and European coasts...pretty cool.

Amazing views. It is all about the way wou will visit it. I have opted for a boat cruise that included the travel up to the Europa Fortress and back (appx 2 hours) plus some bus sightseeing with visit to summer palace Beylerbey, Theodosian walls etc. There are lots of firms offering local tours.

Take the Ferry. Don't waste 60 Euros on a small boat that doesn't go all the way up to the Black Sea. For only 25 Euros you can take the ferry all the way up and back from the Eminonu port near Sultanahmet. Get there 45 minutes in advance to purchase your ticket and get in line for a decent seat on the boat. If you take a morning boat, sit on the starboard (right) side of the vessel--you'll be in the shade and have the best light on the Asian bank of Istanbul's sights!

What a view.. Taking a guided boat ride around Bosphorus is the best way of experiencing the city. You get to see both side of the city, Europe & Asia. Many interesting building , water side restaurants and those expensive homes.
boat trip. don´t miss a boat trip. very nice experience. to see europe and asia is very special. We will go again next time

Perfect. We took the 2 hour (1.5 hrs actually) trip on the Bosphorus. It gave a great overview of the City from a different perspective. WOW. Lots of boat traffic, but never felt endangered. Beautiful Ottoman houses, Municipal buildings and summer homes of the wealthy. HIGHLY recommend this trip all for only 12 TL (about $7 USD)

private bosphorous cruise. Cruising on the Bosphorous in a private yacht at sunset was spectacular. Although the crew did not speak much English they were very attentive to us and served white wine during the 2 hour cruise up the European side and returning via the Asian side. The price included an air conditioned van and driver to our restaurant the same evening.

Choose your ship wisely!. We took almost the first ship we met and it was a mistake. All ships from Eminonu pier could transport you thru Bosphorus, but pay attention which one you take. We had to sit on plastic ordinary chairs on the deck. They were overcrowded and walking from a part to another of the ship was a little difficult.But the sights worth the money :). We saw the Galata bridge, the Bosphorus bridge, etc, The Rumelian Fortress, many other sights from the water. We could use some explanations about the sites, but on that ship there was not possible. It is true that it was very cheap...

Most enjoyable (and cheapest) tour in town!. The reason Istanbul (called Byzantium when founded by the Greeks from Megara in 657BC, then called Constantinople after Roman emperor Constantine the Great made it his capital in 330AD, then called Istanbul after the Turks conquered it in the 1453AD) was built in its location was because it commands and controls the Bosphorus Strait. It can thus permit or prevent maritime travel between the Mediterranean and the Black Sea. All around the city are forts and pleasure palaces, and all manner of interesting sights that reflect the city’s consequent power and history, and its level of command and control over the Bosphorus Strait. Today, you can see this for yourself easily and in comfort, for just a few Turkish Lira, by taking a trip on a classic Istanbul ferry.The ferries of Istanbul are run by four companies. The big traditional multi-deck ferries with wide viewing decks at the stern and stand-up bars serving food and drinks are run by Sehir Hatlari Traditional Ferries. These are the ferries beloved of tourists and Turks alike. They run from Eminonu and Sirkeci on the old Istanbul side of the Galata Bridge and from Karakoy and Kabatas across the Galata Bridge on the modern European side; and they travel to destinations across the Bosphorus on the Asian side, and up and down the Bosphorus Strait on both sides for several kilometers. Two smaller companies, TurYol and Dentur Avrasya, also operate smaller ferries along these routes and out to the Princes Islands. All three operate Bosphorus Cruises which they run twice a day and which last about 2 hours. I personally think the big old traditional ferries are the only ones to travel on, when doing a Bosphorus Cruise, because they have a walk-up bar, lots of toilets, and plenty of viewing space. So make sure you check what vessel you’ll travel on before you book your Bosphorus Cruise.A fourth cruise line is IDO (which stands for Istanbul Deniz Otobusleri). This operates fast ‘SeaBus’ catamaran services and car ferries both within the Istanbul area, and to ports as far away as Canakkale near Gallipoli at the Mediterranean end of the Bosphorus.Bottom line: Taking a ferry ride when you’re in Istanbul is a “must do”. But do your research first, on routes and times, and ask your hotel how to get to your nearest ferry wharf, and what to look for when you get there. Smart travelers can work it out for themselves, but it never hurts to seek a little local help.TIP: There are lots of ferries in Istanbul … and some are run by cowboys. The cowboys tend to use any trick they can to get you aboard their boats … which tend to be more expensive and spend less time motoring on cruises. If you’re just going across the Bosphorus on a short run, maybe it doesn’t matter. But if you want to go on a two-hour cruise, it’s always best to seek out the official ferries. Please be careful you’re not side-tracked. I was planning to take a 2-hour Bosphorus Cruise and I knew the best and cheapest Bosphorus Cruises were run using those old traditional Istanbul ferryboats. Tickets to these cruises are only available at the Government ferry ticket office at Eminonu wharf. So I headed there. Nearby, an older Turk in a white Admiral’s uniform stopped me, claiming to represent an ‘official’ Bosphorus Cruise. He directed me to a mini-van standing on the curb with open door, which ‘he said’ would take me to the ferry wharf on the other side of the Galata Bridge. Since I could see the government ferry ticket office just 30 meters away near the bridge, and a big old traditional ferry beside it, I knew he was actually trying to lure me off track to one of the cowboy’s tour boats. So I brushed him off, and kept walking. But he got some others to enter that mini-van. As a result, I had a leisurely tour of the Bosphorus Strait in the wide back deck of an old traditional Istanbul ferry (see my photos) while they had a faster, more expensive tour in a more modern vessel. I’ll let you decide which tour of the Bosphorus Strait you’d prefer.

A breathtaking experience. This is the most beautiful part of Istanbul, that divides the two continents. A ride on Bosphorous is a must, which takes you through the town passing fascinating structures of Istanbul, and the glorius bridges. You can either take a day ride which operates every half an hour till 7pm and costs just Lira10, or a private night trip at Euro 65. Catch the last day trip at 7. You can see the sunset and the beautifully lit city at night on your return.

Night time view of Bosphorus Strait. We dined our first night at Tugra, a notable restaurant housed in the Kapinski Palace, with a balcony table overlooking the strait and providing a beautiful view of the bridge linking Europe and Asia.

Breath-taking and worthwhile seeing. Find a half-day tour and enjoy a ride on this beautiful body of water linking the Marmara Sea and the Black Sea. No need to spend longer there, but you will always remember the trip on this busy waterway.
Boat ride on the Bosphorus. Hesitated to take this ride, but it was well worth it. The Bosphorus is beautiful and has many interesting structures along it.
well worth the trip. a full days tour all the way up the Bosphorus to the Black sea stop over for lunch opertunity to climb to the fort at the top of the hill and back again to Istanbul

Fantastic Views. Take a cruise along the Bosphorus and see the city from a different side. You will see the skyline of the Asian side of town and all it's buildings, the old city with all it's Mosques, and the modern part of town with all it's tall buildings.
Breathtaking!!. Lovely lovely lovely view!!This is my second time to Istanbul and also my second time of cruising the Bosphorus.. still couldnt have enough of it.Really beautiful!

The pivot of the old world.. A joy to see all the way and back. My first sight of the Black sea.Set foot in Asia for a fish lunch, masses of choice there. The IDO ferry trip was about £10 each from the Marmara side of the Galata bridge and a lovely way to spend a Sunday

enjoyed the nice weather. depends on your time you can choose both short and long tour, the short tour has no stop and takes around 1.5-2 hours and the long tour I guess needs at least 4-5 hours.I have been on the short tour which starts around 2:30 PM. worths trying...
don't miss it. An unforgetable cruise through Bosphorus...Take a boat at around 6 o'clock in order to see the bridges and the city also at night...

A Great trip. This is a fascinating boat trip even if you didn't know much history from Jason and his Argonauts to the armies and navies that have sailed to conquer these waters. There are great fish restaurants at every ferry stop.

Best to go all the way to the Black Sea.. We went on a great half day trip up the Bosphorus which included a barbecue lunch and snacks. Many amazing sights along the river and great to visit the Black Sea.
Boat trip. We did the boat trip up the Bosphorous, went under both bridges, and saw a lot of sites. A bit windy, but fun.

Historic and busy waterway worth a day visit. We spent a Sunday on a big ferry boat travelling from the bottom of the Bosphorous to the Black Sea - stopping off for a fresh fish lunch before taking it back to the City. It's a great day out and the boat is full of people who use the ferry as well as tourists.
Ferry ride was fun. We did a shorter ride, took about 2 hours. The views were spectacular. I had fun doing people watching as well. I a nice muslim lady shared pumpkin seeds with us.

unforgettable memories. This was really unforgettable memory in my life. A have chosen one of lots of small cruises found in the historical areas of Istanbul. The journey took almost 2 hours. it was a very romantic trip.

Catch a local ferry. Want a great photo shot of Aya Sofia, Blue Mosque and Topkapi Palace all in one, then catch a local ferry across the Bosphorus take your photos, don't get off on the other side and just return to the same place you got on. Will cost you alot loess than the boat ride thats on offer from tours.

Great ferry ride. We rode the T1 to Eminonu and got the 2 hour ferry right there. We opted for the audio/video GPS rental 5 TL .We shared an earphone so only needed one. It showed the inside of many of the palaces along the way. The only problem was that the tour tended to hug one shore while the sites were included consecutively so we finally gave up trying to watch the side we were on. Still worth the rental.

A great trip to take by boat. We did the Hop On Hop Off bus tour, offered in Sultanahet Square by City Sightseeing, Istanbul and for another ten Euro you can add on a Bosphorus ferry ride and a ride down the funicular. For the money, it was a nice afternoon out. Seeing the architecture along the Bosphorus was interesting, as it is so varied as you move up and down the coast. In nice weather, on calm water - this is a great trip. The funicular however...totally skippable.

Get a boat from the dock, not through an agency. We had seen a 2-hour cruise advertised in our hotel for 35 euros, with "free snacks". However, we walked to the dockside at Eminonu and easily found a boat doing a 2-hour cruise for 5 euros. We took our own snacks! It's a fabulous ride and gives you a perspective of Istanbul that you don't get from on land.

A good way to get an overview of Istanbul. A boat trip of the Bosphorus is something you really should take the time to do: a) if the weather is nice, it is avery enjoyable ride on the water b) you see a lot of intersting sights from the boat that you most likely would not have seen otherwise and c) it gives you a better understanding of the lay-out of Istanbul. There are a lot of tourist tours that you can go on if you want to sail the Bosphorus, but we chose to take the tram to Kabatas (very easy) and then take one of the roundtrips from there. It is much cheaper and ok maybe it doesn't include a buffet, but the money you have saved can pay for your meal in a decent restaurant.

Nice to do the boat trip. I did the bosphorus strait boat trip that passes through some of the main cultural points by the strait. I did not do the black sea swimming thing, just the cultural part. It was nice.I got to see the forts and heard a nice explanation about the war for the takeover of Constantinople.

One of the two main water arteries of Istanbul. The Bosphorus Strait, busy from dawn til midnight with the ferry traffic that marks this city as a great maritime entity, separates the European and Asian sides of the city. It see a steady stream of large and small commercial vessels as well, including huge oil tankers, cruise ships and pleasure craft. The subject of centuries, if not millennia of history and struggle for control this strategic waterway, the Bosphorus looms large in the Great Power games of the 19th and 20th centuries.

Great to get away from the hussel and bustle of it all. We chose the 6 hour ferry trip 25 tlr return each...definitely get there early or there's no seats outside. I think we would have preferred a shorter trip at the 3 hour stopover was a bit long. Definitely worth going on, but without the 3 hour wait would have been better (the public ferry only dies it this way) we purchased the 5tlr information headphones which were really informative, but check the head clips as the plastic was broken on one of them, which we couldn't use.Overal a relaxing day but personally we would have liked the shorter trip ( which most of the amazing photos are to be taken!)
beautiful and a good exprience.. it is beautiful , try it at night and i think you will enjoy it . i think it 's very good and romantic .

A must. We were rather unfortunate with the weather, but the cruises on the Bosphorus are a must. From the Bosphorus, you truly get to appreciate the sheer scale and size of Istanbul city, and you can see most of the key attractions all around. Highly recommend combining the cruise to Prince's Island.

Beautiful cruise, excellent value, perfect Day 3 or Day 4 activity. My 10:30am cruise to Asia was not fully booked. I lined up at about 10am and got a great seat on the top deck, left side, right next to the water. Try to sit on the left side of the boat in both parts of the round trip: better for lighting. Also, a seat towards the back of the boat is preferable: exhaust fumes are weaker when the boat is docked and idling. Use a good guidebook or rent the audioguide for the tour; otherwise it's impossible to identify some of these buildings. Boat travels at a very modest speed, lots of time to take photos of each sight. Staff come by selling coffee, tea, water and on the cruise back, ice cream.My boat docked at the last Asian fishing village at 12:10pm, and the first boat back started boarding at 2:30pm to leave at 3pm. That's plenty of time to hike to Yoros Castle. That hike is short (20 minutes), but fairly steep at some points; footing is not always great; few handholds and little shade. This is a military training zone, and you aren't allowed to take any photos during the hike, only at the top. You know you're near the top when you see the cafes. You can walk through them without buying anything - they are built on public property. W/Cs here if you need them for 1TL.The view of the Sea of Marmama and Black Sea is worth the trouble. When you get to the top, you get to a small landing with lots of litter and no place to sit (except the ground). You might see a steel door to the castle that's chained shut. Knock or holler for the attendant to open it. It leads to another landing with a much better view. Note the castle interior is not for viewing.This would be an ideal place to have a picnic or just chill out if it were kept cleaner. Also a few picnic tables or benches would help. There are also a few friendly stray dogs looking for your food scraps. So I just took pictures, had some water, and left.The walk downhill is much easier, and then you can have lunch either on top of the hill or by the marina. At the marina, you have basically 3 classes of restaurant: 1) the diner-style where for 15TL you can get a combo meal 2) upscale prix-fixe for 25TL 3) the fancier sit-down style to go a la carte for 40TL (huge portions, whole grilled fish - worth it). The higher price usually gets you a table by the water. The cheaper ones are all more inland. I suspect the food is similar at all of them. None of the restaurants has a free W/C - no matter what, you will be paying 1TL. (So use the one on the boat before docking.)In the town, there is a small grocery store where you can get cheap water (1TL for a 1.5L bottle). There is also a bakery whose specialty is anchovy cornbread (tasty but very dry - needs some melted butter, or at least a big beverage). Some stands sell loksa (donuts in syrup), but the vendor told me they only sell them on weekends. Lots of ice cream, though. Also Anatolian souvenir shops.I lined up for the return cruise at 2:40pm and got a good seat on the top deck. It's a little more crowded because another boat would have docked at 1:30pm or so, and those passengers can opt for this return cruise. On the cruise back (same route exactly), I sat on the left side and got a better view of the Asian sights (they are fewer, less exciting). Closer to the city, I got some great shots of Topkapi and Ayasofya - you are actually closer to the sights than you are shooting from Galata Tower. (i.e. I don't see any value in Galata Tower.) On the return, people are mored tired - some just nap. If you need to take photos of the Europe side, there is no problem. We docked at about 4:30pm and I was exhausted, no energy to see anything else that day.Overall, this is a very enjoyable day, but a big investment in time. The best photo opportunities in the city, for sure, but I wouldn't put this above seeing the Old City sights first. You absolutely need good weather to do this. And at 25TL round-trip, this is an incredible value. IMO, a perfect Day 3 or 4 activity.

Bosphorus Strait. Took a river boat cruise through the strait with a tour guide, totally calming and refreshing. Passed the narrowest point between western and eastern Turkey with a close view of the Dohlmabahce palace and the Rumeli fort. Really makes you think how the ancient Turks were able to fortify a country that straddled two continents.

Great relaxing day on the very low cost ferry all the way. Decided to take the ferry all the way along the Bosporus; got to see all the old buildings and castles form the direction they were meant to be seen. Also got to see how today's rich live, particularly on the Asian side. The Ferry takes 90 minutes to reach Anadolu Kavagi, a village on the Asian side adjacent to the Black Sea. It stayed there for 3 hours, time to take the steep road to Yoros Castle. Great views that make the trip worthwhile, but the castle itself is not worth the walk. The village is essentially dozens of restaurants. I had a very good fish lunch with beer at one for just 11TL (about $7) - great value, then went to another for a good italian coffee for 7TL.The ferry ride costs 25TL round trip, and you can get on at various points, or get off. I took the 10:35 am ferry and returned on the 3 pm. There is also a 1:30 pm and another return at 4:30 pm.There is also a two hour non-stop version but you will miss the upper reaches of the Bosporus.Highly recommend; get there a bit early if you want a good seat on the top level (open-sided but top-cover so no problem with light rain or sun). There are two lower levels.
Very good. interesting but weather was so cold , I do recommend it, I think you should have a look at this site if you travel to Istanbul

Cruise for 2 hrs - long enough. We took the government run ferry cruise for 2 hrs with one audio guide that we shared between us - left at 1130 am - we thought it left at 1030 but when we got to the wharf were told it was leaving at 1130. Was easy enough to get a seat although you had to be a little bit pushy to get to the middle of the rush to ensure a good seat was yours!We found the 2 hrs was plenty long enough - the audio guide was good - was loud enough and the map provided adequate. The sights along the way were fabulous and the photo opportunities many and varied. A very nice way to get more acquainted with Istanbul - would be very pleasant in the late afternoon I also think!
Enjoyable by boat. The only way to see this is to take a guided boat trip and see both sides of Istanbul at once. Lots of interesting buildings and areas with a fascinating history through the ages.

Day cruise. We took a 2 or 3hrs day cruise. It was nice to be on the water and see Istanbul from that angle, as well as the sites we had visited. I would only recommend this for people who have aleady seen the main attractions in Istanbul.
Channel in Istanbul.. Lot of history here, busy vessel traffic, nice bridges, different continents on each side, fresh breeze.

Take a Sunset Cruise!. A sunset cruise down the Bosporus offers astounding view of the city of Istanbul. Make sure you get to the boat early so you can get a seat with a good view, and bring a jacket! It gets chilly on the Bosporus at night!
Just take a cruise and it must be a guided one!!. Sun/water/history/views/people....an incredible 2 hours plus on the water on a beautiful day....what else can I say...yes..JUST GO!!

Great boat ride. The only way to see the wonderful buildings as they were meant to be viewed from the water is by boat. We had an hour plus cruise that took us past old forts and palaces and under modern bridges. It is really amazing to know that all the water traffic to and from the Black Sea must come through here.

Boat trip along the Bosphorous strait. A visit to Istanbul is not complete without a boat trip on the Bosphorous. Apart from marvelling at the various palaces along the shores the traveller will also get a better view of the Sultan Mehmet Bridge which is well lit at night and chages colour.

Must do 1/2 day tour here.. Beautiful place to see. Seems as if there are no rules of the waterway so not for the easily frightened! Lovely day and great sights. Wish it was later in the day for good photos of Istanbul from water with setting sun but great trip well worth 30-40 euros.

Wonderful boat trip to the mouth of the Black Sea. Gave us a sense of the size of Istanbul as we sailed past mosques, villages and some open country on our way to the Black Sea. We had a 2 hour stopover at our destination, and found a fish restaurant. A lovely restful trip after the intense sight-seeing and heat of the city.

Boat trip on the Bosporus. Took boat tip on Bosporus to the black sea and back. Was a great trip. But just do the boat trip, avoid paying to visit the old castle ruins at the last stop. The castle sits on top of a mountain and the only way up is to walk. When we got to the top the castle is closed to visitors. The view is nice but not worth the effort. Pick a boat trip at eminonu stop in the old city. Was 25 Turkish lira for two roundtrip.
Cruise is the highlight!. Of all the places to go and things to see, the cruise is the one that gives ou the best sense of the vibrancy of the city. Enjoy!

A Great Way to See the Palaces and Sprawling Hillsides! Try the Local Ferries!. In good weather, a great way to see the palaces and sprawling hillsides of Istanbul.
