Prices and schedule to be found here: http://www.sehirhatlari.com.tr/en. Be sure to pay extra for the audioguide just after you purchase your ticket and go through the turnstile. It was worth it -- otherwise, you have no idea what the beautiful buildings are along the Bosphorous. Get there early, and stand in line to get good window seats. Take a sweater because even in the summertime, it can get a little windy. At the last stop, there is a little town. We walked up the steep hill to visit Yoros Castle (wear practical shoes), and stopped at one of the many hillside restaurants along the way to have a simple lunch overlooking the water. The path to Yoros Castle isn't particularly well marked, and there isn't much to see once you get to the top, but the view is amazing and you can see where the Bosphorus meets the Black Sea.No need to pay boku bucks for a Bosphorus Cruise when the government does a fine job with its public ferry!
Take a Cruise of the Strait.. Absolutely wonderful seeing all the old palaces on the Europe and Asian sides. Definitely worth doing!

6 hour trip..... ... is definitely the one to go for! I took the boat from the Golden Horn (just by the bridge) at 10:35. And enjoyed a well earned ice cold Efes on top of the hill overlooking both Bosphorus and Black Sea (at Anadolu Kavagi, Asia). Much enjoyed.
Take a boat tour. taking a boat tour is the best way to appreciate this beautiful area!

A MUST DO. A cruise on the Bosphorus is a must. The views from the river are amazing. You are cruising the line between Asia & Europe, the palaces can be seen much better than from the street and the homes on the strait are stunning. The views of the city leave you speechless. The water is so blue contrasting with the green hills and white buildings and it's a great way to start any visit.

Bosphorus.... Boat Trip. This has to be the most amazing country i have ever visited!!! I went on the Bosphorous boat trip and took about 100 photo's whilst on board. I would definately reccomend anyone in Istanbul to go on a boat trip. But make sure you get your ticketd for the Bosphorus right near to the boats. It was 15 TLR. Other people who are selling the tickets are selling them more expensive. I would give this 10/10 ;)

bosphorous blue. opted for a half-day tour that involved a pick-up from hotel then we boarded a lovely yacht/boat with upper deck where we all sat and were given a running talk and history of areas.we also stopped of on the asian side of istanbul for a quick snack which was great.the tour was very informative and well presented.this is done by several companies so one is spolit for choice.i think i would love to do this again as was alovely hot day but nice breeze too so was fantastic.
Sit back and relax. Take a ride (1 1/2 hours) on one of the many boats that tour the Bosphorus it's definetly worth doing. There are some really beautiful houses along the journey.

NOT SO STRAIGHT STRAIT. Take the "Bosphorus Cruise" from the Galata Bridge ferry terminal. There is a one-hour one, which makes no stops but shows you the city from the water turning around beyond the Bosphorus Bridge. Another one crisscrosses the Bosphorus and stops at various points, which were previously serviced by a ferry.Check the schedule at the information kiosk in order to make plans where to get off and on. Do research about the stops before, there is little to no information available once you are on the boat. Kanlica has the world's best yoghurt, Sayer a nice museum, Kavay a ruined fortress to climb.

a panoramic sunset cruise is a must. a sunset cruise along the Bosphorus is am excting way to see Istanbul. The palaces of Dolmabache and Ciragan are stunning from the water. We saw a school of dolphins at play. As they swam along side our boat, breath taking views of the city were all around us
Wonderful view along the strait. Historical and modern building along the Bosporus straits make it beautiful. The strait is clean, as is the harbor. We even saw dolphins during our cruise !

Divides Europe & Asia. One of the highlights of my 3 night break in Istanbul was the ferry trip cruise up the Bosporus Strait, which connects the Black Sea with the Sea of Marmara which is connected to the Mediterranean Sea. The Bosporus Strait divides the city & marks the division between Europe & Asia.You can walk to the ferry docks at Eminonu Quay (a busy square near the Galata Bridge on the Sultanahmet side). Three bodies of water meet here: the Golden Horn, Bosporus Strait & Sea of Marmara. Among the crowd, iPods & designer sunglasses vie with headscarves & prayer beads as the accessory of choice - showcasing the diversity of the 13-million strong local population. Don't miss the chance to unwind & watch the world go by - it's a stopping point for boats & ferries & is a great place to sample a beautiful outdoor restaurant.Then you can join the commuter rush & take a boat which departs daily at 10:30. The ferries are comfortable with plentiful seating inside and out. After several days of walking all over the city it was great to be able to sit outside in the breeze and watch the scenery go by. It really gives you a sense of how big the city is. The ferry passes the waterfront late ottoman Era pleasure palaces of Dolmabahce & Beylerbeyi. All along the shoreline, you see Istanbullus in pursuit of keyif. In a stretch of parkland, four elderly men sat on garden chairs in an intimate circle, playing backgammon. On a nearby bench a man presented a veiled woman with a single red rose.The ferry stops at several points along the route. Then you can return to the old city by another ferry trip.
Great value boat trip. Used TurYol ferry boat as advised by Turkeytravelplanner.com.

Wonderful way to see the city. . .. There are many palaces and beautiful places to see while taking a Bosphorous cruise. . gives you a different perspective of the city. Nice way to relax for a few hours and absorb the two continents of Europe and Asia. . lovely bridges and topography.

Yup, take a ferry!. This was one of my favorite parts of my short visit to Istanbul as there were lots of locals aboard, and I made a couple of nice connections with people who live there. It was a great way to see more of the area, and you could rest your aching feet from all the walking you're probably doing the rest of the time.
east and west. helps you to really appreciate the historical significance of the city
Great trip by boat. Spent over two hours on a boat exploring both European and Asia sides of the Bophorous! Our guide was outstanding.

Take the regular, not tourist ferry!. Pleasant, relaxing view of Istanbul & Bosporus. Brings history alive. Walk up to the old castle at the end is not for the faint of heart but worth the view. Used the Rick Steves audio as we traveled along.

Clear water, dolphin and jellyfish galore, Yalis and Ancient castles. I am not sure I can say much more than what I put in the title but a must visit (ferry/boat/cruise) in Istanbul. The two level currents are amazing and history of the strait is downright fascinating. You cannot experience Istanbul without going on the Bosphorus - the strait without which we would not have Istanbul (or at least it would not be as prominent in history).
Sailing. Enjoyed the tour and commentator's history of all the sites. Very easy to take pictures
boat cruise. Great way to see the sights. Just get on the ferry yhat makes the round trip.
Worth it.. Taking a tour on one of the plenty boat tours in the Bosphorus sis simply a must.

Lovely Moon. The Bosphorous Dinner Cruise was a wonderful experience.The sea was offering a refreshing site . The azure blue waters were halping alleviate the heat. The cruise ship's deck was piled with drinks n snacks. The cruise thru Bos[horouis strait was enchanting to say the least. The first taste of Yani Raki (thye local turkish drink) was very refreshing in the moonlit night and the cool breeze blowing across made the Night on the Strait of Bosphorous a memorable evening. It begun at about 9.0 pm and ended by mid night with a sumptuous spread of delicious meal on the sea.

your guideline. Spend the first minute in Istanbul by cruising Bosphorus. Then you will decide later where you want to go. So many places we missed since we spent last day for the cruise. Regretfully, it's too late. The cruise itself is really nice, on a big ferry, not too crowded, and very close to see what lied on the land.

Take a boat, breath the sea air and the city. Take a boat tour or the normal ferry and see the city from a different perspective. Palaces, mosques, towers, villas and ships... all fighting for a small piece of the horizon. You can taste some specialities along the way (like Kanlica yogurt). The dinner cruises have a charm of their own with all the city lights fighting to keep the dark away ;)

Good. I took a tourist boat which traveled into the Bosphorus, it had a reasonable price but I preferred it stop in some places not just sail in the water far from the European/Asian lands. I took this tour twice in two years with two different boats but the tour was the same.

Spanning two continents. Standing on this bridge spanning the Bosphorus is mind boggling. Can you imagine having one foot in Europe and the other in Asia?Sailing on the Bosphorus is very historic. Memorials to the fighters in the Gallipoli battle were inspiring.

Take a cruise. This is the best way to see Istanbul. You get a great aspect from the water - there are at least three routes - a 2 hour circular route, a 1.5 hour downward route (and 1.5 hours back) and the Golden Horn route. All are great and you can take amazing photos from the water.

Cruise was nice, but just a cruise. there's nothing all that spectacular to see on the actual cruise but I guess it's one of those touristy things that you should cross off your list... Try and combine with the hop on and hop off buses!
Busy, busy, busy. You can't say you've visited Istanbul if you haven't taken a tour on this incredible waterway.

Breath-taking vistas!. We took the two hour boat ride on the Bosphorus strait; by the time we came back, I had filled 1 gb of pictures on my memory card and emptied the last drop of battery power! I highly recommend this trip into Istanbul's splendor. You do not build the capital of an empire in one of the most strategic geographies of the world to offer just another cityscape: Istanbul was the capital of the world for hundred of years and this two hour trip will give you a glimpse of it!

took a private boat cruise. There are good boat parked on the way we took one for 1 and half hour which took us to see golden horn and then back we saw the city from the sea and also saw the sultan hunting palace and summer palace there were houses along the way and it was a wonderful way to spend a relaxing afternoon

The Great Divide. We were there 40 years ago, when a cruise along the Bosphorous was a procession of villages, each with its own mosque , school & market. Now Istanbul, with 19 million people stretches most of its length with modern high rise & shopping malls. Still a great trip.

Very magical - dividing two continents. The fact that when you are in Istanbul and cross over one of the bridges with the Blue Bus, you have left Europe and have landed in Africa. Pretty cool. (The downtown of Istanbul is in Europe, and the majority of it is in Africa). The River is the heartbeat of the city, and many of its most splendid heritage sites sit on its banks. We went back and forth over the river, and enjoyed the vistas each time, particularly from a restaurant with a view.Our most magical Bosphorus experience happened on a previous trip to Istanbul, when for two and a half incredible days we stayed at the Ciragan Palace Hotel, a magnificent 6 star hotel on the banks of the Bosphorus. Well, we did go down to the Old town to see the usual -(Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar etc. etc.) but otherwise we just stayed enjoying the rare experience of a world class hotel, with its infinity swimming pool visually blending into the Bosphorus itself. Perfect weather.We had to pinch ourselves. And then to add to the magic, a political figure was getting married in the hotel that night, and the keeping up with the Joneses in Istanbul is to have fireworks at the wedding. So there we were, with the magic enhanced by fireworks over our heads, reflecting in the pool and river. Can it get better than that?That hotel is very close (I think next door) to the Dolmabahçe Palace - a must see, with an incredible Harem and also fantastic grounds on the Bosphorus. Save your luxury money, and walk from the Palace and harem, to the Ciragan and see it for yourself at a memorable lunch.

Bosphorus Strait. We took the public ferry and had a fantastic day! To get a seat at a window, you really do need to be 30 to 45 minutes early (this was early June). It's like a race for the gold when they open the gates! You can get an audio tour for 5 Turkish Lira, which we didn't do as they wanted our passport for a deposit and we didn't have them with us. My guide book made it sound like you could hop on hop off at will, but your ticket (which was 25TL p.p.) only allows for 2. We rode to the end and spent 3 hours. We made the very hot and rustic climb up to the castle ruins for the beautiful view of the Black Sea and then had a wonderful sea bass lunch at one of the restaurants that are about 1/3 of the way back down. We were delighted with several groups of dolphins along the way and even got to see a Turkish Navy Submarine making it's way out to sea. You can take food and drinks with you, or purchase on board.

Relax with a boat trip. We took a guided boat trip which travelled down to the far bridge on the west side and then back along the Asian side. Plenty to see and photograph. Very relaxing break from the walking.
A trip over the water!. It was so wide and so busy.......took my breath away literally as the wind on the top deck of the Blue Bus did just that!!!!

Ranking based on Chartered Tour. I took a chartered tour for this. At 50 euro, I thought it was rather steep. Sure, I had a guide, lunch at Sultanahmet, mini bus to bring us along, a cruise along bosphorous and then finally a visit to the Summer Palace, I think I have a better suggestion for the traveller out there.Skip this chartered tour. Head to Eminonu, hit the ferry terminal by the river. Take one of the ferries to a destination of choice. If I remember correctly, it is just 10-15 lira. Get off anywhere along the route, then finally take a trip back. Sure, you might not have a tour guide telling you what you are looking at, but trust me, you are not missing out on much. Instead, you get to interact or absorb the local culture with the locals. No better way to travel the bosphorous, in my opinion. I reckon I would have enjoyed this alternative more.
What defines Istanbul..... Istanbul is defined by this natural masterpiece! I love it because I cross it every week! The scenery is wonderful!!!
Bosphorus tours. Take the one and a half hour local ferry from the Galata Bridge, sit back and enjoy the passing show of bridges, palaces, forts, Ottoman seaside villas, shipping and fresh air...
Give your feet a rest and enjoy. We took the six hour tour (which includes a one and a half hour stop at the end of the line). Definitely worth doing.

Treasure!. Walk it, cruise it, ride a ferry, dine on the shores, take photos.
If there was no Bosporus, there would be no Istanbul.
Take a ferry for two lira (doesn't matter which one) - you'll be with the locals, have an amazing ride with stunning views and wherever the ferry lands, you'll find great sites, food and experiences.

Stunning views. From the top of the Galatia Tower the view of the Bosphorus Strait is quite stunning and comparable with Sydney Harbour. Even better is to take a ferry cruise around the shores of the Asian and European sides of this wonderful stretch of water.

Take a boat tour. Take a boat tour of Bhospherous, really good value and unforgettable views. A great way to see Istanbu
From both sides. About 20 euros fab
Important waterway for centuries. The strait is a very busy waterway and it seems the lifeline of the area.
Perfect sunny day cruise. Travelling down this hugely busy strait it is difficult to know which side of the boat to look out from - so much to see and a hugely enjoyable way to see it.

Beautiful area seen through boat trip. The Bosphorus strait is a beautiful area with plenty of elegant houses and palaces on the sides of the strait. Take a boat trip for 1 hour or so to view beautiful sceneries and the bridges that connect between Europe and Asia.

That's A Must Do. You just have to pick among so many trips along Bosphorus Strait ... We took the one that reached up to black sea and visited Pöyrazkoy harbor on the eastern shore of the Bosphorus at its northern entrance. It is a lovely small place where you meet fishermen weaving fishing nets ... Also some nice little coffee shops and ice cream shops up the hill.
tournatour. this is a romance night, the hotel can reserved this tour for you about 50-70 Eur

The soul of Istanbul - The Bosphorus. You must take a drive, walk or dine along this beautiful Bosphorus that separate Istanbul into 2 continents (the European and Asian continents)Marvel at the gorgeous yacht, gutlet, speedboat or just plain fishing boat bobbing in the Bosphorus while anglers from all walks of lives and of several generations lined the straits trying their hands in fishing. In summer, Bosphorus will be made more beautiful with the purple or lilac tree of life or Judas tree. and try the 'balik ekmek' or fish sandwich along the Bosphorus while you're at it. You won't regret it.Read more at my Blog www.1001-nights-in-istanbul.blogspot.com

Boat trip. Take the ferry north to Anadolu Kavağı. The views along the way are breathtaking. If you feel energetic when you get there you can take a walk up to the ruins but you can take a taxi from the dock. Don't get stressed trying to catch everything on the way as it takes the same route back.

Places to sit and watch. Took a public ferry uo the bosphorus and hopped on and off several times. Just about any place you land is a treat for the senses. Ortakoy has a great fleamarket on Saturdays. Ciya Restaurant in Kadakoy was a great place for lunch (ate there twice)

A must-do on our list!!. We took the full trip up the Bosphorus to Anadolu (sp?) , the fishing village near the mouth of the Black Sea. It's a 90-minute ferry ride one-way with a 2-3 hour layover in the village. We grabbed a fish sandwich and hiked (moderately strenuous hike) up to the castle which overlooks the Black Sea...SO WORTH IT!!! Take your camera and be aware of the photo ops along the way. The ferry touches both the Auropean side and the Asian side of the Bosphorus. Take advantage of the fresh yogurt they bring on-board at one of the stops! Yummy with powdered suger!

Porpoise!. We took a trip up the Bosphorus on a small boat after being persuaded by one of the guys at the dock. We were so glad we did. It really helped to get the geography of the waterways in perspective and the highlight for me was seeing a school of porpoise breaching the very very bust waterway! (I also saw two flocks of low flying black shiny birds that looked like puffin).

The full 5 hour tour was way too long. We took the full 5 hour Bosphorus cruise and it turned out to be way too long for our liking. After the initial hour of oohing and aahing at the seaside palaces, mosques, etc., we started to feel bored by the similar scenery. We were also told that the boat would stop at the Asian side for 2 hours but we werent told that the Asian side consists of a village with cafes and restaurants catering mainly to captive tourist groups off the ferry boats, like us. There is also an ancient castle up a steep hill, and a quaint village in the interior, away from the mess at the front, but that is all. On hindsight, we felt that the 2 hour tour was more than sufficient, and the boat does not make any stops like ours did along the Bosphorus.

River of History. The Bosphorus Strait viewed from a river cruise is the best way to understand and enjoy it. You can view the city from two continents, Asia and Europe. You can see the houses by the riverbanks of the rich and famous on one side (one house even cost $150M), and the Rumeli and Anatolia castle that guards the river on the other. Marvel at the magnificent architecure of 15th century structures,a river rich in history.
excellent. A tour of Bosphorus is a must do on your trip,make sure it is a clear day because the contrast between europe and Asia is great and is more visible sailing down the Bosphorus

Memorable trip. My wife & I took one of the 2 hours trips from Eminonu up the the second Bosphorous bridge - cost £4 each! There was no audio guide but, with the DK Istanbul guide, it was not needed. Great trip, very scenic and relaxing. Recommended.

History everywhere!. Just love the mix of historical building alng the strait with newer streets and restaurants. Plenty of local private businesses, parks, food - whatever you want to see, experience, or taste! Don't forget to try the fish bread at Eminonu!

Relax-Climb-Relax. I took the 6-7 hour ferry and sat on the lower deck, outside, starboard. Great views of before-seen sights, this time from the water.  At lunch time break at Andalu, find the bakery. Get some anchovy bread (I don't even like anchovies usually). One is more than enough for two. And prepare for a very steep hike to the castle. Again, it is well worth it for views. Back down in plenty of time for ice cream and to reboard for the cruise home. Crew is very good to bring around snacks for purchase. Enjoy the wind and the sun.

Historic waterway. Just being on this historic divider between Europe and Asia was exciting. The views of both parts of Istanbul from the water were magnificent. If you take a 1/2 or full day tour, you'll hear about the various buildings and neighborhoods you pass, and that's interesting. The tour boats all have canteens, though the prices are (relatively) high, and the selection limited.

the Bosphorus strait. take a cruise either in a private boat or a cruise in a guided tour both ways a deal to do, watch the east and west ,amazing one can be between two continents in a matter of minutes

if you don't go on / over it, you did not see Istanbul. A must !Get a guide to have the palaces, houses explained & pray the weather is fine. When the sun it out, the turquoise of the Bosphorus compares to no other color.You don't need to go from the Marmara to the Black sea, the area between the 2 bridges that connects Europe & Asia will be plenty enough.
Take a boat trip..... If you have enough time take a boat trip from one side of the city(in Asian side)to the other(European side)...Stunning yalis,lovely feel of the Bosphorus....
Nice for a family. Lovely to walk along the Bosphorus Strait and see all the boatson the water. Everywhere is clean and people picnic on thegrass with a view of the sea.

Scenic drive or ferry ride. Soak in the scenery of Istanbul when you drive along the coast or take a ferry ride to cross the Bosphorus Strait. Along the coastal drive, there are many good seafood restaurants.
Boat trip on Bosphorus. Nice trip. Too bad it rained and a loud group drowned out the narrative.

fantastic. absolutely pitoreqsque and romantic any time of the day. It leads on the Asiatic part if u are staying in the european one. Under the bridge there are lots of restaurants while in the upper part u can walk and enjoy the panorama while fisherman try to get some fish and other turkish men work by selling corns or fruit and rice on the road.All the city shows its best by standing on this bridge!Also, if u decide for a cruise many boats are leaving any time till night at 8 pm. The cruise is relaxing and u have a sigh of the Golden Horn but it is not the first thing to do. if u do not have time save ur time for something else, it is enough standing on the Galata bridge!

Take a public ferry like the Istanbulus. We took a ferry across to Asia (Kadikoy) from the beautiful pier in Besiktas to visit the open-air market and a sofrasi made famous by the NY Times called "Ciya". If you are curious about how where local people hang out, albeit in an upscale neighborhood, check out Bagdat cadessi between Caddebostan and Suadiye. I guarantee there are very few tourists here. We also hopped on the ferry that goes up and down the strait from Eminonu to Andolu Kavagi. This trip takes about 5 hours and tickets can be purchased in advance from the first pier on the northern side of the Galata bridge (Bogasz iskelesi). Our highlight is a stop in Kanlica to savor their famous yogurt. Blissful and refreshing.

Makes for a fun day in good weather. Definitely a great way to spend a few hours when it's sunny out. There are plenty of harbor tours on offer but being thrifty backpackers we opted for the "poor man's bosphorus cruise" aka taking the public transport ferry across to the Asian side and back for only 2TL each way. If you are on a budget or just want to explore yourself, that's not a bad way to go!

Boat trip is a must. You just have to do a boat trip.Its amazing to see the other side of this city, the oppulent riverside villas are an eye opener. Haggle and get the right boat but beware they will be packed and personal space invaded by camera weidling passengers!!!!
Bosphorus-vosphorus. Sailing up the Bosphorus, a wonderfully busy modern water-way that's steeped in history which will capture your imagination and leave you smiling.
awesome. great cruise. You can cross it by taking a taxi boat from one side of town to another. best way to cross town without the hustle and bustle of traffic.

Castles, wonderful houses and blue waters!. We made the full Bosphorus Cruise with the SH (Şehir Hatlari) ferry. The trip is magnificent. You can see Dolmabahçe Palace, the fortresses of Europe and Asia, beautiful waterfront houses and wonderful fishing villages. The trip takes you to Anadolu Kavağı, where we climb to the Genoese Castle. The views from the castle to the Bosphorus strait and to the Black Sea entrance are spectacular! In Anadolu you can have a nice fish meal, catch some sun while you wait for the trip back to Istanbul.

Don't miss this. It's cheap, relaxing and fun. No trouble to get directly to the wharves and pay not very much or you can pay a travel tout far too much (like we did) and still have a nice time. Boats normally travel down the Europe side of the Bosphorus down to the second transcontinental bridge (Fatih Sultan Mehmet) and then back on Asia side. It takes about two hours and is hard to beat on a fine day.

Wait for good weather. We did this tour twice - the long one on a day when the weather was cloudy and cold, the short one on a sunny, warm day. The cooler weather really cut to the bone on the upper deck - wait for a good day.
Book Directly. If it is possible, get to eminonu pier and get to the bosphorous tours pier and then take the 1.5 hour boat ride. Inexpensive and completely worth it
Beautiful and relaxing. The boat trip was very pleasant, with beautiful views, nice stops, and some interesting info. The only thing not so good is that the stops were too fast.
Interesting architecture and scenery. Well worth taking a boat trip. Relaxing and gets you out of the city for a bit of peace and quiet.
Brillaint. Shows you modern Istanbul. Completely different from Sultanahmet. Worth he beautiful sights

Lovely river cruise to see Istanbul. The cruise is an inexpensive, lovely way to see Istanbul's continents at the same time and see the wonderful palaces, Aya Sofia, and many other beautiful buildings. Sit at the back and you will see it all!

Enjoyable. We took the two hour boat trip (10lira), which was very enjoyable. If you walk down to the bridge you will find plenty of river boats offering trips from as little as 10lira. Alternatively you could book the same trip near the Blue Mosque via a tout for as much as 35lira.
Great idea. The idea of going up the Bosphorus in a boat is romantic but I found the actual trip fairly ordinary .. .
Another view of Istanbul. From the boat trip you could see the grand palaces of the sultans from a different prospective
Worth it. Take half day tour, no lunch. Take 11 o clock tour as it could be foggy first thing in the morning
Cruise. Great ride on the Bosporus provides more historical knowledge. The mansions along the way(most.y turned into hotels) are absolutely gorgeous.
A magical day out!. The Bosphorous was a stunning waterway to sail along. We really enjoyed the buildings, terrain and learning about the history of Istanbul.
great trip. contact your hotel, trips are available easily, and not expensive. They will pick you up at hotel. Takes two hours and upto the second bridge...

Great Boat Trip. Our guide of the day before suggested we look after this part of our visit to Istanbul ourselves. He told us where to take the boat and only to do a 90 minute trip which was ample. And joy it only cost us 12 Turkish Lire each.

Stunning boat trip. To see the great extent of this 13.5 million person city you really need to take the boat trip up the Bosphorus and through the Golden Horn to see Old Europe, New Europe and Asia and the intersection of the continents.
No idea. Had a relaxing and pleasant cruise on the Bosphorus with lots of photos, but with no commentary unfortunately
Awesome. Loved every minute of this tour - would recommend the 3-hour stop at Yaros castle for lunch.
hop on the ferry. Get on the ferry (run by IDO, better than the private ones) and enjoy the great scenary of istanbul bosphorus for 2 hours).This was my favorite in istanbul

Bosphorus City Tours. It was pretty cool. You get headphones and listen to a narration as you pass by the historic sites and the interesting bits. They stopped atop the highest point that allows you a great view of the city, but stopped there too long I felt. Not bad if you have very little time, like we did.

Cruising on the Bosphorus. We took a day trip on the Bosphorus to the Black Sea and back. Our Guide, Apo, was full of useful and interesting information and we were looked after well by the boat's crew. The contrasts are stark as you move along the historic coastline and look at the past mixed with recent buildings. A most enjoyable way to see the European and Asian sides of Istanbul while meeting other travellers from all over the world.

Ferry on the Bosphorus. Almost a mandatory experience for all visitors to Istanbul is a trip along the Bosphorus. You become aware how busy this waterway is and you see the old and new cities from a different perspective. Count the number of mosques and palaces. A very beautiful and quite peaceful experience in the midst of the tumult of modern Istanbul.
Amazing. Beautiful building, amazing bridges, out of the world views etc

We did the short tour. We did the 1.5 hours tour, which goes to the second bridge following the European side, and then back following the Asian side. It is a nice way to learn some thing, enjoy the view, get some sun, and give the legs some rest. We did this combined with a visit to Pierlotti hill, Golden Horn and City walls. In small lines at the end of the folder it said something about shopping, which turned out a 5 minute leather sales fashion show, and a visit to a leather shop at the end of the tour, not something we wanted, but we could use the toilets, and as soon as we were back in the bus, they left when filled (so within 20 minutes we were gone there).

Lovely views of the city. You cannot visit Istanbul without experiencing a boat trip on the Bosphorus. Various companies offer different trips at various rates. Most trips departs from Eminonu. It is really worth going all the way to the end of the strait where the Black Sea starts. You can get off at Anadolu Kavagi and walk up the hil to the ruins of the castle and from there you have a lovely view of the Black Sea. If your time is limited just take a ferry across to Uskudar or Kadikoy and explore the Asian side of Istanbul.

Try a Cruise - Wonderful Experience. Crossing between Europe and Asia - this is really an interesting journey to take. Some cruises go from Istanbul into the Black Sea and back again. Highly recommendable.
Ferry boats on the Bosphorus Strait. We did not join a tour but took one public boat after another, and ended up in Prince Island, it was great.
Bosphourus Strait. Make sure to take the ferry across to Asia. It only costs the price of a Metro ride.

beautiful. Bosphorus Strait is unique to Istanbul and one should not miss it !It is the 32 km (20 miles) long strait between Black Sea and the Sea of Marmara, separating Europe and Asia.The best way to enjoy Boshorus Strait is by boat…It is the only city which is divided by the sea.We recommend you to take the public boat, leaving from Eminonu, everyday at 10:30 am . You are better off going on this cruise during the week, if you can…During weekends the boat gets quiete crowded..

So much to see.... Take a ferry or two (or more) - there is so much to see from the water; the 'traffic' never stops and it's fascinating just watching the comings and goings. If you want the 'long haul' then you have the option of a short or long trip - an easy way to see a lot without expending too much energy.

Tuyol cruise (1.5 hr) for 12 TL. We enjoyed our Bosphorus cruise on Tuyol, which departs just next to the fish sandwich boats next to Galata Bridge. Lasted 1.5 hrs (which was about right), going up both sides of the straight very near the shore. They say Tuyol gets much closer to the shore than the larger boats. At 12 TL we thought it was a good value.

Pleasant views. I love being on the water and it was great to see Topaki Palace from there and the old protective walls. There is not much to advertise about the one stop on the round trip -- lots of restaurants selling fish. Dolphins appeared just as Rick Steves promised. Women--the Turkish toilet is disgusting!!

The wild Bosphorus Strait!. The Bosphorus Strait is one very busy choke point for ship traffic between the Med and the Black Sea. It's a hoot to watch if you enjoy watching a wide variety of merchant vessels sail by. I sailed through the Straits twice while working in the Merchant Marine for 35 years. It was a place I always wanted to go - just to watch the ship traffic. I took a gabillion ferry rides, dodging ocean going ships, other ferries (they get really thick at rush hours), passenger ships, mega yahts. It's a hoot, no kidding. Then I took the Bosphorus cruise (twice). You chug down the Straits, hitting little twons on both the Asian and European sides. At the last stop the ferry waits about 90 minutes, then hits all the towns on the way back. With a round trip ticket, you can hop off at any stop, then catch it on the way back. It's a very scenic ride. Tons of gorgeous homes tucked up on the hillsides with eye popping views! The whole circuit takes about five to six hours, and they have an early morning run and an early afternoon run. Don't visit Istanbul without taking the Bosphorus Cruise. Then to top it off, I stayed in a hotel with stunning views when you get a room on the Bosphorus side. And they have a HUGE balcony that you can sit out and watch the chaotic, aquatic show that is traffic on the Bosphorus. That hotel is the Hilton. Great hotel great staff, and that balcony to really enjoy it. There are bigger, all glass hotels with great views nearby, but not one room has a balcony.  Seeing the Straits as I did was an experience of a lifetime for me.
Excellent way to spend a few hours. Take a cruise, see the sights! You won't get many chances to cruise from one continent to another and this particular cruise is inexpensive and beautiful.
Ferryboat trip. Brilliant, Go on the local ferry up to the last village and eat a loaf of bread stuffed with crispy fish. Boat is 25 tl return, leaves at 10.35, very busy but great value.

cant forget the view. a must go but dont forget to carry your jackets and raincoat... ho for big ships rather then small steamers, they may ask you for a cheaper price but u cant sit and cant enjoy, you time would be wasted in balancing yourself.. on the bis go early and take a place in front of the deck to cherish the ride :)
Worth taking the ferry. Cross over to Kadikoy to the Asian side and enjoy the brilliant displays of fruit and vegetables and eat in a small street-side restaurant

From city to Black Sea. The boattrips leave from Eminönü. You can take a normal ferry to for example Üsküdar, or Bosphorus cruise. There is a 90 min cruise to the end of the strait. It has several stops where you can exit. If you are lucky you can see dolphins. If you go to the end, you end up in a small village (with several restaurants), from where you can walk to a castle on a hill. You can take the boat or bus back into town. The first boat back is at 3 pm, what means that you have to wait in the village for 3 hours if you took the 10.30 am boat. You can also take the bus 15a back (transfer in for example Kanlica, take a bus or dolmus to Üsküdar and from there take a ferry back to Eminönü, or transfer). If you just want to see the skyline of the city, you may as well take a ferry to/from Üksüdar.

Relaxing ride on the Bosphorous. We went to this by hopping off the hop on hop off bus, which is a must, close to the Spice Market and New Mosque. It is a short uphill walk to the Hagia Sofia area on your return.

Very scenic views of Istanbul. There are many cruises from the port in Istanbul and many people touting them. The one we chose lasted about 11/2 hours which I found to be enough. I enjoyed the trip because it gave me yet another view of Istanbul. As we went up the Bosphorus it was amazing to see even more mosques and old historic buildings, residences up the hillside and cafes on the water. The tour was narrated but at times it was difficult to understand. As we reached the half way point we turned around at the old fort defenses which protected the straits of old. Coming back into port one has a wonderful view of Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque...priceless.
Beautiful views. Definitely a must see when you first arrive to Istanbul!

Old meets new. The area around the Galata bridge if filled with sights and sounds. The bright red and gold decorated food cats and boats lining the river, the ferries taking commuters and tourists to their destinations and the Mosques rising form the bank are all part of the ambiance.

Necessary if you want to taste real Istanbul!. It took the short trip (about 3 hours) and really enjoyed it. I loved the bridge, the glance at the villas by the seas as well as the remains of the castles of Moameth .

A beautiful stretch of water separating Europe and Asia.. We had a superb boat trip from Istanbul, landing for afternoon tea on the Asia side. Some of the mansions on the waterside have to be seen to be believed! There is a never ending flow of ships to and from the Black Sea ports (the Bosphorus is Russia's only sea route to the Mediteranean and the Atlantic) There is a choice of several boats on this route; chose a larger one with plenty of shelter as it can get quite windy and cold on deck. The length of the trips vary too.
A must. Have you seen the pictures from Bosphorus? The water is blue as the pictures, and the skyline is amazing.

Marvellous. The nature was generous...but the turkish people work on the marvellous constructions- real art in architecture- on both sides as welll as the bridges between the two continents is fantastic.

Enjoyable. We elected to take a ferry ride across the strait versus the tourist trap boat ride. Nice views of everything we wanted to see. The return trip at night was very nice and highly recommended. If you do take a boat, we recommend taking a more private boat that doesn't stay out all morning/afternoon.

A fascinating boat ride. We took the trip up the Bosphorus from Eminonu on a dull day but still really enjoyed the experience, staying in the Sullivan for warmth and popping out to take photographs. The kiosk where you buy your tickets is the last one before the Galata Bridge, so be prepared to run the gauntlet of enthusiastic boatman trying to sell you their version of the trip. At 25 Turkish lira the official ferry is very good value. It is worth paying for the audio guide, which has a wealth of information to help you appreciate the buildings on either side of the waterway. Don't forget to take some form of personal identity e.g. passport or driving licence, to leave as a deposit for your audio guide. At the time of our visit, there was plenty of room on board but I can visualise that it would get very busy in high summer; in which case arrive early to secure a ticket.The boat mostly hugs the European side with occasional stops on the Asian shore. Part of the fascination is to see the ocean going container ships and cruise liners being piloted through the Straits. The voyage each way takes about one and a half hours and the boat then stops for lunch at a little town on the Asian shore. There isn't a lot to do here. Most people make fairly stiff climb up to a partly ruined castle(which is not open for visiting)but has extensive views of the Bosphorus,with the city in the distance and, in the other direction, the Black Sea. Most then chose a fish restaurant on the front at which to have a good value lunch. There are several places to choose from and your custom will be actively sought by the staff!

Lovely Cruise. Good cruise if you have nothing else to do.Take a regular ferry round trip about TL 25 pp. The boat will stop at all points. Different seating options are availble,fully closed, semi open and open. The boat is 2 storeyed and has a palce to buy tea,coffee,snacks.There are toilets on board -separate for men and women.The cruise offer some nice photgraphy moments and if lucky you can catch some dolphins swimming alongside too!! Get down at the last stop-a village and spend some time walking up and down the village sampling the fresh sea food or hiking up to a castle. The last boat leaves the village at 5:30 pm so be sure to catch it to be able to return to main city

Excellent Commentary from the Captain's Cabin. We were planning on taking a local ferry to check out the Bosphorus but a tourist boat was leaving within 2 minutes from where we were standing, so we jumped on. It cost only 10TL each and went for about an hour. I asked a crew member if there was any information, headsets, maps that we could use to enhance our experience and he came back with the Captain, who invited our family of 5 into his cabin for the duration of the cruise. He gave us apple tea and information about all the different buildings we passed. We commented upon the many similarities we felt between the waterways of Istanbul and Sydney, so felt quite at home. We loved the whole experience.

Great for sightseeing when your feet are tired. Take one of the boat tours (we used Turyol) so that you can still do some sightseeing even though your feet are killing you. Or if it's raining, you can still see the sights and not get wet. Our boat had such garbled commentary that we could not understand a word. But the sights were still fantastic. They also have some food and drink to sell you. Makes for a nice afternoon.

Now my favourite water way!. We made a couple of trips along and across the Bospherous - even experiencing a thunderstorm. It's busy with both pleasure and commerical traffic, but still has a beautful hue. The number of fishermen are testimony to the obviously healthy marine life!

Save it for a nice day. We did the cruise on a rainy day when the weather was a little rough. We chose a bigger boat and glad we did when we saw the smaller ones tossing in the water. It was a nice trip but cold and not as beautiful as we hoped. Get a fish sandwich on the dock and then visit the spice market.
awesome. its beautiful both day time and night. u can take a taxi and pass the bridge or go with a fairy.

Try to take in the cruise when it is clear. you get the very different view when see Istanbul from Bosphorus. Night trip is worth taking. there is fog specially in spring which limits the view so try to take the trip the very first clear day.
Take the 25 TL tour. Used the public transit for a total price of 25 TL round trip per person. It takes 90 to go one way from Eminonu to A. Kavagi.

A Water Tour -- take this relaxing, pleasing break. Our guide engaged a private boat for a 2-hour Bosphorus tour. We learned about the sights on the European side going one way, turned and saw the massive old European Fort (largest fort we've ever seen), then saw the Asian side and its sights. While relaxing on the waterway we got history, beauty, views of exciting large ship traffic, and a different sense of the city. Credo Tours arranged our tours, and this one was unusual and enjoyable.

its a good tour. I enjoyed very much. You can buy a ticket from the pier at Galata bridge. The price is 12 or 10 lira. There are many ships and you can bargain if you want or if you prefer you can go and find the kiosk and buy a ticket from 12 lira.The trip is about 1.30h and you can see both European and Asian part of the city (coastline of course).

A relaxing full day. The trip up the Bosphorus is a beautiful and relaxing way to take in lots of fantastic scenery. Take the boat all the way to the end and then enjoy walking around the town. You will have time to walk up to the castle ruins where you have great views out to the Black Sea. There are also cafes up near the castle that have much better views than the port side restaurants. However, it was raining, so we ate at the port and had a really good meal of grilled sardines and a fish kebap.
Great for summer. We visited during winter, so it wasn't the best experience. But if the weather is warm, the ferry ride would be great.

Don't miss it!!!. Don't miss boat trip along Bosporus. You will see a different Istanbul from the water. You can choose public transportation ferry (for 2 TL) or sightseeing tour boat operated by TURYOL (for 12 TL). Ferry departs from Eminönü (Eastern part of Galata Bridge) and cruises between Asian and European parts of Istanbul) TURYOL hub is located at the Western Part of Galata Bridge. It takes 1,5 hours. Boat cruises till the 2nd Bosphorus Bridge. You can see Dolmabahce Palace, Ciragan Palace, Ortaköy, Rumeli Hisari, Maiden Tower. Breathtaking!!!Tip: Take the last trip! It departs at daylight but arrives at night!! (At least at the end of April!)
Don't miss it!. Avoid the people trying to sell you the boat trip. Go directly to Galata Bridge and ask for the 2-hour trip

relaxing. Is a good way to explore and have a look at Turkey on the Europe and Asia side. Enjoyed the cold wind and relaxing way listening to the history of Turkey. It all depend on which cruise ship you are using. We were in a smaller one at about 11 am there were not many people so it was really nice.View of the bridges were beautiful. Definitely a break for you from the many walking tours.
sooooo romantic. Cruise at the Bosphorus is something that I highly recommend! Go there, feel tha romantinc and magic atmosphere of the city! Especially at night!

Wonderful scenery. Old Ottoman wooden houses, and 2 Ottoman fortresses, luxury houses and Ottoman palaces are located on the shores of the Bosphorus. It's cool to see how close 2 continents are. There are any posh and good quality fish restaurants and night clubs, too. You can have a boat tour from Ortakoy. It takes off from a boat stop close to the ottoman mosque on the shore.

So much to see......... Take the light rail transit to the harbour and be early...after the journey begins feel free to move around on the boat, go from side to side, end to end to get the best views..Do not rush to the top deck,lots of seat hopping and jostling around, middle level or either end works best...Go to the end of the voyage, getting off is mandatory, so have a bite and enjoy the time before the trip back to Istanbul, an amazing way to spend the day...So much to see...

Bosphrous bosphrous bosphrous. This is what the guy selling the tickets kept calling out. Although it was cold and windy the trip was fantastic and good to be able to see the buildings from the water.
Bosphorous straight. Booked a cruise for the afternoon up until the second bridge. Absolutely beautiful and well worth the time etc...

see it, two continents at the same time. Where else can you see two continents at the same time. See it from land or see it from a ship. The view from a ship makes you want to see the land. The water traffic is like a freeway.
The wonder of it!!!. I will try to enter as many "reviews" as I can but, if you only saw one site, the views of the Bosphorus from either side are simply astonishing.

Have a rest on a boat. The views from the boat of the buildings alongside the Bosphorus were amazing. It was a good opportunity to see the palaces on both sides and to experience going under the bridges. You could get a good idea of Istanbul looking back and put the historic buildings into place.

Worth a cruise!. It is worth going on a cruise to the Bosphorous, a place of immense beauty and which offers great views of Istanbul and it's history! Watching the city unveiling before your eyes as you go along is an unforgettable experience.

Oh the views. It's an amazing experience!! Make sure to to go on both sides of the trip. The amazing European site, so elegant and boheme at the same time. The Asian side, so modern, and those villages!! Amazing!! The little town they take you (I forgot the name) it's very cute. You can walk and discover it. Have lunch and then do some shopping. Only the views worth the whole excursion.

Beautiful views. Took the afternoon tourist cruise, because I was told that the commuter boats timetable are unpredictable and requires language knowledge to get back to Eminonu/Karakoy or even Kabatas.Don't regret it at all, it was not very crowded and provided me beatiful photo opportunities of the city and the place to run around the boat for the perfect lighting/angle/view.
Wonderful view. Great leisure cruise down the Bosphorus river gives you some great views of both the European and Asian sides of the city.

Do not miss Europe-Asia ferry. 1)Must take a ferry from Beşıktaş‎ to Üsküdar‎
2)Enjoy the tea/ fish at upper deck
3)Snap the pics across Bosporus Bridge
4)take Ferry from Üsküdar‎ to Galata
5)each ferry 2.5 TL but unforgettable experience
Use the commuter boats. Went across the Bosphorus on the commuter boat cost 74pence absolutely amazing views and so much cheaper that the tourist version.

Beautiful Bosphorus. We got tickets from a man near the ferry port and went on a family-owned boat which felt like much more fun than the big tourist ones. No guide or cafe but all the better for that. We saw dolphins in the wake of one of the big boats.
I live there. Every morning I thank God for letting me wake up at Bosphorus. Dolphins say hello on my spring breakfasts on the banks of beautiful channel.

Enchanting ferry ride on the Bosphorous. Istanbul really needs to be seen from the water as well as on land - a ferry/boat ride on the Bosphorous is a must! From Eminonu pier, there are several options. The public ferry has a longer and shorter option. I took the shorter option at 14:30, which for me was adequate. It passed both bridges (Bosphorous & Faith) before turning around; the trip took close to 2 hours and cost 10 TL. You can rent a audio guide for 5 TL, but very few passengers rented one.The longer option takes 6 hours, at either 10:35 or 1:35 (or 10:35 or 13:35), including a 2-hr stop for meal and/or sightseeing on your own.There are also commercial boats (Tuyol, I believe) that costs 12 TL and lasts for 1.5 hours that offer more frequently service: hourly service on weekdays, and more frequent service on weekends and holidays.Of course there are many other options, including private boats.

good boat ride. really is a must if you are looking to see both sides of the continent and some different areas other than the inner city , some interesting little bays with incredible historical buildings
Beautiful and very Blue. A wonderful river - blue sea and skys - Must try an evening cruise with a meal - there is lots of choice.
Excellent. If it's sunny and a little windy, it's the perfect weather to take the ferry ( long cruse or short cruise [ 1 or 2 hours] ) and to admire the expensive villas along the shore

East meets west. Absolutely a must. Many reviews suggeat you can take a Public Ferry across form one side to the other. The tour though was educational.We had an excellent guide and we traversed the European side , then the Asian side of the Bosphorus. This was the only tour we took from the Hotel .

Tourist Boat Very Good. We took a trip on the tourist boat which is still quite reasonable at 10TL. Thankfully the cheaper local ferries keep this price from being a rip off. You get a good 2 hours travel but no commentry. I liked that. The views are beautiful and the houses lovely, go in April when all the blossoms are out. A much better journey than the Cairo boat trip. The boat was the one directly oppiste the underpass at Emminou. Get drinks beforehand as the ones on board. Make sure you are on the port side as it always keeps this side towards the shore.
Amazing and beautiful stretch of water.. This strait absolutely makes the city what it is, beautiful, sophisticated, exciting. What other city has such amazing views?

Dolphins in the Bosphorus!. We took a boat from Bebek - a lovely area worth seeing in an of itself - and spent the afternoon up and down the Bosphorus. It was relaxing and lovely. Did you know the Bosphorus was full of Dolphins? I sure didn't. It was such joy to see them playing around the boat! It was a lovely way to end our trip to Istanbul - very relaxing and beautiful after a hectic week of sightseeing.

Boat trip yes, bus tour no. Don't visit Istanbul without taking a boat trip up the Bosphorus. Unless you want to visit the islands, I recommend you take a 2-3 hour trip. The waterline architecture is very interesting and you simply do not get the same view from the bus tours. You also pay less, especially if you find an official guide and barter over the price. 20 Turkish lire is a fair price. Even in April the sun can be quite strong so be ready with sun cream or lotion. Our boat did not have a bar but they did provide free tea. It stopped for an hour at a local riverside resort where you could have a stroll around or visit the fortress.
Boat trip. We took a trip along the Bosphorus which was another way of seeing a selection of palaces from times gone by and also saw some dolphins as we returned.

Use public ferries. Do not get tricked into paying 10TL or more for a trip. Use public ferries that run between different harbors at the price of a single-fare ticket (2TL or less with Istanbul card). Pick an early morning/late evening boat, as it can get quite hot at midday. Kabatas to Sariyer is a good route.

Two continents in one day? No problem.. I went on a Bosphorus cruise and not only was it very interesting architecturally - the whole thing is lined with palaces and so on from different eras - but I had the opportunity to stand on the shores of both Asia and Europe in a day. That's pretty cool.

Cruising along time. Took the cruise here and the experience was relaxing and yet informative. You can see appreciate the history of Istanbul and see many sites, houses, mosques, buildings, landscapes from this angle. Cruising between the two continents is a must do when in Istanbul.

Public Ferry on Bosphorous!. What a great day and nice way to see greater Istanbul from the water! Forget private yachts or smaller boats. No need for a guide. Take the public ferry on the Bosphorous all the way to the Black Sea to the Asian side of Istanbul. Stop in Anadolu Kavagi and have a wonderful seafood lunch and walk around the small town.Return back to Istanbul. Trip takes 6 - 7 hours. About 90 minutes one way then 3 hours in Anadolu Kavagi. Then about 90 minute return. Use the audio guide and map to see the sites and learn a bit about Istanbul. Wonderful, memorable day!

Bosphorus Strait Cruise. A Bosphorus cruise should be part of your visit to Istanbul, especially if you are visiting Turkey for the first time. One can make the choice of taking a more pricey tourist boat trip or the less expesive commuting boats used by locals. I can imagine that on hot summer days, these boat rides would be a relaxing treat. However, we did it the later part of March, when, although a perfectly sunny day, the wind was still cold. The views were awesome but we had to make sure to protect ourselves from draft.

House viewing from the water...!. the short trip (1.5 hours) is a bit like house spotting from a boat as you never get beyond the houses all along the banks of the river. Really great mix of people on the boats though and some beautiful old houses to see.

bosphorus. good way to get explanation of Europe vs. Asia
prompt pick-up but lots of waiting for other people
Spice market amazing - very worthwhile
liked smaller boat (SHE tours)
sultan's palace worthwhile
panoramic view of bosphorus worthwhile
great city view. take a ferryboat or just walk along the strait - it gives spectacular views over the city at any time of the day and specially at night!
Beautiful. Beautiful views of the houses on the shore. Take the boat for 10 TYL and you will have 1h30min of beautiful views.
A must. Go down to the quay side and take a trip up the Bosphorus.

Europe or Asia. If you get a chance, take the local ferry to the Asian side of Istanbul and walk to the park overlooking the Bosphorus. Its a pretty steep walk but worth the view! Watch out for the guys trying to sell you other tours! we took the local ferry for 2Lira as apposed to the 20-70Euro cost some of these guys were quoting.

Don't leave Istanbul without a trip on the Bosphorous. The boat trip we went on started in the Golden Horn and then went up the coast on the European land mass side before crossing over to the Asian side of Turkey. On this side we stopped for a short break at the fishing village of Kanlica where we sampled some of their special yogurt with honey. We were then taken to the Maiden's Tower in the middle of the 2 shores where we climbed to the top (there's a bar and restaurant here). We got a good overview of Istanbul and were able to see from the boat all the palaces and fortifications we hadn't had time to visit. Well worth going on this trip even if only to rest your feet after all the walking you will surely do when visiting the sites of the city.
Get the ferry. |We took the Bosphorus ferry to the last stop. Had lunch there and walked up to the castle for a view of the Black Sea. Much cheaper than the cruises!

Breath taking views. There is no need to explain the beauty of the location. Just you don't have to pay through your nose to take a tour seeing it. There are boats in Eminonu station that would take you on an hour cheap tour like say 15 TL. You could even do something more fun and head for one of the islands in istanbul and not only enjoy the views but also visit the islands as well.
Enjoy a boat ride!. No matter the weather, you will enjoy a scenic ride on this pretty waterway.
Perfect for relaxation. The city is very vivid. Thus, the boat cruise on the Bosporus is a perfect way to calm down and get relaxed.

You must do it!. Take a boat and go for a Bosphorus tour. It is unbelievable! Hint: if you think touristic boats are too expensive, just take a normal boat (the boats/ ferries used by Turkish people for commuting), it cost only a couple of euros.You can also have a walk on the Bosphorus shores: Kennedy Street, Galata Bridge, Kabatas area and till to the bridge. Don't miss it!

Avoid the scalpers, take the municipal ferry. There's many tour operators fighting for your business if you plan on taking a tour on the bosporus. In our experience, the best way to go is to take the municipal ferry, who provide a short - 2 hour - tour for just 7,50TL. Get tickets at the end of the quay, the last building before the Galata bridge. Get there in time so you can choose a good seat on the upper deck. The tour takes you a good distance up the river, with many things to see along the way. Vendors provide tea, coffee, ice-cream, and there's a cafeteria on the lower deck. Excellent value for money !.

Boat trip down the Bosphorus.. I would say that this is a must do if you visit Istanbul in the summer. The weather is so hot that there is nothing like a boat trip down the Bosphorus. The architecture that you view along the coast and even up into the mountains is incredible. This is a trip I will do again, the next time I am in Istanbul.

take the full day tour of the Bosphorus!. The Bosphorous Strait was amazing. Such a busy water way. I highly recommend you take the full day, public ferry tour (avoid all the touristy half day tours with no stops). The full day tour is very nice and scenic and it drops you off at a nice little fishing village at the mouth of the Black Sea (Anadolu Kavagi). There you can hike up a huge hill to an ancient castle (with great views of the Black Sea), and then walk down and eat lunch in a nice little outdoor restaurant. Go to Eminonu and walk along the waterfront to find the public ferry stand (just don't get suckered into hopping on one of the tourist ferries as you try to find it). One of the neater days we spent in Istanbul. You're back by dinner time too!
Boat Cruise is the way to go. Get a private boat tour and do this. It will show you the beauty of Istanbul. I enjoyed it.
Can't miss!. The Bosphorus Strait boat tour was a highlight of this trip. Make sure you take a guide or tour because they offer so much about the history and background of this wonderful ride.

excellent ferry. Take the state run boat trip up the river to Kavagi. It leaves at 10:35 and returns at 4:30pm allowing you time for lunch in Kavagi. At 25TL this is a bargain. Get to the ferry an hour early to secure a place on board. This is a popular trip.

Ferry fantastic. If you have a day to spare catch the ferry up the Bosphorus to the entrance to the Black Sea. Great value for money. Good audio guide available. The ferry, which you catch by the Galata Bridge on the Sultanhamet side, takes about 90 minutes for the first leg of the trip - a village/suburb on the Asian side just before the Black Sea where you have a stopover for a couple of hours - time for lunch (plenty of restaurants clamouring for your custom) and then a climb up the hill to an old fort guarding the northern entrance to the Bosphorus to watch the endless parade of ships pouring out of the Black Sea. The ferry is comfortable with seating inside and out, and with well stocked cafe. A great day out of central Istanbul to catch a glimpse of a splendid history.

Public Ferry!. Yes for 5 Euro each we had over an hour trip on the passenger ferry up the Bosphorus Strait. What a deal! We sat upstairs outside but under cover of the awning. Had Turkish tea that was sold by vendor who came by...what a lovely way to rest from all the walking the tourist sites. Don't miss this fun and inexpensive trip and the wonderful sites up the Strait! Beautiful views...
Cruise. The half day Bosphorus Cruise is the best value. Meal on board, excellent crew, four hours approximately in duration. Collection and drop off at hotel.
Take a cruise. Our cruise on the Bosphorus was beautiful and relaxing. It's a must do.
boat trip. We took a boat trip through the bosphorus strait. 2 hours by boat along the coast. Amazing. Long line waiting and bought tickets the day before

Beautiful, a very relaxing trip. You can pay 20TL for the Bosphorous Tour or you can Pay 2TL and take the ferry, either way, a cruise up the Bosphorous is very relaxing and nice to see all the palaces lining the strait. At the end, if you are able it is worth the hike from the village up to the top of the hill where the ruined castle is. The views of the Bosphorous and Black Sea are stunning!

Two hours of relaxation. We paid 10 TL each for a great boat journey up to the second suspension bridge having set off from Eminonou. Watch out for the hawkers who sell you a ticket and then transport you by minibus a mile or so away to a waiting boat. There are plenty of boats leaving directly from the vicinity of Galata bridge
What a sight. You will never see anything like this - it is just great.
Great location. Take a boat trip, it is really worth it,,,Amazing views and great location

Unforgettable ferry trip. I went on the Bosphorus ferry trip in 2008 , using a local ferry which stopped at various pontoons and docks to let peopple on and off. It took from around 10 am to 3pm and we stopped at the entrance to the Black sea for lunch. This time in 2012 we went on a tourist cruise which went up and back, with our guide who told us what the various buildings and landmarks were as we motored past. Both were worthwhile although in both cases we were in istanbul at Easter and it was showery and cool. Well worth doing. If you do have the time, take the local ferry which costs very little. Vendors come aboard and sell you yoghurt; people take their children and lovestock sometimes. It's more fun! but the fish restaurants at the far end are not exactly cheap.
Cruisin'!. Not to be missed; a Bosphorous boat trip to see the city from the water: mosques, palaces, old wooden houses, cafes and city life from the deck of a boat in the sun!

A very pleasant trip.. Really enjoyed our trip along the Bosphorus Strait. The various sights are spectacular especially when re-entering the port on return. We took the Turyol cruise which cost 10 Euro for two. Luckily, we had a guide book with us so did not have to rely on the commentary which was almost impossible to hear. Refreshments on board reasonably priced and plentiful. We sat on the port side which gave us very good views going up. It gets very windy on the boat so it is wise to take a jacket. Ticket office accepts most currencies. Overall, a lovely way to spend 90 minutes away from the traffic and bustle of this beautiful city.

Must do. Ensure to visit the bosphoros river, it's the only place in the world where you can go forth and back in two continent, it where the europe stops and asia begins. The water is lovely and wind is clean and you can see alot of attarction from just sitting in the boat.

Lots to see. Very picturesque.. Be observant and choose well for which boat you take if going for a cruise. Some are much better than others; make sure that you choose one with plenty of outside open space, some are too crowded or badly designed for large crowds. Cruise is worthwhile though. Some amazing buildings / old palaces and impressive private dwellings on the Asia side.
Boat trip. A must do, do not take the big tourist boat but check routes and take one of the smaller boats that go closer to he shore.
cruise. we took a day long tour with a long cruise on the Bosphorus. The pictures we took on that cruise-the Asian and European side- were the best of the trip.
Stunning. Took the boat trip along the Bosphorus and thoroughly enjoyed it
Water trip. Took the boat along to the black sea.stopped of a river side spot to have a drink before the return journey.Many great buildings on the way
nice cruise. Very interestig ,beautiful views.Good place to look at Istanbul city from the water,good information on board.
Make sure it's not a rainy day. The trip up and down the Bosphorus is great, just make sure it's not a rainy day.
Nice cruise. It is just a great view of the city, and away from the roads and the extremely busy traffic

A City-tour with Bosphorus. It is not fundamental but useless.You have to cross the Bosphorus strait if you are traveling to Prince Islands or you are going to Çile, in Black Sea or if you are hosted in Asiatic side of Istambul....that´s the modern part of the city of Istambul...very nice, specially Bagdat Avenue.
Taske the boat trip. Amazing sights and history. Old palaces now housing upscale hotels.
great. i enjoy my time in the bosphorus strait i recommend it to every one
average cruise. Glad it wasn't very long as there was not much worth seeing. Get the cheap 12TL tickets at the dock.

Pay for the commentary. We greatly enjoyed our cruise on the Bosphorous but unfortunately the boat we took - a one hour trip - did not have any commentary. It left us trying to follow a map, to read the guidebook and to view the sights all at the same time. Next time we would definitely seek out a boat with an english speaking guide .

Dolmabache Palace. Wow! a great palace in a great location, just on bosphure strait.. went there because I heard about it from friends, and they also told me that it will be a long que waiting.. and yeah.. waited for an hour till we got our tickets but it wasn't bad because the weather was so nice in April, not hot.. I won't recommend it in summer but in this month of the year. It's really nice to visit Istanbul in April because also you'll see toulip roses everywhere. The tickets for adults is 40Lira.. that is if u want to see the 2 palaces there.. if u want to see just one palace so it's only 30 Lira.. kids below 7 is free, from 7- 12 u have to pay only 7 turkish lira. When u enter the first big door, the gate door, you'll say: wow.. what a beautiful garden, and you'll tell yourself: I'd pay this 40Lira just to see this garden, even if I didn't see the palace! you're not allowed to take pictures inside the palace but it's a huge palce which is worth yr visit.. in one sentence I'd say: if u didn't see this place in Istanbul.. u saw nothing in Istanbul, a great place to visit.. the place has also a nice cafe, restaurant on bosphure outside the palace gate.. it's one of the best places which I visited this year.

Easy and Delightful overview of a Complex city. We fit this tour in as a last-minute add-on to an otherwise packed daylong visit to Istanbul, and it ended up being the favorite "stop" for many of us. Boats leave on the hour basically. We took a tour guide with us to help identify and describe the sites, but it would be very enjoyable regardless. There are nice, affordable panini-style sandwiches, tea, fresh squeezed OJ, and Turkish coffee available on the main floor of the boat, too.
Just fabulous. I loved the fact it divides Istanbul in Two half in Europe and half in Asia

Don't go on a windy day!. We have enjoyed the trip in the sea of Marmara to Buyukada Islnad. Beautiful scenic views, so don't forget your camera! However, we had some complications on our way back from Buyukada. The weather has suddenly changed and became very windy that the boat could not take us back on time and we had to wait for a couple of hours on the island until the weather calms down. The trip back was difficult, since we took double the time (boat had to stop by 5 islands before we arrive). That was certainly not a perfect day to go for a Cruise! P.S. There was a very talented artist on the boat :) Enjoyed watching her draw a portrait.Tip: Pick a clear and preferably a sunny day!
Wow!. Always wanted to see this and it did not disappoint. Next time will go further up towards the Black Sea.Guides well informed and keep us informed without being intrusive.

Boazichi. Best relaxation on a sunny day. Take a commuter ferry from Kabatas toward the Black Sea, bus or taxi back, instead of spending loads of cash on a guided tour. Or take a commuter ferry from Eminonou to the Asian side and back.
Ferry, not tour. You don't need to pay an arm and a leg. Get the regular ferry to Anatolia Harisi.
Exploring. Seeing Turkey from sea and hearing the "Call to prayer"

A must. If you plan on going to Istanbul, you must do a sunset boat tour up the Bosphorus. Lovely pictures with the great lighting at the end of the day. Remember to take a sweater as it can get chilly on board after dark.

Not very interesting. Go on the Golden Horn side of Eminonu square and you'll be hounded, well, pestered, by touts offering Bosphorus cruises. 10 or 12 lira for an hour or more on the water. Frankly, it's not very interesting. Be prepared for the cold breeze once you get away from the shore.

Take the longer boat trip. We found it very worthwhile to take the 25TL boat trip which leaves at about 10.330 in the morning and goes up the Bosphorus stopping at places along the way. There were only two boat trips a day when we went in April and I do not know if there are more later. This meant that we only got off at the "end" - the Asian side - where we had nearly three hours to climb up to the fortress and have a meal. The rrange of different styles of architecture along the route is very interesting and the two suspension bridges are awe inspiring.
Bosphorus Boat Trip. We went on a boat trip down (up?) the Bosphorus on a sunny day. The commentary was very interesting and the scenery almost like being by the Med. Good fun.

for the boat/ship lover. I always try to include at least one boat/ship ride in every trip, this really fun on the BOsphorus. The touted tours for 10 lira or just taking one trip on an IDO ferry for 2 lira are all worth the time, if for nothing else than to get off your feet and sip some tea.

Awesome Cruize !. I did a cruize on the Bosphorous ! The whole city looks so good at night ! There were some cultural programs on the cruize including a belly dance ! The Dolma Bagche palace and the Bosphorous bridge looks stunning at night !
Beautiful. This is a trip nobody should miss. Especially the old Greek Houses are so beautiful when you cross by on the boat trip on the Bosporus

Hope it was a sunny day... I think it's better to take the night cruise (better view with city lights). When I took the morning cruise, the weather was not so good and cloudy. It was a short cruise, around 1 hour, but it's enough to get the big picture of the city.

The local ferries are cheap, frequent, and will help you find new places.. The local ferry system is quite extensive and a ride costs around 2-4 Lira...this is very cheap compared to the cruise prices I've seen on this collection of reviews which went from 15 up to 55 Euro. Still, our ferry was just transportation from one side to another and we then found places to eat when we alighted. Most tourist maps list where the ferry ports are, but if not, if you're near water, look for quick walking local citizens-they'll probably be headed for the nearest ferry port. Eminou is the easiest to find because it's a major tourist hub.The one caution is that I never did quite figure out how the written destinations matched the ferries and had a couple of detours along the way. Once I thought I was going back to Eminou (that's what I thought it said on the ferry anyway) and ended up going over to the Asia side, so I hopped on another ferry and got the the most amazing photography opportunities as we crossed over the Bosphorus again, so it was a happy accident. Another time I was coming back from the Prince's Islands and we passed Eminou again! We got off on the Galata side and caught a tram back to Eminou. Anyway, it wasn't a big deal since we were on vacation, but be prepared for the occasional detour if you get on the local ferries.
Grab a Tour. I took a boat ride which is so scenic. Do bring lot of batteries for the photo ops are spendid.
A wonderful way to understand the geography of Istanbul. Take a cruise - any cruise - and get a feel for the lie of the land.
Loved it. Nice way to spend the afternoon, we took the little boats back and forward around the Bosphorus, also did one of the boat tours around it. Weather was perfect and we enjoyed it very much.
Dont miss out on this one.. We could identify only a few buildings.You definetly need someone to explain to you the ones on the Asian side.
Cruise. There are many Bosphorus Cruises that you can book. Its a great way to spend a day.

Do this on a sunny day!. You cannot visit Istanbul and not take a trip on the Bosphorus. There are many boats to choose from and you can either do this as an organised trip, or on your own.It is easy to get to the departure points from the main tram line

Bosphorus tour is great. You must have the tour, it's great.The all day tour is 70€/person, but we negotiate and go it for 55€.The half day tour is 55€.They are made together till lunch time. In the morning you see the Bosphorus and Golden Horn, it's the most beautiful part.The all day tour includes, after these, the lunch without the drinks. The food is nor good nor bad. A a guided tour to a palace, which is nice but you can get it and the palace, where there are guided tour at appointed times. Than they take you to asian side, but they just take you to a coffee on a hill and you have to stay there 40 minutes waiting. I did the all day, but if was now, I would have choosen the hal day one.

The so-called cruise :). The cruise boat was not a fancy one, but it's adequate. The deck upstairs gave a very beautiful view of Istanbul, but the wind made it even colder since it was early spring. The ride back to the dockside was better we don't have to 'fight' the wind. If you want to sit downstairs, you can have a cup of Turkish tea or coffee to warm you up for only 2 TYL.

Really relaxing 3 hours including lunch. We went with a guide Baarish standing near Aya Sophia, who showed us Aya sophia. He charged 15 euros per person. We went on a bus to the harbour and were taken on a boat with other people woth their own guides. It was a lovely ride for about 1 hour on a beautiful day, then they stop on the Asian side for linch in a nice restaurant for 10 euros each. We preferred to eat doner kebabs. Then we headed back and were dropped off near the spice market. It was inexpensive and very comfortable. The views were beautiful and you get to chat with lots of different types of people.

Dodgy Dogan Gezi. When booking your trip along the Bosphorus at one of the ticket stalla just south east of the Galata Bridge, beware that you will be whisked away to the west of the bridge and the luxury vessel that you may have been led to believe you were booking. Nevertheless the little tub that took us up to the Rumeli Fortress and back safely and we saw everything that there was to see whilst chugging past.

Great sail. The regular trip is quite super at great value at 25lire. the toilets on the boat can be disgusting... clean them more guys pl. Do walk up to the castle at end stop. Views to Black see stunning.

We did it wrong. We got hustled on our way to take the main boat up the Bosphorus, so we only made it up to the second bridge. Warning - do not succumb to hustlers telling you that you'll go way up the strait. We probably paid too much (not that big a deal) and got under served.That being said, what we did see was reasonably interesting. There are a number of Ottoman style buildings on the water and the views of Rumelli Fortress are worthwhile. However, all in all, it could have been a much more rewarding trip.
Lots of private tours. Very busy down at the river but some great private tours. 90 minutes is more than enough to see everything.

Sailing between Europe and Asia. Literally sailing between Europe and Asia. Nice to see the bridges connecting 2 continents. Houses on the Asian side very nice to watch. Disliked the fact that you are stuck with the ferry schedule or you have to take a taxi back to Istanbul. Should have more ferries travelling that route
