My wife and I took a boat trip and the buildings that we saw on either side were beautiful.A WORD OF WARNING: Get your tickets from the official kiosks NOT from the men hanging around offering mostly unofficial tours. If you do, you'll find yourself paying about €50 each instead of the normal €10 to €20.
Have to go on a boat ride. The natural views are amazing. This is a great way to see more of Turkey

Worth doing- great views. We took a night cruise on the Bosphorus Strait which included dinner & music & belly dancing.We got picted up from our hotel & driven to the boat marina. The driver was on time & everything went smoothly.The views are amazing & so are some of the beautiful building along the strait.The meal was good & the entertainment was good too.Make sure you take your camera as there is some lovely scenery.My only regret is that we did a night crisue & not a day cruise. Once the sun went down it was difficult to see some of the scenery & we did get distracted with eating & the entertainment.If you have the time- I would suggest you do the day cruise so you can fully take in the spectacular strait.

Take a cruise, cost less than lunch. I got a 2 hour cruise without stops for 10 euro, great vantage point to photograph the palace, bridges and just to see the busy bosphorus with it's cargo ships, yachts, and water taxis. Tea was offered on the trip and there was inside and outside seating. It is worth the 10 eu just to see it all

Take a ferry on the Bosphorus. We booked a boat trip that took us on the Bosphorus. In the day you can see both sides of the strait, buildings, mosques etc, pretty clearly. At nights the lights are magical.
2 hour tour a good choice. We took the 2 hour tour on the Bosphorus with Turvol. With only a few days in Istanbul we didn't want to spare a full day but felt the 2 hour ride was just right.

Take a cruise on the Bosphorus and enjoy the views. It's a "must do" when in Istanbul - - take a cruise on the Bosphorus. We took a morning round trip that was just perfect. Saw the historic area and palace etc from the boat and also went under several bridges that connect Europe to Asia. All in all, it's very relaxing and good way to appreciate the role of the Bosphorus Strait in that area's economy.

An Easy Introduction to the beauty of Istanbul. At least do it once, and you will get a sense on how important this city now and then. Have a stop at several villages along the way and enjoy the scenery as you go along.

A Ride to remember!. Take a good camera with a photographic lens. Get off at the Black Sea. Take a taxi or private car w/driver in to the hills. Check out the small seafood restaurants in tiny villages. Enjoy the local wine.Leave the Bordeaux where they belong. Get into the swing of things. Learn some Turkish and Arabic. Its easy!
trip not to be missed. It took the full day but the Bosphorus trip was a highlight

Amazing views. We took the cruise from Aminono station, we enjoyed seeing both sides of Asia and Europe specially the bridge connecting them. We took lovely photos and enjoyed watching the celebrity huge ships and watching the palaces views to the sea
Ortakoy and Bebek. Go for a walk on Sunday morning. After 2 PM the roads are almost blocked.
Superb. Took the regular ferry to/from Asia for €1.60 return. Great fun and highly recommended
A Wonderful Experience. It was a wonderful experience to be on the cruise and see the historical sites and other landmarks from the sea

Breath taking view from Black waters. It was indeed a pleasure to be on this trip but the colour of the water was scary. We enjoyed the wonderful view & had a nice breakfast on the ship but due to some strange fear within we dint finish the entire tour & did a half tour only :-(

Three palaces (Or was it 5) and 2 bridges.Unmissable!. A Bosphorus boat trip is a must, in the 19th Century Sultans built three enormous palaces, the Dolmabice is the first and biggest (Where Attaturk died) followed by the Ciragan and just beyond the Bosphorus bridge on the Asin side, the Beylerbei. There are also smaller ones. Trips go under the Bosphorus bridge and turn round just beyond the Mehmet Fathi bridge wher the Europe side .

Bosphorous Bridge is NOT to be missed. Upper and lower.. Loved the people watching and the fish sandwiches. Constant flow of people going from Europe to Asia over the bridge. Grab a seat at an outside restaurant, relax and enjoy.

The great divide. It's indeed a great feeling to be on water and look at land on both sides, knowing that both sides belong to two different continents...this is a must do when in Istanbul as probably nowhere in the world would you be able to experience this phenomenon
bosphorus. Seeing the sunset at any location by the bosphorus is an amazing experience

take a boat ride. We were told to take the government-run boatride, but it ran only twice a day and we missed it. So we took a private boat--there are many. To me, cruising the Bosporus made me think of all the history that has happened here at the crossroads of east and west. We were disappointed that the cruise went only as far as the first bridge and didn't take us all the way to the Black Sea. But it was the last cruise of the day and that's what there was. We did get to see the Bosporus in daylight and as night fell.

One full day on a boat. If you have time, the cruise (from 10:35 to 16:30 by public line, leaving beside the Galata bridge) allows to grasp the development of Istanbul (mainly from mid 19th to end 20th century). Many villas were summer residences for the establishment high ranking officers.You may understand the strategic importance of the narrow Bosphorus strait, controlling all sea traffic from the Black Sea to the Mediterranean (and from here to the Atlantic and Indian oceans)

Bosphorus Cruise. On a clear day, a very enjoyable tour. Avoid the agents and get your cruise tickets (20 Lira) from the ticket widow. Arrive at least 45 minutes ahead of the scheduled departure to get a good seat on the open deck

Beautiful way to see the city. We took an afternoon cruise on the Bosphorus. What an amazing city Istanbul is and it was great to see it from a different angle. It was also nice to sit back and relax for a hour or so.

Beautiful. We were a bit short on time so we just did the quick Bosphorus cruise that is run by the public ferry system. It took 2 hours, cost 10 lira but didn't stop anywhere so we just got a good look at all the sights. It's a beautiful city so it was nice to see if from the water.

great views, lovely fish restaurants. A trip along the Bosphorus is a must to get a good idea of the amount of Mosques there are.There are lots of fish restaurants under the bridge too - freshly caught and brought straight to the restaurants

Historic and Present day importance of Istanbuls location. The boat trip down the Bosphorus is well worth doing. Having done it twice it was just as enjoyable the second time. The boat takes a more direct route now with fewer stops which is better. There is a great deal of interest to see on route especially on the European side and at one stop Kanlica they bring on fresh yoghurt locally produced for sale.It is fresh on board so be prepared with warm clothes whatever the season There is Coffee and Chai for sale throughout the trip and a small shop with food.At the tip of the Bosphorus there is a three hour stop at anadolu Kavagi where you can visit a ruined castle which has been fenced off now so you cant go inside which is probably as well as the drops were spectacular.You can either take a steep walk up if you are fit it is short but very steep or there are taxis which will take you up and wait at the top to take you down negotiate the fee in advance. There is a cafe at the top but we were plagued with wasps and most people just take in the views and have a meal near the ferry drop off.There are lots of fish restaurants and lots of people touting for your business. You have to decide on whether you want a waterside view or a view from a high terrace.Most are good quality but can be pricey. Walking along the waterfront a bit can pay off .Overall its a great day out and the views are spectacular
Overall view. A great way to take the weight off your feet for a day and a good way to see all the sights from different aspect
Very busy waterway. So much going on in such a narrow waterway. How boats don't collide just goes to show how adept the crews are. Something happening all the time.
Go at Sunset. If possible do the cruise at sunset. The shots we took of the Blue Mosque with the sunset behind it were amazing.

The Blue Bosphorous. It was a pleasure cruising in a medium sized ship through the straits of Bosphorous all the way upto the Black sea. the houses lining the strait had amazing architecture and look.....the houses were at the edge of the water. Must be fun to live in one of those houses. The water got choppy only when huge oil tankers coming down from Black sea passed iur ship on the way to the Mediterranean.
Boat trip. Nice sightseeing (2 hrs), smaller boat approx 20 passengers. Pick up by minibus, 20 T Lira in total.

Public ferry. We took the 1:30pm sailing on a Friday, it wasn't too crowded, and there is much to see. We went all the way to the end, where you have an hour or two to head up the hill to the castle (ruin) for views back up the Bosphorus and out to the Black Sea, or chill out in the village centre, with plenty of restaurants to choose from. The journey back was different, with late afternoon light and then the sky colouring in preparation for sunset - got some great photos!
Boat cruise. We thoroughly enjoyed a family wedding cruise on the Bospherus.

Cruising between the west and the orient. It could be that you have cruised through the Bosphorus by cruise ship, but the best is to cruise on a small boat. You can choose to take a tour, which means that you cover the whole stretch without stopping, or you take local ferries zig zagging between Europe and Asia, which gives you a better cultural connection. Make sure to plan in a whole afternoon for this.

See the Black Sea. Consider a one way trip to Anadolu Kavagi, climb up to the old Castle and the view of the Balck Sea with lunch on the way up, then catch a 15A down to Kanlica or the Beylerbeyi Palace

The 90 minute cruise. There are two ways we know of to cruise the Bosphorus: the all-day affair for 25 TL, and the 90-minute ride for 10 TL. We opted for the 90-minute ride. Both tours are to the east of the old city side of the Galata bridge, look for the "Bosphorus Tours" sign; go past the 25 TL sign to the next departure area for the 10 TL boat. It leaves whenever it gets full and goes up as far as the second bridge. There is no narration but if you refer to your guidebook you will learn what you are passing. It's a good way to get a flavor of the Bosphorus and still have time to tour other parts of Istanbul the same day.

Food at the dock. When you get off the tour boat, grab a sandwich from the boat/kitchens that are rockin and rollin as they hand the sandwich to the servers on shore. Five Turkish lira for a great sandwich.All the locals eat them.

You havent seen Istanbul if you havent done the Bosporus tour.. You can either take the boat from Eminonu or BEsiktas and go all the way to Anadolu kavagi to eat fish and drink raki at the low key restaurants. Dont forget to take your camera. On the way you will see how the Istanbul riche lives./

Must do.. Cruises can be all day or about four hours, but either way this famous waterway and geological treasure with its architectural wonders along both its Asian and European shores is a sight to behold. The cruise company picks up at all major hotels twice a day. If one does the afternoon cruise, it is likely that the 5:00 p.m.bus ride back will take a very long time. One might want to get off the bus at Taksim Square and take the tram back, if your hotel is not around Taksim.

A view from the veranda. Interesting history of the Bosphorus Strait. We learned the Bosphorus seperates Instanbuls Europe side with the Asian (The otherside as they call it). The ships are allowed to travel from the Marmaris Sea to the Black sea in the morning, and the Black sea to the MarMaris sea in the afternoon. No ships are able to travel in the evening or night, as it interfers with the view of the home owners that live along the Bosphorus. Interesting history, worth taking a tour to hear about.
Take a boat ride. Catch a tour boat from near the bridge over the Golden Horn. Reasonable price and the 1 1/2 hour cruise is very nice.
Boat trips. There are both guided tours 1-4 hours and then the easy to jump on/off regular ferries
Its magical. The cruise is magical you feel one with world going poast hip clubs like Riena make you feel good. We enjoyed may be we had good company. The food on cruise was bad

Lovely. We went on a 3 hour cruise and it's so lovely. Coming from a city with sky-scrapers, it's lovely to see the houses along the Bosphorus. We went to the Maiden's Tower as well. Nothing much but a rather nice view.

Explore a blue jewel. A cruise on the Bosphorus is a worth-while addition to any tour of Istanbul. This is the only city in the world to straddle two continents and a ride on the Bosphorus lets you feel the splendor of both worlds.The striaight is lined with opulent mosques, fortresses, palaces, hotels and luxury homes such that you will not see in the rest of Istnabul. The white marbel of these structures fairly shimmers in contrast to the dark blue waters of the Bosphorus.Beautiful boats ply the waters and local urchins can be seen diving in from the low cliffs along the shoreline. In the central areas the buildings are a blaze of colors that rival old San Francisco.A ride on the Bosphorus will make you hungry to explore the rest of the city by land.

The world's best commute route. Go early, grab a cup of tea and a waterside seat, sit back and enjoy the view. Get off at one of the Bosphorus villages and explore--each has a distinct personality. Kanlica (on the Asian side) has Istanbul's best yogurt, and Emirgan (directly across from Kanlica) is one of a string of very pleasant suburbs, and home to the excellent Sakip Sabanci Museum. When you are done exploring, take the frequent 25E bus back into town.

Get near the outside speaker. We went on the regular boat, but the sound inside was virtually unintelligible. Near the end of the trip, I discovered that standing under one of the outdoor speakers (outside the door at the front of the boat) made it easy to hear.

A wonderful excursion. We took what we believe was a local ferry/cruise of the Bosphorus for 12 Turkish Lira. Sites were explained in Turkish and English. Tea and snacks available on the 90 minute cruise. Board near the Galata bridge. And don't miss the mackeral sandwich sold off the boats near there.
The greatest view. This is the only place where you can be in both east and the west with the exquisite dotted yali's(mansions from Ottoman time) will take your breath away.

Nice cruise. We took a cruise (included in the tour we took) on Bosphorus. Very nice!! One of the most enjoyable cruises ever took. Beautiful scenary. Breezy but not cold. See most important buildings in the cruise. Highly recommended.

Book a cruise to see the Bosphorus Strait :). We booked a 90 minute ferry cruise and it was worth it. Relaxing and you get to see great scenery. Bring a jacket and scarves tho, coz it does get chilly if you're sitting on the upper deck! Get there early to score great seats on the upper viewing deck (we did) :))
Boat ride. Boat ride is exceptionally pleasant and the sights are beautiful
take a boat. go all the way to the Black Sea, return by public bus.
Peaceful..... Sailing on this bit of water was very interested as we watched the traffic of ferries going to the various ports in Turkey.

Consider a boat ride. If you have time, consider a day long ride to Anadoli Kavagi. It is a relaxing way to spend a day and only costs 25 TL. Eat in one of the numerous restaurants in Anadoli Kavagi before the return boat ride.

I feel strange reviewing the Bosphorus. I like that is the boundary between continents and you can swivel your head back and forth and see Europe-Asia-Europe-Asia etc. I took two boat tours because it was so interesting to see the shorelines and the bridges and all the other boats.
Great dinner cruise. Take any reasonable rated dinner cruise and the sights at night are beautiful.

A special perspective.. The Bosphorous is teeming with water traffic...ferries, ocean freighters, pleasure craft, naval ships, cruise liners. You get a totally different perspective of Istanbul from the Strait and you get a sense of how important this waterway is to Turkey and the world.

Visit two continents in one day!. Tram 1 from the centre of time will bring you to the ferry port and the palace where Ataturk used to live (!).The local passenger ferries will take you across the Bosphorus for pennies. If you have enough time, the same companies that run the ferries for the locals also offer cruises for very attractive rates. Get on the ferry in Europe and disembark in Asia. Two continents in ten minutes for a handful of small change. No passport or customs checks necessary Where else is that possible?
View to everything. We took the boat from Sultanahmedares to Asia. I always love being in boats. Everything looks a bit different from the waterside.

Beware of hard selling merchants. Don't just buy any ticket for a Bosphorus Cruise. Ask to see th boat first. We bought a ticket from someone by the water that led us to a different far away pier and to a real run-down vessel that resembled a fishing boat.
Boating on the bosporus. I had the pleasure to sail on the bospurus twice this trip. Once with the delegates of the ISEA conference and once as guests of the Biennale organizers.

Bosphorus Cruise Tour was amazing!. I am very glad we chose to take a Bosphorus Cruise tour because we would not have been able to see certain parts of Istanbul because they are further away, including the beautiful homes and mansions that line the Bosphorus which were breathtaking. The views of the Hagia Sophia and Blue Mosque from the strait were incredible, and we have awesome pictures of our cruise under the Galata and Bosphorus bridges.
dolphins. from west to east , we did a couple of short ferry trips, we saw DOLPHINS chasing the ferry!!

Take that ride and have memories of a lifetime!. Imagine...you're seeing the city, the buildings the Mosques, along with all the various smells...wait until you take the boat/ferry ride down the Bosphorus. You don't need a tour guide, it's cheap and you'll be captivated by all of the sites to see. Stop and get off if you'd like and then get back on. Everyone is friendly and will give you directions, although they may try to sell you something first, but you'll get a cup or two of tea before you finally say, "No thanks, I gotta go!"

Cold on top. Boat roads are always cool. This was showed the Asian and European sides and how great some of theses houses and apt´s are just sitting on top with such an incredible view.
Beautiful October day but it was freezing on top, stay there for 20 minutes and go downstairs -- same view, a lot warmer.
Worth the money too.

Bosphorus beautiful. The busy waterway is stunning with historic busildings all along its length. Its especially awesome at night. We dined on the Galata Bridge spelbound by the lights and twinkling on the water but engrossed by the ferry activity

Boats ahoy. Great to chug up and down on. Get on a cruiser or a ferry and see as much as you can cope with on this continental divide. How often can you look out of two windows and see different continents?
Technical problems.... Nice tour, but due to technical problems we did'nt understand a word of the tour guide: speakers did not work.

Beautiful cruise. We took the public ferry cruise of the Bosphorus. There is no reason to pay more since you get to see everything and have a lunch break at the far end before heading back. Tram stops at the ticket booth.

Must-do when in Istanbul. We did the full day trip (10:30 am - 4:30 pm) where you spend 3 hours at the end (on the Asia side) and have lunch, and can visit shops or hike to the old fort. Others we spoke with did 1/2 tours. It is cheaper and easy to just book it yourself and go to the port. If you want to get picked up at your hotel and eat on the boat instead of on-land, book one of the tours.
I Felt Like a Princess. A trip down the Bosporus is one of the most romantic things to do.

Too many tourists. We went on the 1030 tour and by 1000 there was huge crowds trying to get on.. The boat was packed and it was difficult to move round and see the views. In the end we got off and got a taxi back. Note if you are doing one way and hoping to get back by bus you need a blue card as the don't use tickets any more.

A GREAT ride!!. I'd hightly recommend the public ferry. It leaves near the Galata Bridge. The price is now 25T round trip and leaves at 10:35am. They will give you a map with a few sites decribed or we used the Rick Steve Istanbul book which also discribes the route...although some stops have changed. Ride the ferry to the end. You will then have about a 3 hr. "lay-over". The tour guide boats will tell you this is BORING but it is NOT. It is enough time to hike up to the fort or have a leisurely lunch, or both. We really enjoyed the day on the water.Note: it is VERY windy and cooler as you get near the Black Sea. You'll be gald to have a wrap.

Wonderful experience. It is the section of the sea flowing and separating Istanbul into two sides one is Europe and other Asia. Cruise through Bosphorus strait gives excellent view of Istanbul city specially at night when the ship passes through all the monuments and buildings on either side giving great view of Dolmabache palace, Rumeili fortress, Sultanahmet district and the high minarets on the skyline. Must see.

cheap way of cruising the Golden Horn and Bosphorus. Last month I visited Istanbul. I was astounded to learn by observing the locals, that I could enjoy crusing those two water areas for mere 3.50 Turkish Lira. You need to decide which part of Istanbul you wish to visit, eg. Uskudar, then you walk along the harbour to check which boats go there(there are huge signs). Outside the 'stalls' are money machines(I believe you need COINS ), you place 2 T.L. and out comes your change and a TOKEN. You use that to get a 1 way ride. You can save time and queues by purchasing a second token for the way back. Just ensure you enter the correct gate(for your destination) as they don't give you a refund. You'll have to buy another token. Last year I didn't know and the same trip cost me in excess of 60euros, instead of 3.50 Turkish Lira!!!!!

A Great Day Trip!. One of the highlights of my week in Istanbul was the ferry cruise up the Bosphorus toward the Black Sea. It leaves at 10:35 from the Bogaz Iskelesi terminal just opposite the Eminonu tram stop. A round-trip ticket costs 20 TL and takes about 5-6 hours (there's a 2-3 hour stop at the furthest point). The ferrys are comfortable with plentiful seating inside and out. After several days of walking all over the city it was great to be able to sit outside in the breeze and watch the scenery go by. It really gives you a sense of how big the city is.
